original: Namo tassa bhagavato arahato sammāsambuddhassa
analyzed: namaḥ tassa bhagavataḥ arahataḥ sammāsambuddhassa
translated: In the presence of the Fortunate One, the Worthy One, the Perfect Sambuddha.

original: Vinayapiṭake
analyzed: vinaya piṭake
translated: In the Vinaya Piṭaka

original: Sāratthadīpanī-ṭīkā (tatiyo bhāgo)
translated: The Commentary on the Sāratthapakāsinī (third part)

original: 5. Pācittiyakaṇḍaṃ
analyzed: pācittiyakaṇḍam
translated: The Chapter on the Pācittiyas

original: 1. Musāvādavaggo
analyzed: musā vāda vaggo
translated: The First Division: On Lying

original: 1. Musāvādasikkhāpadavaṇṇanā
translated: The Explanation of the Training Precept on Lying

original: 1. Musāvādavaggassa paṭhamasikkhāpade khuddakānanti ettha “khuddaka-saddo bahu-saddapariyāyo.
analyzed: musāvāda vaggassa paṭhama sikkhāpade khuddakānam ti ettha khuddaka saddaḥ bahu sadda pariyāyaḥ
translated: In the first training precept of the first division on lying, “small things” here is a synonym for the word “many”.

original: Bahubhāvato imāni khuddakāni nāma jātānī”ti vadanti. Tatthāti tesu navasu vaggesu,
analyzed: bahu bhāvataḥ imāni khuddakāni nāma jātāni iti vadanti tattha ati tesu navasu vaggesu
translated: They say: “Because of the many things, these are called small things.” There means in those nine divisions,

original: tesu vā khuddakesu. Kāraṇena kāraṇantarapaṭicchādanameva vibhāvetuṃ “rūpaṃ anicca”ntiādimāha.
analyzed: tesu vā khuddakesu kāraṇena kāraṇa antara paṭicchādanam eva vibhāvetum rūpam aniccanti ādim āha
translated: or in those small things. In order to make clear the concealing of one reason with another reason he says “form is impermanent” and so on.

original: Rūpaṃ aniccanti paṭijānitvā tattha kāraṇaṃ vadanto “jānitabbato”ti āha. “Yadi evaṃ
analyzed: rūpam aniccanti paṭijānitvā tattha kāraṇam vadantaḥ jānitabbato ti āha yadi evam
translated: Having admitted “form is impermanent” he says “because it should be known” as the reason. If it is so,

original: nibbānassapi aniccatā āpajjatī”ti parena vutto taṃ kāraṇaṃ paṭicchādetuṃ puna “jātidhammato”ti
analyzed: nibbānassa api anicca tā āpajjati iti parena vuttaḥ tam kāraṇam paṭicchādetum puna jāti dhammato ti
translated: then the opponent says: “the impermanence of Nibbāna is implied.” In order to conceal that reason he says “because it has the nature of arising”

original: aññaṃ kāraṇaṃ vadati.
analyzed: aññam kāraṇam vadati
translated: as another reason.

original: “Sampajānaṃ musā bhāsatī”ti vattabbe sampajāna musā bhāsatīti anunāsikalopena niddesoti āha “jānanto musā bhāsatī”ti.
analyzed: sampajānam musā bhāsati iti vattabbe sampajāna musā bhāsati iti anunāsika lopena niddesaḥ ti āha jānantaḥ musā bhāsati iti
translated: “He speaks falsehood knowingly” should be said. “He speaks falsehood knowingly” is a description by way of the elision of the middle term.🔽He speaks falsehood knowingly.

original: 2. Jānitvā jānantassa ca musā bhaṇaneti pubbabhāgepi jānitvā vacanakkhaṇepi jānantassa🔽musā bhaṇane. Bhaṇanañca nāma idha abhūtassa vā bhūtataṃ bhūtassa vā abhūtataṃ katvā
analyzed: jānitvā jānantassa ca musā bhaṇanā iti pubba bhāge pi jānitvā vacana khaṇe pi jānantassa  musā bhaṇane bhaṇanam ca nāma a bhūtassa vā bhūtatam bhūtassa vā a bhūtatam katvā
translated: He speaks falsehood knowingly both at the time of knowing and at the time of speaking.🔽And speaking here is the act of making known by body or by speech, having made what is not so to be so or what is so not to be so.

original: kāyena vā vācāya vā viññāpanapayogo. Sampajānamusāvādeti ca nimittatthe bhummavacanaṃ,
analyzed: kāyena vā vācāya vā viññāpana payogaḥ sampajāna musāvādā iti ca nimitta atthe bhumma vacanam
translated: And “he speaks falsehood knowingly” is a locative absolute construction in the sense of a reason.

original: tasmā yo sampajāna musā vadati, tassa taṃnimittaṃ taṃhetu tappaccayā pācittiyaṃ hotīti
analyzed: tasmā yaḥ sampajāna musā vadati tassa tad nimittam tad hetu tad paccayā pācittiyam hoti iti
translated: Therefore, for one who speaks falsehood knowingly, that is the reason, that is the cause, that is the condition for the offense entailing confession.

original: evamettha aññesu ca īdisesu attho veditabbo.🔽3. Visaṃvādenti etenāti visaṃvādanaṃ, vañcanādhippāyavasappavattaṃ cittaṃ. Tenāha
analyzed: evam ettha aññesu ca īdisesu atthaḥ veditabbo  visaṃvādenti etena ati visaṃvādanam vañcana adhippāya vasa ppavattam cittam tena āha
translated: This is how the meaning should be understood here and in other similar cases.🔽It deceives by means of this, thus it is deception ; it is the mind occurring with the aim of deceiving. Therefore he said,🔽“having made the mind of deception evident.”

original: “visaṃvādanacittaṃ purato katvā vadantassā”ti. Vadati etāyāti vācā, vacanasamuṭṭhāpikā
analyzed: visaṃvādana cittam puratas katvā vadantassa ati vadati etāya ati vācā vacana samuṭṭhāpikā
translated: It is spoken by means of this, thus it is speech ; it is the speech that is the instigation to the act of speaking.

original: cetanā. Tenāha “micchāvācā…pe… cetanā”ti. Pabhedagatā vācāti anekabhedabhinnā. Evaṃ
analyzed: cetanā cetanā ati aneka bheda bhinnā evam
translated: Intention. Hence he said: “Wrong speech … is intention” . Or else, “speech that has been analysed” is speech that has been divided into many kinds.🔽Thus,

original: paṭhamapadena suddhacetanā…pe… kathitāti veditabbāti iminā imaṃ dīpeti – suddhacetanā
analyzed: paṭhama padena suddha cetanāpe kathitā ati veditabbā ati iminā imam dīpeti suddha cetanā
translated: it should be understood that pure intention … is stated by the first phrase. This is what is shown: pure intention,

original: vā suddhasaddo vā suddhaviññatti vā musāvādo nāma na hoti, viññattiyā saddena ca🔽sahitā taṃsamuṭṭhāpikā cetanā musāvādoti. Cakkhuvasena aggahitārammaṇanti cakkhusannissitena
analyzed: vā suddha saddaḥ vā suddha viññatti vā musāvādaḥ nāma na hoti viññattiyā saddena ca  sahitā tad samuṭṭhāpikā cetanā musāvādaḥ ti cakkhu vasena aggahita ārammaṇanti cakkhu sannissitena
translated: pure speech, or pure intimation is not called lying. But the intention that originates it, together with the sound of the intimation,🔽is lying. “The object not apprehended by the eye” : the object not apprehended by the consciousness dependent on the eye.

original: viññāṇena aggahitamārammaṇaṃ. Ghānādīnaṃ tiṇṇaṃ indriyānaṃ sampattavisayaggāhakattā🔽vuttaṃ “tīhi indriyehi ekābaddhaṃ viya katvā”ti. “Dhanunā vijjhatī”tiādīsu viya “cakkhunā
analyzed: viññāṇena aggahitam ārammaṇam ghāna ādīnam tiṇṇam indriyānam sampatta visaya ggāhaka ttā  vuttam tīhi indriyehi eka ābaddham viya katvā ati dhanunā vijjhati iti ādīsu viya cakkhunā
translated: Since the three faculties of nose, etc., apprehend only objects that have come into contact with them,🔽it is said that “the object is as if not connected with the three faculties.” The expression “seen with the eye” is well known in the world, as in the passage “He shoots with the bow” .

original: diṭṭha”nti ayaṃ vohāro loke pākaṭoti āha “oḷārikeneva nayenā”ti.
analyzed: diṭṭhanti ayam vohāraḥ loke pākaṭaḥ iti āha oḷārikena iva nayena ati
translated: Therefore it is said that “the object is as if connected with the eye by the well-known method.”

original: 11. Avīmaṃsitvāti anupaparikkhitvā. Anupadhāretvāti avinicchinitvā. Jaḷattāti aññāṇatāya.
analyzed: a vīmaṃsitvā iti an upaparikkhitvā an upadhāretvā ati a vinicchinitvā jaḷa ttā ati aññāṇa tāya
translated: Without having reflected: without having investigated. Without having considered: without having decided. Dullness: because of ignorance.

original: Dārusakaṭaṃ yojetvā gatoti dārusakaṭaṃ yojetvā tattha nisīditvā gatoti adhippāyo.
analyzed: dāru sakaṭam yojetvā gataḥ ti dāru sakaṭam yojetvā tattha nisīditvā gataḥ ti adhippāyaḥ
translated: “He went after yoking the cart of wood” means that he went after sitting down in the cart of wood and yoking it.

original: Gato bhavissatīti tatheva sanniṭṭhānaṃ katvā vuttattā musāvādo jāto. Keci pana “keḷiṃ
analyzed: gataḥ bhavissati iti tathā iva sanniṭṭhānam katvā vutta ttā musāvādaḥ jātaḥ keci pana keḷim
translated: “He will have gone” means that he said this after making a resolution in the same way. Therefore, a lie was spoken. But some say that since he said “I am playing,”

original: kurumānoti vuttattā evaṃ vadanto dubbhāsitaṃ āpajjatī”ti vadanti, taṃ na gahetabbaṃ.
analyzed: kurumāno ti vutta ttā evam vadantaḥ dubbhāsitam āpajjati iti vadanti tat na gahetabbam
translated: he committed a wrong speech. That should not be accepted.

original: Jātiādīhiyeva hi dasahi akkosavatthūhi davakamyatāya vadantassa dubbhāsitaṃ vuttaṃ. Vuttañhetaṃ –
analyzed: jāti ādīhi yā iva hi dasahi akkosa vatthūhi dava kamyatāya vadantassa dubbhāsitam vuttam vuttam ha etam
translated: For it is said that one who speaks with the ten grounds of abuse such as birth, etc., out of desire to quarrel, commits a wrong speech. It is said:

original: “Hīnukkaṭṭhehi ukkaṭṭhaṃ, hīnaṃ vā jātiādihi;
analyzed: hīna ukkaṭṭhehi ukkaṭṭham hīnam vā jāti ādihi
translated: “With the low and the high, the low, or birth, etc.,

original: Ujuṃ vāññāpadesena, vade dubbhāsitaṃ davā”ti.🔽Cittena thokatarabhāvaṃyeva aggahetvā bahubhāvaṃyeva gahetvā vuttattā “gāmo ekatelo”tiādināpi
analyzed: ujum vāññāpadesena vade dubbhāsitam davāti  cittena thokatara bhāvaṃya iva aggahetvā bahu bhāvaṃya iva gahetvā vutta ttā
translated: Or the straight with the word ‘please,’ speak a wrong speech out of desire.”🔽Since he spoke after not taking the lesser state of mind but taking the greater state of mind, he also committed a lie by saying “The village is one league.”

original: musāvādo jāto. Cāresunti upanesuṃ. Visaṃvādanapurekkhāratā, visaṃvādanacittena yamatthaṃ
analyzed: musāvādaḥ jātaḥ upanesum visaṃvādana purekkhāra tā visaṃvādana cittena yamattham
translated: “They brought” means they brought to him. The state of being intent on deceiving, the state of mind of deceiving, the matter that was said,

original: vattukāmo, tassa puggalassa viññāpanapayogo cāti imānettha dve aṅgāni. Uttarimanussadhammārocanatthaṃ
analyzed: vattu kāmo tassa puggalassa viññāpana payogo ca ati imāni ettha dve aṅgāni uttari manussa dhamma ārocana attham
translated: For the purpose of announcing a superhuman quality,

original: musā bhaṇantassa pārājikaṃ, amūlakena pārājikena anuddhaṃsanatthaṃ saṅghādiseso,🔽saṅghādisesena anuddhaṃsanatthaṃ pācittiyaṃ, ācāravipattiyā dukkaṭaṃ, “yo te vihāre
analyzed: musā bhaṇantassa pārājikam amūlakena pārājikena an uddhaṃsana attham saṅgha ādisesaḥ  saṅgha ādi sesena an uddhaṃsana attham pācittiyam ācāra vipattiyā dukkaṭam yaḥ te vihāre
translated: there is an offense entailing expulsion for lying; for the purpose of accusing without grounds of an offense entailing expulsion, there is an offense entailing suspension;

original: vasatī”tiādipariyāyena uttarimanussadhammārocanatthaṃ paṭivijānantassa musā bhaṇite
analyzed: vasati iti ādi pariyāyena uttari manussa dhamma ārocana attham paṭivijānantassa musā bhaṇite
translated: for the purpose of accusing without grounds of an offense entailing suspension, there is an offense entailing confession; for the purpose of accusing without grounds of failure in conduct, there is an offense of wrong conduct; for the purpose of announcing a superhuman quality by means of a roundabout expression such as, “The one who is staying in your dwelling …”🔽there is a serious offense for one who understands, and an offense of wrong conduct for one who does not understand, when lying.

original: thullaccayaṃ, appaṭivijānantassa dukkaṭaṃ, kevalaṃ musā bhaṇantassa idha pācittiyaṃ vuttaṃ.
analyzed: thullaccayam a paṭivijānantassa dukkaṭam kevalam musā bhaṇantassa idha pācittiyam vuttaṃ
translated: The only lying mentioned here is the offense entailing confession.

original: Musāvādasikkhāpadavaṇṇanā niṭṭhitā.
analyzed: musāvāda sikkhāpada vaṇṇanā niṭṭhitā
translated: The commentary on the training rule on lying is finished.

original: 2. Omasavādasikkhāpadavaṇṇanā
analyzed: omasavāda sikkhāpada vaṇṇanā
translated: The training rule on abusive speech

original: 12. Dutiye kaṇṇakaṭukatāya amanāpaṃ vadantā kaṇṇesu vijjhantā viya hontīti āha “omasantīti ovijjhantī”ti. Padhaṃsentīti abhibhavanti.
analyzed: dutiye kaṇṇa kaṭuka tāya amanāpam vadantā kaṇṇesu vijjhantā viya honti iti āha omasanti iti ovijjhanti iti padhaṃsenti iti abhibhavanti
translated: “They abuse” means they pierce the ears, as if they were stabbing the ears with something sharp because of the bitterness of the words. “They revile” means they overpower.

original: 13. Bodhisatto tena samayena hotīti tena samayena bodhisatto nandivisālo nāma ahosīti
analyzed: bodhisatto tena samayena hoti iti tena samayena bodhisattaḥ nandivisālaḥ nāma ahosi iti
translated: The Bodhisatta at that time was the bull named Nandivisāla.

original: attho. Atītatthe vattamānavacanaṃ, kiriyākālavacanicchāya vā vattamānappayogo saddantarasannidhānena
analyzed: atthaḥ atīta atthe vattamāna vacanam kiriyā kāla vacanicchāya vā vattamāna ppayogaḥ sadda antara sannidhānena
translated: The meaning is that he was. The present tense is used for the past. Or the present tense is used because of the desire to speak of the time of the action. The meaning of the past can be understood by the proximity of the word “was.”

original: bhūtatāvagamo siyāti. Paccesīti “amanāpaṃ ida”nti aññāsi. Heṭṭhārukkhe datvāti upatthambhake
analyzed: bhūta tā avagamo siyāti paccesi iti amanāpam idam ti aññāsi heṭṭhā rukkhe da tvā ati upatthambhake
translated: He knew: “This is unpleasant.”🔽Having given it to the tree below: having given it to the support.

original: datvā. Pubbe patiṭṭhitārappadesaṃ puna are patteti pubbe ujukaṃ heṭṭhāmukhaṃ patiṭṭhitaarassa🔽bhūmippadesaṃ puna tasmiṃyeva are parivattetvā heṭṭhāmukhabhāvena sampatte, paṭhamaṃ
analyzed: da tvā pubbe patiṭṭhita ara ppadesam puna are patte ti pubbe ujukam heṭṭhā mukham patiṭṭhita arassa  bhūmi ppadesam puna tasmin yeva are parivattetvā heṭṭhāmukha bhāvena sampatte paṭhamam
translated: The place where the tree was previously established, again, O bull, in the bowl: the place on the ground where the tree was previously established upright with its head below,

original: bhūmiyaṃ patiṭṭhitanemippadese parivattetvā puna bhūmiyaṃ patiṭṭhiteti vuttaṃ hoti.
analyzed: bhūmiyam patiṭṭhita nemi ppadese parivattetvā puna bhūmiyam patiṭṭhitā iti vuttam hoti
translated: again, having turned it in just that place, having brought it to the state of having its head below, having turned the place of the wheel that was previously established on the ground, it is said, again, it is established on the ground.

original: Sithilakaraṇanti sithilakiriyā.
analyzed: sithila kiriyā
translated: The making loose: the making loose.

original: 15. Pubbeti aṭṭhuppattiyaṃ. Tacchakakammanti vaḍḍhakīkammaṃ. Koṭṭakakammanti vā pāsāṇakoṭṭakakammaṃ.
analyzed: pubbe ti aṭṭhuppattiyam tacchaka kamman ti vaḍḍhakī kammam koṭṭaka kamman ti vā pāsāṇa koṭṭaka kammam
translated: Previously: in the arising of the eight. The work of the carpenter: the work of the builder. The work of the mason: the work of the stone mason.

original: Hatthamuddāgaṇanāti aṅgulisaṅkoceneva gaṇanā. Pādasikamilakkhakādayo viya navantavasena
analyzed: hattha muddā gaṇanā ati aṅguli saṅkocena iva gaṇanā viya
translated: Counting without gaps is counting by the fingers as if they were the numerals one to nine.

original: gaṇanā acchiddakagaṇanā. Ādi-saddena saṅkalanapaṭuppādanavoklanabhāgahārādivasena
analyzed: gaṇanā acchiddaka gaṇanā ādi saddena saṅkalana paṭuppāda navoklana bhāgahāra ādi vasena
translated: The word “etc.” includes counting by groups, by adding up, by pairs, by threes, by fours, by fives, by tens, by twenties, by thirties, by forties, by fifties, by hundreds, by thousands, by tens of thousands, by hundreds of thousands, by millions, by hundreds of millions, by thousands of millions, by hundreds of thousands of millions, by hundreds of millions of millions, by hundreds of millions of hundreds of millions.

original: pavattā piṇḍagaṇanā gahitā. Yassa sā paguṇā hoti, so rukkhampi disvā “ettakāni ettha
analyzed: pavattā piṇḍa gaṇanā gahitā yassa sā paguṇā hoti saḥ rukkham pi disvā ettakāni ettha
translated: One who is skilled in that can know, on seeing a tree, “There are so many leaves there.”

original: paṇṇānī”ti jānāti. Yabha methuneti vacanato ya-kāra bha-kāre ekato yojite asaddhammavacanaṃ hoti.
analyzed: paṇṇāni iti jānāti methuna iti vacanataḥ yakāra bhakāre ekatas yojite asat dhamma vacanam hoti
translated: The word “etc.” includes the words “You are a thief,” etc., which are not given in the text.

original: 16-26. Āpattiyā kāretabboti pācittiyena kāretabbo upasaggādimattavisiṭṭhānaṃ aticaṇḍālādipadānaṃ
analyzed: āpattiyā kāretabbo ti pācittiyena kāretabbo upasagga ādi matta visiṭṭhānam aticaṇḍāla ādi padānam
translated: “Should be dealt with for an offense”: should be dealt with for an offense entailing confession.

original: pāḷiyaṃ āgatesuyeva saṅgahitattā. Corosītiādīnaṃ pana kenaci pariyāyena pāḷiyaṃ anāgatattā
analyzed: pāḷiyam saṅgahita ttā corosī iti ādīnam pana kenacid pariyāyena pāḷiyam anāgata ttā
translated: “You are a caṇḍāla,” etc., are included because they are specified in the text.🔽But “You are a thief,” etc., are said to be wrong conduct because they are not given in the text in any way.

original: dukkaṭaṃ vuttaṃ. Hasādhippāyatāti purimapadassa atthavivaraṇaṃ. Pāḷiyaṃ avuttepi
analyzed: dukkaṭam vuttam hasa adhippāya tā ti purima padassa attha vivaraṇam pāḷiyam a vutte pi
translated: “With the aim of laughter”: this explains the meaning of the preceding word.

original: “jātiādīhi akkosavatthūhi parammukhā akkosantassa vatthūnaṃ anaññabhāvato yathā dukkaṭaṃ,
analyzed: jāti ādīhi akkosa vatthūhi parammukhā akkosantassa vatthūnam anañña bhāvataḥ yathā dukkaṭam
translated: “As the grounds for abuse are the same in the case of one who abuses another by means of the grounds for abuse beginning with ‘You are born of such-and-such a womb,’ the offence is wrong conduct,

original: tathā davakamyatāya parammukhā vadantassapi dubbhāsitamevā”ti ācariyā vadanti. Sabbasattāti
analyzed: tathā dava kamyatāya parammukhāḥ vadantassa api dubbhāsitam eva ati ācariyāḥ vadanti sabba satta ati
translated: just as it is in the case of one who speaks thus by way of mockery and contempt. ” All beings:

original: ettha vacanatthavijānanapakatikā tiracchānagatāpi gahetabbā.🔽35. Anusāsanipurekkhāratāya ṭhatvā vadantassa cittassa lahuparivattibhāvato antarā🔽kope uppannepi anāpatti. Yaṃ akkosati, tassa upasampannatā, anaññāpadesena jātiādīhi
analyzed: ettha vacana attha vijānana pakatikā tiracchāna gatā api gahetabbā  anusāsani purekkhāra tāya ṭhatvā vadantassa cittassa lahu parivatti bhāvataḥ antarā  kope uppanne pi anāpatti yam akkosati tassa upasampanna tā anañña apadesena jāti ādīhi
translated: herein, even animals, if they are of the kind that understand the meaning of words, are to be included.🔽because the mind of one who speaks with the intention of giving instruction turns quickly away, there is no offence even if resentment arises in the interval.

original: akkosanaṃ, “maṃ akkosatī”ti jānanā, atthapurekkhāratādīnaṃ abhāvatāti imānettha cattāri aṅgāni.
analyzed: akkosanam mam akkosati iti jānanā attha purekkhāra tā ādīnam abhāva tā ati imāni ettha cattāri aṅgāni
translated: The four constituents of the offence are: the person abused is fully ordained; he abuses by means of the grounds for abuse beginning with ‘You are born of such-and-such a womb,’ not by means of any other; he knows that he is abusing him; there is no perception of benefit, etc.

original: Omasavādasikkhāpadavaṇṇanā niṭṭhitā.
analyzed: omasavāda sikkhāpada vaṇṇanā niṭṭhitā
translated: The commentary on the training rule on abuse is finished.

original: 3. Pesuññasikkhāpadavaṇṇanā
analyzed: pesuñña sikkhāpada vaṇṇanā
translated: The training rule on malicious talebearing

original: 36. Tatiye bhaṇḍanaṃ jātaṃ etesanti bhaṇḍanajātā. Sammantananti raho saṃsandanaṃ.
analyzed: tatiye bhaṇḍanam jātam bhaṇḍana jātā raho saṃsandanam

translated: With the five kinds of roofing: with the five kinds of roofing called bricks, stone, plaster, grass, and leaves.🔽By the method of measuring: by the method of measuring with a carpenter’s cubit.

original: Ekūpacāroti vaḷañjanadvārassa ekattaṃ sandhāya vuttaṃ. Satagabbhaṃ vā catussālaṃ
analyzed: eka upacāraḥ ti vaḷañjana dvārassa ekattam sandhāya vuttam sata gabbham vā catur sālam
translated: One curtained bed: this is said with reference to the unity of the door of the curtained bed. A curtained bed with a hundred panels

original: ekūpacāraṃ hotīti sambandho.
analyzed: eka upacāram hoti iti sambandhaḥ
translated: is one curtained bed.

original: Uparimatalena saddhiṃ asambaddhabhittikassāti idaṃ tulāya abbhantare sayitvā puna
analyzed: uparima talena saddhim asambaddha bhittikassa ati idam tulāya abbhantare sayitvā puna
translated: With walls not connected with the upper floor: this is said with reference to one who lies down inside the scales and then

original: teneva susirena nikkhamitvā bhittiantarena heṭṭhimatalaṃ pavisituṃ yoggepi uparimatalena
analyzed: tena iva susirena nikkhamitvā bhitti antarena heṭṭhima talam pavisitum uparima talena
translated: climbs out through the same hole and enters the lower floor through the wall.

original: asambaddhabhittike senāsane anāpattiyā vuttāya tathā pavisituṃ asakkuṇeyye sambaddhabhittike
analyzed: a sambaddha bhittike senāsane anāpattiyāḥ vuttāyāḥ tathā pavisitum a sakkuṇeyye sambaddha bhittike
translated: If the dwelling has no connecting wall, and if it is impossible to enter it in the way described, there is no offense.

original: vattabbameva natthīti dassanatthaṃ vuttaṃ, na pana sambaddhabhittike āpattīti dassanatthaṃ🔽vuttaṃ. Heṭṭhāpāsāde sayitabhikkhussa anāpattīti idampi tādise senāsane heṭṭhimatale
analyzed: vattabbam eva natthi iti dassana ttham vuttam na pana sambaddha bhittike āpatti iti dassana ttham  vuttam heṭṭhā pāsāde sayita bhikkhussa anāpatti iti idam pi tādise senāsane heṭṭhima tale
translated: This is said in order to show that there is no offense, not in order to show that there is an offense if the dwelling has a connecting wall.🔽There is no offense for a monk who is lying down downstairs in such a dwelling. This is said in order to prevent the possibility of an offense for one who is lying down downstairs,

original: sayitasseva āpattippasaṅkā siyāti taṃnivāraṇatthaṃ vuttaṃ, na pana uparimatale sayitassa🔽āpattīti dassanatthaṃ. Nānūpacāreti yattha bahi nisseṇiṃ katvā uparimatalaṃ ārohanti,
analyzed: sayitassa iva āpatti ppasaṅkā siyāti tad nivāraṇa attham vuttam na pana uparima tale sayitassa  āpatti iti dassana attham yattha bahi nisseṇim katvā uparima talam ārohanti
translated: not in order to show that there is no offense for one who is lying down upstairs.

original: tādisaṃ sandhāya vuttaṃ. Uparimatalepi ākāsaṅgaṇe nipajjantassa āpattiyā abhāvato
analyzed: tādisam sandhāya vuttam ākāsa ṅgaṇe nipajjantassa āpattiyāḥ abhāvato
translated: In a building with no roof-cover: this refers to a building where one climbs up to the upper floor by making a ladder outside.🔽Because there is no offense for one who lies down in the open space under the roof,

original: “chadanabbhantare”ti vuttaṃ.
analyzed: chadana abbhantarā iti vuttam
translated: it is said that there is no offense if one lies down inside the building.

original: Sabhāsaṅkhepenāti sabhākārena. Aḍḍhakuṭṭake senāsaneti ettha “aḍḍhakuṭṭakaṃ nāma
analyzed: sabhā saṅkhepena ati sabhākārena aḍḍhakuṭṭake senāsane iti ettha aḍḍhakuṭṭakam nāma
translated: In the manner of an assembly hall: in the manner of an assembly hall. In a building with a half-roof: here is what is said.

original: yattha ekaṃ passaṃ muñcitvā tīsu passesu bhittiyo baddhā honti, yattha vā ekasmiṃ
analyzed: yattha ekam passam muñcitvā tīsu passesu bhittiyaḥ baddhāḥ honti yattha vā ekasmin
translated: Where one side is open and the walls are on three sides, or where

original: passe bhittiṃ uṭṭhāpetvā ubhosu passesu upaḍḍhaṃ upaḍḍhaṃ katvā bhittiyo uṭṭhāpenti,
analyzed: passe bhittim uṭṭhāpetvā ubhosu passesu upaḍḍham upaḍḍham katvā bhittiyaḥ uṭṭhāpenti
translated: the wall on one side is removed and the walls on the other two sides are half the height of a man,

original: tādisaṃ senāsana”nti tīsupi gaṇṭhipadesu vuttaṃ. Gaṇṭhipade pana “aḍḍhakuṭṭaketi
analyzed: tādisam senāsanan ti tīsu pi gaṇṭhi padesu vuttam gaṇṭhi pade pana aḍḍhakuṭṭaka iti
translated: such a building is a “sleeping-place.”

original: chadanaṃ aḍḍhena asampattakuṭṭake”ti vuttaṃ, tampi no na yuttaṃ. “Vāḷasaṅghāṭo nāma
analyzed: chadanam aḍḍhena a sampatta kuṭṭaka iti vuttam tat pi no na yuttam vāḷa saṅghāṭaḥ nāma
translated: In the “knotted place” it is said that “a half-thatched building is one that is not completely thatched.” That is not right.

original: thambhānaṃ upari vāḷarūpehi katasaṅghāṭo vuccatī”ti vadanti. Parikkhepassa bahigateti
analyzed: thambhānam upari vāḷa rūpehi kata saṅghāṭaḥ vuccati iti vadanti parikkhepassa bahigatā iti
translated: They say that a “fenced-in place” is one that is enclosed by a fence made of bamboo poles.

original: ettha yasmiṃ passe parikkhepo natthi, tatthāpi parikkhepārahappadesato bahigate anāpattiyevāti
analyzed: ettha yasmin passe parikkhepaḥ natthi tattha api parikkhepa araha ppadesataḥ bahigate anāpattiyā iva āti
translated: Outside the enclosure: here, even if there is no enclosure on one side, there is no offence if the place is outside the area of the enclosure.

original: daṭṭhabbaṃ. Aparicchinnagabbhūpacāreti ettha majjhe vivaṭaṅgaṇavantāsu pamukhamahācatussālāsu
analyzed: daṭṭhabbam aparicchinna gabbhū upacārā iti ettha majjhe vivaṭaṅgaṇavantāsu pamukha mahā catussālāsu
translated: In the case of “a building with an enclosed space in the middle,” in a large building with an open space in the middle, such as a four-square building,

original: yathā ākāsaṅgaṇaṃ anotaritvā pamukheneva gantvā sabbagabbhe pavisituṃ na sakkā hoti,
analyzed: yathā ākāsaṅgaṇam an otaritvā pamukhena iva gantvā sabba gabbhe pavisitum na sakkā hoti
translated: one cannot enter all the rooms without going out into the open space in the middle.

original: evaṃ ekekagabbhassa dvīsu passesu kuṭṭaṃ nīharitvā kataṃ paricchinnagabbhūpacāraṃ
analyzed: evam ekeka gabbhassa dvīsu passesu kuṭṭam nīharitvā katam paricchinna gabbha upacāram
translated: So it is called “with the precincts of the dwelling places defined.”

original: nāma, idaṃ pana tādisaṃ na hotīti “aparicchinnagabbhūpacāre”ti vuttaṃ. Sabbagabbhe
analyzed: nāma idam pana tādisam na hoti iti aparicchinna gabbhu upacārā iti vuttam sabba gabbhe
translated: But this is not like that. That is why it is said, “in a monastery without defined precincts.”

original: pavisantīti gabbhūpacārassa aparicchinnattā ākāsaṅgaṇaṃ anotaritvā pamukheneva gantvā
analyzed: pavisanti iti gabbhūpacārassa a paricchinna ttā ākāsaṅgaṇam an otaritvā pamukhena iva gantvā
translated: Entering all the dwellings: because the precincts of the dwelling places are not defined, they go straight in by the front door without going round to the side door.

original: taṃ taṃ gabbhaṃ pavisanti. Atha kuto tassa parikkhepoyeva sabbaparicchannattāti vuttanti
analyzed: tam tam gabbham pavisanti atha kutas tassa parikkhepaḥ yā iva sabba paricchanna ttā ti vuttan ti
translated: Then how is it that it is said, “The definition of the precincts of the dwelling places is the definition of the precincts of the monastery”?

original: āha “gabbhaparikkhepoyeva hissa parikkhepo”ti. Idañca samantā gabbhabhittiyo sandhāya🔽vuttaṃ. Catussālavasena sanniviṭṭhepi senāsane gabbhapamukhaṃ visuṃ aparikkhittampi
analyzed: āha gabbha parikkhepaḥ yā iva hissa parikkhepaḥ ti idam ca samantā gabbha bhittiyaḥ sandhāya  vuttam catu sāla vasena sanniviṭṭhe api senāsane gabbha pamukham visum a parikkhittam pi
translated: He said, “The definition of the precincts of the dwelling places is the definition of the precincts of the monastery.”🔽And this is said with reference to the walls all round the dwelling places.

original: samantā ṭhitagabbhabhittīnaṃ vasena parikkhittaṃ nāma hoti.
analyzed: samantā ṭhita gabbha bhittīnam vasena parikkhittam nāma hoti
translated: Even in a monastery laid out with four dwelling places, the front of the dwelling place is not defined separately, but it is called “defined” by the walls of the dwelling places standing all round it.

original: “Nanu ca ‘aparikkhitte pamukhe anāpattī’ti andhakaṭṭhakathāyaṃ avisesena vuttaṃ,
analyzed: nanu ca aparikkhitte pamukhe anāpatti iti andhaka aṭṭhakathāyam avisesena vuttam
translated: “But isn’t it said in the Andhaka Khandhaka without any distinction that there is no offense in an undefined monastery in the front?

original: tasmā catussālavasena sanniviṭṭhepi senāsane visuṃ aparikkhitte pamukhe anāpattiyevā”ti
analyzed: tasmā catur sāla vasena sanniviṭṭhe api senāsane visum a parikkhitte pamukhe anāpattiyā iva ati
translated: So if the dwelling is surrounded by a wall on all four sides, there is no offence even if the front is not enclosed. ”

original: yo vadeyya, tassa vādaparimocanatthaṃ idaṃ vuttaṃ “yaṃ pana…pe… pāṭekkasannivesā🔽ekacchadanā gabbhapāḷiyo sandhāya vutta”nti. Idaṃ vuttaṃ hoti – “aparikkhitte pamukhe
analyzed: yaḥ vadeyya tassa vāda parimocana attham idam vuttam yam pana pe pāṭekka sannivesā  ekacchadanāḥ gabbhapāḷiyaḥ sandhāya vuttanti idam vuttam hoti a parikkhitte pamukhe
translated: If anyone should say this, it is for the purpose of freeing him from his assertion that this is said: “But if it is surrounded by a wall on all sides … the Pāṭekka enclosure.

original: anāpattīti yaṃ vuttaṃ, taṃ na catussālavasena sanniviṭṭhā gabbhapāḷiyo sandhāya vuttaṃ,
analyzed: anāpatti iti yam vuttam tam na catu sāla vasena sanniviṭṭhāḥ gabbha pāḷiyaḥ sandhāya vuttam
translated: It is said with reference to a dwelling with a roof but no walls. ” This is what is said: “As to what was said that there is no offence if the front is not enclosed, that is not said with reference to dwellings with walls on all four sides.

original: kiñcarahi visuṃ sanniviṭṭhaṃ ekameva gabbhapāḷiṃ sandhāya. Tādisāya hi gabbhapāḷiyā
analyzed: kiñcarahi visum sanniviṭṭham ekam eva gabbha pāḷim sandhāya tādisāya hi gabbha pāḷiyā
translated: But rather with reference to a single dwelling with a roof but no walls.

original: aparikkhitte pamukhe anāpatti, na catussālavasena sanniviṭṭhāyā”ti. Ekāya ca gabbhapāḷiyā🔽tassa tassa gabbhassa upacāraṃ paricchinditvā antamaso ubhosu passesu khuddakabhittīnaṃ
analyzed: a parikkhitte pamukhe anāpatti na catur sāla vasena sanniviṭṭhāya ati ekāya ca gabbha pāḷiyā  tassa tassa gabbhassa upacāram paricchinditvā antamasaḥ ubhosu passesu khuddaka bhittīnam
translated: For if the front of such a dwelling is not enclosed, there is no offence, but if it is surrounded by walls on all four sides, there is.🔽And if the front of a dwelling with walls on all four sides

original: uṭṭhāpanamattenapi pamukhaṃ parikkhittaṃ nāma hoti, catussālavasena sanniviṭṭhāsu
analyzed: uṭṭhāpana mattena api pamukham parikkhittam nāma hoti catur sāla vasena sanniviṭṭhāsu
translated: is enclosed by defining the space with the throwing of a ball, or even by the mere placing of a small wall on both sides,🔽it is called “enclosed at the front.”

original: pana gabbhapāḷīsu ubhosu passesu gabbhabhittīnaṃ vasenapi pamukhaṃ parikkhittaṃ nāma🔽hoti. Tasmā yaṃ iminā lakkhaṇena parikkhittaṃ pamukhaṃ, tattha āpatti, itarattha
analyzed: pana gabbha pāḷīsu ubhosu passesu gabbha bhittīnam vasena api pamukham parikkhittam nāma  hoti tasmai yam iminā lakkhaṇena parikkhittam pamukham tattha āpatti itarattha
translated: But in the texts on the offense entailing suspension, the open area is also enclosed by the walls of the inner and outer rooms on both sides.

original: anāpattīti idamettha sanniṭṭhānaṃ.
analyzed: anāpatti iti idam ettha sanniṭṭhānam
translated: Therefore the decision is that there is an offense in the open area that is enclosed by this definition, but not in the other kind.

original: Idāni “aparikkhitte pamukhe anāpattī”ti vatvā tasseva vacanassa adhippāyaṃ pakāsentena
analyzed: idāni aparikkhitte pamukhe anāpatti iti vatvā tassa eva vacanassa adhippāyam pakāsentena
translated: Now, in order to explain the intention behind the statement “There is no offense in an unenclosed open area,”

original: yaṃ vuttaṃ “bhūmiyaṃ vinā jagatiyā pamukhaṃ sandhāya kathita”nti, tassa ayuttatāvibhāvanatthaṃ
analyzed: yam vuttam bhūmiyam vinā jagatiyā pamukham sandhāya kathitam ti tassa ayutta tā vibhāvana attham
translated: and in order to show that it is illogical to say that it refers to an open area that is not on the ground,🔽he began the passage starting with “And what is there?”

original: “yañca tatthā”tiādi āraddhaṃ. Bhūmiyaṃ vinā jagatiyā pamukhaṃ sandhāya kathitanti
analyzed: yat ca tattha atiādi āraddham bhūmiyam vinā jagatiyā pamukham sandhāya kathitan ti
translated: The intention behind the statement “It refers to an open area that is not on the ground”

original: hi imassa vacanassa ayamadhippāyo – “aparikkhitte pamukhe anāpattī”ti yaṃ vuttaṃ,
analyzed: hi imassa vacanassa ayam adhippāyaḥ a parikkhitte pamukhe anāpatti iti yam vuttam
translated: is this: the statement “There is no offense in an unenclosed open area”

original: taṃ vinā vatthuṃ bhūmiyaṃ katagehassa pamukhaṃ sandhāya kathitaṃ. Sace pana uccavatthukaṃ
analyzed: tam vinā vatthum bhūmiyam kata gehassa pamukham sandhāya kathitam sace pana ucca vatthukam
translated: refers to an open area that is not on the ground, but is on a building.

original: pamukhaṃ hoti, parikkhittasaṅkhyaṃ na gacchatīti. Tenevāha “dasahatthubbedhāpi hi🔽jagati parikkhepasaṅkhyaṃ na gacchatī”ti. Heṭṭhāpi idameva manasi sannidhāya vuttaṃ
analyzed: pamukham hoti parikkhitta saṅkhyam na gacchati iti tena iva āha dasa hatthu bbedhā api hi  jagati parikkhepa saṅkhyam na gacchati iti heṭṭhā api idam eva manasi sannidhāya vuttam
translated: and it is not reckoned as enclosed space. Hence it is said, “For even if it is ten cubits high,

original: “uccavatthukaṃ cepi hoti, pamukhe sayito gabbhe sayitānaṃ āpattiṃ na karotī”ti. Tatthāti
analyzed: ucca vatthukam ce ipi hoti pamukhe sayitaḥ gabbhe sayitānam āpattim na karoti iti tattha ati
translated: it is not reckoned as enclosed space.” And the same idea is conveyed by the words “If he lies down in a place that is not enclosed space, but on a bed that is enclosed space, he commits no offence.” “There”

original: andhakaṭṭhakathāyaṃ. Jagatiyā pamāṇaṃ vatvāti “sace jagatiyā otaritvā bhūmiyaṃ sayito,🔽jagatiyā upari sayitaṃ na passatī”ti evaṃ jagatiyā ubbedhena pamāṇaṃ vatvā. Ekasālādīsu
analyzed: jagatiyā pamāṇam vatvā ati sace jagatiyā otaritvā  jagatiyāḥ upari sayitam na passati iti evam jagatiyāḥ ubbedhena pamāṇam vatvā eka sāla ādīsu
translated: refers to the discussion of the Andhaka huts. “Having stated the measure of enclosed space” means that if he lies down on the ground after descending from the enclosed space,

original: ujukameva dīghaṃ katvā sannivesito pāsādo ekasālasanniveso. Dvisālasannivesādayopi
analyzed: ujukam eva dīgham katvā sannivesitaḥ pāsādaḥ eka sāla sannivesaḥ dvi sāla sannivesa ādayaḥ api
translated: and he does not see anyone lying down above the enclosed space, then the measure of enclosed space is stated by its height. A building that is constructed by making one hall long is a one-hall building. A two-hall building, etc.,

original: vuttānusārato veditabbā. Sālappabhedadīpanameva cettha heṭṭhā vuttato viseso.
analyzed: vutta anusārataḥ veditabbā sāla ppabheda dīpanam eva ca ittha heṭṭhā vuttataḥ visesaḥ
translated: should be understood in the same way, according to the number of halls. The difference here is that the kinds of halls are illustrated.

original: Majjhepākāraṃ karontīti etthāpi parikkhepassa heṭṭhimaparicchedena diyaḍḍhahatthubbedhattā
analyzed: majjhepākāram karonti iti ettha api parikkhepassa heṭṭhima paricchedena diyaḍḍha hatthu bedha ttā
translated: “Having made a central wall” means that since the lower limit of the enclosure is one and a half cubits,

original: diyaḍḍhahatthaṃ cepi majjhe pākāraṃ karonti, nānūpacārameva hotīti veditabbaṃ. Na🔽hi chiddena gehaṃ ekūpacāraṃ nāma hotīti ettha sace ubbedhena diyaḍḍhahatthabbhantare
analyzed: ce ipi majjhe pākāram karonti na anūpacāram eva hoti iti veditabbam na  hi chiddena geham ekūpacāram nāma hoti iti ettha sace ubbedhena
translated: For a house is not one enclosure just because it is hidden.🔽Herein, if there is a hole in it less than half a man’s height by which a man can get in, that is a door, and so it is one enclosure.

original: manussānaṃ sañcārappahonakaṃ chiddaṃ hoti, tampi dvāramevāti ekūpacāraṃ hoti. Kiṃ🔽parikkhepoviddhastoti pamukhassa parikkhepaṃ sandhāya vadati. Sabbattha pañcannaṃyeva
analyzed: manussānam sañcāra ppahonakam chiddam hoti tat pi dvāram eva ati eka upacāram hoti kiṃ parikkhepaḥ uviddhaḥ toti pamukhassa parikkhepam sandhāya vadati sabbattha
translated: What is the meaning of ‘enclosure’? He is referring to the enclosure of the principal building.

original: chadanānaṃ āgatattā vadati “pañcannaṃ aññatarena chadanena channā”ti.
analyzed: chadanānam āgatattā vadati pañcannam aññatarena chadanena
translated: He says ‘covered by any one of the five kinds of roofs’ because only the five kinds of roofs are mentioned in the text.

original: 53. Pāḷiyaṃ “seyyā nāma sabbacchannā sabbaparicchannā yebhuyyenacchannā yebhuyyenaparicchannā”ti
analyzed: pāḷiyam seyyā nāma sabba channā sabba paricchannā yebhuyyena channā yebhuyyena paricchannā ati
translated: In the text it is said, ‘A bed is what is completely covered, completely enclosed, mostly covered, mostly enclosed.’

original: vadantena yebhuyyenacchannayebhuyyenaparicchannasenāsanaṃ pācittiyassa avasānaṃ viya
analyzed: vadantena yebhuyyena channa yebhuyyena paricchanna senāsanam pācittiyassa avasānam viya
translated: By this he shows that a sleeping place that is mostly covered and mostly enclosed is an offence entailing a formal meeting of the Order, just like the sleeping place that is completely covered and completely enclosed.

original: katvā dassitaṃ, “upaḍḍhacchanne upaḍḍhaparicchanne āpatti dukkaṭassā”ti vadantena
analyzed: katvā dassitam upaḍḍha channe upaḍḍha paricchanne āpatti dukkaṭassa ati vadantena
translated: He says, ‘In one half covered and half enclosed there is an offence of wrong-doing,’

original: ca upaḍḍhacchannaupaḍḍhaparicchannasenāsanaṃ dukkaṭassa ādiṃ katvā dassitaṃ, ubhinnamantarā
analyzed: ca upaḍḍha channa aupaḍḍha paricchanna senāsanam dukkaṭassa ādim katvā dassitam ubhinnam antarā
translated: and the lodging that is half-roofed and half-screened, beginning with the offense of wrong conduct, are shown.

original: kena bhavitabbaṃ pācittiyena, udāhu dukkaṭenāti? Lokavajjasikkhāpadasseva anavasesaṃ🔽katvā paññāpanato imassa ca paṇṇattivajjattā yebhuyyenacchannayebhuyyenaparicchannassa
analyzed: kena bhavitabbam pācittiyena udāhu dukkaṭena ati lokavajja sikkhāpadassa iva anavasesam  katvā paññāpanataḥ imassa ca paṇṇatti vajjattā yebhuyyena channa yebhuyyena paricchannassa
translated: Between these two, is there to be an offense entailing confession or an offense of wrong conduct?🔽Because the offense entailing confession in the training rule on what is despised is laid down without remainder,🔽and because this is an offense of wrong conduct by rule, between the one that is mostly roofed and mostly screened and the one that is half-roofed and half-screened,

original: upaḍḍhacchannaupaḍḍhaparicchannassa ca antarā pācittiyaṃ anivāritameva, tasmā vinayavinicchaye🔽ca garukeyeva ṭhātabbattā aṭṭhakathāyampi pācittiyameva dassitaṃ. Satta pācittiyānīti
analyzed: upaḍḍha channa aupaḍḍha paricchannassa ca antarā pācittiyam a nivāritam eva tasmai vinaya vinicchaye  ca garukeya iva ṭhātabba ttā aṭṭhakathāyam pi pācittiyam eva dassitam satta pācittiyāni iti
translated: the offense entailing confession is not prohibited. Therefore,🔽in the analysis of the Monastic Law,🔽it is heavy. And because it must be regarded as heavy, it is shown in the commentary as an offense entailing confession. ‘Seven offenses entailing confession’:🔽This is said by taking the offense entailing confession stated in the text as a whole.

analyzed: sabba paricchanne pācittiyam yebhuyyena channe yebhuyyena paricchanne pācittiyam ti 🔽aṭṭha iva pācittiyāni honti

original: Senambamaṇḍapavaṇṇaṃ hotīti sīhaḷadīpe kira uccavatthuko sabbacchanno sabbaaparicchanno🔽evaṃnāmako sannipātamaṇḍapo atthi, taṃ sandhāyetaṃ vuttaṃ. translated: It is the colour of the Senāni pavilion. original: eko channo, sesā acchannā, idaṃ cūḷakacchannaṃ. Yassa tīsu bhāgesu dve channā, eko🔽acchanno, idaṃ yebhuyyenacchannaṃ. Yassa dvīsu bhāgesu eko channo, eko acchanno,🔽idaṃ upaḍḍhacchannaṃ nāma senāsanaṃ. Cūḷakaparicchannādīnipi imināva nayena veditabbāni.
analyzed: ekaḥ channaḥ sesāḥ a channāḥ idam cūḷaka channam yassa tīsu bhāgesu dve channāḥ ekaḥ  a channaḥ idam yebhuyyena channam yassa dvīsu bhāgesu ekaḥ channaḥ ekaḥ a channaḥ  idam upaḍḍhacchannam nāma senāsanam cūḷaka paricchanna ādīni pi iminā ava nayena veditabbāni
translated: It is the colour of a tent for an army: in the island of Sri Lanka, it seems, there is a meeting hall called the “All-enclosing” or the “Completely-enclosing” . translated: They say that the commentary, etc., is just the recitation of the text. original: Dutiyassa viññūpurisassa aggahaṇaṃ akiriyā. Mātugāmena saddhiṃ ṭhitassa ca viññūpurisassa🔽ca upacāro aniyatesu vuttanayeneva gahetabbo. Sesaṃ uttānameva. Vuttalakkhaṇassa🔽dhammassa channaṃ vācānaṃ upari desanā, vuttalakkhaṇo mātugāmo, iriyāpathapaavattanābhāvo,
analyzed: dutiyassa viññū purisassa aggahaṇam akiriyā mātugāmena saddhim ṭhitassa ca viññū purisassa  ca upacāraḥ aniyatesu vutta nayena iva gahetabbo sesam uttānam eva vutta lakkhaṇassa  dhammassa channam vācānaṃ upari desanā vutta lakkhaṇaḥ mātugāmaḥ iriyāpatha paavattanā bhāvo
