What is the beginning of virtue? Right view and right thinking. What is the middle of virtue? Right speech, right action, and right livelihood. What is the end of virtue? Right effort, right mindfulness, and right concentration” .🔽And this is said:🔽“Therefore, Udayin, purify the beginning, purify the middle, and purify the end of your virtue. What is the beginning of virtue? Right view and right thinking. What is the middle of virtue? Right speech, right action, and right livelihood. What is the end of virtue? Right effort, right mindfulness, and right concentration” .🔽And this is said:

original: ādimhi sīlaṃ sodheti, tato aparabhāge samādhivipassanāmaggaphalanibbānāni sacchikaroti.
analyzed: ādimhi sīlam sodheti tatas apara bhāge samādhi vipassanā magga phala nibbānāni sacchikaroti
translated: “Therefore, Udayin, purify the beginning, purify the middle, and purify the end of your virtue. What is the beginning of virtue? Right view and right thinking. What is the middle of virtue? Right speech, right action, and right livelihood. What is the end of virtue? Right effort, right mindfulness, and right concentration” .🔽And this is said:

original: Yathā vā pana rajako paṭhamaṃ tīhi khārehi vatthaṃ dhovitvā parisuddhe vatthe yadicchakaṃ
analyzed: yathā vā pana rajakaḥ paṭhamam tīhi khārehi vattham dhovitvā parisuddhe vatthe yadicchakam
translated: “Therefore, Udayin, purify the beginning, purify the middle, and purify the end of your virtue. What is the beginning of virtue? Right view and

original: raṅgajātaṃ upaneti, yathā vā pana cheko cittakāro rūpaṃ likhitukāmo ādito bhittiparikammaṃ
analyzed: raṅga jātam upaneti yathā vā pana chekaḥ cittakāraḥ rūpam likhitu kāmaḥ āditas bhitti parikammam
translated: Just as a clever painter, wishing to paint a picture, first prepares his palette,

original: karoti, tato aparabhāge rūpaṃ samuṭṭhāpeti, evameva yogāvacaro āditova sīlaṃ visodhetvā
analyzed: karoti tatas apara bhāge rūpam samuṭṭhāpeti evam eva yogāvacaraḥ āditas va sīlam visodhetvā
translated: and only later produces the picture, so too the meditator first purifies his virtue,

original: aparabhāge samathavipassanādayo dhamme sacchikaroti. Tasmā sīlaṃ “ādī”ti vuttaṃ.🔽Tadetaṃ caraṇasarikkhatāya caraṇaṃ. “Caraṇā”ti pādā vuccanti. Yathā hi chinnacaraṇassa🔽purisassa disaṃgamanābhisaṅkhāro na jāyati, paripuṇṇapādasseva jāyati, evameva yassa
analyzed: apara bhāge samatha vipassanā ādayaḥ dhamme sacchikaroti tasmā sīlam ādi iti vuttam  tat etam caraṇa sarikkhatāya caraṇam caraṇa ati pādāḥ vuccanti yathā hi chinna caraṇassa  purisassa disaṃgamana abhisaṅkhāraḥ na jāyati paripuṇṇa pādassa iva jāyati evam eva yassa
translated: and only later realizes the states beginning with concentration. That is why virtue is called the “base.”🔽It is a “base” in the sense of a foundation for virtue. For just as a man with sound feet does not lose his footing and fall when he walks,

original: sīlaṃ bhinnaṃ hoti khaṇḍaṃ aparipuṇṇaṃ, tassa nibbānagamanāya ñāṇagamanaṃ na sampajjati.
analyzed: sīlam bhinnam hoti khaṇḍam a paripuṇṇam tassa nibbāna gamanāya ñāṇa gamanam na sampajjati
translated: so too the meditator, by observing the lesser rules of the Pātimokkha, does not lose his footing and fall into states of loss.🔽That is why virtue is called a “base.”🔽It is a “base” in the sense of a foundation for the states beginning with concentration. For just as a man with sound feet can walk,

original: Yassa pana taṃ abhinnaṃ hoti akhaṇḍaṃ paripuṇṇaṃ, tassa nibbānagamanāya ñāṇagamanaṃ
analyzed: yassa pana tat abhinnam hoti akhaṇḍam paripuṇṇam tassa nibbāna gamanāya ñāṇa gamanam
translated: so too the meditator, by observing the lesser rules of the Pātimokkha, can realize the states beginning with concentration.

original: sampajjati. Tasmā sīlaṃ “caraṇa”nti vuttaṃ.
analyzed: sampajjati tasmā sīlam caraṇan ti vuttam
translated: That is why virtue is called a “base.”

original: Tadetaṃ saṃyamanavasena saṃyamo, saṃvaraṇavasena saṃvaroti ubhayenapi sīlasaṃyamo
analyzed: tat etam saṃyamana vasena saṃyamaḥ saṃvaraṇa vasena saṃvaroti ubhayena api sīla saṃyamaḥ
translated: This is restraint in the sense of restraining, in the sense of restraining from transgression, and it is also control in the sense of controlling, in the sense of controlling by restraining from transgression.

original: ceva sīlasaṃvaro ca kathito. Vacanattho panettha saṃyameti vītikkamavipphandanaṃ,
analyzed: ca iva sīla saṃvaro ca kathitaḥ vacana atthaḥ pana ittha saṃyama iti vītikkama vipphandanam
translated: So it is called both restraint of virtue and virtue as restraint.

original: puggalaṃ vā saṃyameti vītikkamavasena tassa vipphandituṃ na detīti saṃyamo, vītikkamassa
analyzed: puggalam vā saṃyameti vītikkama vasena tassa vipphanditum na deti iti saṃyamaḥ vītikkamassa
translated: The meaning of the words in this stanza is as follows. It restrains , thus it is restraint ; it restrains by not giving a person opportunity to transgress,

original: pavesanadvāraṃ saṃvarati pidahatīti saṃvaro. Mokkhanti uttamaṃ mukhabhūtaṃ vā. Yathā🔽hi sattānaṃ catubbidho āhāro mukhena pavisitvā aṅgamaṅgāni pharati, evaṃ yoginopi
analyzed: pavesana dvāram saṃvarati pidahati iti saṃvaraḥ uttamam mukha bhūtam vā yathā  hi sattānam catubbidhaḥ āhāraḥ mukhena pavisitvā aṅgam aṅgāni pharati evam yoginaḥ api
translated: or it restrains by restraining from transgression. It controls , thus it is control ; it controls , it closes, the door to the entry of transgression.🔽It is the foremost , thus it is foremost ; or it is the foremost , thus it is foremost ; it is the best , thus it is foremost .

original: catubhūmakakusalaṃ sīlamukhena pavisitvā atthasiddhiṃ sampādeti. Tena vuttaṃ “mokkha”nti.
analyzed: catubhūmaka kusalam sīla mukhena pavisitvā attha siddhim sampādeti tena vuttam mokkha nti
translated: For just as the four kinds of nutriment enter the various limbs and bring them to growth by entering through the mouth, so too this virtue of the four kinds of consciousness is foremost in bringing success in the undertaking of the various kinds of profitable action by entering through the mouth of virtue. That is why it is called “foremost.”

original: Pamukhe sādhūti pamokkhaṃ, pubbaṅgamaṃ seṭṭhaṃ padhānanti attho. Kusalānaṃ dhammānaṃ🔽samāpattiyāti catubhūmakakusalānaṃ paṭilābhatthāya pamokkhaṃ pubbaṅgamaṃ seṭṭhaṃ
analyzed: pamukhe sādhu iti pamokkham pubbaṅgamam seṭṭham padhānanti attho kusalānam dhammānaṃ  samāpattiyā ti catu bhūmaka kusalānam paṭilābha atthāya pamokkham pubbaṅgamam seṭṭham
translated: It is the foremost , thus it is foremost ; it is the best , thus it is foremost ; it is the chief , thus it is foremost .

original: padhānanti veditabbaṃ.
analyzed: padhānam ti veditabbam
translated: It should be understood that it is the foremost , the best, the chief, for the obtaining of the profitable states of the four kinds of consciousness.

original: Kāyiko avītikkamoti tividhaṃ kāyasucaritaṃ. Vācasikoti catubbidhaṃ vacīsucaritaṃ.
analyzed: kāyikaḥ avītikkamaḥ tividham kāya su caritam vācasikaḥ iti catubbidham vacī su caritam
translated: “Physical non-transgression” is the three kinds of good conduct by body. “Verbal” is the four kinds of good conduct by speech.

original: Kāyikavācasikoti tadubhayaṃ. Iminā ājīvaṭṭhamakasīlaṃ pariyādāya dasseti. Saṃvutoti🔽pihito, saṃvutindriyo pihitindriyoti attho. Yathā hi saṃvutadvāraṃ gehaṃ “saṃvutagehaṃ
analyzed: kāyika vācasikaḥ ti tat ubhayam iminā ājīva ṭhamaka sīlam pariyādāya dasseti saṃvutaḥ ti  pihitaḥ saṃvuta indriyaḥ pihita indriyaḥ ti atthaḥ yathā hi saṃvuta dvāram geham saṃvuta geham
translated: “Physical and verbal” is both of these. By this he shows that he has mastered the virtue of the eighth factor of the noble path, namely, right livelihood. “Restrained” means🔽covered, guarded. The meaning is that he has covered, guarded his faculties. For just as a house with closed doors is called “a house with closed doors,”

original: pihitageha”nti vuccati, evamidha saṃvutindriyo “saṃvuto”ti vutto. Pātimokkhasaṃvarenāti
analyzed: pihita gehanti vuccati evam idha saṃvut indriyo saṃvuto ti vutto pātimokkha saṃvarena ati
translated: “a house with guarded doors,” so here the one with guarded faculties is called “restrained.” “Restraint of the Patimokkha” means

original: pātimokkhasaṅkhātena saṃvarena. Upetotiādīni sabbāni aññamaññavevacanāni.
analyzed: pātimokkha saṅkhātena saṃvarena upetaḥ iti ādīni sabbāni aññamañña vevacanāni
translated: restraint by means of the Patimokkha code. “Endowed” and the rest are synonyms.

original: Iriyatītiādīhi sattahipi padehi pātimokkhasaṃvarasīle ṭhitassa bhikkhuno iriyāpathavihāro🔽kathito. Tattha iriyatīti catunnaṃ iriyāpathānaṃ aññatarasamaṅgibhāvato iriyati.
analyzed: iriyati itiādīhi padehi pātimokkha saṃvara sīle ṭhitassa bhikkhuno iriyāpatha vihāro  kathitaḥ tattha iriyati iti catunnam iriyāpathānam aññatara samaṅgi bhāvato iriyati
translated: By the seven terms beginning with “conduct” the bhikkhu who is established in the virtue of restraint by the Patimokkha is shown to be one who conducts himself well in posture and in daily activities.🔽Herein, he conducts himself means that he conducts himself with one or other of the four postures.

original: Tehi iriyāpathacatukkehi kāyasakaṭavattanena vattati. Ekaṃ iriyāpathadukkhaṃ aparena
analyzed: tehi iriyāpatha catukkehi kāya sakaṭa vattanena vattati ekam iriyāpatha dukkham aparena
translated: He behaves means that he behaves by means of the four postures in such a way that his body is not unwieldy.

original: iriyāpathena vicchinditvā ciraṭṭhitibhāvena sarīrarakkhaṇato pāleti. Ekasmiṃ iriyāpathe
analyzed: iriyāpathena vicchinditvā cira ṭṭhiti bhāvena sarīra rakkhaṇato pāleti ekasmin iriyāpathe
translated: and by interrupting the postures and by keeping the body safe through long endurance it protects.🔽By not remaining in one posture

original: asaṇṭhahitvā sabbairiyāpathe vattanato yapeti. Tena tena iriyāpathena tathā tathā
analyzed: a saṇṭhahitvā sabba eriyāpathe vattanataḥ yapeti tena tena iriyāpathena tathā tathā
translated: but by carrying out all the postures, it carries.🔽By keeping the body going in this way and that by means of this or that posture, it keeps going.

original: kāyassa yāpanato yāpeti. Cirakālavattāpanato carati. Iriyāpathena iriyāpathaṃ vicchinditvā
analyzed: kāyassa yāpanataḥ yāpeti cira kālavat tāpanataḥ carati iriyāpathena iriyāpatham vicchinditvā
translated: By carrying out the postures for a long time, it carries out.

original: jīvitaharaṇato viharati.
analyzed: jīvita haraṇataḥ viharati
translated: By interrupting one posture with another, it lives.

original: Micchājīvapaṭisedhakenāti –🔽“Idhekacco veḷudānena vā pattadānena vā puppha phala sinānadantakaṭṭhadānena vā cāṭukamyatāya🔽vā muggasūpyatāya vā pāribhaṭayatāya vā jaṅghapesanikena vā aññataraññatarena vā
analyzed: micchājīva paṭisedhakena ati  idha ekaccaḥ veḷu dānena vā patta dānena vā puppha phala sināna danta kaṭṭha dānena vā cāṭu kamyatāya  vā muggasūpyatāya vā pāribhaṭayatāya vā jaṅghapesanikena vā aññatara aññatarena vā
translated: With the opposite of wrong means of livelihood:

original: buddhapaṭikuṭṭhena micchāājīvena jīvikaṃ kappeti, ayaṃ vuccati anācāro”ti –
analyzed: buddha paṭikuṭṭhena micchāājīvena jīvikam kappeti ayam vuccati anācāraḥ ti
translated: “Here someone makes his living by giving gifts of vegetables, or by giving gifts of leaves, or by giving gifts of flowers, or by giving gifts of fruits, or by giving gifts of oil-press cakes, or by flattery, or by bean-soupery, or by being a go-between, or by being a matchmaker, or by being a messenger, or by being a trader in goods, or by one of the wrong kinds of livelihood condemned by the Noble Ones. This is called wrong conduct” .

original: Evaṃ vuttaanācārasaṅkhātamicchājīvapaṭipakkhena.
analyzed: evam vutta anācāra saṅkhātam icchājīva paṭipakkhena
translated: It is the opposite of wrong livelihood called “wrong conduct” stated thus.

original: Na veḷudānādinā ācārenāti –
analyzed: na veḍu dāna ādinā ācārena ati
translated: Not by the conduct consisting in giving vegetables, etc.,

original: “Idhekacco na veḷudānena na patta na puppha na phala na sināna na dantakaṭṭha na
analyzed: idha ekaccaḥ na na na puppha na phala na sināna na dantakaṭṭha na
translated: “Here someone does not give a gift of a bamboo park, a gift of a grass park, a gift of a grove, a gift of a temple, a gift of a dwelling, a gift of a lamp,

original: cāṭukamyatāya na muggasūpyatāya na pāribhaṭayatāya na jaṅghapesanikena na aññataraññatarena
analyzed: cāṭu kamyatāya na mugga sūpyatāya na pāribhaṭayatāya na jaṅgha pesanikena na aññatara aññatarena
translated: “Here someone does not make a living by giving gifts of bamboo, or of bowls, or of flowers, or of fruits, or of bathing-house requisites, or of tooth-sticks, or by flattery, or by making bean soup, or by acting as a go-between, or by divining omens, or by one of the kinds of wrong livelihood condemned by Buddhas,

original: buddhapaṭikuṭṭhena micchāājīvena jīvikaṃ kappeti, ayaṃ vuccati ācāro”ti –
analyzed: buddha paṭikuṭṭhena micchāājīvena jīvikam kappeti ayam vuccati ācāro ti
translated: This is called ‘conduct.’“

original: Evaṃ vuttena na veḷudānādinā ācārena.
analyzed: evam vuttena na veḷu dāna ādinā ācārena
translated: By the conduct stated thus as “not by giving gifts of bamboo, etc.”

original: Vesiyādiagocaraṃ pahāyāti –
analyzed: vesiya ādi agocaram pahāya āti
translated: Having abandoned the resort to harlots and the rest:

original: “Idhekacco vesiyagocaro vā hoti vidhava thullakumāri paṇḍaka bhikkhuni pānāgāragocaro🔽vā, saṃsaṭṭho viharati rājūhi rājamahāmattehi titthiyehi titthiyasāvakehi ananulomikena🔽saṃsaggena, yāni pana tāni kulāni assaddhāni appasannāni anopānabhūtāni akkosakaparibhāsakāni
analyzed: idha ekaccaḥ vesiya gocaraḥ vā hoti vidhava thullakumāri paṇḍaka bhikkhuni pānāgāra gocaraḥ  vā saṃsaṭṭhaḥ viharati rājūhi rāja mahāmattehi titthiyehi titthiya sāvakehi ananulomikena  saṃsaggena yāni pana tāni kulāni assaddhāni appasannāni anopāna bhūtāni akkosaka paribhāsakāni
translated: “Here someone resorts to harlots, or to widows, or to stout virgins, or to paṇḍakas, or to bhikkhunīs, or he resorts to drinking booths,🔽or he associates with kings, with kings’ ministers, with sectarians, with sectarians’ disciples, in a way that is not proper for a recluse,🔽or he visits families at improper times, or he visits families while the members of the family are in a secret place, or he visits families in unsuitable ways,

original: anatthakāmāni ahitakāmāni aphāsukakāmāni ayogakkhemakāmāni bhikkhūnaṃ bhikkhunīnaṃ
analyzed: anattha kāmāni ahita kāmāni a phāsuka kāmāni a yogakkhema kāmāni bhikkhūnam bhikkhunīnam
translated: or he visits families that are hostile to his preceptor and teacher and to those who are on their side,

original: upāsakānaṃ upāsikānaṃ, tathārūpāni kulāni sevati bhajati payirupāsati, ayaṃ vuccati agocaro”ti –
analyzed: upāsakānam upāsikānam tathārūpāni kulāni sevati bhajati payirupāsati ayam vuccati a gocaraḥ ti
translated: he associates with, pays attention to, and attends upon such families of male and female lay followers. This is called ‘the wrong resort.’ ”

original: Evamāgataṃ vesiyādiagocaraṃ pahāya.
analyzed: evam āgatam vesiyā ādi agocaram pahāya
translated: So he should avoid the wrong resort of prostitutes and so on.

original: Saddhāsampannakulādināti ettha ādi-saddena upanissayagocarādiṃ saṅgaṇhāti. Tividho
analyzed: saddhā sampanna kula ādinā ti ettha ādi saddena upanissaya gocara ādim saṅgaṇhāti tividhaḥ
translated: “Families endowed with faith, etc.”: the word “etc.” includes the right resort as support, and so on.🔽For there are three kinds of right resort:🔽the right resort as support, the right resort as protection, and the right resort as a tie.

original: hi gocaro upanissayagocaro ārakkhagocaro upanibandhagocaroti. Katamo upanissayagocaro?
analyzed: hi gocaraḥ upanissaya gocaraḥ ārakkha gocaraḥ upanibandha gocaraḥ ti katamaḥ upanissaya gocaraḥ
translated: What is the right resort as support?🔽A good friend who possesses the ten qualities of a good friend as described in the Ktha.v.

original: Dasakathāvatthuguṇasamannāgato kalyāṇamitto, yaṃ nissāya asutaṃ suṇāti, sutaṃ pariyodapeti,
analyzed: dasa kathā vatthu guṇa samannāgataḥ kalyāṇa mittaḥ yam nissāya a sutam suṇāti sutam pariyodapeti
translated: Depending on him, one hears the unheard, rectifies what one has heard,

original: kaṅkhaṃ vitarati, diṭṭhiṃ ujuṃ karoti, cittaṃ pasādeti. Yassa vā pana anusikkhamāno
analyzed: kaṅkham vitarati diṭṭhim ujum karoti cittam pasādeti yassa vā pana anusikkhamāno
translated: removes one’s doubts, straightens one’s views, and gains confidence.

original: saddhāya vaḍḍhati, sīlena sutena cāgena paññāya vaḍḍhati, ayaṃ upanissayagocaro.
analyzed: saddhāya vaḍḍhati sīlena sutena cāgena paññāya vaḍḍhati ayam upanissaya gocaro
translated: Or, training under him, one grows in faith, virtue, learning, generosity, and wisdom. This is the right resort as support.🔽What is the right resort as protection? Here a bhikkhu, having entered an inhabited area for alms,

original: Katamo ārakkhagocaro? Idha bhikkhu antaragharaṃ paviṭṭho vīthiṃ paṭipanno okkhittacakkhu
analyzed: katamaḥ ārakkha gocaraḥ idha bhikkhu antara gharam paviṭṭhaḥ vīthim paṭipannaḥ okkhitta cakkhu
translated: walks unhurriedly, with downcast eyes,

original: yugamattadassāvī saṃvuto gacchati, na hatthiṃ olokento, na assaṃ, na rathaṃ, na pattiṃ,
analyzed: yuga matta dassāvī saṃvutaḥ gacchati na hatthim olokentaḥ na assam na ratham na pattim
translated: He goes with his eyes downcast to the extent of a plough’s length, not looking at an elephant, a horse, a chariot, an infantry soldier,

original: na itthiṃ, na purisaṃ olokento, na uddhaṃ olokento, na adho olokento, na disāvidisaṃ
analyzed: na itthim na purisam olokentaḥ na uddham olokentaḥ na adhas olokentaḥ na disāvidisam
translated: not looking at a woman, not looking at a man, not looking up, not looking down, not looking around,

original: vipekkhamāno gacchati, ayaṃ ārakkhagocaro. Katamo upanibandhagocaro? Cattāro satipaṭṭhānā,
analyzed: vipekkhamānaḥ gacchati ayam ārakkha gocaraḥ katamaḥ upanibandha gocaraḥ cattāro sati paṭṭhānā
translated: but looking ahead only the length of a plough’s yoke. This is the resort of guarding. What is the resort of anchoring? The four foundations of mindfulness,

original: yattha cittaṃ upanibandhati. Vuttañhetaṃ bhagavatā “ko ca, bhikkhave, bhikkhuno gocaro
analyzed: yattha cittam upanibandhati vuttam ha etam bhagavatā kaḥ ca bhikkhave bhikkhunaḥ gocaraḥ
translated: where consciousness is anchored. This has been said by the Blessed One: “And what, bhikkhus, is a bhikkhu’s resort,

original: sako pettiko visayo? Yadidaṃ cattāro satipaṭṭhānā”ti, ayaṃ upanibandhagocaro. Iti
analyzed: sakaḥ pettikaḥ visayaḥ yat idam cattāro sati paṭṭhānā ati ayam upanibandha gocaraḥ iti
translated: his own ancestral property that has come down to him? It is this: the four foundations of mindfulness.” This is the resort of anchoring. Thus

original: ayaṃ tividho gocaro idha ādi-saddena saṅgahitoti daṭṭhabbo.
analyzed: ayam tividhaḥ gocaraḥ idha ādi saddena saṅgahito ti daṭṭhabbo
translated: this threefold resort should be regarded as included by the word “beginning” here.

original: Appamattakesu vajjesūti asañcicca āpannasekhiyaakusalacittuppādādibhedesu vajjesu.
analyzed: appamattakesu vajjesu iti asañcicca āpanna sekhiya akusala cittuppāda ādi bhedesu vajjesu
translated: In the case of slight faults: in the case of faults classed as offences of wrong-doing, etc., that are incurred unintentionally, and in the case of the arising of unprofitable thoughts, and so on.

original: Bhayato dassanasīloti paramāṇumattaṃ vajjaṃ aṭṭhasaṭṭhiyojanasatasahassubbedhasinerupabbatasadisaṃ
analyzed: bhayataḥ dassana sīlo ti paramāṇu mattam vajjam aṭṭha saṭṭhi yojana sata sahassa ubbedha sineru pabbata sadisam
translated: One who has the habit of seeing fear: one who sees a fault as small as a mere atom as like Mount Sineru, which is eighty-four thousand leagues high,

original: katvā dassanasabhāvo, sabbalahukaṃ vā dubbhāsitamattaṃ pārājikasadisaṃ katvā dassanasabhāvo.
analyzed: katvā dassana sabhāvaḥ sabba lahukam vā dubbhāsita mattam pārājika sadisam katvā dassana sabhāvaḥ
translated: and the mere bad action of speaking is made to appear as serious as an offence entailing Defeat.

original: Sammā ādāyāti sammadeva sakkaccaṃ sabbaso vā ādiyitvā.🔽Vaṭṭadukkhanissaraṇatthikehi sotabbato sutaṃ, pariyattidhammo. Taṃ dhāretīti sutadharo,
analyzed: sammā ādāya ati sammadā eva sakkaccam sabbasas vai ādiyitvā  vaṭṭa dukkha nissaraṇa atthikehi sotabbataḥ sutam pariyatti dhammo tam dhāreti iti sutadharaḥ
translated: Having taken up rightly: having taken up rightly, properly, thoroughly, or wholly.🔽The heard is the doctrine in the scriptures, because it is to be heard by those who are desirous of escape from the suffering of the round of rebirths. He who bears that is a bearer of the heard.

original: sutassa ādhārabhūto. Yassa hi ito gahitaṃ etto palāyati, chiddaghaṭe udakaṃ viya
analyzed: sutassa ādhāra bhūtaḥ yassa hi itas gahitam ettas palāyati chidda ghaṭe udakam viya
translated: He is the support of the heard. For when one has taken something from here and it slips away from there,

original: na tiṭṭhati, parisamajjhe ekaṃ suttaṃ vā jātakaṃ vā kathetuṃ vā vācetuṃ vā na sakkoti,
analyzed: na tiṭṭhati parisamajjhe ekam suttam vā jātakam vā kathetum vā vācetum vā na sakkoti
translated: it is like water in a cracked pot; it does not stay. He is unable to tell or to have told a sutta or a Jātaka in the midst of an assembly.

original: ayaṃ na sutadharo nāma. Yassa pana uggahitaṃ buddhavacanaṃ uggahitakālasadisameva
analyzed: ayam na sutadharaḥ nāma yassa pana uggahitam buddha vacanam uggahita kāla sadisam eva
translated: He is not called a bearer of the heard. But when one has taken up a Buddha word and it is as though it were taken up at the time of taking it,

original: hoti, dasapi vīsatipi vassāni sajjhāyaṃ akarontassa na nassati, ayaṃ sutadharo nāma.
analyzed: hoti dasa pi vīsati pi vassāni sajjhāyam a karontassa na nassati ayam sutadharaḥ nāma
translated: and it does not get lost even though one does not exercise it for ten or twenty years, he is called a bearer of the heard.

original: Tenevāha “yadassa ta”ntiādi. Ekapadampi ekakkharampi avinaṭṭhaṃ hutvā sanniciyatīti
analyzed: tena iva āha yat assa tanti ādi eka padam pi eka kkharam pi a vinaṭṭham hutvā sanniciyati iti
translated: Hence it is said: “What he has taken in stays with him” .

original: sannicayo, sutaṃ sannicayo etasminti sutasannicayoti āha “sutaṃ sannicitaṃ asminti
analyzed: sannicayaḥ sutam sannicayaḥ etasmin ti suta sannicaya uti āha sutam sannicitam asmin ti
translated: Accumulation of what is heard: it is an accumulation of what is heard in this , thus it is an accumulation of what is heard. He said: “In this there is an accumulation of what is heard.

original: sutasannicayo”ti. Yassa hi sutaṃ hadayamañjusāyaṃ sannicitaṃ silāya lekhā viya suvaṇṇaghaṭe
analyzed: suta sannicayā iti yassa hi sutam hadaya mañju sāyam sannicitam lekhā viya suvaṇṇa ghaṭe
translated: For when what is heard is accumulated in the heart’s core, as if written with a stylus on soft clay, or as if placed in a golden casket,

original: pakkhittā sīhavasā viya ca sādhu tiṭṭhati, ayaṃ sutasannicayo nāma. Tenāha “etena…pe…🔽avināsaṃ dassetī”ti.
analyzed: pakkhittā sīha vasā viya ca sādhu tiṭṭhati ayam sutasannicayaḥ nāma tena āha  avināsam dasseti iti
translated: it is well kept. This is called an accumulation of what is heard. Hence it is said: “By this … he shows non-loss” .

original: Dhātāti paguṇā vācuggatā. Ekassa hi uggahitabuddhavacanaṃ niccakālikaṃ na hoti, “asukasuttaṃ🔽vā jātakaṃ vā kathehī”ti vutte “sajjhāyitvā aññehi saṃsanditvā paripucchāvasena atthaṃ
analyzed: dhātā ati paguṇā ekassa hi uggahita buddha vacanam niccakālikam na hoti asuka suttam  vā jātakam vā kathehi iti vutte sajjhāyitvā aññehi saṃsanditvā paripucchā vasena attham
translated: Store: what is well learned, well got by heart. For when one has learned the Buddha’s word, it is not always available. When one is asked to recite a sutta or a stanza,

original: ogāhitvā jānissāmī”ti vadati. Ekassa paguṇaṃ pabandhavicchedābhāvato gaṅgāsotasadisaṃ
analyzed: ogāhitvā jānissāmi iti vadati ekassa paguṇam pabandha viccheda abhāvataḥ gaṅgā sota sadisam
translated: one says, “I will know after I have prepared it, after I have gone over it with others, after I have investigated its meaning.” But when it is well learned, it comes easily, like the flow of a river,

original: bhavaṅgasotasadisañca akittimaṃ sukhappavatti hoti, “asukasuttaṃ vā jātakaṃ vā kathehī”ti
analyzed: bhavaṅga sota sadisam ca akittimam sukha ppavatti hoti asuka suttam vā jātakam vā kathehi iti
translated: like the flow of the life-continuum, without any break in the sequence, without any effort, as if it were placed in a golden casket. When one is asked to recite a sutta or a stanza,

original: vutte uddharitvā tameva katheti. Taṃ sandhāya vuttaṃ “dhātā”ti. Vācāya paguṇā katāti🔽suttadasakavaggadasakapaṇṇāsadasakavasena vācāya sajjhāyitā, dasa suttāni gatāni,
analyzed: vutte uddharitvā tam eva kathā iti tam sandhāya vuttam dhātā ati vācāya paguṇā katā iti  sutta dasaka vagga dasaka paṇṇāsa dasaka vasena vācāya dasa suttāni gatāni
translated: and when the latter is mentioned, he brings up the former and talks about that. It is of him that the text says “he is one who has memorized the Dhamma. ”🔽“He has recited the Dhamma with his speech”: he has recited the Dhamma by way of the ten suttas, the ten vaggas, the ten paṇṇāsas, and the ten dasakas.

original: dasa vaggāni gatānītiādinā sallakkhetvā vācāya sajjhāyitāti attho. Suttekadesassa
analyzed: dasa vaggāni gatāni itiādinā sallakkhetvā vācāya sajjhāyi tā ti attho sutta ekadesassa
translated: The meaning is that he has recited the Dhamma by way of the ten suttas, the ten vaggas, and so on.

original: hi suttamattassa ca vacasā paricayo idha nādhippeto, atha kho vaggādivaseneva. Manasā
analyzed: hi sutta mattassa ca vacasā paricayaḥ idha na adhippetaḥ atha kho vagga ādi vasena iva manasā
translated: For here it is not intended that he should be familiar with the suttas and the suttas in their entirety by way of his speech, but rather by way of the vaggas, etc.

original: anupekkhitāti manasā anu anu pekkhitā, bhāgaso nijjhāyitā cintitāti attho. Āvajjantassāti
analyzed: anupekkhitā ti manasā anu anu pekkhitā bhāgasaḥ nijjhāyitā cintitā ati attho āvajjantassa ti
translated: “He has reviewed it with his mind”: he has reviewed it with his mind again and again, he has reflected on it part by part. The meaning is that he has thought about it.

original: vācāya sajjhāyituṃ buddhavacanaṃ manasā cintentassa. Suṭṭhu paṭividdhāti nijjaṭaṃ
analyzed: vācāya sajjhāyitum buddha vacanam manasā cintentassa suṭṭhu paṭividdhā ati nijjaṭam
translated: “When he adverts”: when he adverts to the Buddha’s word in order to recite it with his speech, to think about it with his mind.

original: niggumbaṃ katvā suṭṭhu yāthāvato paṭividdhā.
analyzed: niggumbam katvā suṭṭhu yāthāvataḥ paṭividdhā
translated: “He has penetrated it well”: he has penetrated it well, as it really is, after having disentangled it and unraveled it.

original: Dve mātikāti bhikkhumātikā bhikkhunīmātikā ca. Vācuggatāti purimasseva vevacanaṃ.
analyzed: dve mātikā ati bhikkhu mātikā bhikkhunī mātikā ca vācuggatā iti purimassa iva vevacanam
translated: “Two mātikas”: the mātikā of the bhikkhus and the mātikā of the bhikkhunīs. “With his speech” is a synonym for the former.

original: Tisso anumodanāti saṅghabhatte dānānisaṃsapaṭisaṃyuttaanumodanā, vihārādimaṅgale
analyzed: tissaḥ saṅgha bhatte dāna anisaṃsa paṭisaṃyutta anumodanāḥ vihāra ādi maṅgale
translated: Rejoicing in three ways: rejoicing connected with the benefits of giving, connected with the benefits of the monastery, etc.,

original: maṅgalasuttādianumodanā, matakabhattādiavamaṅgale tirokuṭṭādianumodanāti imā tisso
analyzed: maṅgala sutta ādi anumodanā mataka bhatta ādi avamaṅgale tirokuṭṭa ādi anumodanā ti imāḥ tisso
translated: Three kinds of appreciation: appreciation connected with the benefits of giving, which is called “appreciation of the Sangha meal”; appreciation of the auspiciousness of a monastery, etc., which is called “appreciation of the auspiciousness of the auspicious discourses”; and appreciation of the inauspiciousness of a dead person’s food, etc., which is called “appreciation of the inauspiciousness of the inauspicious discourses.”🔽The method of the legal procedures: the method stated in the chapter on legal procedures at the end of the Parivāra.

original: anumodanā. Kammākammavinicchayoti parivārāvasāne kammavagge vuttavinicchayo. “Vipassanāvasena
analyzed: anumodanā kamma a kamma vinicchayo ti parivāra avasāne kamma vagge vutta vinicchayaḥ vipassanā vasena
translated: “One who learns by insight

original: uggaṇhantena catudhātuvavatthānamukhena uggahetabba”nti tīsupi gaṇṭhipadesu vuttaṃ.
analyzed: uggaṇhantena catu dhātu vavatthāna mukhena uggahetabbanti tīsu pi gaṇṭhi padesu vuttam
translated: should learn by way of the defining of the four elements” is stated in the three key terms.

original: Catūsu disāsu appaṭihatattā catasso disā etassāti catuddiso, catuddisoyeva cātuddiso,
analyzed: catūsu disāsu a paṭihata ttā catassaḥ disāḥ etassa ati catuddisaḥ catuddisaḥ yā iva cātuddisaḥ
translated: He is called “one who has four quarters” because he is unobstructed in the four quarters. He is called “one who has four quarters” because he is unobstructed in the four quarters.

original: catasso vā disā arahati, catūsu vā disāsu sādhūti cātuddiso.
analyzed: catassaḥ vā disāḥ arahati catūsu vā disāsu sādhu iti cātuddisaḥ
translated: He is called “one who has four quarters” because he is worthy of the four quarters or because he is good in the four quarters.🔽In the Monastic Law: in the entire Vinaya Piṭaka.

original: Abhivinayeti sakale vinayapiṭake. Vinetunti sikkhāpetuṃ. “Dve vibhaṅgā paguṇā vācuggatā
analyzed: abhivinaya iti sakale vinaya piṭake vinetum ti sikkhāpetum dve vibhaṅgā paguṇā
translated: To train: to instruct. “The two analyses should be mastered, their words and their meaning,

original: kātabbāti idaṃ paripucchāvasena uggahaṇampi sandhāya vutta”nti vadanti. Ekassa pamuṭṭhaṃ,
analyzed: kātabbā ti idam paripucchā vasena uggahaṇam pi sandhāya vuttan ti vadanti ekassa pamuṭṭham
translated: This is said with reference to learning by questioning.” One who has forgotten,

original: itarassa paguṇaṃ hotīti āha “tīhi janehi saddhiṃ parivattanakkhamā kātabbā”ti. Abhidhammeti
analyzed: itarassa paguṇam hoti iti āha tīhi janehi saddhim parivattana khamā kātabbā ati abhidhamma iti
translated: in the Description of Mentality-Materiality.🔽“The three lower sections” means the three sections below the Great Section, namely, the Section with Verses, the Section on Origins,

original: nāmarūpaparicchede. Heṭṭhimā vā tayo vaggāti mahāvaggato heṭṭhā sagāthakavaggo nidānavaggo
analyzed: nāma rūpa paricchede heṭṭhimāḥ vā tayaḥ vaggā ati mahā vaggataḥ heṭṭhā sagāthaka vaggaḥ nidāna vaggo
translated: and the Section on the Aggregates.

original: khandhakavaggoti ime tayo vaggā. “Dhammapadampi saha vatthunā uggahetuṃ vaṭṭatī”ti🔽mahāpaccariyaṃ vuttattā jātakabhāṇakena sāṭṭhakathaṃ jātakaṃ uggahetvāpi dhammapadampi
analyzed: khandhaka vaggo ti ime tayaḥ vaggāḥ dhamma padam pi saha vatthunā uggahetum vaṭṭati iti  mahāpaccariyam vutta ttā jātaka bhāṇakena sa aṭṭhakatham jātakam uggahetvā api dhamma padam pi
translated: “The Dhammapada together with its exegesis should be learned”🔽because it is stated in the Maha-Paccaya Sutta.🔽Therefore, even though the reciter of the Jataka stories has learned the Jataka together with its commentary,

original: saha vatthunā uggahetabbameva.🔽Kalyāṇā sundarā parimaṇḍalapadabyañjanā vācā assāti kalyāṇavāco. Tenāha “sithiladhanitādīnaṃ…pe…🔽vācāya samannāgato”ti. Tattha parimaṇḍalapadabyañjanāyāti ṭhānakaraṇasampattiyā sikkhāsampattiyā
analyzed: saha vatthunā uggahetabbam eva  kalyāṇā sundarā parimaṇḍala pada byañjanā vācā tena āha sithila dhanitā ādīnaṃpe  vācāya samannāgataḥ ti tattha parimaṇḍala pada byañjanāya ati ṭhāna karaṇa sampattiyā sikkhā sampattiyā
translated: he must also learn the Dhammapada together with its exegesis.🔽He is one whose speech is good, beautiful, and well-rounded in its words and syllables, thus he is one “whose speech is good” .🔽“He is endowed with speech that is well-rounded in its words and syllables” means that his speech is well-rounded in its words and syllables because it is complete in terms of place and action and because it is complete in training.

original: ca katthacipi anūnatāya parimaṇḍalapadāni byañjanāni akkharāni etissāti parimaṇḍalapadabyañjanā,
analyzed: ca katthacipi anūna tāya parimaṇḍala padāni byañjanāni akkharāni etissā ati parimaṇḍala pada byañjanā
translated: It is well-rounded in its words and syllables because it is not deficient in any way.

original: padameva vā atthassa byañjanato padabyañjanaṃ, taṃ akkharapāripūriṃ katvā sithiladhanitādidasavidhaṃ
analyzed: padam eva vā atthassa byañjanataḥ pada byañjanam tam akkhara pāripūrim katvā sithila dhanitā ādi dasavidham
translated: Or else, the word-and-syllable is the word itself as the meaning’s sign. It is called “rounded” when it is stated without omitting any letters, without omitting any slack or tight pronunciation, etc.,

original: byañjanabuddhiṃ aparihāpetvā vuttaṃ parimaṇḍalaṃ nāma hoti. Akkharapāripūriyā hi
analyzed: byañjana buddhim a parihāpetvā vuttam parimaṇḍalam nāma hoti akkhara pāripūriyā hi
translated: and without omitting any word-and-syllable pronunciation. For the roundedness of the word-and-syllable

original: padabyañjanassa parimaṇḍalatā. Tena vuttaṃ “sithiladhanitādīnaṃ yathāvidhānavacanenā”ti,🔽parimaṇḍalaṃ padabyañjanaṃ etissāti parimaṇḍalapadabyañjanā. Atha vā pajjati ñāyati
analyzed: pada byañjanassa parimaṇḍala tā tena vuttam sithila dhanitā ādīnam yathā vidhāna vacanena ati  parimaṇḍalam pada byañjanam parimaṇḍala pada byañjanā atha vā pajjati ñāyati
translated: is due to the completeness of the letters. Hence it is said, “By stating it in the way appropriate to slack, tight, etc.”

original: attho etenāti padaṃ, nāmādi. Yathādhippetamatthaṃ byañjetīti byañjanaṃ, vākyaṃ. Tesaṃ
analyzed: etena ati padam nāma ādi yathā adhippetam attham byañjeti iti byañjanam vākyam tesam
translated: The word-and-syllable is rounded: it is rounded in the word-and-syllable. Or alternatively, it is a word because by it a meaning is made known,

original: paripuṇṇatāya parimaṇḍalapadabyañjanā.
analyzed: paripuṇṇa tāyai parimaṇḍala pada byañjanā
translated: and it is a syllable because it is the sign of a name, etc. It is rounded because of the completeness of both.

original: Apica yo bhikkhu parisati dhammaṃ desento suttaṃ vā jātakaṃ vā nikkhipitvā aññaṃ
analyzed: apica yaḥ bhikkhu parisati dhammaṃ desento suttam vā jātakam vā nikkhipitvā aññam
translated: Moreover, when a bhikkhu is teaching the Dhamma in an assembly and he omits a sutta or a Jātaka and then

original: upārambhakaraṃ suttaṃ āharati, tassa upamaṃ katheti, tadatthaṃ otāreti, evaṃ idaṃ
analyzed: upārambha karam suttam āharati tassa upamam kathā iti tad attham evam idam
translated: brings in another sutta or Jātaka, and he illustrates it with a simile and explains its meaning, then it is rounded in this way.

original: gahetvā ettha khipanto ekapasseneva pariharanto kālaṃ ñatvā vuṭṭhahati, nikkhittasuttaṃ
analyzed: gahetvā ettha khipantaḥ eka passena iva pariharantaḥ kālam ñatvā vuṭṭhahati nikkhitta suttam
translated: and he gets up when the time is announced, having kept the time by the one side as he was taking it.

original: pana nikkhittamattameva hoti, tassa kathā aparimaṇḍalā nāma hoti atthassa aparipuṇṇabhāvato.
analyzed: pana nikkhitta mattam eva hoti tassa kathā aparimaṇḍalā nāma hoti atthassa a paripuṇṇa bhāvato
translated: But the thread that is just laid down is only laid down; and his talk is called “not rounded” because of the incompleteness of the meaning.

original: Yo pana suttaṃ vā jātakaṃ vā nikkhipitvā bahi ekapadampi agantvā yathānikkhittassa🔽suttassa atthasaṃvaṇṇanāvaseneva suttantarampi ānento pāḷiyā anusandhiñca pubbāparañca
analyzed: yaḥ pana suttam vā jātakam vā nikkhipitvā bahi eka padam pi a gantvā yathā nikkhittassa  suttassa attha saṃvaṇṇanā vasena iva suttantaram pi ānento pāḷiyā anusandhiñca pubba aparañca
translated: But when someone, after laying down a Thread or a story, does not go outside it even for a single word,

original: apekkhanto ācariyehi dinnanaye ṭhatvā tulikāya paricchindanto viya taṃ taṃ atthaṃ
analyzed: apekkhantaḥ ācariyehi dinna naye tulikāya paricchindantaḥ viya tam tam attham
translated: but brings in other Threads by way of commentary on the meaning of the Thread as laid down, and he looks to the connection in the texts and to what is said before and after,

original: suvavatthitaṃ katvā dassento gambhīramātikāya udakaṃ pesento viya gambhīramatthaṃ
analyzed: su vavatthitam katvā dassentaḥ gambhīra mātikāya udakam pesentaḥ viya gambhīram attham
translated: and he shows the meaning, having made it quite clear by defining each point as if with a knife, as it were pouring water over the deep Abhidhamma,

original: gamento vaggihārigatiyā pade padaṃ koṭṭento sindhavājānīyo viya ekaṃyeva padaṃ anekehi
analyzed: gamentaḥ vaggihāri gatiyā pade padam koṭṭentaḥ sindhavājānīyaḥ viya ekaṃ yā iva padam anekehi
translated: and he goes on, picking out each word with the gait of a leader of a herd of elephants, as it were, by repeating again and again in many ways that one word,

original: pariyāyehi punappunaṃ saṃvaṇṇanto gacchati, tassa kathā parimaṇḍalā nāma hoti dhammato
analyzed: pariyāyehi punappunam saṃvaṇṇantaḥ gacchati tassa kathā parimaṇḍalā nāma hoti dhammato
translated: his talk is called “rounded” because of the completeness of the meaning.

original: atthato anusandhito pubbāparato ācariyuggahatoti sabbaso paripuṇṇabhāvato. Evarūpampi
analyzed: atthataḥ anusandhitaḥ pubba aparataḥ ācari yuggahato ti sabbaso paripuṇṇa bhāvataḥ evarūpam pi
translated: and in meaning, in sequence, in the beginning, in the teacher’s instruction, in every way, in the fullness.

original: kathaṃ sandhāya “parimaṇḍalapadabyañjanāyā”ti vuttaṃ.
analyzed: katham sandhāya parimaṇḍala pada byañjanāya iti vuttam
translated: And it is said in the way beginning, “In the rounded and polished phrasing” with reference to such a talk.

original: Guṇaparipuṇṇabhāvena pure bhavāti porī, tassa bhikkhuno tenetaṃ bhāsitabbaṃ atthassa
analyzed: guṇa paripuṇṇa bhāvena pure bhavāti porī tassa bhikkhuno tena itam bhāsitabbam atthassa
translated: It is “polished” because it is full of virtue in the past, and it is to be spoken by that bhikkhu. The meaning is this:

original: guṇaparipuṇṇabhāvena pure puṇṇabhāve bhavāti attho. Pure vā bhavattā poriyā nāgarikitthiyā
analyzed: guṇa paripuṇṇa bhāvena pure puṇṇa bhāve bhavāti pure vā bhavattā poriyā nāgarikitthiyā
translated: It is “polished” because it is full of virtue in the fullness in the past, or it is “polished” because it was in the past.

original: sukhumālattanena sadisāti porī, pure saṃvaḍḍhanārī viya sukumārāti attho. Purassa
analyzed: sukhumālattanena sadisā ati porī pure saṃvaḍḍha nārī viya sukumārā ati attho purassa
translated: It is like a slender creeper, thus it is “polished” . The meaning is that it is slender like a woman who has grown up in the past.🔽It is “polished” because it is his,

original: esātipi porī, purassa esāti nagaravāsīnaṃ kathāti attho. Nagaravāsino hi yuttakathā
analyzed: esā atipi porī purassa esā ati nagara vāsīnam kathā ati atthaḥ nagara vāsinaḥ hi yutta kathā
translated: The meaning is that it is the talk of the town. For the people of the town are talkative.

original: honti pitimattaṃ “pitā”ti, bhātimattaṃ “bhātā”ti vadanti. Evarūpī hi kathā bahuno
analyzed: honti pitimattam pitā ati bhātimattam bhātā ati vadanti evarūpī hi kathā
translated: They say “father” for “uncle” and “brother” for “cousin.” For such talk

original: janassa kantā hoti manāpā, tāya poriyā.
analyzed: janassa kantā hoti manāpā tāya poriyā
translated: is dear and welcome to many people. With such polished talk

original: Vissaṭṭhāyāti pittasemhādīhi apalibuddhāya sandiṭṭhavilambitādidosarahitāya. Atha
analyzed: vissaṭṭhāya ati pitta semha ādīhi apalibuddhāya sandiṭṭha vilambita ādi dosa rahitāya atha
translated: “Unrestrained” : unhampered by bile, phlegm, etc., and free from the faults of being too fast or too slow.

original: vā nātisīghaṃ nātisaṇikaṃ nirantaraṃ ekarasañca katvā parisāya ajjhāsayānurūpaṃ dhammaṃ
analyzed: vā na ati sīgham na ati saṇikam nirantaram ekarasam ca katvā parisāya ajjhāsayā anurūpam dhammaṃ
translated: Or when he is expounding the Dhamma to an assembly in a way suitable to the dispositions of the people, then his speech is called “unconfused.”

original: kathentassa vācā vissaṭṭhā nāma. Yo hi bhikkhu dhammaṃ kathento suttaṃ vā jātakaṃ🔽vā ārabhitvā āraddhakālato paṭṭhāya turitaturito araṇiṃ manthento viya uṇhakhādanīyaṃ
analyzed: kathentassa vācā vissaṭṭhā nāma yaḥ hi bhikkhu dhammam kathentaḥ suttam vā jātakam  vā ārabhitvā āraddha kālataḥ paṭṭhāya turita turitaḥ araṇim manthentaḥ viya uṇha khādanīyam
translated: For when a bhikkhu is expounding the Dhamma, whether a sutta or a story,

original: khādanto viya pāḷiyā anusandhipubbāparesu gahitaṃ gahitameva, aggahitaṃ aggahitameva🔽katvā purāṇapaṇṇantaresu caramānaṃ godhaṃ uṭṭhāpento viya tattha tattha paharanto
analyzed: khādantaḥ viya pāḷiyā anusandhi pubba aparesu gahitam gahitam eva aggahitam aggahitam eva  katvā purāṇa paṇṇantaresu caramānam godham uṭṭhāpentaḥ viya tattha tattha paharantaḥ
translated: from the time he begins, he is like one churning quickly, like one eating hot food,🔽taking up only what is in the text, not taking up what is not there,🔽like one driving a snake into a hollow bamboo, striking it here and there,

original: osāpetvā uṭṭhāya gacchati. Purāṇapaṇṇantaresu hi paripātiyamānā godhā kadāci dissati
analyzed: osāpetvā uṭṭhāya gacchati purāṇa paṇṇa antaresu hi paripātiyamānā godhā kadāci dissati
translated: and then getting up and going away. For when snakes are driven into a hollow bamboo, sometimes they are seen and sometimes not.

original: kadāci na dissati, evamekaccassa atthavaṇṇanā katthaci dissati katthaci na dissati.
analyzed: kadāci na dissati evam ekaccassa attha vaṇṇanā katthaci dissati katthaci na dissati
translated: So too, sometimes the commentary on the meaning is seen and sometimes not.

original: Yopi dhammaṃ kathento kālena sīghaṃ, kālena saṇikaṃ, kālena mandaṃ, kālena mahāsaddaṃ,
analyzed: yaḥ api dhammam kathentaḥ kālena sīgham kālena saṇikam kālena mandam kālena mahā saddam
translated: Or when he is expounding the Dhamma, sometimes quickly, sometimes slowly, sometimes softly, sometimes loudly,

original: kālena khuddakasaddaṃ karoti, yathā nijjhāmataṇhikapetassa mukhato niccharaṇakaaggi
analyzed: kālena khuddaka saddam karoti yathā nijjhāma taṇhika petassa mukhataḥ
translated: he makes a little noise at the right time, like the fire that issues from the mouth of the one who has quenched his thirst for craving,

original: kālena jalati kālena nibbāyati, evaṃ petadhammakathiko nāma hoti, parisāya uṭṭhātukāmāya
analyzed: kālena jalati kālena nibbāyati evam peta dhamma kathikaḥ nāma hoti parisāya uṭṭhātu kāmāya
translated: at one time blazing, at another time dying down. So too the one who tells the story of the departed one is called a “departed one.” When the assembly wants to get up,

original: puna ārabhati. Yopi kathento tattha tattha vitthāyati, appaṭibhānatāya āpajjati,
analyzed: punar ārabhati yaḥ api kathentaḥ tattha tattha vitthāyati appaṭibhāna tāya āpajjati
translated: he starts again. Even if he is verbose here and there, he does not fall into uneloquence,

original: kenaci rogena nitthunanto viya kandanto viya katheti, imesaṃ sabbesampi kathā vissaṭṭhā
analyzed: kenacid rogena nitthunantaḥ viya kandantaḥ viya kathā iti imesam sabbesam pi kathā vissaṭṭhā
translated: he speaks as if he were groaning with some disease, as if he were weeping. The talk of all these is called “disjointed,”

original: nāma na hoti sukhena appavattabhāvato. Yo pana suttaṃ āharitvā ācariyehi dinnanaye
analyzed: nāma na hoti sukhena appavatta bhāvataḥ yaḥ pana suttam āharitvā ācariyehi dinna naye
translated: because it does not proceed smoothly. But the one who, having quoted the sutta, stands in the method given by the teachers,🔽not letting go of the teachers’ grip, and explaining in the same way

original: ṭhito ācariyuggahaṃ amuñcanto yathā ca ācariyā taṃ taṃ suttaṃ saṃvaṇṇesuṃ, teneva
analyzed: ṭhitaḥ ācari yuggaham a muñcantaḥ yathā ca ācariyā tam tam suttam saṃvaṇṇesum tena iva
translated: as the teachers commented on this or that sutta,

original: nayena saṃvaṇṇento nātisīghaṃ nātisaṇikantiādinā vuttanayena kathāpabandhaṃ avicchinnaṃ
analyzed: nayena saṃvaṇṇentaḥ na ati sīgham na ati saṇikam ti ādinā vutta nayena kathā apabandham avicchinnam
translated: without interruption, in the way stated thus: “not too fast, not too slow,” etc.,🔽and makes the continuity of the talk flow on like the stream of a river,

original: katvā nadīsoto viya pavatteti, ākāsagaṅgāto bhassamānaudakaṃ viya nirantarakathaṃ
analyzed: katvā nadī sotaḥ viya pavatta iti ākāsagaṅgātaḥ bhassamāna audakam viya nirantara katham
translated: like the water flowing from the sky-river,

original: pavatteti, tassa kathā vissaṭṭhā nāma hoti. Taṃ sandhāya vuttaṃ “vissaṭṭhāyā”ti.
analyzed: pavattā iti tassa kathā vissaṭṭhā nāma hoti tam sandhāya vuttam vissaṭṭhāya ati
translated: He is called one who has lost his way.🔽Without stammering: without stammering, without faltering.

original: Anelagaḷāyāti elagaḷavirahitāya. Kassaci hi kathentassa elaṃ gaḷati, lālā paggharati,
analyzed: anelagaḷāya ati elagaḷa virahitāya kassaci hi kathentassa elam gaḷati lālā paggharati
translated: For when someone speaks, his tongue stammers, his saliva dribbles,

original: kheḷaphusitāni vā nikkhamanti, tassa vācā elagaḷā nāma hoti, tabbiparītāyāti attho.
analyzed: kheḷa phusitāni vā nikkhamanti tassa vācā elagaḷā nāma hoti tad biparītāya ati attho
translated: or his lips tremble, then his speech is called stammering. The meaning is that it is the opposite of that.

original: Atthassa viññāpaniyāti ādimajjhapariyosānaṃ pākaṭaṃ katvā bhāsitatthassa viññāpanasamatthatāya
analyzed: atthassa viññāpaniyā ti ādi majjha pariyosānam pākaṭam katvā bhāsita atthassa viññāpana samattha tāya
translated: Capable of making known the meaning: capable of making known the meaning that is being spoken by making its beginning, middle, and end clear.

original: atthañāpane sādhanāya.
analyzed: attha ñāpane sādhanāya
translated: Capable of establishing the knowledge of the meaning.

original: Vācāva karaṇanti vākkaraṇaṃ, udāhāraghoso. Kalyāṇaṃ madhuraṃ vākkaraṇaṃ assāti kalyāṇavākkaraṇo.
analyzed: vācā ava vāc karaṇanti vāc karaṇam udāhāra ghosaḥ kalyāṇam madhuram vāc karaṇam assa ati kalyāṇa vāc karaṇaḥ
translated: Pleasant speech: speech is a speech act, a vocal sound. He has pleasant speech, he has sweet speech.🔽Therefore it is said, “sweet-voiced.”

original: Tenevāha “madhurassaro”ti. Hīḷetīti avajānāti. Mātugāmoti sambandho. Manaṃ apāyati🔽vaḍḍhetīti manāpo. Tenāha “manavaḍḍhanako”ti. Vaṭṭabhayena tajjetvāti yobbanamadādimattā
analyzed: tena iva āha madhuraḥ saraḥ ti hīḍeti iti avajānāti mātugāmī iti sambandhaḥ manam apāyati 🔽vaḍḍheti iti tena āha vaṭṭa bhayena tat jetvā ati yobbana mada ādimat tā
translated: He delights the mind: he delights the mind. He is pleasing. Therefore it is said, “he delights the mind.”🔽Having frightened with the fear of the round of rebirths: having frightened with the fear of youthfulness, intoxication, and so on,

original: bhikkhuniyo saṃsārabhayena tāsetvā. Gihikāleti attano gihikāle. Bhikkhuniyā methunena🔽bhikkhunīdūsako hotīti bhikkhuniyā kāyasaṃsaggameva vadati. Sikkhamānāsāmaṇerīsu
analyzed: bhikkhuniyaḥ saṃsāra bhayena tāsetvā gihi kāle ti attanaḥ gihi kāle bhikkhuniyā methunena  bhikkhunī dūsakaḥ hoti iti bhikkhuniyā kāya saṃsaggam eva vadati sikkhamānā sāmaṇerīsu
translated: The bhikkhunis were frightened by the danger of the round of rebirths. “A lay follower”: when she was a lay follower. “A bhikkhuni”🔽means that he is guilty of defiling a bhikkhuni only if there is bodily contact with a bhikkhuni. But he is not guilty of defiling a bhikkhuni if he has sexual intercourse with a probationer or a novice nun.

original: pana methunenapi bhikkhunīdūsako na hotīti āha “sikkhamānāsāmaṇerīsu methunadhamma”nti.
analyzed: pana methunena api bhikkhunī dūsakaḥ na hoti iti āha sikkhamānā sāmaṇerīsu methuna dhamman ti
translated: “A probationer or a novice nun” means that he is guilty of defiling a bhikkhuni if he has sexual intercourse with a probationer or a novice nun.

original: “Kāsāyavatthavasanāyā”ti vacanato dussīlāsu bhikkhunīsikkhamānāsāmaṇerīsu garudhammaṃ🔽ajjhāpannapubbo paṭikkhittoyevāti daṭṭhabbaṃ. Tassā bhikkhuniyā abhāvepi yā yā tassā
analyzed: kāsāya vattha vasanāya ati vacanataḥ dussīlāsu bhikkhunī sikkhamānā sāmaṇerīsu garu dhammam  ajjhāpanna pubbaḥ paṭikkhittaḥ yeva āti daṭṭhabbam tassāḥ bhikkhuniyāḥ abhāve pi yā yā tassā
translated: “A woman dressed in yellow” means that he is guilty of defiling a bhikkhuni if he has sexual intercourse with an immoral bhikkhuni, probationer, or novice nun.🔽But he is not guilty of defiling a bhikkhuni if he has sexual intercourse with a woman dressed in white.🔽“If there is no bhikkhuni” means that even though there is no bhikkhuni, the other bhikkhunis who heard her statement think that there is one.

original: vacanaṃ assosuṃ, tā tā tatheva maññantīti āha “mātugāmo hī”tiādi.🔽Idāni aṭṭha aṅgāni samodhānetvā dassetuṃ “ettha cā”tiādi āraddhaṃ. Imehi pana aṭṭhahaṅgehi
analyzed: vacanam tā tā tathā iva maññanti iti āha mātugāmaḥ hi itiādi  idāni aṭṭha aṅgāni samodhānetvā dassetum ettha ca atiādi āraddham imehi pana aṭṭhahaṅgehi
translated: “A woman” means that he is guilty of defiling a bhikkhuni if he has sexual intercourse with a woman.

original: asamannāgataṃ ñatticatutthena kammena sammannento dukkaṭaṃ āpajjati, bhikkhu pana sammatoyeva hoti.
analyzed: a samannāgatam ñatti catutthena kammena sammannentaḥ dukkaṭam āpajjati bhikkhu pana hoti
translated: “If he is appointed by a unanimous chapter” means that he commits an offense of wrong conduct if he is appointed by a chapter that does not fulfill the eight requirements. But he is appointed even if there is only one bhikkhuni present.

original: 148. Garukehīti garukātabbehi. Ekatoupasampannāyāti upayogatthe bhummavacanaṃ. “Ovadatī”ti
analyzed: garukehi iti garukātabbehi ekatas upasampannāya ati upayoga atthe bhumma vacanam ovadati iti
translated: “One who is worthy of respect”: one who should be respected. “One who has been fully admitted to the order”: the locative case is in the sense of the instrument. “Instruct”

original: vā imassa “vadatī”ti atthe sati sampadānavacanampi yujjati. Bhikkhūnaṃ santike upasampannā
analyzed: vā imassa vadati iti atthe sati sampadāna vacanam pi yujjati bhikkhūnam santike upasampannā
translated: can also be taken as a compound meaning “one who gives advice.” “Bhikkhunīs who have been fully admitted in the presence of bhikkhus”

original: nāma parivattaliṅgā vā pañcasatasākiyāniyo vā.
analyzed: nāma parivatta liṅgāḥ vā vā
translated: are those who have changed sex or the five hundred Sakyan women.

original: 149. Āsanaṃ paññapetvāti ettha “sace bhūmi manāpā hoti, āsanaṃ apaññāpetumpi vaṭṭatī”ti
analyzed: āsanam paññapetvā ti ettha sace bhūmi manāpā hoti āsanam a paññāpetum pi vaṭṭati iti
translated: “Having prepared a seat”: it is said in the three manuals that if the ground is suitable, it is allowable not to prepare a seat.

original: tīsupi gaṇṭhipadesu vuttaṃ. Mātugāmaggahaṇena bhikkhunīpi saṅgahitāti āha “dhammadesanāpattimocanattha”nti.
analyzed: tīsu pi gaṇṭhi padesu vuttam mātu gāma gahaṇena bhikkhunī pi saṅgahitā ti āha dhamma desanā āpatti mocana atthan ti
translated: Since the bhikkhunīs are included by the words “women,” the commentator says “in order to be released from the offense of teaching the Dhamma.”

original: Sammatassa bhikkhuno santikaṃ pāṭipade ovādatthāya sabbāhi bhikkhunīhi āgantabbato🔽“samaggāttha bhaginiyo”ti iminā sabbāsaṃ āgamanaṃ pucchatīti āha “sabbā āgatātthā”ti.
analyzed: sammatassa bhikkhuno santikam pāṭipade ovāda tthāya sabbāhi bhikkhunīhi āgantabbato  samaggāḥ attha bhaginiyaḥ iti iminā sabbāsam āgamanam pucchati iti āha sabbāḥ āgatā attha ati
translated: Since all the bhikkhunīs must come to the presence of the approved bhikkhu on the following day in order to be instructed,🔽he says “Are you all together, sisters?” in order to ask whether they are all present.

original: Gilānāsu anāgatāsupi gilānānaṃ anāgamanassa anuññātattā āgantuṃ samatthāhi ca sabbāhi
analyzed: gilānāsu anāgatāsu pi gilānānam anāgamanassa anuññāta ttā āgantum samatthāhi ca sabbāhi
translated: Since it is allowed that the sick need not come and that the sick need not be brought, he says “Are you all present?”

original: āgatattā “samaggāmhayyā”ti vattuṃ vaṭṭati. Antogāme vātiādīsu yattha pañca aṅgāni🔽bhūmiyaṃ patiṭṭhāpetvā vandituṃ na sakkā hoti, tattha ṭhitāya eva kāyaṃ purato nāmetvā🔽“vandāmi ayyā”ti añjaliṃ paggayha gantumpi vaṭṭati. Antaragharanti katthaci nagaradvārassa
analyzed: āgata ttā vattum vaṭṭati antogāme vāti ādīsu pañca aṅgāni  bhūmiyam patiṭṭhāpetvā vanditum na sakkā hoti tattha ṭhitāya eva kāyam puratas nāmetvā  vandāmi ayyā iti añjalim paggayha gantum pi vaṭṭati antara gharanti katthaci nagara dvārassa
translated: “We are united” is the right thing to say. In a village, etc., where it is not possible to pay homage by placing the five points on the ground, it is allowable for one who is standing there to pay homage by raising one’s joined palms above one’s head and saying, “I pay homage, Noble Ones,” and then to go on. In a house: in some places the door of a house is the village gate.

original: bahiindakhīlato paṭṭhāya antogāmo vuccati, katthaci gharummārato paṭṭhāya antogehaṃ.
analyzed: bahi indakhīlataḥ paṭṭhāya antogāmaḥ vuccati katthaci gharummārataḥ paṭṭhāya antogeham
translated: Since they have come, it is proper to say, “We are united.” In a village, etc.: where it is not possible to pay respect by placing the five limbs on the ground, it is proper to pay respect by raising one’s joined palms above the head while standing and saying, “I pay respect, Noble Lady,” and then to go. In a house: in some places the village is said to extend from the city gate or the village gate to the edge of the threshing floor; in some places the house is said to extend from the road to the house to the edge of the threshing floor.

original: Idha pana “antogāme vā”ti visuṃ vuttattā “antaraghare vā”ti antogehaṃ sandhāya vuttanti
analyzed: idha pana antogāme vā ati visum vutta ttā antara ghare vā ati antogeham sandhāya vuttan ti
translated: But here, since “in a village” is stated separately, “in a house” should be taken to refer to the interior of a house.

original: daṭṭhabbaṃ. Yattha katthacīti antogāmādīsu yattha katthaci.🔽Vaṭṭatīti “vasatha ayye, mayaṃ bhikkhū ānessāmā”ti vuttavacanaṃ saddahantīhi vasituṃ
analyzed: daṭṭhabbam yattha katthaci iti antogāma ādīsu yattha katthaci  vaṭṭati iti vasatha ayye mayam bhikkhū ānessāma ati vutta vacanam saddahantīhi vasitum
translated: Anywhere: in any of the places such as a village, etc.

original: vaṭṭati. Na nimantitā hutvā gantukāmāti manussehi nimantitā hutvā gantukāmā na hontīti
analyzed: vaṭṭati na nimantitā hutvā gantu kāmā ati manussehi nimantitāḥ hutvā gantu kāmāḥ na honti iti
translated: It is proper: it is proper for them to stay there if they believe the words, “Stay, Noble Lady, we will bring the monks.” Not wanting to go, though invited: they do not want to go, though invited by people.

original: attho, tattheva vassaṃ upagantukāmā hontīti adhippāyo. Yatoti bhikkhunupassayato.
analyzed: attho tattha eva vassam upagantu kāmāḥ honti iti adhippāyaḥ yatas ti
translated: The meaning is, they wanted to do the residence right there. ‘Because’: because of the nuns’ residence.

original: Yācitvāti “tumhehi ānītaovādeneva mayampi vasissāmā”ti yācitvā. Tatthāti tasmiṃ bhikkhunupassaye.
analyzed: yācitvā ti tumhehi ānīta ovādena iva mayam pi vasissāma ati yācitvā tattha āti tasmin bhikkhun upassaye
translated: ‘Having asked’: having asked, “We will live with the advice brought by you.” ‘There’: in that nuns’ residence.

original: Āgatānaṃ santike ovādena vasitabbanti pacchimikāya vassaṃ vasitabbaṃ. Abhikkhukāvāse
analyzed: āgatānam santike ovādena vasitabbanti pacchimikāya vassam vasitabbam abhikkhuka āvāse
translated: ‘They should live with the advice of those who have come’: they should do the residence by the last-named method.

original: vasantiyā āpattīti codanāmukhena sāmaññato āpattippasaṅgaṃ vadati, na pana tassā
analyzed: vasantiyāḥ āpatti iti codanā mukhena sāmaññataḥ āpatti ppasaṅgam vadati na pana tassā
translated: ‘There is an offence for one who lives in a residence without monks’: by way of the accusation he states the offence that is incurred by the general rule, but not the offence

original: āpatti. Vassacchedaṃ katvā gacchantiyāpi āpattīti vassānupagamamūlaṃ āpattiṃ vadati.
analyzed: āpatti vassa chedam katvā gacchantiyā api āpatti iti vassa anupagama mūlam āpattim vadati
translated: for that (nun). ‘There is an offence for one who goes after breaking up the residence’: he states the offence that has the non-residence during the rainy season as its source.

original: Itarāya āpattiyā anāpattikāraṇasabbhāvato “sā rakkhitabbā”ti vuttaṃ, sā vassānupagamamūlā
analyzed: itarāya āpattiyāḥ anāpatti kāraṇa sabbhāvataḥ sā rakkhitabbā iti vuttam sā vassa anupagama mūlā
translated: ‘She should be protected’ is said because of the absence of a reason for an offence for the other (nun). The meaning is, the offence that has the non-residence during the rainy season as its source

original: āpatti rakkhitabbāti attho, abhikkhukepi āvāse īdisāsu āpadāsu vassaṃ upagantabbanti
analyzed: āpatti rakkhitabbā ti attho abhikkhuke pi āvāse īdisāsu āpadāsu vassam upagantabbanti
translated: should be protected. The meaning is, in a residence without monks, in such dangers as these, the residence during the rainy season should be undertaken.

original: adhippāyo. Tenāha “āpadāsu hi…pe… anāpatti vuttā”ti. Itarāya pana āpattiyā anāpatti,
analyzed: adhippāyaḥ tena āha āpadāsu hipe anāpatti vuttā ati itarāya pana āpattiyāḥ anāpatti
translated: This is the purport. Therefore he said, “In dangers, etc., an offence is stated.” But for the other offence there is no offence,

original: kāraṇe asati pacchimikāyapi vassaṃ na upagantabbaṃ. Santesu hi bhikkhūsu vassaṃ anupagacchantiyā
analyzed: kāraṇe asati vassam na upagantabbam santesu hi bhikkhūsu vassam an upagacchantiyā
translated: For if she enters for the Rains when there are bhikkhus, she commits an offense.

original: āpatti. Tattha gantvā pavāretabbanti ettha apavārentīnaṃ āpattisambhavato. Sace dūrepi
analyzed: āpatti tattha gantvā pavāretabbanti ettha apavārentīnam āpatti sambhavato sace dūre pi
translated: “Having gone there, she should invite”: because there is an offense for those who do not invite.

original: bhikkhūnaṃ vasanaṭṭhānaṃ hoti, sakkā ca hoti navamiyaṃ gantvā pavāretuṃ, tattha gantvā
analyzed: bhikkhūnam vasana ṭṭhānam hoti sakkā ca hoti navamiyam gantvā pavāretum tattha gantvā
translated: If there are bhikkhus living nearby, and if it is possible to go there on the fourteenth day and invite, then she should go there and invite.

original: pavāretabbaṃ. Sace pana navamiyaṃ nikkhamitvā sampāpuṇituṃ na sakkā hoti, agacchantīnaṃ anāpatti.🔽Uposathassa pucchanaṃ uposathapucchā, sāyeva ka-ppaccayaṃ rassattañca katvā uposathapucchakanti
analyzed: pavāretabbam sace pana navamiyam nikkhamitvā sampāpuṇitum na sakkā hoti a gacchantīnam anāpatti  uposathassa pucchanam uposatha pucchā sāyā iva kappa ccayam rassattam ca katvā uposathapucchakanti
translated: But if it is not possible to go there on the fourteenth day and return on the same day, there is no offense for those who do not go.🔽“Asking about the observance day”: the asking about the observance day is called “the observance-day asking”.🔽It is said that it is “the observance-day asking” when it is made short by the contraction of syllables.

original: vuttāti āha “uposathapucchana”nti. Uposatho pucchitabboti “kadā, ayya, uposatho”ti
analyzed: vuttā iti āha uposatha pucchananti uposathaḥ pucchitabbo ti kadā ayye uposatho ti
translated: “The observance day should be asked about”: “When, Venerable Sir, is the observance day?”🔽should be asked. And the bhikkhu should say, “Tomorrow, Sister, is the observance day.”

original: pucchitabbo. Bhikkhunāpi “sve, bhagini, uposatho”ti vattabbaṃ. Bhikkhū kadāci kenaci
analyzed: pucchitabbaḥ bhikkhunā api sve bhagini uposathaḥ ti vattabbam bhikkhū kadāci kenacid
translated: Sometimes the bhikkhus do not know the observance day.

original: kāraṇena pannarasikaṃ vā cātuddasīuposathaṃ, cātuddasikaṃ vā pannarasīuposathaṃ karonti,
analyzed: kāraṇena pannarasikam vā cātuddasī uposatham cātuddasikam vā pannarasī uposatham karonti
translated: If they do it for a reason, then on the fourteenth day they may do the observance-day ceremony of the fourteenth, and on the fifteenth day they may do the observance-day ceremony of the fifteenth.

original: yasmiñca divase bhikkhūhi uposatho kato, tasmiṃyeva bhikkhunīhipi uposatho kātabboti
analyzed: yasmin ca divase bhikkhūhi uposathaḥ kato tasmin yeva bhikkhunīhi pi uposathaḥ kātabbo ti
translated: And on the day when the monks do the observance-day ceremony, the nuns should do it on that same day.

original: adhippāyena “pakkhassa terasiyaṃyeva gantvā”tiādi vuttaṃ. Evaṃ pucchitena bhikkhunā🔽sace cātuddasiyaṃ uposathaṃ karonti, “cātuddasiko bhaginī”ti vattabbaṃ. Sace pana
analyzed: adhippāyena pakkhassa terasiyam yeva gantvā itiādi vuttam evam pucchitena bhikkhunā  sace cātuddasiyam uposatham karonti cātuddasikaḥ bhaginī iti vattabbam sace pana
translated: The intention is that the monk who is asked should say, “Having gone on the thirteenth day of the fortnight,” and so on.🔽If they do the observance-day ceremony on the fourteenth day, he should say, “The observance-day ceremony is on the fourteenth day, sister.” If they do it on the fifteenth day, he should tell them, “The observance-day ceremony is on the fifteenth day.”

original: pannarasiyaṃ karonti, “pannarasiko bhaginī”ti ācikkhitabbaṃ. Ovādatthāyāti ovādayācanatthāya.🔽Pāṭipadadivasato pana paṭṭhāya dhammasavanatthāya gantabbanti pāṭipadadivase ovādaggahaṇatthāya
analyzed: pannarasiyam karonti pannarasikaḥ bhaginī iti ācikkhitabbam ovāda tthāya ati ovāda yācana tthāya  pāṭipada divasataḥ pana paṭṭhāya dhamma savana tthāya gantabbanti pāṭipada divase ovāda ggahaṇa tthāya
translated: For the purpose of requesting instruction: for the purpose of requesting instruction.🔽But from the day after the fourteenth, they may go for the purpose of listening to the Teaching.🔽On the fourteenth day, they should go for the purpose of receiving instruction.

original: dutiyadivasato paṭṭhāya antarantarā dhammasavanatthāya gantabbaṃ. Ovādaggahaṇampi
analyzed: dutiya divasataḥ paṭṭhāya antarantarā dhamma savana tthāya gantabbam ovāda ggahaṇam pi
translated: From the day after that, they may go from time to time for the purpose of listening to the Teaching.🔽For the receiving of instruction is said to be included in “listening to the Teaching.”

original: hi “dhammasavanamevā”ti abhedena vuttaṃ. Nirantaraṃ vihāraṃ upasaṅkamiṃsūti yebhuyyena
analyzed: hi dhamma savanam eva ati abhedena vuttam nirantaram vihāram upasaṅkamiṃsu iti yebhuyyena
translated: They approached the monastery without a break:

original: upasaṅkamanaṃ sandhāya vuttaṃ. Vuttañhetantiādinā yathānusiṭṭhaṃ paṭipajjissāmāti
analyzed: upasaṅkamanam sandhāya vuttam vuttam ha etat tiādinā yathānusiṭṭham paṭipajjissāma ati
translated: The passage beginning, “The Blessed One said: ‘Monks, I allow you to approach the nuns’ quarters’ ” is said with reference to approaching.🔽For the passage is given in order to show that all nuns should be approached.

original: sabbāsaṃyeva bhikkhunīnaṃ upasaṅkamanadīpanatthaṃ pāḷi nidassitā. Ovādaṃ gacchatīti🔽ovādaṃ yācituṃ gacchati. Dve tissoti dvīhi tīhi. Karaṇatthe cetaṃ paccattavacanaṃ.
analyzed: sabbāsam yeva bhikkhunīnam upasaṅkamana dīpana attham nidassitā ovādam gacchati iti  ovādam yācitum gacchati dve tissaḥ ti dvīhi tīhi karaṇa atthe ca itam paccattavacanam
translated: “She goes for advice”: she goes to ask for advice.🔽“Two or three”: the singular form is used because of the plural.🔽“With pleasing behavior”: with behavior that inspires confidence, that is, with faultless bodily behavior, etc.

original: Pāsādikenāti pasādajanakena niddosena kāyakammādinā. Sampādetūti tividhaṃ sikkhaṃ
analyzed: pāsādikena ati pasāda janakena niddosena kāya kamma ādinā sampādetu uti tividham sikkham
translated: “May she fulfill the training”: may she fulfill the three trainings.

original: sampādetu. Sace pātimokkhuddesakaṃyeva disvā tāhi bhikkhunīhi ovādo yācito bhaveyya,
analyzed: sampādetu sace pātimokkha uddesakam yā iva disvā tāhi bhikkhunīhi ovādaḥ yācitaḥ bhaveyya
translated: If the nuns ask for advice from the one who recites the Pāṭimokkha,🔽what should he do?

original: tena kiṃ kātabbanti? Uposathagge sannipatite bhikkhusaṅghe pubbakiccavasena “atthi🔽kāci bhikkhuniyo ovādaṃ yācamānā”ti pucchiyamāne “evaṃ vadehī”ti ovādapaṭiggāhakena
analyzed: tena kim kātabbanti uposatha gge sannipatite bhikkhu saṅghe pubba kicca vasena atthi  kāci bhikkhuniyo ovādam yācamānā ati pucchiyamāne evam vadehi iti ovāda paṭiggāhakena
translated: When the Sangha of monks has gathered for the Uposatha, the first duty is to ask, “Are there any nuns who have come to ask for advice?”🔽If there are, the one who receives the advice should say, “Please say so.”🔽Then another monk should announce,

original: vattabbavacanaṃ aññena bhikkhunā kathāpetvā pātimokkhuddesakena vattabbavacanaṃ attanā
analyzed: vattabba vacanam aññena bhikkhunā kathāpetvā pātimokkha uddesakena vattabba vacanam attanā

analyzed: vatvā puna sayam eva gantvā bhikkhunīnam ārocetabbam aññena vā bhikkhunā tasmin divase
translated: Having said that, he should go himself and inform the nuns, or another monk should be told to recite the Pāṭimokkha on that day.

translated: not to the absence of a companion. From many nunneries:

analyzed: upāya maggesu arahataḥ pariniṭṭhita sikkhattā āha idam cape vuttanti atha vā appamajjataḥ

original: So kira pubbe rājā hutvā nagaraṃ padakkhiṇaṃ karonto nalāṭato sede muccante parisuddhena🔽sāṭakena nalāṭaṃ puñchi, sāṭako kiliṭṭho ahosi. So “imaṃ sarīraṃ nissāya evarūpo
analyzed: so kira pubbe rājā hutvā nagaram padakkhiṇam karontaḥ nalāṭato sede muccante parisuddhena  sāṭakena nalāṭam puñchi sāṭako kiliṭṭhaḥ ahosi saḥ imam sarīram nissāya evarūpo
translated: He was a king in a previous birth. He was circumambulating a city. Sweat flowed from his forehead. He wiped his forehead with a clean cloth.

original: parisuddhasāṭako pakatiṃ jahitvā kiliṭṭho jāto, aniccā vata saṅkhārā”ti aniccasaññaṃ
analyzed: parisuddha sāṭakaḥ pakatim jahitvā kiliṭṭhaḥ jātaḥ aniccāḥ vata saṅkhārā ti anicca saññam
translated: The cloth became soiled. He thought: “This cloth is clean. It has lost its original condition and become soiled because of this body. Impermanent, indeed, are formations.”

original: paṭilabhati, tena kāraṇenassa rajoharaṇameva paccayo jāto. Rajaṃ haratīti rajoharaṇaṃ.
analyzed: paṭilabhati tena kāraṇena assa rajaḥ haraṇam eva paccayaḥ jātaḥ rajam harati iti rajaḥ haraṇam
translated: He attained the perception of impermanence. Therefore, the wiping of the sweat became the condition for his attainment of insight. The wiping of the sweat is called rajoharaṇa.

original: Saṃvegaṃ paṭilabhitvāti asubhasaññaṃ aniccasaññañca upaṭṭhapento saṃvegaṃ paṭilabhitvā.🔽So hi yoniso ummajjanto “parisuddhaṃ vatthaṃ, natthettha doso, attabhāvassa panāyaṃ
analyzed: saṃvegam paṭilabhitvā ti asubha saññam anicca saññañca upaṭṭhapento saṃvegam paṭilabhitvā  so hi yonisas ummajjantaḥ parisuddham vattham nattha ittha doso atta bhāvassa pana ayam
translated: He attained a sense of spiritual urgency: he attained a sense of spiritual urgency by developing the perception of foulness and the perception of death.

original: doso”ti asubhasaññaṃ aniccasaññañca paṭilabhitvā nāmarūpapariggahādinā pañcasu khandhesu
analyzed: doso ti asubha saññam anicca saññañca paṭilabhitvā nāma rūpa pariggaha ādinā pañcasu khandhesu
translated: For, while he was contemplating wisely, he thought: “The cloth is clean. There is no fault in it. The fault is in the body.” He attained the perception of foulness and the perception of death. He directed his knowledge to the five aggregates, which are the objects of the perception of foulness and the perception of death, by way of the aggregates of material form, feeling, perception, mental formations, and consciousness.

original: ñāṇaṃ otāretvā kalāpasammasanādikkamena vipassanaṃ vaḍḍhetvā udayabbayañāṇādipaapāṭiyā
analyzed: ñāṇam otāretvā kalāpa sammasana ādi kkamena vipassanam vaḍḍhetvā udaya bbaya ñāṇa ādi paapāṭiyā
translated: He developed insight by way of the contemplation of the body as a compound of elements, etc., and attained the knowledge of rise and fall, etc.

original: vipassanaṃ anulomagotrabhusamīpaṃ pāpesi. Taṃ sandhāya vuttaṃ “vipassanaṃ ārabhī”ti.
analyzed: vipassanam anuloma gotra bhu samīpam pāpesi tam sandhāya vuttam vipassanam ārabhi iti
translated: He brought insight to the neighbourhood of the flood of conformity. In reference to this it was said: “He began insight” .

original: Obhāsagāthaṃ abhāsīti obhāsavissajjanapubbakabhāsitagāthā obhāsagāthā, taṃ abhāsīti attho.

analyzed: imāḥ tissaḥ obhāsa gāthāḥ abhāsi iti vuttam adhicetasā iti ca ayam cūḷapanthaka therassa
translated: These are the three illumination verses he spoke. And this “The higher mind” is the verse of the Elder Cūḷapanthaka.

analyzed: udāna gāthā ti imissāya eva pāḷiyā āgatam thera gāthāyam pana cūḷapanthaka therassa udāna gāthāsu
translated: The verse of the brief summary is found in this same text. But in the Theragāthā, in the verses of brief summaries,🔽this verse is not found. It is said there: “This verse of brief summary is that of the elder Ekudāniya.”

analyzed: ayam anāruḷhā ekudāniya therassa pana ayam udāna gāthā ti tattha vuttam evam sante pi
translated: But even though that is so,

original: arahattaṃ pāpuṇi. Abhabbo tvantiādivacanato anukampāvasena saddhivihārikādiṃ saṅghikavihārā🔽nikkaḍḍhāpentassa anāpatti viya dissati. Abhabbo hi thero sañcicca taṃ kātuṃ, nikkaḍḍhanasikkhāpade
analyzed: arahattam pāpuṇi abhabbo tvan ti ādi vacanataḥ anukampā vasena saddhivihārika ādim saṅghika vihārā  nikkaḍḍhāpentassa anāpatti viya dissati abhabbaḥ hi thero sañcicca tam kātum nikkaḍḍhana sikkhāpade
translated: From the words “But you are incapable” it appears that there is no offence for one who expels a pupil or a co-resident from a dwelling belonging to the Community out of compassion.

analyzed: vā a paññatte therena evam katam nti gahetabbam

original: 156. Ovadantassa pācittiyanti atthaṅgate sūriye garudhammehi vā aññena vā dhammeneva
analyzed: ovadantassa pācittiyanti atthaṅgate sūriye garu dhammehi vā aññena vā dhammena iva

analyzed: ovadantassa sammatassa api pācittiyam sesam ettha uttānam eva atthaṅgata sūriya tā paripuṇṇa upasampanna tā

analyzed: ovadananti imāni pana ittha tīṇi aṅgāni

original: Atthaṅgatasikkhāpadavaṇṇanā niṭṭhitā.
analyzed: atthaṅgata sikkhāpada vaṇṇanā niṭṭhitā
translated: The commentary on the training rule on the sun having set is finished.

original: 3. Bhikkhunupassayasikkhāpadavaṇṇanā
analyzed: bhikkhun upassaya sikkhāpada vaṇṇanā
translated: The training rule on the nuns’ dwelling place

original: 162. Tatiyaṃ uttānatthameva. Upassayūpagamanaṃ, paripuṇṇūpasampannatā, samayābhāvo, garudhammehi ovadananti imāni panettha cattāri aṅgāni.

translated: The third rule has an obvious meaning. Going to a dwelling place, she is fully ordained, it is not the right time, he advises on the serious rules: these are the four points here.

original: Bhikkhunupassayasikkhāpadavaṇṇanā niṭṭhitā.🔽4. Āmisasikkhāpadavaṇṇanā🔽164. Catutthe “upasampannaṃ…pe… bhikkhunovādaka”nti imesaṃ “maṅkukattukāmo”ti iminā🔽sambandho. “Avaṇṇaṃ kattukāmo ayasaṃ kattukāmo”ti imesaṃ pana vasena “upasampanna”ntiādīsu
analyzed: bhikkhunupassaya sikkhāpada vaṇṇanā niṭṭhitā  āmisa sikkhāpada vaṇṇanā  catutthe imesam maṅku kattu kāmo ti iminā  sambandhaḥ avaṇṇam kattu kāmaḥ ayasam kattu kāmaḥ iti imesam pana vasena
translated: The commentary on the training rule on the nuns’ dwelling place is finished.🔽The training rule on material support

analyzed: upasampannassa ati vibhatti vipariṇāmaḥ kātabbo ti imam attham sandhāya ujjhāpanake
translated: In the fourth rule, “one who is aiming to get her tonsure” is connected with “one who is aiming to get her to be criticized” and “one who is aiming to get her to be humiliated”. But in the case of “one who is fully ordained”, “one who is aiming to get her to be criticized” and “one who is aiming to get her to be humiliated” should be changed to “one who is fully ordained’s”. With the meaning of this, “one who is aiming to get her to be criticized” and “one who is aiming to get her to be humiliated” are connected with “one who is aiming to get her tonsure”.

original: vuttanayenevattho veditabbo”ti vuttaṃ. “Cīvarahetu ovadatī”tiādinā bhaṇantassa ekekasmiṃ
analyzed: vutta nayena iva atthaḥ veditabbaḥ iti vuttam cīvara hetu ovadati itiādinā bhaṇantassa ekekasmin
translated: The meaning should be understood in the way already stated.🔽As to the words “if he teaches the nuns for the sake of robes,” etc., it should be understood that there is an offense entailing confession for each statement.

original: vacane niṭṭhite pācittiyaṃ veditabbaṃ. “Upasampannaṃ saṅghena asammata”nti pāḷivacanato🔽“sammatena vā saṅghena vā bhāraṃ katvā ṭhapito”ti aṭṭhakathāvacanato ca aṭṭhahi aṅgehi🔽samannāgato sammatena vā vippavasitukāmena “yāvāhaṃ āgamissāmi, tāva te bhāro hotū”ti
analyzed: vacane niṭṭhite pācittiyam veditabbam upasampannam saṅghena a sammatan ti pāḷivacanato  sammatena vā saṅghena vā bhāram katvā ṭhapitaḥ iti aṭṭhakathā vacanato ca aṭṭhahi aṅgehi  samannāgataḥ sammatena vā vippavasitu kāmena yāva aham āgamissāmi tāva te bhāraḥ hotu uti
translated: Because of the words of the rule, “a fully ordained monk who has not been appointed by the Sangha,”🔽and because of the commentary’s words, “one who has been appointed by the Sangha or who has been made the burden by the Sangha,”🔽it should be understood that one who has eight qualities may be appointed by the Sangha. If he wants to stay apart, he should be appointed by the Sangha in this way: “Until I return, let this be your burden.”

original: yācitvā ṭhapito tassābhāvato saṅghena vā tatheva bhāraṃ katvā ṭhapito aṭṭhahi garudhammehi🔽aññena vā dhammena ovadituṃ labhatīti veditabbaṃ. Tasmā “yo pana, bhikkhu, asammato
analyzed: yācitvā ṭhapitaḥ tassa abhāvato saṅghena vā tathā iva bhāram katvā ṭhapitaḥ aṭṭhahi garu dhammehi  aññena vā dhammena ovaditum labhati iti veditabbam tasmā yaḥ pana bhikkhu a sammataḥ
translated: Because of the eight important principles,🔽or because of some other rule, he may teach.🔽Therefore, “If a monk who has not been appointed teaches the nuns, he commits an offense entailing confession,”

original: bhikkhuniyo ovadeyya, pācittiya”nti idaṃ pageva bhāraṃ katvā aṭṭhapitaṃ sandhāya🔽vuttanti gahetabbaṃ.
analyzed: bhikkhuniyaḥ ovadeyya pācittiyam ti idam pagā iva bhāram katvā aṭṭhapitam sandhāya 🔽vuttam ti gahetabbam
translated: this should be taken as referring to one who has been made the burden and then appointed.

analyzed: anāpatti pakatiyā cīvara hetu pe ovadantam bhaṇati iti ettha āmisa hetu ovadantam
translated: “There is no offense if she says, ‘I’m speaking to one who is instructing me for the sake of material gains’ …🔽“If she says, ‘I’m speaking to one who is advising me for the sake of material gains’ …

analyzed: āmisa hetu ovadati iti saññāya evam bhaṇantassa anāpatti na āmisa hetu ovadati iti
translated: “There is no offense if she says, ‘I’m not instructing for the sake of worldly gain,’🔽but she says, ‘She’s instructing for the sake of worldly gain,’

analyzed: saññinaḥ pana dukkaṭam na āmisa hetu ovadantam pana āmisa hetu ovadati iti saññāya  bhaṇantassa api anāpatti sacittaka ttā sikkhāpadassa sesam ettha uttānam eva upasampanna tā
translated: and she says it because she doesn’t want to praise her. But if she says it because she wants to criticize her,🔽then there’s an offense because of the intention to break the training rule. The rest is as above.

original: dhammena laddhasammutitā, anāmisantaratā, avaṇṇakāmatāya evaṃ bhaṇananti imāni panettha cattāri aṅgāni.
analyzed: dhammena laddha sammuti tā anāmisa antara tā avaṇṇa kāma tāya evam bhaṇanan ti imāni pana ittha cattāri aṅgāni
translated: Four things: she is fully ordained; she is agreed upon by the Sangha in accordance with the rule; she is not instructing for the sake of worldly gain; she says it because she doesn’t want to praise her.

original: Āmisasikkhāpadavaṇṇanā niṭṭhitā.
analyzed: āmisa sikkhāpada vaṇṇanā niṭṭhitā
translated: The training rule on for the sake of worldly gain, the first, is finished.

translated: . The fifth is clear.

analyzed: ujjhāpeyyum tatas mahājanaḥ passitum na labhati iti maññamānaḥ yathāsaṃhaṭam haritvā

analyzed: nikkhipitvā iti ādim āha  nīharati iti sakim nīharati ye pi tesam sambandhaḥ
translated: He says, “having laid aside.”

original: “sabrahmacārīnaṃ kātuṃ vaṭṭatī”ti itikattabbatāvasena sūcikammakaraṇaṃ. Ācariyupajjhāyānaṃ

original: dukkaṭanti akappiyasamādānavasena dukkaṭaṃ. Vañcetvāti “tava ñātikāyā”ti avatvā “ekissā
analyzed: dukkaṭanti akappiya samādāna vasena dukkaṭam vañcetvā iti tava ñātikāya ati avatvā ekissā

translated: Even if he has them weave without saying, “This is your mother’s robe,” etc., but just saying, “Weave this robe,” there is no offense if he does it with a pure mind.

original: 179. Upāhanatthavikādinti ādi-saddena yaṃ cīvaraṃ nivāsetuṃ vā pārupituṃ vā na sakkā
analyzed: upāhana thavika ādin ti ādi saddena yam cīvaram nivāsetum vā pārupitum vā na sakkā

analyzed: idam kasmā vuttanti so kira ājīvakaḥ tam dānam dentaḥ bimbisāra kālataḥ paṭṭhāya adāsi  pacchā ajāta sattu kāle sikkhāpada paññattitaḥ paṭṭhāya bhikkhū kukkuccāyantā tam dānaṃ  na paṭiggaṇhiṃsu tasmai āditas paṭṭhāya tat vatthu dassitan ti veditabbam atha kho

analyzed: bhuñjanti iti nimantana vasena iva pada bhājane gaṇa bhojanam vuttam kiñci pana sikkhāpadam 🔽vatthu ananurūpam pi siyāti pada bhājane vutta nayena nimantana vasena iva gaṇa bhojanam
translated: where the action doesn’t correspond to the analysis of the terms?” In the analysis of the terms, “eating in a group” is said only in terms of the invitation,

analyzed: hoti iti āsaṅkā bhaveyyāti tad nivattana attham tam pana itam gaṇa bhojanam dvīhākārehi
