analyzed: pasavati iti vuttam pañcannam bhojanānam nāmam gahetvā ati ettha bhojanam gaṇhatha ati  vutte api gaṇa bhojanam vadanti heṭṭhā addhāna gamana vatthusmim nāvā abhiruhana vatthusmim ca  idha iva bhante bhuñjatha ati vutte yasmai kukkuccāyantāḥ na paṭiggaṇhiṃsu tasmai bhuñjatha ati  vutte api gaṇa bhojanam na tīsu pi gaṇṭhi padesu vuttam pañcannam bhojanānam  nāmam gahetvā nimanteti iti vutta ttā pana odanam bhuñjatha ati vā bhattam bhuñjatha ati
translated: Taking the names of the five kinds of staple food: here they say that even when the names of the five kinds of staple food are not taken, it is still a group meal.🔽But in the three places where it is said that “in the case of the journey of more than a league, in the case of the journey by boat, and in the case of the invitation to eat curry, ‘Eat here, venerable sirs,’ they did not accept out of scrupulousness, so it is not a group meal even when the words ‘Eat’ are used,” it is said that it is not a group meal.

translated: But since it is said that “he invites them by taking the names of the five kinds of staple food,” it is a group meal only when the names of the five kinds of staple food are taken, thus: “Eat rice,” “Eat boiled rice,” “Eat porridge,” “Eat mung-bean curry,” “Eat fresh green vegetables,” and not otherwise.

original: etthāpi “odana”nti vā “bhatta”nti vā vatvāva te evaṃ nimantesunti gahetabbaṃ. Gaṇavasena
analyzed: ettha api odananti vā bhattanti vā vatvā ava te evam nimantesunti gahetabbam gaṇa vasena
translated: Or else, because they were invited as a group,

analyzed: vā nimantita ttā te bhikkhū apakataññu tāya kukkuccāyantāḥ na paṭiggaṇhiṃsu iti ayam amhākam

original: khanti, vīmaṃsitvā yuttataraṃ gahetabbaṃ.

analyzed: ekatas gaṇhanti iti ettha aññamaññassa dvādasa hattham a muñcitvā ṭhitāḥ ekatas gaṇhanti

analyzed: heṭṭhā tvam ekassa bhikkhuno bhattam dehi tvam dvinnam ti evam viññāpetvā ati vacanato

analyzed: sikkhāpadena āpatti visum gahaṇe paṇīta bhojana sūpodana viññattīhi āpatti veditabbā
translated: The offense is to be understood as coming from the training rule, not from the individual act of taking.

original: Vicāretīti pañcakhaṇḍādivasena saṃvidahati. Ghaṭṭetīti anuvātaṃ chinditvā hatthena
analyzed: vicāra iti iti pañca khaṇḍa ādi vasena saṃvidahati ghaṭṭa iti iti anuvātam chinditvā hatthena
translated: “He considers” means he makes an agreement by means of the five parts, etc. “He touches” means he touches by cutting across the wind, with his hand,

analyzed: daṇḍakena vā ghaṭṭeti suttam karoti iti suttam vaṭṭeti valeti iti daṇḍake vā hatthe

analyzed: vā āvaṭṭeti abhinavassa iva cīvarassa karaṇam idha cīvarakammam nāma purāṇa cīvare  sūcikammam nāma na hoti iti vadanti catutthe āgate na yāpenti iti vacanato sace añño
translated: They say that “making a robe” here means making a new robe; it does not mean sewing an old one.

analyzed: koci āgacchantaḥ natthi cattāro yeva ca tattha nisinnāḥ yāpetum na sakkonti na vaṭṭati iti vadanti  gaṇa bhojana āpatti janaka nimantana bhāvataḥ akappiya nimantanan ti vuttam sampavesetvā iti
translated: They say that “if they do not finish when the fourth arrives” means that if no one else arrives, and if the four of them are unable to finish while sitting there, it is not allowable.

original: nisīdāpetvā. Gaṇo bhijjatīti gaṇo āpattiṃ na āpajjatīti adhippāyo. “Yattha cattāro
analyzed: nisīdāpetvā gaṇaḥ bhijjati iti gaṇaḥ āpattim na āpajjati iti adhippāyaḥ yattha cattāro
translated: Because there is no offense that originates from the act of inviting, it is called “an improper invitation”. “Having seated” means having made them sit down. “The group breaks up” means that the group does not commit an offense. This is the intention.

original: bhikkhū…pe… bhuñjantī”ti imāya pāḷiyā saṃsandanato “itaresaṃ pana gaṇapūrako hotī”ti
analyzed: bhikkhu upe bhuñjanti iti imāya pāḷiyā saṃsandanataḥ itaresam pana gaṇapūrakaḥ hoti iti

translated: “Without distinction” means without distinguishing “one who is sick or one who is making robes.”

translated: “Therefore” means because there is no distinction. “When they have eaten and gone”: if they have not gone, but the meal is finished, it is allowable to take it.

original: vaṭṭati. Tāni ca tehi ekato na gahitānīti yehi bhojanehi visaṅketo natthi, tāni bhojanāni
analyzed: vaṭṭati tāni ca tehi ekatas na gahitāni iti yehi bhojanehi visaṅketaḥ natthi tāni bhojanāni
translated: “They have not taken it together with them”: the meals in regard to which there is no doubt,

analyzed: vuttam dūtassa puna paṭipatham āgantvā bhattam gaṇhatha ati vacana bhayena gāma dvāre
translated: “Standing at the village gate”: because of the fear of the messenger’s words, “Take the meal,” when he returns.

original: aṭṭhatvāvā”ti vuttaṃ. Tattha tattha gantvāti antaravīthiādīsu tattha tattha ṭhitānaṃ

translated: “Going here and there”: going to those who are standing here and there in the streets, etc.🔽“The same method applies even when it is set out at the door of the house for the sake of the monks.”

original: santikaṃ gantvā. Bhikkhūnaṃ atthāya gharadvāre ṭhapetvā diyyamānepi eseva nayo. Nivattathāti
analyzed: santikam gantvā bhikkhūnaṃ atthāya ghara dvāre ṭhapetvā diyyamāne pi esa iva nayaḥ nivattatha ati

analyzed: vutta pade nivattitum vaṭṭati iti nivattatha ati vicchinditvā pacchā bhattam gaṇhatha ati  vutta ttā vaṭṭati sesam ettha uttānam eva gaṇa bhojana tā samaya abhāvaḥ ajjhoharaṇanti
translated: It is allowable to break off the sentence with “Return” and then to say “Take the food” afterwards, because it is necessary to return to the place where the food is. The rest here is clear. Eating in a group, absence of an occasion, eating,🔽

original: imāni panettha tīṇi aṅgāni.
analyzed: imāni pana itthā tīṇi aṅgāni
translated: It is allowable to break off the sentence with “Turn back” and then to say “Take the food” afterwards, because it is allowable to turn back at the words already spoken. The rest here is clear. The three factors in this training rule are eating in a group, the absence of a (formal) occasion, and eating.

original: Gaṇabhojanasikkhāpadavaṇṇanā niṭṭhitā.
analyzed: gaṇa bhojana sikkhāpada vaṇṇanā niṭṭhitā
translated: The commentary on the training rule on eating in a group is finished.

original: 3. Paramparabhojanasikkhāpadavaṇṇanā🔽221. Tatiye kulapaṭipāṭiyā abbocchinnaṃ katvā nirantaraṃ diyyamānattā “bhattapaṭipāṭi
analyzed: parampara bhojana sikkhāpada vaṇṇanā  tatiye kula paṭipāṭiyā abbocchinnam katvā nirantaram bhatta paṭipāṭi
translated: The training rule on eating in turn

original: aṭṭhitā hotī”ti pāḷiyaṃ vuttaṃ, antarā aṭṭhatvā nirantaraṃ pavattāti vuttaṃ hoti.🔽Upacāravasenāti vohāravasena. Na hi so badaramattameva deti, upacāravasena pana evaṃ
analyzed: a ṭṭhitā hoti iti pāḷiyam vuttam antarā a ṭhatvā nirantaram pavattā iti vuttam hoti  upacāra vasena ati vohāra vasena na hi saḥ badara mattam eva deti upacāra vasena pana evam
translated: In the third, it is said in the text, “The turn for food is not interrupted,” because it is given without a break, having been made without interruption by the order of families. What is meant is: it proceeds without interruption, without a break.

analyzed: eso pavārito nāma ati ayam paṭikkhepa pavāraṇā vippakata bhojana tā ādi pañcaṅga sahito  bhojana paṭikkhepaḥ yā iva ha ittha pakāra yuttā vāraṇā ati pavāraṇā paṇītena khādanīyena

original: bhojanassa pavāraṇā yāvadatthapavāraṇā.
analyzed: bhojanassa pavāraṇā yāvadattha pavāraṇā
translated: The invitation of what is enough is the invitation of what is enough for one.🔽The words ‘without saying the words of refusal’ are said in order to show the way of inviting.

original: 237. Ti-kāraṃ avatvā…pe… vattuṃ vaṭṭatīti idaṃ vattabbākāradassanatthaṃ vuttaṃ. “Ti-kāre pana vuttepi akataṃ nāma na hotī”ti tīsupi gaṇṭhipadesu vuttaṃ.🔽238-239. Pavāritoti paṭikkhepito. Yo hi bhuñjanto parivesakena upanītaṃ bhojanaṃ
analyzed: tikāram a vatvā āpe vattum vaṭṭati iti idam vattabba ākāra dassana attham vuttam tikāre pana vutte pi akatam nāma na hoti iti tīsu pi gaṇṭhi padesu vuttam  pavāritaḥ ti paṭikkhepitaḥ yaḥ hi bhuñjantaḥ parivesakena upanītam bhojanam
translated: The words ‘but if he says the words of refusal, it is not done’ are said in order to show the way of refusing.🔽The words ‘he is invited’ mean he is refused.

original: anicchanto paṭikkhipati, so tena pavārito paṭikkhepito nāma hoti. Byañjanaṃ pana
analyzed: an icchantaḥ paṭikkhipati saḥ tena pavāritaḥ paṭikkhepitaḥ nāma hoti byañjanam pana
translated: For when one who is eating refuses what is brought to him by the server, he is called ‘invited,’ ‘refused.’

original: anādiyitvā atthamattameva dassetuṃ “katapavāraṇo katapaṭikkhepo”ti vuttaṃ. Yasmā
analyzed: an ādiyitvā attha mattam eva dassetum kata pavāraṇaḥ kata paṭikkhepaḥ iti vuttam yasmā
translated: But in order to show the meaning only, without taking the words, it is said: ‘He who has invited, has refused.’

original: “asana”nti imināva padena “bhuttāvī”ti imassa attho vutto, tasmā na tassa kiñci payojanaṃ
analyzed: iminā ava padena bhuttāvī iti imassa attho vutto tasmā na tassa kiñci payojanam
translated: “He has eaten” is the meaning of “he has eaten staple food” by means of the word “has eaten” . Therefore it has no function.

original: visuṃ upalabbhati. Yadi hi upalabbheyya, pavāraṇā chaḷaṅgasamannāgatā āpajjeyyāti
analyzed: visum upalabbhati yadi hi upalabbheyya pavāraṇā chaḍaṅga samannāgatā āpajjeyya ati
translated: If it were to be found, then the invitation ceremony would be undertaken with six factors.

original: manasi katvā pañcasamannāgatattaṃyeva dassetuṃ “vuttampi ceta”ntiādinā pāḷiṃ āharati.
analyzed: manasi katvā pañca samannāgata ttam yeva dassetum vuttam pi cetanti ādinā pāḷim āharati
translated: Bearing in mind that it is undertaken with five factors, he quotes the text beginning with the words “Although it is said” .

original: Keci pana “hatthapāse ṭhito abhiharatī”ti ekameva aṅgaṃ katvā “caturaṅgasamannāgatā🔽pavāraṇā”tipi vadanti.🔽Ambilapāyāsādīsūti ādi-saddena khīrapāyāsādiṃ saṅgaṇhāti. Tattha ambilapāyāsaggahaṇena
analyzed: keci pana hattha pāse ṭhitaḥ abhiharati iti ekam eva aṅgam katvā catur aṅga samannāgatā  vadanti  ambila pāyāsa ādīsu iti ādi saddena khīra pāyāsa ādim saṅgaṇhāti tattha ambila pāyāsa ggahaṇena
translated: But some, taking “standing within arm’s reach he invites” as a single factor, say that the invitation ceremony is undertaken with four factors.🔽“With sour gruel, etc.”: the word “etc.” includes milk-rice, and so on. Herein, by the mention of sour gruel

original: takkādiambilasaṃyuttā ghanayāgu vuttā. Khīrapāyāsaggahaṇena khīrasaṃyuttā yāgu saṅgayhati.
analyzed: takka ādi ambila saṃyuttā ghana yāgu vuttā khīra pāyāsa ggahaṇena khīra saṃyuttā yāgu saṅgayhati
translated: thick rice gruel mixed with sour stuff such as tamarind, etc., is included. By the mention of milk-rice, rice gruel mixed with milk is included.

original: Pavāraṇaṃ na janetīti anatirittabhojanāpattinibandhanaṃ paṭikkhepaṃ na sādheti. Katopi
analyzed: pavāraṇam na janeti iti an atiritta bhojana āpatti nibandhanam paṭikkhepam na sādheti kataḥ api
translated: “He does not cause the invitation ceremony to be performed”: he does not make effective the prohibition that is the condition for the offense of eating what has not been formally received.

original: paṭikkhepo anatirittabhojanāpattinibandhano na hotīti akataṭṭhāneyeva tiṭṭhatīti🔽āha “pavāraṇaṃ na janetī”ti. “Yāgu-saddassa pavāraṇajanakayāguyāpi sādhāraṇattā ‘yāguṃ
analyzed: paṭikkhepaḥ anatiritta bhojana āpatti nibandhanaḥ na hoti iti a kata ṭṭhāneyā iva tiṭṭhati iti  āha pavāraṇam na janeti iti yāgu saddassa pavāraṇa janaka yāguyā api sādhāraṇa ttā yāgum
translated: The prohibition is not a condition for the offence of eating what has not been left over. It stands in its own place.🔽He says, “It does not give rise to invitation” because the word “gruel” is also used for the gruel that gives rise to invitation.

original: gaṇhathā’ti vuttepi pavāraṇā hotīti pavāraṇaṃ janetiyevāti vutta”nti tīsupi gaṇṭhipadesu🔽vuttaṃ, taṃ parato tattheva “bhattamissakaṃ yāguṃ āharitvā”ti ettha vuttakāraṇena🔽na sameti. Vuttañhi tattha “heṭṭhā ayāguke nimantane udakakañjikakhīrādīhi saddhiṃ
analyzed: gaṇhatha iti vutte api pavāraṇā hoti iti pavāraṇam vuttam tīsu pi gaṇṭhi padesu  vuttam tam paratas tattha eva bhatta missakam yāgum āharitvā iti ettha vutta kāraṇena  na sameti vuttam hi tattha heṭṭhā a yāguke nimantane udaka kañjika khīra ādīhi saddhim
translated: It is said in the three Commentaries that “when ‘Take gruel’ is said, invitation arises because it is used in common for the gruel that gives rise to invitation.🔽But what is said there does not agree with the reason given here in the text, namely, “having brought the gruel mixed with rice.”

original: madditaṃ bhattameva sandhāya ‘yāguṃ gaṇhathā’ti vuttattā pavāraṇā hoti, ‘bhattamissakaṃ
analyzed: madditam bhattam eva sandhāya yāgum gaṇhatha ati vutta ttā pavāraṇā hoti bhatta missakam
translated: For it is said there: “When the invitation is not for gruel, then because it is rice that is meant when ‘Take gruel’ is said, the invitation arises, mixed with rice.

original: yāguṃ āharitvā’ti ettha pana visuṃ yāguyā vijjamānattā pavāraṇā na hotī”ti. Tasmā
analyzed: yāgum āharitvā ati ettha pana visum pavāraṇā na hoti iti tasmā
translated: But here, because there is a separate gruel, the invitation does not arise.”

original: tattha vuttanayeneva khīrādīhi saṃmadditaṃ bhattameva sandhāya “yāguṃ gaṇhathā”ti
analyzed: tattha vutta nayena iva khīra ādīhi saṃmadditam bhattam eva sandhāya yāgum gaṇhatha ati
translated: Therefore, in accordance with the method stated there, it is rice that is meant when ‘Take gruel’ is said, mixed with milk, etc.

original: vuttattā yāguyā ca tattha abhāvato pavāraṇā hotīti evamettha kāraṇaṃ vattabbaṃ. Evañhi🔽sati parato “yenāpucchito, tassa atthitāyā”ti aṭṭhakathāyaṃ vuttakāraṇenapi saṃsandati,
analyzed: vutta ttā yāguyā ca tattha abhāvataḥ pavāraṇā hoti iti evam ettha kāraṇam vattabbam evam hi  sati paratas yena āpucchito tassa atthi tāya ati aṭṭhakathā ayam vutta kāraṇena api saṃsandati
translated: and because it is stated, and because there is no conjey there, the Invitation should be performed. This is how the reason should be stated here.🔽For in that case it is in agreement with the reason stated in the Commentary: “Because of the presence of one who has been asked.”🔽Otherwise there would be contradiction between the earlier and later passages in the Thread,

original: aññathā gaṇṭhipadesuyeva pubbāparavirodho āpajjati. Aṭṭhakathāvacanena ca na sameti.
analyzed: aññathā gaṇṭhi padesu yeva pubba apara virodho āpajjati aṭṭhakathā vacanena ca na sameti
translated: and it would not agree with the Commentary passage.

original: Sace…pe… paññāyatīti iminā vuttappamāṇassa macchamaṃsakhaṇḍassa nahāruno vā sabbhāvamattaṃ
analyzed: sa cepe paññāyati iti iminā vutta ppamāṇassa maccha maṃsa khaṇḍassa nahārunaḥ vā sabbhāva mattam
translated: If … is found: this shows the mere nature of a piece of fish meat of the size stated by “a finger’s breadth long” or “a finger’s breadth round.”

original: dasseti. Tāhīti puthukāhi.
analyzed: dassa iti tāhi iti puthukāhi
translated: By that: by the separate pieces.

original: Sālivīhiyavehi katasattūti yebhuyyanayena vuttaṃ, satta dhaññāni pana bhajjitvā katopi
analyzed: sāli vīhi yavehi kata sattu uti yebhuyya nayena vuttam satta dhaññāni pana bhajjitvā kataḥ api

analyzed: tena iva āha kaṅgu vara kape sattu saṅgaham eva gacchati iti
translated: That is why it is said, “The flour of the sesamum plant … is reckoned as the seventh kind of flour” . Flour-cake is

original: sattuyo piṇḍetvā kato apakko sattuguḷo. Pañcannaṃ bhojanānaṃ aññataravasena vippakatabhojanabhāvassa
analyzed: sattuyo piṇḍetvā kataḥ apakkaḥ sattu guḷo pañcannam bhojanānam aññatara vasena vippakata bhojana bhāvassa
translated: a flour-ball made by kneading flour and then baking it. As to being a prepared food by being one of the five kinds of foods,

original: upacchinnattā “mukhe sāsapamattampi…pe… na pavāretī”ti vuttaṃ. “Akappiyamaṃsaṃ paṭikkhipati,🔽na pavāretī”ti vacanato sace saṅghikaṃ lābhaṃ attano apāpuṇantaṃ jānitvā vā ajānitvā
analyzed: upacchinna ttā mukhe na pavāreti iti vuttam akappiya maṃsam paṭikkhipati  na pavāreti iti vacanataḥ sace saṅghikam lābham apāpuṇantam jānitvā vā a jānitvā
translated: “Because it is cut off” is said. “He does not invite when he has refused what is not allowable,🔽because of the words, ‘He does not invite when he has refused.’ If, knowing or not knowing that a gain belongs to the Community, he refuses it, he does not invite, because what should be refused has been refused.

original: vā paṭikkhipati, na pavāreti paṭikkhipitabbasseva paṭikkhittattā. Alajjisantakaṃ
analyzed: vā paṭikkhipati na pavāreti paṭikkhipitabbassa iva paṭikkhitta ttā alajji santakam
translated: But if he refuses what is reprehensible, he does not invite.

original: paṭikkhipantopi na pavāreti. Avatthutāyāti anatirittāpattisādhikāya pavāraṇāya avatthubhāvato.
analyzed: paṭikkhipantaḥ api na pavāreti avatthu tāya ati anatiritta āpatti sādhikāya pavāraṇāya avatthu bhāvato
translated: Because of the absence of a basis: because there is no basis for a resolution of the invitation that would make him guilty of an offense.

original: Etena paṭikkhipitabbasseva paṭikkhittabhāvaṃ dīpeti. Yañhi paṭikkhipitabbaṃ hoti,
analyzed: etena paṭikkhipitabbassa iva paṭikkhitta bhāvam dīpeti yat hi paṭikkhipitabbam hoti
translated: This shows that what should be refused has been refused. For what should be refused

original: tassa paṭikkhepo āpattiaṅgaṃ na hotīti taṃ “pavāraṇāya avatthū”ti vuccati.
analyzed: tassa paṭikkhepaḥ āpatti aṅgam na hoti iti tam pavāraṇāya avatthu iti vuccati
translated: is said to be ‘no basis for the invitation’ because the refusal of it is not a condition for an offense.

original: Upanāmetīti iminā kāyābhihāraṃ dasseti. Hatthapāsato bahi ṭhitassa satipi dātukāmābhihāre
analyzed: upanāmeti iti iminā kāya abhihāram dasseti hattha pāsataḥ bahi ṭhitassa sati pi dātu kāma abhihāre
translated: ‘He offers’ shows a bodily indication. Even though one who stands outside the range of a hand has a desire to give and makes an indication of it,

original: paṭikkhipantassa dūrabhāveneva pavāraṇāya abhāvato therassapi dūrabhāvamattaṃ gahetvā
analyzed: paṭikkhipantassa dūra bhāvena iva pavāraṇāya abhāvataḥ therassa api dūra bhāva mattam gahetvā
translated: because of his distance he does not invite. The elder, taking account only of the distance,

original: pavāraṇāya abhāvaṃ dassento “therassa dūrabhāvato”ti āha, na pana therassa abhihārasabbhāvato.
analyzed: pavāraṇāya abhāvam dassentaḥ therassa dūra bhāvato ti āha na pana therassa abhihāra sabbhāvato
translated: He says that the absence of invitation is due to the absence of the elder, not due to the absence of the elder’s consent.

original: Sacepi gahetvā gato hatthapāse ṭhito hoti, kiñci pana avatvā ādhārakaṭṭhāne ṭhitattā
analyzed: sace pi gahetvā gataḥ hattha pāse ṭhitaḥ hoti kiñci pana avatvā ādhāraka ṭṭhāne ṭhita ttā
translated: Even if he has taken it and is standing within arm’s reach, but without saying anything, he is standing in the place of the one who is to receive it,

original: abhihāro nāma na hotīti “dūtassa ca anabhiharaṇato”ti vuttaṃ. “Gahetvā gatena ‘bhattaṃ
analyzed: abhihāraḥ nāma na hoti iti dūtassa ca an abhiharaṇato ti vuttam gahetvā gatena bhattam
translated: and so it is said that “there is no consent because the messenger has not conveyed it.”🔽If he says, “Take the food,” then it is said that there is consent.

original: gaṇhathā’ti vutte abhihāro nāma hotīti ‘sace pana gahetvā āgato bhikkhu…pe… pavāraṇā🔽hotī’ti vutta”nti tīsupi gaṇṭhipadesu vuttaṃ. Keci pana “pattaṃ kiñci upanāmetvā
analyzed: gaṇhatha iti vutte abhihāraḥ nāma hoti iti sace pana gahetvā āgataḥ bhikkhupe pavāraṇā  hoti iti vuttanti tīsu pi gaṇṭhi padesu vuttam keci pana pattam kiñci upanāmetvā
translated: If the monk who has taken it … then there is consent.🔽But some say that it should be taken if he has brought the bowl and said, “Take this food.”

original: ‘imaṃ bhattaṃ gaṇhathā’ti vuttanti gahetabba”nti vadanti, taṃ yuttaṃ viya dissati
analyzed: imam bhattam gaṇhatha ati vuttam ti gahetabbanti vadanti tam yuttam viya dissati
translated: This seems appropriate,

original: vācābhihārassa idha anadhippetattā.
analyzed: vācābhihārassa idha an adhippeta ttā
translated: because the conveying by speech is not intended here.

original: Parivesanāyāti bhattagge. Abhihaṭāva hotīti parivesakeneva abhihaṭā hoti. Tato dātukāmatāya
analyzed: parivesanāya ati bhattagge abhihaṭā ava hoti iti parivesakena iva abhihaṭā hoti tatas dātu kāma tāya
translated: “At the serving” means in the refectory. “It is as if conveyed” means it is as if conveyed by the server.

original: gaṇhantaṃ paṭikkhipantassa pavāraṇā hotīti ettha agaṇhantampi paṭikkhipato pavāraṇā
analyzed: gaṇhantam paṭikkhipantassa pavāraṇā hoti iti ettha a gaṇhantam pi paṭikkhipataḥ pavāraṇā
translated: If he refuses to accept it, his invitation is canceled.

original: hotiyeva. Kasmā? Dātukāmatāya abhihaṭattā. “Tasmā sā abhihaṭāva hotī”ti hi vuttaṃ.
analyzed: hotiyā iva kasmā dātu kāma tāya abhihaṭattā tasmā sā abhihaṭā ava hoti iti hi vuttam
translated: If he refuses to accept it, his invitation is canceled even if he does not accept it. Why is that? Because he has already made an offer to give. For this is said: ‘Therefore it is an offer.’

original: Teneva tīsupi gaṇṭhipadesu “dātukāmābhihāre sati kevalaṃ ‘dassāmī’ti gahaṇameva abhihāro
analyzed: tena iva gaṇṭhi padesu dātu kāma abhihāre sati kevalam dassāmi iti gahaṇam eva abhihāraḥ
translated: And that is why it is said in the three summaries that when there is an offer to give, it is not just the mere acceptance with the words ‘I will give’ that is called an offer.

original: nāma na hoti, ‘dassāmī’ti gaṇhantepi agaṇhantepi dātukāmābhihārova abhihāro nāma
analyzed: nāma na hoti dassāmi iti gaṇhante api a gaṇhante api dātu kāma abhihāraḥ uva abhihāraḥ nāma
translated: When there is an offer to give, it is called an offer even if he does not accept with the words ‘I will give.’

original: hoti, tasmā gahaṇasamaye vā aggahaṇasamaye vā taṃ paṭikkhipato pavāraṇā hotī”ti vuttaṃ.
analyzed: hoti tasmā gahaṇa samaye vā aggahaṇa samaye vā tam paṭikkhipato pavāraṇā hoti iti vuttam
translated: Therefore, whether he refuses at the time of acceptance or at the time of non-acceptance, his invitation is canceled.’

original: Idāni asati tassa dātukāmābhihāre gahaṇasamayepi paṭikkhipato pavāraṇā na hotīti
analyzed: idāni asati tassa dātu kāma abhihāre gahaṇa samaye pi paṭikkhipato pavāraṇā na hoti iti
translated: Now, in order to show that if there is no offer to give, his invitation is not canceled even if he refuses at the time of acceptance,

original: dassetuṃ “sace panā”tiādi vuttaṃ.
analyzed: dassetum sace pana itiādi vuttam
translated: the following is said:

original: “Rasaṃ gaṇhathā”ti apavāraṇajanakassa nāmaṃ gahetvā vuttattā “taṃ sutvā paṭikkhipato
analyzed: rasam gaṇhatha ati apavāraṇa janakassa nāmam gahetvā vutta ttā tam sutvā paṭikkhipataḥ
translated: If he says, ‘Take the flavor,’ and he refuses after hearing it, his invitation is canceled.

original: pavāraṇā natthī”ti vuttaṃ. Maccharasaṃ maṃsarasanti ettha pana na kevalaṃ macchassa
analyzed: pavāraṇā natthi iti vuttam maccharasam maṃsa rasanti ettha pana na kevalam macchassa

original: rasaṃ maccharasamicceva viññāyati, atha kho maccho ca maccharasañca maccharasanti
analyzed: rasam maccha rasam iti ca iva viññāyati atha kho macchaḥ ca maccha rasam ca maccha rasanti
translated: For it is understood in this way too: “Fish and fish-essence are fish-essence; meat and meat-essence are meat-essence.”

original: evaṃ pavāraṇajanakasādhāraṇanāmavasenapi viññāyamānattā taṃ paṭikkhipato pavāraṇāva
analyzed: evam pavāraṇa janaka sādhāraṇa nāma vasena api viññāyamāna ttā tam paṭikkhipato
translated: So when he refuses, it is an invitation.

original: hoti. Parato macchasūpanti etthāpi eseva nayo. “Idaṃ gaṇhathā”ti vuttepīti ettha
analyzed: hoti paratas ettha api esa iva nayaḥ idam gaṇhatha ati vutte pi iti ettha
translated: In the case of “fish-soup” and “from another,” the same explanation applies.

original: evaṃ avatvāpi pavāraṇapahonakaṃ yaṃkiñci abhihaṭaṃ paṭikkhipato pavāraṇā hotiyevāti
analyzed: evam a vatvā api pavāraṇa pahonakam yaṃkiñci abhihaṭam paṭikkhipato pavāraṇā hotiyā iva ati
translated: In the case of “take this,” it should be regarded as an invitation even when he refuses what has been brought and offered to him without specifying it thus, “Take this.”🔽“Mixed” is a term for a mixture.

original: daṭṭhabbaṃ. Karambakoti missakādhivacanametaṃ. Yañhi aññenaññena missetvā karonti,
analyzed: daṭṭhabbam karambakā iti missaka adhivacanam etam yat hi aññena aññena missetvā karonti

analyzed: so karambakaḥ ti vuccati saḥ sace pi maṃsena missetvā kataḥ uva hoti karambakam gaṇhatha ati

analyzed: apavāraṇā rahassa nāmena vutta ttā paṭikkhipato pavāraṇā na hoti maṃsa karambakam
translated: it is not an invitation when he refuses, since what is fit to be invited to is stated by name.🔽“Meat-mixed”

translated: “In the invitation to drink a beverage that is not a beverage,

original: udakakañjikakhīrādīhi saddhiṃ madditaṃ bhattameva sandhāya ‘yāguṃ gaṇhathā’ti vuttattā🔽pavāraṇā hoti, ‘bhattamissakaṃ yāguṃ āharitvā’ti ettha pana visuṃ yāguyā vijjamānattā🔽pavāraṇā na hotī”ti vadanti. Ayamettha adhippāyoti “yenāpucchito”tiādinā vuttamevatthaṃ
analyzed: udaka kañjika khīra ādīhi saddhim madditam bhattam eva sandhāya yāgum gaṇhatha iti vutta ttā  pavāraṇā hoti bhatta missakam yāgum āharitvā iti ettha pana visum yāguyā vijjamāna ttā  pavāraṇā na hoti iti vadanti ayam ettha adhippāyaḥ ti yena apucchito tiādinā vuttam eva attham
translated: it is said that it is a case of invitation because he says, ‘Take a beverage,’ referring to rice that has been mixed with water, sour gruel, milk, etc.,🔽but that it is not a case of invitation in the words ‘Bring a beverage mixed with rice,’ because there is a separate beverage that exists.🔽” This is the intention here: he says this referring to the meaning stated in the words “When he is asked with what he will be invited,” etc.

original: sandhāya vadati. Kāraṇaṃ panettha duddasanti ettha eke tāva vadanti “yasmā yāgumissakaṃ
analyzed: sandhāya vadati kāraṇam pana ittha duddasanti ettha eke tāva vadanti yasmai yāgumissakam
translated: But here the reason is hard to see. Herein, some say this: “Since what is mixed with a beverage is not just rice, but is also milk, etc.,

original: nāma bhattameva na hoti, khīrādikampi hotiyeva, tasmā karambake viya pavāraṇāya na
analyzed: nāma bhattam eva na hoti khīra ādikam pi tasmā karambake viya pavāraṇāya na
translated: therefore, as in the case of the karambha fruit, it is not a case of invitation.

original: bhavitabbaṃ. Evañca sati yāgu bahutarā vā hoti samasamā vā, na pavāreti. ‘Yāgu mandā,
analyzed: bhavitabbam evañca sati yāgu bahutarā vā hoti samasamā vā na yāgu mandā
translated: and in that case, if the rice gruel is more or less the same as the meal, he should not invite.🔽But if the rice gruel is less and the meal more, then he should invite. The reason is hard to see here.”

original: bhattaṃ bahutaraṃ, pavāretī’ti ettha kāraṇaṃ duddasa”nti. Keci pana vadanti “yāgumissakaṃ🔽nāma bhattaṃ, tasmā taṃ paṭikkhipato pavāraṇāya eva bhavitabbaṃ. Evañca sati ‘idha
analyzed: bhattam bahutaram pavāreti iti ettha kāraṇam duddasanti keci pana vadanti yāgu missakam  nāma bhattam tasmā tam paṭikkhipato pavāraṇāya eva bhavitabbam evam ca sati idha
translated: But some say that the meal is mixed with rice gruel,

original: pavāraṇā hoti na hotī’ti ettha kāraṇaṃ duddasa”nti.
analyzed: pavāraṇā hoti na hoti iti ettha kāraṇam duddasanti
translated: and so when he refuses that, there must be invitation. And in that case, the reason is hard to see here for saying that “here there is invitation, here there is not.”

original: Yathā cettha kāraṇaṃ duddasaṃ, evaṃ parato “missakaṃ gaṇhathā”ti etthāpi kāraṇaṃ
analyzed: yathā ca ittha kāraṇam duddasam evam paratas missakam gaṇhatha ati ettha api kāraṇam
translated: But just as the reason is hard to see here, so too it should be understood that the reason is hard to see in the following passage: “Take the mixed food.”

original: duddasamevāti veditabbaṃ. Na hi pavāraṇappahonakassa appabahubhāvo pavāraṇāya bhāvābhāvanimittaṃ,🔽kiñcarahi pavāraṇajanakassa nāmaggahaṇamevettha pamāṇaṃ, tasmā “idañca karambakena
analyzed: duddasam eva ati veditabbam na hi pavāraṇa ppahonakassa appa bahu bhāvaḥ pavāraṇāya bhāva abhāva nimittam  kiñcarahi pavāraṇa janakassa nāma ggahaṇam eva itthā pamāṇam tasmai idam ca karambakena
translated: For the fact that there is little or much of what is sufficient for invitation is not the reason for the presence or absence of invitation.

original: na samānetabba”ntiādinā yampi kāraṇaṃ vuttaṃ, tampi pubbe vuttena saṃsandiyamānaṃ
analyzed: na samānetabba nti ādinā yam pi kāraṇam vuttam tam pi pubbe vuttena saṃsandiyamānam
translated: What is the reason then? The mere naming of what causes invitation is the measure here. Therefore the reason given thus: “And this should not be taken as equal to the karambaka fruit,” and so on,🔽is open to doubt in the light of what has been said above.

original: na sameti. Yadi hi “missaka”nti bhattamissakeyeva ruḷhaṃ siyā, evaṃ sati yathā “bhattamissakaṃ
analyzed: na sameti yadi hi missakam ti bhatta missakā iya iva ruḷham siyā evam sati yathā bhatta missakam
translated: It does not agree. For if the rice were growing only in the mixture of rice and weeds, then just as the rice is called “mixed with weeds,”

original: gaṇhathā”ti vutte bhattaṃ bahutaraṃ vā samaṃ vā appataraṃ vā hoti, pavāretiyeva,🔽evaṃ “missakaṃ gaṇhathā”ti vuttepi appatarepi bhatte pavāraṇāya bhavitabbaṃ missakanti
analyzed: gaṇhatha iti vutte bhattam bahutaram vā samam vā appataram vā hoti  evam missakam gaṇhatha ati vutte pi appatare pi bhatte pavāraṇāya bhavitabbam missakanti
translated: If it were only the rice that was mixed with the curry, then just as when the instruction is given, “Take the rice mixed with curry,” the rice may be more, or the same, or less, and the invitation is still valid,🔽so too it would be valid if the rice were less than the curry.

original: bhattamissakeyeva ruḷhattā. Tathā hi “missakanti bhattamissakeyeva ruḷhavohārattā
analyzed: bhatta missakā iyā iva ruḷha ttā tathā hi missakanti bhatta missakā iyā iva ruḷha vohāra ttā
translated: For in that case the meaning of “mixed” would be that the rice was mixed with the curry.

original: idaṃ pana ‘bhattamissakamevā’ti vutta”nti tīsupi gaṇṭhipadesu vuttaṃ. Atha “missaka”nti
analyzed: idam pana bhatta missakam eva ati vuttanti tīsu pi gaṇṭhi padesu vuttam atha missakam
translated: And this is said in the three passages beginning, “Because the rice is mixed with the curry.”

original: bhattamissake ruḷhaṃ na hoti, missakabhattaṃ pana sandhāya “missakaṃ gaṇhathā”ti🔽vuttanti. Evampi yathā ayāguke nimantane khīrādīhi saddhiṃ madditaṃ bhattameva sandhāya
analyzed: bhatta missake ruḷham na hoti missaka bhattam pana sandhāya missakam gaṇhatha ati  vuttam ti evam pi yathā a yāguke nimantane khīra ādīhi saddhim madditam bhattam eva sandhāya
translated: But if it is not the rice that is mixed with the curry, then the meaning of “mixed” is that the curry is mixed with the rice.🔽And in that case the invitation would be valid if the curry were less than the rice,

original: “yāguṃ gaṇhathā”ti vutte pavāraṇā hoti, evamidhāpi missakabhattameva sandhāya “missakaṃ
analyzed: yāgum gaṇhatha iti vutte pavāraṇā hoti evam idha api missaka bhattam eva sandhāya missakam
translated: just as when the instruction is given, “Take the rice-gruel,” the invitation is valid if the rice-gruel is mixed with milk, etc., and the rice is not mentioned.

original: gaṇhathā”ti vutte bhattaṃ appaṃ vā hotu bahu vā, pavāraṇā eva siyā. Tasmā “missaka”nti
analyzed: gaṇhatha iti vutte bhattam appam vā hotu bahu vā pavāraṇā eva siyā tasmā missakam ti
translated: So it is said with reference to the mixture.

original: bhattamissake ruḷhaṃ vā hotu sandhāyabhāsitaṃ vā, ubhayatthāpi pubbenāparaṃ na sametīti
analyzed: bhatta missake ruḷham vā hotu sandhāya bhāsitam vā ubhayattha api pubbena aparam na sameti iti
translated: Or it is said with reference to what is placed on the rice or what is mixed with it. In both cases the latter does not agree with the former.

original: kimettha kāraṇacintāya, īdisesu pana ṭhānesu aṭṭhakathāpamāṇeneva gantabbanti ayaṃ amhākaṃ khanti.
analyzed: kim ettha kāraṇa cintāya īdisesu pana ṭhānesu aṭṭhakathā pamāṇena iva gantabbanti ayam amhākam khanti
translated: So what is the use of thinking about the reason here? But in such cases one should go by the evidence of the commentaries. This is our opinion.

original: “Visuṃ katvā detīti bhattassa upari ṭhitaṃ rasādiṃ visuṃ gahetvā detī”ti tīsupi gaṇṭhipadesu🔽vuttaṃ. Kenaci pana “yathā bhattasitthaṃ na patati, tathā gāḷhaṃ hatthena pīḷetvā🔽parissāvetvā detī”ti vuttaṃ. Tathāpi kāraṇaṃ na dissati. Yathā hi bhattamissakaṃ
analyzed: visum katvā deti iti bhattassa upari ṭhitam rasa ādim visum gahetvā deti iti tīsu pi gaṇṭhi padesu  vuttam kenacid pana yathā bhatta sittham na patati tathā gāḷham hatthena pīḷetvā  parissāvetvā deti iti vuttam tathā api kāraṇam na dissati yathā hi bhattamissakam
translated: “He gives after separating it”: he gives after taking out the relish, etc., that is on top of the rice, so it is said in all three Niddesa passages.🔽But someone says: “He presses it down with his hand so that it is firm and then he gives it after warming it up.”

original: yāguṃ āharitvā “yāguṃ gaṇhathā”ti vatvā yāgumissakaṃ bhattampi dentaṃ paṭikkhipato
analyzed: yāgum āharitvā yāgum gaṇhatha ati vatvā yāgu missakam bhattam pi dentam paṭikkhipato
translated: But even so, no reason is seen. For just as when they bring rice gruel with a mixture of rice and say, “Take rice gruel,” and they give rice mixed with rice gruel, and one refuses it,

original: pavāraṇā na hoti, evamidhāpi bahukhīrarasādīsu bhattesu “khīraṃ gaṇhathā”tiādīni
analyzed: pavāraṇā na hoti evam idha api bahu khīra rasa ādīsu bhattesu khīram gaṇhatha ati ādīni
translated: it is not a choice, so too here, when they bring rice with much milk and say, “Take milk,” and they give rice mixed with milk,

original: vatvā khīrādīni vā detu khīrādimissakabhattaṃ vā, ubhayathāpi pavāraṇāya na bhavitabbaṃ,🔽tasmā “visuṃ katvā detī”ti tenākārena dentaṃ sandhāya vuttaṃ, na pana bhattamissakaṃ🔽katvā diyyamānaṃ paṭikkhipato pavāraṇā hotīti dassanatthanti gahetabbaṃ. Yadi pana🔽bhattamissakaṃ katvā diyyamāne pavāraṇā hotīti adhippāyena aṭṭhakathāyaṃ “visuṃ katvā
analyzed: vatvā khīra ādīni vā detu khīra ādi missaka bhattam vā ubhayathā api pavāraṇāya na bhavitabbam  tasmā visum katvā deti iti tena ākārena dentam sandhāya vuttam na pana bhatta missakam  katvā diyyamānam paṭikkhipato pavāraṇā hoti iti dassana attham ti gahetabbam yadi pana  bhatta missakam katvā diyyamāne pavāraṇā hoti iti adhippāyena aṭṭhakathāyam visum katvā
translated: and let him give milk, etc., or let him give rice with milk, etc., mixed with it. In both cases there is no invitation.🔽So it should be understood that what is said in the Vibhanga is said with reference to giving in that way, not with reference to giving mixed with rice.

original: detī”ti vuttaṃ, evaṃ sati aṭṭhakathāyevettha pamāṇanti gahetabbaṃ, na pana kāraṇantaraṃ gavesitabbaṃ.🔽Sace ukkuṭikaṃ nisinno pāde amuñcitvāpi bhūmiyaṃ nisīdati, iriyāpathaṃ vikopento
analyzed: deti iti vuttam evam sati aṭṭhakathāya iva ittha pamāṇam ti gahetabbam na pana kāraṇa antaram gavesitabbam  sace ukkuṭikam nisinnaḥ pāde a muñcitvā api bhūmiyam nisīdati iriyāpatham vikopento
translated: But if it is intended that there is an invitation when it is given mixed with rice, then the Vibhanga itself should be accepted as the standard, and no other reason need be sought.🔽But if he sits down on the ground without letting go of his feet while he is sitting squatting, then he is said to be “disturbing his posture.”🔽So he should sit down comfortably without disturbing his squatting position.

original: nāma hotīti ukkuṭikāsanaṃ avikopetvāva sukhena nisīdituṃ “tassa pana heṭṭhā…pe… nisīdanakaṃ
analyzed: nāma hoti iti ukkuṭikāsanam a vikopetvā ava sukhena nisīditum tassa pana heṭṭhāpe nisīdanakam
translated: “But if he sits down on a seat spread out below him …

original: dātabba”nti vuttaṃ. “Āsanaṃ acāletvāti pīṭhe phuṭṭhokāsato ānisadamaṃsaṃ amocetvā,🔽anuṭṭhahitvāti vuttaṃ hoti, adinnādāne viya ṭhānācāvanaṃ na gahetabba”nti tīsupi
analyzed: dātabbanti vuttam āsanam a cāletvā iti pīṭhe phuṭṭha ukāsataḥ ānisada maṃsam a mocetvā  anuṭṭhahitvā iti vuttam hoti adinnādāne viya ṭhāna ācāvanam na gahetabbanti tīsu pi
translated: “It should be given” is said. “Without moving the seat”: without moving the flesh of the buttocks from the place touched by the seat,

original: gaṇṭhipadesu vuttaṃ.🔽Akappiyakatanti ettha akappiyakatasseva anatirittabhāvato kappiyaṃ akārāpetvā tasmiṃ🔽patte pakkhittamūlaphalādiyeva atirittaṃ na hoti, sesaṃ pana pattapariyāpannaṃ atirittameva
analyzed: gaṇṭhi padesu vuttam  akappiya katanti ettha akappiya katassa iva an atiritta bhāvataḥ kappiyam a kārāpetvā tasmin  patte atirittam na hoti sesam pana patta pariyāpannam atirittam eva
translated: without rising up, is what is meant. As in the case of theft, the moving from the place is not to be taken. This is said in all three Threads.🔽“What is not allowable”: because what is not allowable is not to be stored, the roots and fruits placed in that bowl are not stored,

original: hoti, paribhuñjituṃ vaṭṭati. Taṃ pana mūlaphalādiṃ paribhuñjitukāmena tato nīharitvā
analyzed: paribhuñjitum vaṭṭati tam pana mūla phala ādim paribhuñjitu kāmena tatas nīharitvā
translated: but the rest that is included in the bowl is stored and is allowable to consume. But if he wants to consume that root and so on, he should take it out of that bowl

original: kappiyaṃ kārāpetvā aññasmiṃ bhājane ṭhapetvā atirittaṃ kārāpetvā bhuñjitabbaṃ.🔽So puna kātuṃ na labhatīti tasmiṃyeva bhājane kariyamānaṃ paṭhamaṃ katena saddhiṃ
analyzed: kappiyam kārāpetvā aññasmim bhājane ṭhapetvā atirittam kārāpetvā bhuñjitabbam  saḥ puna kātum na labhati iti tasmin yā iva bhājane kariyamānam paṭhamam katena saddhim
translated: and have it made allowable in another vessel, and then he should store the remainder and eat it.🔽He is not allowed to make it again: if it is made in that same vessel, it is made together with what was made first,

original: kataṃ hotīti puna soyeva kātuṃ na labhati, añño labhati. Aññasmiṃ pana bhājane tena
analyzed: katam hoti iti puna saḥ yā iva kātum na labhati aññaḥ labhati aññasmin pana bhājane tena
translated: and so he is not allowed to make it again, but another is allowed to. But if it is made in another vessel,

original: vā aññena vā kātuṃ vaṭṭati. Tenāha “yena akataṃ, tena kātabbaṃ. Yañca akataṃ, taṃ
analyzed: vā aññena vā kātum vaṭṭati tena āha yena a katam tena kātabbam yat ca a katam tam
translated: or by another. Hence it was said: “What has not been made should be made. What has not been done should be done.”

original: kātabba”nti. Tenapīti ettha pi-saddo na kevalaṃ aññena vāti imamatthaṃ dīpeti. Evaṃ
analyzed: kātabbanti tena api iti ettha pi saddaḥ na kevalam aññena vā ti imam attham dīpeti evam
translated: By that too: the word too shows that it is not only by another.🔽Thus made: made in another vessel.

original: katanti aññasmiṃ bhājane kataṃ. Pesetvāti anupasampannassa hatthe pesetvā. Imassa
analyzed: katam ti aññasmin bhājane katam pesetvā ti anupasampannassa hatthe pesetvā imassa
translated: Having sent: having sent it into the hand of one not fully admitted.

original: vinayakammabhāvato “anupasampannassa hatthe ṭhitaṃ na kāretabba”nti vuttaṃ.
analyzed: vinaya kamma bhāvataḥ anupasampannassa hatthe ṭhitam na kāretabbanti vuttam
translated: Because it is a legal procedure of the Monastic Law, it is said, “It should not be made in the hand of one not fully admitted.”

original: Sace pana āmisasaṃsaṭṭhānīti ettha sace mukhagatenapi anatirittena āmisena saṃsaṭṭhāni
analyzed: sace pana āmisa saṃsaṭṭhāni iti ettha sace mukha gatena api anatirittena āmisena saṃsaṭṭhāni
translated: But if they are mixed with food: if they are mixed with food that has not been left over but which has come into the mouth,🔽it should be understood that there is an offense entailing confession.

original: honti, pācittiyamevāti veditabbaṃ. Tasmā pavāritena bhojanaṃ atirittaṃ kārāpetvā🔽bhuñjantenapi yathā akatena missaṃ na hoti, evaṃ mukhañca hatthañca suddhaṃ katvā
analyzed: honti pācittiyam eva ati veditabbam tasmai pavāritena bhojanam atirittam kārāpetvā  bhuñjantena api yathā a katena missam na hoti evam mukham ca hatthañca suddham katvā
translated: Therefore, if one who has refused food has food made that is left over,🔽and then eats it, he should wash his mouth and hands well,🔽so that it is not mixed with what has not been made.

original: bhuñjitabbaṃ. Kiñcāpi appavāritassa purebhattaṃ yāmakālikādīni āhāratthāya paribhuñjatopi
analyzed: bhuñjitabbam kiñca api a pavāritassa purebhattam yāma kālikā ādīni āhāra atthāya paribhuñjataḥ api
translated: Even if one who has not refused food eats what is allowable for a half-month, etc., for the purpose of nourishment,

original: anāpatti, pavāritassa pana pavāraṇamūlakaṃ dukkaṭaṃ hotiyevāti “yāmakālikaṃ…pe… ajjhohāre
analyzed: anāpatti pavāritassa pana pavāraṇa mūlakam dukkaṭam hoti yeva ati yāma kālikaṃpe ajjhohāre
translated: There is no offense if he has invited him, but there is an offense of wrong conduct for the one who invites.

original: āpatti dukkaṭassā”ti pāḷiyaṃ vuttaṃ.
analyzed: āpatti dukkaṭassa ati pāḷiyam vuttam
translated: The text says, “If he eats what is left over from one who has invited him, he commits an offense entailing confession. If he eats what is left over from one who has not invited him, he commits an offense of wrong conduct. If he eats what is left over from one who has invited him, but he has not consented to the invitation, he commits an offense of wrong conduct. If he eats what is left over from one who has not invited him, but he has consented to the invitation, he commits an offense of wrong conduct. If he eats what is left over from one who has not invited him, and he has not consented to the invitation, he commits an offense of wrong conduct. If he eats what is left over from one who has invited him, and he has consented to the invitation, there is no offense.”

original: 241. Kāyena bhuñjanato vācāya āṇāpetvā atirittaṃ akārāpanato ca āpajjatīti “kāyavācato”ti🔽vuttaṃ. Sesamettha uttānameva. Pavāritabhāvo, āmisassa anatirittatā, kāle ajjhoharaṇanti
analyzed: kāyena bhuñjanataḥ vācāya atirittam a kārāpanataḥ ca āpajjati iti kāya vācataḥ ti  vuttam sesam ettha uttānam eva pavārita bhāvaḥ āmisassa anatiritta tā kāle ajjhoharaṇan ti
translated: “By body” means by eating, and “by speech” means by having others bring more than the amount consented to.🔽The rest is clear.

original: imāni panettha tīṇi aṅgāni.
analyzed: imāni pana itthā tīṇi aṅgāni
translated: The three requisite conditions for the offense are: being invited; not consenting to the invitation; eating at the wrong time.

original: Paṭhamapavāraṇāsikkhāpadavaṇṇanā niṭṭhitā.
analyzed: paṭhama pavāraṇā sikkhāpada vaṇṇanā niṭṭhitā
translated: The first training rule on invitations is finished.

original: 6. Dutiyapavāraṇāsikkhāpadavaṇṇanā
analyzed: dutiya pavāraṇā sikkhāpada vaṇṇanā
translated: The sixth training rule on invitations

original: 243. Chaṭṭhe sādhāraṇamevāti “handa bhikkhu khāda vā”tiādinā vuttapavāraṇāya sādhāraṇaṃ.🔽“Bhuttasmiṃ pācittiya”nti mātikāyaṃ vuttattā bhojanapariyosāne āpatti, na ajjhohāre
analyzed: chaṭṭhe sādhāraṇam eva ati handa bhikkhu khāda vā ti ādinā vutta pavāraṇāya sādhāraṇam  bhuttasmin pācittiyam ti mātikāyam vutta ttā bhojana pariyosāne āpatti na ajjhohāre
translated: “In common” means in common with the invitation expressed by saying, “Come, monk, eat.”🔽Because it is said in the summary, “The offense entailing confession is for eating after the meal is finished,” the offense is at the end of the meal, not with each mouthful.

original: ajjhohāre. Abhihaṭṭhuṃ pavāreti, āpatti pācittiyassāti idañca bhojanapariyosānaṃyeva
analyzed: ajjhohāre abhihaṭṭhum pavāreti āpatti pācittiyassa ati idam ca bhojana pariyosānam yeva
translated: It is at the end of the meal.

original: sandhāya vuttanti veditabbaṃ. Sesamettha uttānameva. Pavāritatā, pavāritasaññitā,
analyzed: sandhāya vuttam ti veditabbam sesam ettha uttānam eva pavārita tā pavārita saññi tā
translated: should be understood as said with reference to that. The rest here is clear. The five constituents of this training rule are: being invited, the perception of being invited,

original: āsādanāpekkhatā, anatirittena abhihaṭṭhuṃ pavāraṇā, bhojanapariyosānanti imāni panettha pañca aṅgāni.
analyzed: āsādana apekkha tā an atirittena abhihaṭṭhum pavāraṇā bhojana pariyosānan ti imāni pana ittha pañca aṅgāni
translated: expecting to get something, inviting to make use of what has not been set out as an offering, the end of the meal.

original: Dutiyapavāraṇāsikkhāpadavaṇṇanā niṭṭhitā.

translated: The commentary on the second training rule for monks on inviting is finished.

analyzed: vikālabhojana sikkhāpada vaṇṇanā  sattame aggasamajjā iti uttamam naccam tam kira pabbata matthake ṭhatvā ekam devatam

analyzed: uddissa karonti naṭānam nāṭakāni naṭa nāṭakāni sītā haraṇa ādīni a paññatte sikkhāpade ti
translated: aiming at a deity. The actors’ plays: the actors’ plays, such as the abduction of Sita. Before the training rule was laid down:

original: ūnavīsativassasikkhāpade apaññatte. Adaṃsūti “vihāraṃ netvā khādissathā”ti adaṃsu.
analyzed: ūnavīsati vassa sikkhāpade a paññatte adaṃsu iti vihāram netvā khādissatha ati adaṃsu
translated: before the training rule on those under twenty years old. They gave: they gave, saying, “We’ll take it to the monastery and eat it there.”

original: 248-249. Mūlakamūlādīni upadesatoyeva veditabbāni. Na hi tāni pariyāyantarena vuccamānānipi
analyzed: mūlaka mūla ādīni veditabbāni na hi tāni pariyāya antarena vuccamānāni pi
translated: The root, the root-to-be-eaten, and so on, should be understood from the directions. For even if they are mentioned in another section,

original: sakkā viññātuṃ. Pariyāyantarepi hi vuccamāne taṃ taṃ nāmaṃ ajānantānaṃ sammohoyeva
analyzed: sakkā viññātum pariyāyantare pi hi vuccamāne tam tam nāmam a jānantānam
translated: they cannot be known. For even if they are mentioned in another section, those who do not know the names🔽will be confused.

original: siyā, tasmā tattha na kiñci vakkhāma. Khādanīyatthanti khādanīyena kattabbakiccaṃ.🔽Neva pharantīti na nipphādenti. Tesu tesu janapadesūti ettha “ekasmiṃ janapade āhārakiccaṃ🔽sādhentaṃ sesajanapadesupi na kappatī”ti vadanti. Rukkhavalliādīnanti heṭṭhā vuttameva🔽sampiṇḍetvā vuttaṃ. Antopathavīgatoti sālakalyāṇīkhandhaṃ sandhāya vuttaṃ. Sabbakappiyānīti🔽mūlakhandhatacapattādivasena sabbaso kappiyāni. Tesampi nāmavasena na sakkā pariyantaṃ
analyzed: siyā tasmā tattha na kiñci vakkhāma khādanīya tthanti khādanīyena kattabba kiccam  na iva pharanti iti na nipphādenti tesu tesu janapadesu iti ettha ekasmin janapade āhāra kiccam  sādhentam sesa janapadesu pi na kappati iti vadanti rukkha valli ādīnam ti heṭṭhā vuttam eva  sampiṇḍetvā vuttam antar upathavī gataḥ ti sāla kalyāṇī khandham sandhāya vuttam sabba kappiyāni iti  mūla khandha taca patta ādi vasena sabbaso kappiyāni tesam pi nāma vasena na sakkā pariyantam
translated: So we shall say nothing about it here. ‘The work to be done with food’: the work to be done with food.

original: dassetunti sambandho. Acchivādīnaṃ aparipakkāneva phalāni yāvajīvikānīti dassetuṃ🔽“aparipakkānī”ti vuttaṃ.
analyzed: dassetum ti sambandhaḥ acchiva ādīnam a paripakkāna eva phalāni yāvajīvikāni iti dassetum  a paripakkāni iti vuttam
translated: ‘Do not produce’: do not bring about. ‘In this or that country’: here they say that what is suitable for accomplishing the work of food in one country is not suitable in another country. ‘Tree, creeper, etc.’: this is a combination of what was said above. ‘In the earth inside’: this is said with reference to the trunk of the Sālakalyāṇī tree. ‘All are allowable’: they are allowable in every way, by way of root, trunk, bark, leaf, etc. ‘It is not possible to show a limit even by name’: this is the connection. ‘Unripe’ is said in order to show that the fruits of the acchī, etc., are allowable for life-long use only when unripe.

original: Harītakādīnaṃ aṭṭhīnīti ettha miñjaṃ paṭicchādetvā ṭhitakapālāni yāvajīvikānīti ācariyā.
analyzed: harītaka ādīnam aṭṭhīni iti ettha miñjam paṭicchādetvā ṭhita kapālāni yāvajīvikāni iti ācariyā
translated: ‘The bones of harītakī, etc.’: the teachers say that the skulls that are inside, covering the marrow, are allowable for life-long use.

original: Miñjampi yāvajīvikanti eke. Hiṅgūti hiṅgurukkhato paggharitaniyyāso. Hiṅgujatuādayopi
analyzed: miñjam pi yāvajīvikanti eke hiṅgū ti hiṅgu rukkhato paggharita niyyāsaḥ hiṅgu jatu ādayaḥ api
translated: Some say that even the juice of the leaves is allowable for life.🔽Hiṅgu is the juice that exudes from the hiṅgu tree. Hiṅgu-jatū, etc.,

original: hiṅguvikatiyo eva. Tattha hiṅgujatu nāma hiṅgurukkhassa daṇḍapattāni pacitvā kataniyyāso,
analyzed: hiṅgu vikatiyaḥ eva tattha hiṅgujatu nāma hiṅgu rukkhassa daṇḍa pattāni pacitvā kata niyyāsaḥ
translated: are also just hiṅgu. Herein, hiṅgu-jatū is the juice made by boiling the stem and leaves of the hiṅgu tree.🔽Hiṅgu-sipāṭika is the juice made by boiling the leaves of the hiṅgu tree.

original: hiṅgusipāṭikaṃ nāma hiṅgupattāni pacitvā kataniyyāso. “Aññena missetvā kato”tipi
analyzed: hiṅgusipāṭikam nāma hiṅgu pattāni pacitvā kata niyyāsaḥ aññena missetvā
translated: They say that it is also made by mixing with other things.

original: vadanti. Takanti aggakoṭiyā nikkhantasileso. Takapattinti pattato nikkhantasileso.
analyzed: vadanti takam ti agga koṭiyā nikkhanta sileso taka pattim ti pattataḥ nikkhanta sileso
translated: Takā is the juice that comes out at the tip of the stalk. Takapatti is the juice that comes out of the leaf.

original: Takapaṇṇinti palāse bhajjitvā katasileso. “Daṇḍato nikkhantasileso tipi vadanti.
analyzed: palāse bhajjitvā kata silesaḥ daṇḍataḥ nikkhanta silesaḥ tipi vadanti
translated: Takapallaṅka is the juice that comes out of the stalk. They say that it is the juice that comes out of the stalk.

original: Sesamettha uttānameva. Vikālatā, yāvakālikatā, ajjhoharaṇanti imāni panettha tīṇi aṅgāni.
analyzed: sesam ettha uttānam eva vikāla tā yāvakālika tā ajjhoharaṇanti imāni pana ittha tīṇi aṅgāni
translated: The rest here is clear. Herein, the three factors are the wrong time, what is allowable for a limited period, and eating.

original: Vikālabhojanasikkhāpadavaṇṇanā niṭṭhitā.
analyzed: vikālabhojana sikkhāpada vaṇṇanā niṭṭhitā
translated: The training rule on eating at the wrong time is finished.

original: 8. Sannidhikārakasikkhāpadavaṇṇanā
analyzed: sannidhi kāraka sikkhāpada vaṇṇanā
translated: The training rule on storing

original: 252-3. Aṭṭhame tādisanti asūpabyañjanaṃ. Yaṃkiñci yāvakālikaṃ vā yāmakālikaṃ vāti
analyzed: aṭṭhame tādisanti yaṃkiñci yāvakālikam vā yāmakālikam vā ati
translated: In the eighth , “like that” means without rice or bean curry. “Whatever is allowable for a limited period or for one day only” means

original: ettha “yāmakālika”nti iminā na kevalaṃ yāvakālike eva sannidhipaccayā pācittiyaṃ,🔽atha kho yāmakālikepīti dasseti. Nanu ca yāmakālikaṃ neva khādanīyesu antogadhaṃ,🔽na bhojanīyesu. Teneva padabhājanīye “khādanīyaṃ nāma pañca bhojanāni yāmakālikaṃ
analyzed: ettha yāmakālikam ti iminā na kevalam yāvakālike eva sannidhi paccayā pācittiyam  atha kho yāma kālike ipi iti dasseti nanu ca yāma kālikam na iva khādanīyesu antogadham  na bhojanīyesu tena iva pada bhājanīye khādanīyam nāma pañca bhojanāni yāma kālikam
translated: “What is to be eaten within seven days” shows that there is an offense entailing confession not only for what is to be eaten when received,🔽but also for what is to be eaten within seven days. But isn’t what is to be eaten within seven days not included in fresh or cooked food?🔽That is why, in the analysis of the words, it is said, “Fresh food: the five cooked foods, except what is to be eaten within seven days,

original: sattāhakālikaṃ yāvajīvikaṃ ṭhapetvā avasesaṃ khādanīyaṃ nāma. Bhojanīyaṃ nāma pañca🔽bhojanānī”ti vuttaṃ, “yo pana bhikkhu sannidhikārakaṃ khādanīyaṃ vā bhojanīyaṃ vā🔽khādeyya vā bhuñjeyya vā, pācittiya”nti ca vuttaṃ, tasmā yāmakālike pācittiyena bhavitabbanti
analyzed: satta aha kālikam yāvajīvikam ṭhapetvā avasesam khādanīyam nāma bhojanīyam nāma pañca  bhojanāni iti vuttam yaḥ pana bhikkhu sannidhi kārakam khādanīyam vā bhojanīyam vā  khādeyya vā bhuñjeyya vā pācittiyanti ca vuttam tasmā yāmakālike pācittiyena bhavitabbanti
translated: what is to be eaten within one day, and what is to be eaten all one’s life. Cooked food: the five cooked foods.”🔽And it is said, “If a monk eats fresh or cooked food that he has asked for, he commits an offense entailing confession.” So how can it be known that there is an offense entailing confession for what is to be eaten within seven days?

original: kathaṃ viññāyatīti? Vuccate – padabhājane khādanīya-saddassa atthadassanatthaṃ “yāmakālikaṃ
analyzed: katham viññāyati iti vuccate pada bhājane khādanīya saddassa attha dassana attham yāma kālikam
translated: It may be said: “In the analysis of the words, ‘except what is to be eaten within seven days’ is said in order to show the meaning of the word ‘fresh food’,

original: ṭhapetvā”ti vuttaṃ, na pana sannidhipaccayā anāpattidassanatthaṃ. Khāditabbañhi yaṃkiñci
analyzed: ṭhapetvā ti vuttam na pana sannidhi paccayāḥ anāpatti dassana attham khāditabbam hi yaṃ kiñci
translated: not in order to show that there is no offense for what is to be eaten within seven days. For anything at all may be eaten within seven days.

original: khādanīyanti adhippetaṃ, na ca yāmakālikesu kiñci khāditabbaṃ atthi pātabyabhāvato.
analyzed: khādanīyanti adhippetam na ca yāmakālikesu kiñci khāditabbam atthi pātabya bhāvato
translated: and what is intended is what is to be chewed. And there is nothing to be eaten among what is for one day and night.

original: Tasmā kiñcāpi yāmakālikaṃ khādanīyabhojanīyehi na saṅgahitaṃ, tathāpi anāpattiṃ dassentena
analyzed: tasmā kiñca api yāma kālikam khādanīya bhojanīyehi na saṅgahitam tathā api anāpattim dassentena
translated: Therefore, although what is for one day and night is not included among what is to be chewed and what is to be swallowed, nevertheless, in order to show that there is no offence,

original: “anāpatti yāmakālikaṃ yāme nidahitvā bhuñjatī”ti vacanato yāmātikkame sannidhipaccayā
analyzed: anāpatti yāma kālikam yāme nidahitvā bhuñjati iti vacanataḥ yāma atikkame sannidhi paccayā
translated: it is said, “There is no offence if what is for one day and night is eaten after it has been stored for one day and night.” And so it is clear that there is an offence entailing confession when it is allowed to pass beyond the day and night because of storing.

original: pācittiyena bhavitabbanti viññāyati. “Yāmakālikena, bhikkhave, sattāhakālikaṃ yāvajīvikaṃ
analyzed: pācittiyena bhavitabban ti viññāyati yāma kālikena bhikkhave satta aha kālikam yāvajīvikam
translated: And this meaning is established by this statement: “Monks, what is for one day and night may be used for seven days … for life

original: tadahupaṭiggahitaṃ yāme kappati, yāmātikkante na kappatī”ti imināpi cāyamattho siddho.
analyzed: tad ahu paṭiggahitam yāme kappati yāma atikkante na kappati iti iminā api ca ayam attho siddho
translated: if it is received on that day, it is allowable for one day and night; if it is allowed to pass beyond the day and night, it is not allowable.”

original: Teneva bhagavato adhippāyaññūhi aṭṭhakathācariyehi yāmakālike pācittiyameva vuttaṃ.
analyzed: tena iva bhagavataḥ adhippāya ñūhi aṭṭhakathā cariyehi yāmakālike pācittiyam eva vuttam
translated: And so the commentators, who know the Blessed One’s purport, say that there is an offence entailing confession in what is for one day and night.

original: Paṭiggahaṇeti gahaṇameva sandhāya vuttaṃ. Paṭiggahitameva hi taṃ, puna paṭiggahaṇakiccaṃ
analyzed: paṭiggahaṇa iti gahaṇam eva sandhāya vuttam paṭiggahitam eva hi tam puna paṭiggahaṇa kiccam
translated: “Receiving” is said with reference to the act of receiving. For it is only that which has been received that is to be used again after being stored.

original: natthi. Teneva “ajjhoharitukāmatāya gaṇhantassa paṭiggahaṇe”ti vuttaṃ. Mātikāṭṭhakathāyaṃ
analyzed: natthi tena iva ajjhoharitu kāma tāya gaṇhantassa paṭiggahaṇā iti vuttam mātikāṭṭhakathāyam
translated: There is not. That is why it is said, “If he takes it with the wish to eat, there is an offence for the receiving.”🔽But in the Commentary on the Schedule it is said, “If he takes it with the thought ‘I will eat it,’ there is an offence for the receiving.”

original: pana “ajjhoharissāmīti gaṇhantassa paṭiggahaṇe”icceva vuttaṃ. Yanti yaṃ pattaṃ. Sandissatīti
analyzed: pana ajjhoharissāmi iti gaṇhantassa vuttam yanti yam pattam sandissati iti
translated: The bowl: the bowl in which.🔽Appears: appears on top of the rice gruel.

original: yāguyā upari sandissati. Telavaṇṇe patte satipi nisnehabhāve aṅguliyā ghaṃsantassa
analyzed: yāguyā upari sandissati tela vaṇṇe patte nisneha bhāve aṅguliyā
translated: Even though there is a bowl the colour of oil, if it is free from oiliness, a line is still seen there by the colour when it is tapped with a finger.

original: vaṇṇavaseneva lekhā paññāyati, tasmā tattha anāpattīti dassanatthaṃ “sā abbohārikā”ti
analyzed: vaṇṇa vasena iva lekhā paññāyati tasmā tattha anāpatti iti dassana ttham sā abbohārikā ti
translated: That is why it is said, “That is not a receptacle” in order to show that there is no offence there.

original: vuttaṃ. Sayaṃ paṭiggahetvā apariccattameva hi dutiyadivase na vaṭṭatīti ettha paṭiggahaṇe
analyzed: vuttam sayam paṭiggahetvā a pariccattam eva hi dutiya divase na vaṭṭati iti ettha paṭiggahaṇe
translated: For if he himself receives it and does not give it away, it is not allowable on the following day.

original: anapekkhavissajjanena anupasampannassa nirapekkhadānena vā vijahitapaṭiggahaṇaṃ pariccattameva
analyzed: anapekkha vissajjanena anupasampannassa nirapekkha dānena vā vijahita paṭiggahaṇam pariccattam eva
translated: Here, by the giving up of the receiving without regard for it, or by the giving without regard for it to one not fully admitted to the Order, the receiving is given up.

original: hotīti “apariccatta”nti iminā ubhayathāpi avijahitapaṭiggahaṇameva vuttaṃ. Tasmā
analyzed: hoti iti iminā ubhayathā api a vijahita paṭiggahaṇam eva vuttam tasmā
translated: That is why it is said by “not given away” that the receiving is not given up in either case.

original: yaṃ parassa pariccajitvā adinnampi sace paṭiggahaṇe nirapekkhavissajjanena vijahitapaṭiggahaṇaṃ
analyzed: yam parassa pariccajitvā a dinnam pi sace paṭiggahaṇe nirapekkha vissajjanena vijahita paṭiggahaṇam
translated: If, after giving up what belongs to another, he gives it away by relinquishing the act of receiving it without any concern for it,🔽

original: hoti, tampi dutiyadivase vaṭṭatīti veditabbaṃ.🔽Yadi evaṃ “patto duddhoto hotī”tiādīsu kasmā āpatti vuttāti? “Paṭiggahaṇaṃ avissajjetvāva
analyzed: hoti tat pi dutiya divase vaṭṭati iti veditabbam  yadi evam pattaḥ duddhotaḥ hoti itiādīsu kasmai āpatti vuttā ati paṭiggahaṇam a vissajjetvā ava
translated: If it is not given to him by another but he himself gives it up by relinquishing it without any expectation of receiving it in return, then it should be understood that it is allowable on the following day.

original: sayaṃ vā aññena vā tucchaṃ katvā na sammā dhovitvā niṭṭhāpite patte laggampi avijahitapaṭiggahaṇameva
analyzed: sayam vā aññena vā tuccham katvā na sammā dhovitvā niṭṭhāpite patte laggam pi a vijahita paṭiggahaṇam eva
translated: If that is so, why is it said in the case of the bowl that is not washed, etc., that there is an offence? It is said there that “the bowl is not washed properly without relinquishing the bowl and without making it empty either by oneself or by another, and the offence is in the bowl that is finished, even though it is stuck to.”

original: hotīti tattha āpattī”ti tīsupi gaṇṭhipadesu vuttaṃ. Keci pana “sāmaṇerānaṃ pariccajantīti🔽imasmiṃ adhikāre ṭhatvā ‘apariccattamevā’ti vuttattā anupasampannassa pariccattameva
analyzed: hoti iti tattha āpatti iti tīsu pi gaṇṭhi padesu vuttam keci pana sāmaṇerānam pariccajanti iti  imasmin adhikāre ṭhatvā a pariccattam eva ati vutta ttā an upasampannassa pariccattam eva
translated: In the three passages beginning “giving to novices” it is said that “it is not given up.”

original: vaṭṭati, apariccattaṃ na vaṭṭatīti āpannaṃ, tasmā nirālayabhāvena paṭiggahaṇe vijahitepi
analyzed: vaṭṭati a pariccattam na vaṭṭati iti āpannam tasmai nirālaya bhāvena paṭiggahaṇe vijahite api
translated: Therefore it is allowable only if it is not given up to an uninitiated person. It is not allowable if it is given up. So it is allowable to use the bowl of an uninitiated person if it is not given up, though the relinquishing of it is effected by the state of being without a bowl.

original: anupasampannassa apariccattaṃ na vaṭṭatī”ti vadanti, taṃ yuttaṃ viya na dissati.
analyzed: anupasampannassa apariccattam na vaṭṭati iti vadanti tam yuttam viya na dissati
translated: But some say that it is not allowable to use the bowl of an uninitiated person even if it is not given up. This does not seem right.

original: Yadaggena hi paṭiggahaṇaṃ vijahati, tadaggena sannidhimpi na karoti vijahitapaṭiggahaṇassa
analyzed: yad aggena hi paṭiggahaṇam vijahati tad aggena sannidhim pi na karoti vijahita paṭiggahaṇassa
translated: For as soon as the acceptance is abandoned, so too is the storing.🔽Because what has been abandoned is the same as what has not been accepted.

original: appaṭiggahitasadisattā. Paṭiggahetvā nidahiteyeva ca sannidhipaccayā āpatti vuttā.
analyzed: a paṭiggahita sadisa ttā paṭiggahetvā nidahitā iya iva ca sannidhi paccayā āpatti vuttā
translated: And it is said that the offence on the basis of the condition of storing is when the alms food has been accepted and stored.

original: “Paṭiggahetvā ekarattaṃ vītināmitassetaṃ adhivacana”nti hi vuttaṃ.
analyzed: paṭiggahetvā eka rattam vītināmitassa etam adhivacanam iti hi vuttam
translated: “This is a term for what has been accepted and kept overnight” .

original: Pāḷiyaṃ “sattāhakālikaṃ yāvajīvikaṃ āhāratthāya paṭiggaṇhāti, āpatti dukkaṭassā”tiādinā
analyzed: pāḷiyam sattāha kālikam yāvajīvikam āhāra atthāya paṭiggaṇhāti āpatti dukkaṭassa ati ādinā
translated: In the text it is said: “If he accepts for the purpose of nutriment what has been prepared as ready-to-eat food that may be eaten after seven days or that may be eaten all one’s life, he commits an offence of wrong conduct” .

original: sannihitesu sattāhakālikayāvajīvikesu purebhattampi āhāratthāya ajjhoharaṇepi dukkaṭassa🔽vuttattā yāmakālikepi āhāratthāya ajjhoharaṇe visuṃ dukkaṭenapi bhavitabbanti āha
analyzed: sannihitesu satta aha kālika yāvajīvikesu purebhattam pi āhāra atthāya ajjhoharaṇe pi dukkaṭassa  vutta ttā yāma kālike api āhāra atthāya ajjhoharaṇe visum dukkaṭena api bhavitabban ti āha
translated: And because it is said that there is an offence of wrong conduct in eating what has been stored, that is, what has been prepared as ready-to-eat food that may be eaten after seven days or that may be eaten all one’s life, even before the meal,🔽it follows that there should be a separate offence of wrong conduct in eating what has been prepared as ready-to-eat food that may be eaten within one day for the purpose of nutriment.

original: “āhāratthāya ajjhoharato dukkaṭena saddhiṃ pācittiya”nti. Pakatiāmiseti odanādikappiyāmise.
analyzed: āhāra atthāya ajjhoharataḥ dukkaṭena saddhim pācittiyanti pakati āmise iti odana ādikappiya āmise
translated: So he says, “Along with the offence of wrong conduct, there is an offence entailing confession for one who eats it for the purpose of nutriment.”🔽‘Ordinary alms food’ means ordinary food such as rice, etc.

original: Yāmakālikaṃ sati paccaye sāmisena mukhena ajjhoharato dveti hiyyo paṭiggahitayāmakālikaṃ
analyzed: yāma kālikam sati paccaye sāmisena mukhena ajjhoharataḥ dve iti hiyyas paṭiggahita yāma kālikam
