analyzed: avijjā ādayaḥ imesam saṅkhāra ādīnam paccayā ati idappaccayā avijjā ādayaḥ idappaccayā
translated: “These are the conditions for formations, etc.” are the conditions beginning with ignorance.

original: eva idappaccayatā yathā devo eva devatā. Idappaccayānaṃ vā avijjādīnaṃ attano phalaṃ
analyzed: eva idappaccaya tā yathā devaḥ eva devatā idappaccayānam vā avijjā ādīnam attanaḥ phalam
translated: The “specific conditionality” of the states beginning with ignorance is the state of being a condition in the sense of being able to cause the arising of their respective fruits.

original: paṭicca paccayabhāvo uppādanasamatthatā idappaccayatā. Tena samatthapaccayalakkhaṇo
analyzed: paṭicca paccaya bhāvaḥ uppādana samattha tā idappaccaya tā tena samattha paccaya lakkhaṇaḥ
translated: Thus the characteristic of a condition that is able to cause the arising of a state is shown by the words “specific conditionality.”

original: paṭiccasamuppādo dassito hoti. Paṭicca samuppajjati phalaṃ etasmāti paṭiccasamuppādo.🔽Padadvayenapi dhammānaṃ paccayaṭṭho eva vibhāvito. Saṅkhārādipaccayānañhi avijjādīnaṃ
analyzed: paṭiccasamuppādaḥ dassitaḥ hoti paṭicca samuppajjati phalam etasma ati paṭiccasamuppādaḥ  pada dvayena api dhammānam paccaya ṭṭhaḥ eva vibhāvito saṅkhāra ādi paccayānam hi avijjā ādīnam
translated: The “dependent origination” is the state of being a condition in the sense of being able to cause the arising of a fruit.🔽By the two terms “specific conditionality” and “dependent origination” the meaning of the states as conditions is shown.🔽For these are terms for the states beginning with ignorance that are conditions for formations, etc.

original: etaṃ adhivacanaṃ idappaccayatāpaṭiccasamuppādoti. Sabbasaṅkhārasamathotiādi sabbaṃ
analyzed: etam adhivacanam idappaccaya tā paṭiccasamuppādo ti sabba saṅkhāra samathaḥ tiādi sabbam
translated: All the rest of the passage beginning with the words “the stilling of all formations” is all of one meaning with Nibbāna.

original: atthato nibbānameva. Yasmā hi taṃ āgamma paṭicca ariyamaggassa ārammaṇapaccayabhāvahetu
analyzed: atthataḥ nibbānam eva yasmā hi tam āgamma paṭicca ariya maggassa ārammaṇa paccaya bhāva hetu
translated: For it is because of Nibbāna that the noble path becomes a condition in the sense of object condition for the stilling, the subsiding, of all the vacillations of formations.

original: sabbasaṅkhāravipphanditāni sammanti vūpasammanti, tasmā “sabbasaṅkhārasamatho”ti
analyzed: sabba saṅkhāra vipphanditāni sammanti vūpasammanti tasmā sabba saṅkhāra samathaḥ ti
translated: That is why it is said that Nibbāna is “the stilling of all formations.”

original: vuccati. Sabbasaṅkhatavisaṃyutte hi nibbāne saṅkhāravūpasamapariyāyo ñāyāgatoyevāti.
analyzed: vuccati sabba saṅkhata visaṃyutte hi nibbāne saṅkhāra vūpasama pariyāyaḥ ñāya āgato yā iva ati
translated: For in Nibbāna, which is dissociated from all formations, the stilling of formations is rightly approached by the path of seeing.

original: Idaṃ panettha nibbacanaṃ – sabbe saṅkhārā sammanti etthāti sabbasaṅkhārasamathoti.
analyzed: idam pana ittha nibbacanam sabbe saṅkhārā sammanti ettha ati sabba saṅkhāra samatho ti
translated: This is the explanation here: “All formations are stilled here” , thus it is the stilling of all formations.

original: Yasmā ca taṃ āgamma sabbe upadhayo paṭinissaṭṭhā samucchedavasena pariccattā honti,🔽aṭṭhasatappabhedā sabbāpi taṇhā khīyanti, sabbe kilesarāgā virajjanti, jarāmaraṇādibhedaṃ
analyzed: yasmā ca tam āgamma sabbe upadhayaḥ paṭinissaṭṭhāḥ samuccheda vasena pariccattāḥ honti  aṭṭha sata ppabhedā sabbā api taṇhā khīyanti sabbe kilesa rāgāḥ virajjanti jarā maraṇa ādi bhedam
translated: And because of it all the clingings are given up, relinquished by way of cutting them off,🔽all craving of the eighty-nine kinds is exhausted, all defilement-lusts are dispassioned,

original: sabbaṃ vaṭṭadukkhaṃ nirujjhati, tasmā “sabbūpadhipaṭinissaggo taṇhākkhayo virāgo
analyzed: sabbam vaṭṭa dukkham nirujjhati tasmā sabba upadhi paṭinissaggo taṇhā kkhayaḥ virāgo
translated: all suffering of the round of rebirths, classified as ageing-and-death, etc., is stopped, thus it is called “the giving up of all clinging, the exhaustion of craving, dispassion,

original: nirodho”ti vuccati, yā panesā taṇhā tena tena bhavena bhavantaraṃ bhavanikantibhāvena
analyzed: nirodhaḥ ti vuccati yā pana esā taṇhā tena tena bhavena bhavantaram bhava nikanti bhāvena
translated: stopping” . But this craving, which by way of rebirth-linking in this or that becoming, generation, destiny, station, or abode,

original: vinati saṃsibbati, phalena vā saddhiṃ kammaṃ vinati saṃsibbatīti katvā vānanti vuccati,
analyzed: vinati saṃsibbati phalena vā saddhim kammam vinati saṃsibbati iti katvā vānanti vuccati
translated: is bent , stretched out, or which, by way of the kamma-result, is bent, stretched out, in association with the result, is called “bent” .

original: tato nikkhantaṃ vānatoti nibbānaṃ. Kilamathoti kāyakilamatho. Vihesāpi kāyavihesāyeva,
analyzed: tatas nikkhantam vānato ti nibbānam kilamatho ti kāya kilamatho vihesā api kāya vihesāya iva
translated: Nibbana is “come out from that bending” . “Fatigue” is fatigue of the body. “Affliction” is also affliction of the body.

original: citte pana ubhayampetaṃ buddhānaṃ natthi bodhimūleyeva samucchinnattā. Ettha ca ciranisajjācirabhāsanehi
analyzed: citte pana ubhayampetam buddhānam natthi bodhi mūleya iva ettha ca cira nisajja a cira bhāsanehi
translated: But in the case of Buddhas, both these are absent, since they have been cut off at the root at the foot of the Tree of Enlightenment. And here, by the words “long-standing intimacy” and “glib talk”

original: piṭṭhiāgilāyanatālugalasosādivasena kāyakilamatho ceva kāyavihesā ca veditabbā, sā🔽ca kho desanāya atthaṃ ajānantānañca appaṭipajjantānañca vasena. Jānantānaṃ pana🔽paṭipajjantānañca desanāya kāyaparissamopi satthu aparissamova, tenāha bhagavā “na🔽ca maṃ dhammādhikaraṇaṃ vihesetī”ti. Teneva vuttaṃ “yā ajānantānaṃ desanā nāma, so
analyzed: piṭṭhiā gilāyana tālu gala sosa ādi vasena ca iva kāya vihesā ca veditabbā sā  ca kho desanāya attham a jānantānam ca appaṭipajjantānam ca vasena jānantānam pana  paṭipajjantānam ca desanāya kāya parissamaḥ api satthu a parissamaḥ va tena āha bhagavā na  ca mam dhamma adhikaraṇam viheseti iti tena iva vuttam yā a jānantānam desanā nāma so
translated: But the Exalted One has no such thing in his mind, for he cut it off at the root at the foot of the Bodhi Tree. And here physical fatigue and mental strain should be understood as the physical fatigue and mental strain that arise through long standing and long sitting, through long drawn out preaching, through the drying up of the throat and palate, etc.,🔽and as the physical fatigue and mental strain that arise through teaching the Dhamma to those who do not understand the meaning and do not practice it. But for those who understand the meaning and practice it, the teaching of the Dhamma is not even a slight affliction for the Master. Therefore the Exalted One said: “The Dhamma does not trouble me” .

original: mama kilamatho assā”ti.🔽Apissūti sampiṇḍanatthe nipāto. So na kevalaṃ etadahosi, imāpi gāthā paṭibhaṃsūti
analyzed: mama kilamathaḥ assa ati  sampiṇḍana tthe nipātaḥ saḥ na kevalam imā api gāthāḥ
translated: That is why it is said: “What is called teaching for those who do not understand is a fatigue for me.”

original: dīpeti. Bhagavantanti paṭisaddayogena sāmiatthe upayogavacananti āha “bhagavato”ti.
analyzed: dīpeti bhagavantanti paṭisadda yogena sāmi atthe upayoga vacananti āha bhagavatā iti
translated: Apissuva, “and also,” is a particle in the sense of inclusion. It shows that not only did this thought occur to the Exalted One, but also the following verses occurred to him. Bhagavato means “of the Exalted One” in the sense of the possessor, by the addition of the possessive ending -a.

original: Vuddhippattā acchariyā vā anacchariyā. Vuddhiatthopi hi a-kāro hoti yathā “asekkhā
analyzed: vuddhi ppattā acchariyā vā an acchariyā vuddhi atthaḥ pi hi akāraḥ hoti yathā asekkhā
translated: and the wonder is that he has reached growth. For the letter a is used to denote growth, as in “asekkhā dhammā” .

original: dhammā”ti. Kappānaṃ cattāri asaṅkhyeyyāni satasahassañca sadevakassa lokassa dhammasaṃvibhāgakaraṇatthameva
analyzed: dhammā ti kappānam cattāri asaṅkhyeyyāni sata sahassam ca sa devakassa lokassa dhamma saṃvibhāga karaṇa ttham eva
translated: And the wonder is that he has reached growth in the sense of the fulfilment of the pāramīs for the sake of the distribution of the Dhamma to the world with its gods for four incalculables and a hundred thousand eons.

original: pāramiyo pūretvā idāni samadhigatadhammarajjassa tattha appossukkatāpattidīpanattā🔽gāthātthassa anuacchariyatā tassa vuddhippatti ca veditabbā. Atthadvārena hi gāthānaṃ
analyzed: pāramiyaḥ pūretvā idāni samadhigata dhamma rajjassa tattha appa ussukka tā āpatti dīpana ttā  gāthā atthassa anuacchariya tā tassa vuddhi ppatti ca veditabbā attha dvārena hi gāthānaṃ
translated: And the wonder is that he has reached growth in the sense of the attainment of non-remorse in that he has now attained sovereignty over the Dhamma.🔽For the wonder of the meaning of the verse is that it shows the attainment of non-remorse by him who has attained sovereignty over the Dhamma.

original: anacchariyatā. Gocarā ahesunti upaṭṭhahaṃsu, upaṭṭhānañca vitakkayitabbatāti āha🔽“parivitakkayitabbabhāvaṃ pāpuṇiṃsū”ti.
analyzed: gocarāḥ ahesun ti upaṭṭhahaṃsu upaṭṭhānam ca vitakkayitabba tā ti āha  parivitakkayitabba bhāvam pāpuṇiṃsu iti
translated: “They became his attendants” means they became his supporters. And support is the same as reflection. Therefore it is said: “they became the object of his reflection.”

original: Kicchenāti na dukkhappaṭipadāya. Buddhānañhi cattāropi maggā sukhappaṭipadāva honti.
analyzed: kicchena ati na dukkha ppaṭipadāya buddhānam hi cattāraḥ api maggā sukha ppaṭipadā va honti
translated: “With difficulty” means not with the difficult path. For the four paths of the Buddhas are only the easy path.

original: Pāramīpūraṇakāle pana sarāgasadosasamohasseva sato āgatāgatānaṃ yācakānaṃ alaṅkatappaṭiyattaṃ
analyzed: pāramī pūraṇa kāle pana sa rāga sa dosa sa mohassa iva sataḥ āgata āgatānam yācakānam alaṅkata paṭiyattam
translated: But during the time of fulfilling the pāramīs, he, who was still possessed of lust, hatred, and delusion, became remorseful when he gave away to suppliants who came again and again his own limbs,

original: sīsaṃ kantitvā galalohitaṃ nīharitvā suañjitāni akkhīni uppāṭetvā kulavaṃsappadīpaṃ
analyzed: sīsam kantitvā gala lohitam nīharitvā su añjitāni akkhīni uppāṭetvā kula vaṃsa padīpam
translated: Having his head shaved, having blood drawn from his throat, having his eyes plucked out, having his family lineage traced,

original: puttaṃ manāpacāriniṃ bhariyanti evamādīni dentassa aññāni ca khantivādisadisesu attabhāvesu🔽chejjabhejjādīni pāpuṇantassa āgamanīyapaṭipadaṃ sandhāyetaṃ vuttaṃ. Ha-iti vā byattanti
analyzed: puttam manāpa cārinim bhariyanti evamādīni dentassa aññāni ca khanti vādi sadisesu attabhāvesu  chejja bhejja ādīni pāpuṇantassa āgamanīya paṭipadam sandhāya itam vuttam ha eti vā byattanti
translated: having his son, his beloved wife, etc., given away, and having to undergo the various kinds of bodily pain in other existences that are the outcome of the same kind of action,

original: etasmiṃ atthe nipāto. Ekaṃsattheti keci. Ha byattaṃ ekaṃsena vā alaṃ nippayojanaṃ
analyzed: etasmin atthe nipātaḥ ekaṃsa atthā iti keci ha byattam ekaṃsena vā alam nippayojanam
translated: the meaning is, “having to undergo the various kinds of bodily pain in other existences that are the outcome of the same kind of action.” “Ha” is a particle in the sense of “indeed.” “Ekasenā” means “by one means” or “sufficiently, without purpose.”

original: evaṃ kicchena adhigataṃ dhammaṃ desetunti yojanā. Halanti vā alanti iminā samānatthaṃ
analyzed: evam kicchena adhigatam dhammam desetunti yojanā vā iminā samāna attham
translated: The construction is: “having taught the Dhamma that was attained with difficulty.” “Halānī” is a word of the same meaning as “alānī.”

original: padaṃ “halanti vadāmī”tiādīsu viya. “Pakāsita”ntipi paṭhanti, desitanti attho. Evaṃ
analyzed: padam ha lanti vadāmi iti ādīsu viya paṭhanti desitanti evam
translated: “Halānī” is like “halānī vadāmī” , etc. Some read “pakāsitā” , the meaning being “taught.”

original: kicchena adhigatassa dhammassa alaṃ desitaṃ pariyattaṃ desitaṃ, ko attho desitenāti
analyzed: kicchena adhigatassa dhammassa alam desitam pariyattam desitam kaḥ atthaḥ desitena ati
translated: The Dhamma that was attained with difficulty is sufficiently taught, is well taught, is taught in full; what is the use of teaching it?

original: vuttaṃ hoti. Rāgadosaparetehīti rāgadosaphuṭṭhehi, phuṭṭhavisena viya sappena rāgena
analyzed: vuttam hoti rāga dosa paretehi iti rāga dosa phuṭṭhehi phuṭṭha visena viya sappena rāgena
translated: is what is meant. “By those overcome by lust, hate, and delusion”: by those affected by lust, hate, and delusion, as by a snake affected by poison.

original: dosena ca samphuṭṭhehi abhibhūtehīti attho. Atha vā rāgadosaparetehīti rāgadosānugatehi,
analyzed: dosena ca samphuṭṭhehi abhibhūtehi iti attho atha vā rāga dosa paretehi iti rāga dosa anugatehi
translated: Or else, “by those who are possessed by lust and hate” means by those who are accompanied by lust and hate;

original: rāgena ca dosena ca anubandhehīti attho.🔽Paṭisotagāminti niccagāhādīnaṃ paṭisotaṃ aniccaṃ dukkhamanattā asubhanti evaṃ gataṃ
analyzed: rāgena ca dosena ca anubandhehi iti attho  paṭisota gāmin ti nicca gāha ādīnam paṭisotam aniccam dukkham anattā asubhanti evam gatam
translated: the meaning is that they are followed by lust and hate.🔽“Going against the stream”: the meaning is, “going to the four noble truths, which are the opposite of the four streams of sensuality, etc., and which are impermanent, painful, empty, and not-self.”

original: pavattaṃ catusaccadhammanti attho. Rāgarattāti kāmarāgena bhavarāgena diṭṭhirāgena
analyzed: pavattam catu sacca dhammanti attho rāga rattā ati kāma rāgena bhava rāgena diṭṭhi rāgena
translated: “Lust-ridden”: infatuated with sensual lust, lust for existence, and lust for non-existence.

original: ca rattā. Na dakkhantīti aniccaṃ dukkhamanattā asubhanti iminā sabhāvena na passissanti,
analyzed: ca rattāḥ na dakkhanti iti aniccam dukkham anattāḥ asubhanti iminā sabhāvena na passissanti
translated: “Will not see”: they will not see the true nature of things as impermanent, painful, empty, and not-self.

original: te apassante ko sakkhissati aniccantiādinā sabhāvena yāthāvato dhammaṃ jānāpetunti
analyzed: te a passante kaḥ sakkhissati aniccanti ādinā sabhāvena yāthāvataḥ dhammam jānāpetunti
translated: The intention is this: “When they do not see this, who will be able to make them understand the true nature of things as it really is, saying, ‘This is impermanent,’ etc.?”

original: adhippāyo. Rāgadosaparetatāpi nesaṃ sammuḷhabhāvenevāti āha “tamokhandhena āvuṭā”ti,
analyzed: adhippāyaḥ rāga dosa pareta tā api sammuḷha bhāvena iva ati āha tamaḥ khandhena
translated: “Covered by a mass of darkness” : their lust and hate are covered by ignorance.

original: avijjārāsinā ajjhotthaṭāti attho.
analyzed: avijjārāsinā ajjhotthaṭā ati
translated: The meaning is: they are overwhelmed by the mass of ignorance.

original: Appossukkatāya cittaṃ namatīti kasmā panassa evaṃ cittaṃ nami, nanu esa “muttohaṃ mocessāmi, tiṇṇohaṃ tāressāmi,
analyzed: appossukka tāya cittam namati iti kasmā pana assa evam cittam nami nanu esa mutta ūham mocessāmi tiṇṇa ūham tāressāmi
translated: Why does his mind incline to inaction? Has he not made the aspiration: ‘I will be the liberator of those not yet liberated, the leader of those not yet led,🔽the comforter of those not yet comforted.

original: Kiṃ me aññātavesena, dhammaṃ sacchikatenidha;
analyzed: kim me aññāta vesena dhammam
translated: What is the use of my attaining the Dhamma

original: Sabbaññutaṃ pāpuṇitvā, tārayissaṃ sadevaka”nti. –
analyzed: sabbaññu tam pāpuṇitvā tārayissam sa devakam ti
translated: if I do not lead across the world with its gods?’

original: Patthanaṃ katvā pāramiyo pūretvā sabbaññutaṃ pattoti? Saccameva, tadeva paccavekkhaṇānubhāvena
analyzed: patthanam katvā pāramiyo pūretvā sabbaññu tam patto ti saccam eva tat eva paccavekkhaṇa anubhāvena
translated: And after making this aspiration, did he not fulfil the pāramīs, attain omniscience, and lead across the world with its gods?

original: panassa evaṃ cittaṃ nami. Tassa hi sabbaññutaṃ patvā sattānaṃ kilesagahanataṃ dhammassa
analyzed: panassa evam cittam tassa hi sabbaññu tam patvā sattānam kilesa gahana tam dhammassa
translated: It is true that he did all this, but his mind inclines to inaction through the power of his reflection on the following:

original: ca gambhīrataṃ paccavekkhantassa sattānaṃ kilesagahanatā ca dhammagambhīratā ca sabbākārena
analyzed: ca gambhīra tam paccavekkhantassa sattānam kilesa gahana tā ca dhamma gambhīra tā ca sabba ākārena
translated: After attaining omniscience, he reflected on the depth of the Dhamma and on the great burden of defilements carried by beings.🔽The depth of the Dhamma and the great burden of defilements carried by beings became fully evident to him.

original: pākaṭā jātā. Athassa “ime sattā kañjiyapuṇṇalābu viya takkabharitacāṭi viya vasātelapītapilotikā
analyzed: pākaṭāḥ jātāḥ athassa ime sattā
translated: Then he thought: “Beings are extremely defiled, like a gourd full of poison, like a bowl full of takka, like a cloth soaked in oil.

original: viya añjanamakkhitahattho viya ca kilesabharitā atisaṃkiliṭṭhā rāgarattā dosaduṭṭhā
analyzed: viya añjana makkhita hatthaḥ viya ca kilesa bharitāḥ ati saṃkiliṭṭhāḥ rāga rattāḥ dosa duṭṭhā
translated: They are greedy for sensual pleasures, hateful, and deluded.

original: mohamuḷhā, te kiṃ nāma paṭivijjhissantī”ti cintayato kilesagahanapaccavekkhaṇānubhāvenapi evaṃ cittaṃ nami.🔽“Ayaṃ dhammo pathavīsandhārakaudakakkhandho viya gambhīro, pabbatena paṭicchādetvā
analyzed: moha muḷhā te kim nāma paṭivijjhissanti iti cintayataḥ kilesa gahana paccavekkhaṇa anubhāvena api evam cittam nami  ayam dhammaḥ pathavī sandhāraka odaka khandhaḥ viya gambhīraḥ pabbatena paṭicchādetvā
translated: This is how his mind inclined through the power of reflecting on the depth of the defilements.

original: ṭhapito sāsapo viya duddaso, satadhā bhinnassa vālassa koṭi viya aṇu. Mayā hi imaṃ
analyzed: ṭhapitaḥ sāsapaḥ viya duddasaḥ satadhā bhinnassa vālassa koṭi viya aṇu mayā hi imaṃ
translated: “This Dhamma is as deep as the ocean, which supports the earth; it is as hard to see as a mustard seed placed on the point of an awl and hidden in the folds of a palm leaf; it is as subtle as the point of an awl split a hundred times.

original: dhammaṃ paṭivijjhituṃ vāyamantena adinnaṃ dānaṃ nāma natthi, arakkhitaṃ sīlaṃ nāma
analyzed: dhammam paṭivijjhitum vā āyamantena adinnam dānam nāma natthi arakkhitam sīlam nāma
translated: For when I was striving to penetrate this Dhamma, there was no gift I would not give, no moral precept I would not observe, no perfection I would not fulfil.

original: natthi, aparipūritā kāci pāramī nāma natthi, tassa me nirussāhaṃ viya mārabalaṃ vidhamantassapi🔽pathavī na kampittha, paṭhamayāme pubbenivāsaṃ anussarantassapi na kampittha, majjhimayāme
analyzed: natthi a paripūritā kāci pāramī nāma natthi tassa me nirussāham viya māra balam vidhamantassa api  pathavī na kampittha paṭhama yāme pubbenivāsam anussarantassa api na kampittha majjhima yāme
translated: When I was destroying the power of Mara, as if it were nothing,🔽the earth did not tremble. When I was recollecting my past lives in the first watch of the night, the earth did not tremble.

original: dibbacakkhuṃ visodhentassapi na kampittha, pacchimayāme pana paṭiccasamuppādaṃ paṭivijjhantasseva
analyzed: dibba cakkhum visodhentassa api na kampittha pacchima yāme pana paṭiccasamuppādam paṭivijjhantassa eva
translated: When I was purifying the divine eye in the middle watch of the night, the earth did not tremble. But when I was penetrating dependent origination in the last watch of the night,🔽the earth trembled.

original: me dasasahassilokadhātu kampittha. Iti mādisenapi tikkhañāṇena kicchenevāyaṃ dhammo🔽paṭividdho, taṃ lokiyamahājanā kathaṃ paṭivijjhissantī”ti dhammagambhīratāya paccavekkhaṇānubhāvenapi
analyzed: me dasa sahassi lokadhātu kampittha iti mādisena api tikkha ñāṇena kicchena iva ayam dhammo  paṭividdhaḥ tam lokiya mahājanā katham paṭivijjhissanti iti dhamma gambhīra tāya paccavekkhaṇa anubhāvena api
translated: and the ten-thousand world-element shook. So this Dhamma, which was penetrated with difficulty by me whose knowledge was keen,🔽how will it be penetrated by the people of the world who are so dull?”

original: evaṃ cittaṃ namīti veditabbaṃ.
analyzed: evam cittam namīti veditabbam
translated: And he should be understood to have inclined his mind in this way through the power of reflecting on the profundity of the Dhamma.

original: Apica brahmunā yācite desetukāmatāyapissa evaṃ cittaṃ nami. Jānāti hi bhagavā “mama
analyzed: apica brahmunā yācite evam cittam jānāti hi bhagavā mama
translated: Besides, he inclined his mind in this way because he was willing to teach when requested by Brahmā. For the Exalted One knew that

original: appossukkatāya citte namamāne mahābrahmā dhammadesanaṃ yācissati, ime ca sattā brahmagarukā,🔽te ‘satthā kira dhammaṃ na desetukāmo ahosi, atha naṃ mahābrahmā yācitvā desāpeti,
analyzed: appossukka tāya citte namamāne mahābrahmā dhamma desanam yācissati ime ca sattā brahma garukā  te satthā kira dhammam na desetu kāmaḥ ahosi atha nam mahābrahmā yācitvā desāpeti
translated: if his mind inclined to inaction, Great Brahmā would request him to teach the Dhamma, and that beings would be respectful towards the Dhamma

original: santo vata bho dhammo paṇīto’ti maññamānā sussūsissantī”ti. Idampissa kāraṇaṃ paṭicca
analyzed: santaḥ vata bho dhammo paṇīto ti maññamānā sussūsissanti iti idam pissa kāraṇam paṭicca
translated: if they thought, “The Teacher was unwilling to teach the Dhamma, but he was requested by Great Brahmā and then he taught it.” This is the reason

original: appossukkatāya cittaṃ nami, no dhammadesanāyāti veditabbaṃ.
analyzed: appossukka tāya cittam nami no dhamma desanāya ati veditabbam
translated: why he inclined his mind to inaction and not to teaching the Dhamma.

original: 8. Sahampatissāti so kira kassapassa bhagavato sāsane sahako nāma thero paṭhamajjhānaṃ
analyzed: sahampatissa ati saḥ kira kassapassa bhagavato sāsane sahakaḥ nāma theraḥ paṭhama jhānam
translated: Sahampati’s: it is said that in the dispensation of the Blessed One Kassapa there was a monk called Sahaka who,

original: nibbattetvā paṭhamajjhānabhūmiyaṃ kappāyukabrahmā hutvā nibbatto, tatra naṃ sahampati🔽brahmāti sañjānanti. Taṃ sandhāyāha “brahmuno sahampatissā”ti. Nassati vatāti so
analyzed: nibbattetvā paṭhama jhāna bhūmiyam kappāyuka brahmā hutvā nibbattaḥ tatra nam sahampati  brahmā iti sañjānanti tam sandhāya āha brahmunaḥ sahampatissa ati nassati vata iti so
translated: having attained the first jhana, was reborn as a Brahma in the Brahma-world of the first jhana. There they know him as Sahampati Brahma.

original: kira imaṃ saddaṃ tathā nicchāreti, yathā dasasahassilokadhātubrahmāno sutvā sabbe
analyzed: kira imam saddam tathā yathā dasa sahassi lokadhātu brahmāno sutvā sabbe
translated: Referring to him, the Exalted One said, “Sahampati’s.” He would be heard: it is said that he directs his voice in such a way that the Brahmas of the ten thousand world-realms hear it and all assemble.

original: sannipatiṃsu. Apparajakkhajātikāti paññāmaye akkhimhi appaṃ parittaṃ rāgadosamoharajaṃ🔽etesaṃ evaṃsabhāvāti apparajakkhajātikā. Appaṃ rāgādirajaṃ yesaṃ te sabhāvā apparajakkhajātikāti
analyzed: sannipatiṃsu paññā maye akkhimhi appam parittam rāga dosa moha rajam  etesam evaṃsabhāvā ti appa rajakkha jātikāḥ appam rāga ādi rajam yesam te sabhāvāḥ appa rajakkha jātikā ati
translated: Of little dust: in the eye of wisdom there is little dust, that is, little passion, hatred, and delusion.🔽They are of such a nature that they have little dust. The meaning should be understood thus: they are of such a nature that they have little dust of passion, etc.

original: evamettha attho daṭṭhabbo. Assavanatāti “sayaṃ abhiññā”tiādīsu viya karaṇatthe paccattavacanaṃ,
analyzed: evam ettha atthaḥ daṭṭhabbo assavana tā ti sayam abhiññā ti ādīsu viya karaṇa atthe paccatta vacanam
translated: Not heard: the pronoun “his” is in the instrumental case in the sense of the agent.

original: assavanatāyāti attho. Bhavissantīti purimabuddhesu dasapuññakiriyavasena katādhikārā🔽paripākagatapadumāni viya sūriyarasmisamphassaṃ dhammadesanaṃyeva ākaṅkhamānā catuppadikagāthāvasāne
analyzed: assavana tāya ti atthaḥ bhavissanti iti purima buddhesu dasa puñña kiriya vasena kata adhikārā  paripāka gata padumāni viya sūriya rasmi samphassam dhamma desanaṃyā iva ākaṅkhamānā catuppadika gāthā avasāne
translated: the meaning is, they will be heard. They will be: they will be those who will be able to understand the Dhamma, not just one or two, but many hundreds of thousands, who will be able to enter upon the noble plane at the end of the four-line stanza,

original: ariyabhūmiṃ okkamanārahā na eko, na dve, anekasatasahassā dhammassa aññātāro bhavissantīti dasseti.
analyzed: ariya bhūmim okkamana arahā naḥ ekaḥ na dve aneka sata sahassā dhammassa aññātāraḥ bhavissanti iti dasseti
translated: like the lotuses in the story of the sunbeam that reached the lotuses that had been tended by the performance of the ten kinds of good conduct under former Buddhas and were now fully grown.

original: Pāturahosīti pātubhavi. Samalehi cintitoti samalehi pūraṇakassapādīhi chahi satthārehi🔽cintito. Te hi puretaraṃ uppajjitvā sakalajambudīpe kaṇṭake pattharamānā viya visaṃ
analyzed: pāturahosi iti samalehi cintito ti samalehi pūraṇa kassapa ādīhi chahi satthārehi  cintitaḥ te hi puretaram uppajjitvā sakala jambudīpe kaṇṭake pattharamānāḥ viya visam
translated: He has appeared: he has become manifest. Thought of by the stained: thought of by the six teachers beginning with Pūraṇa Kassapa, who were stained.🔽For these, having arisen earlier, taught a doctrine of wrong view that was stained, as if they were spreading thorns all over the whole of India, as if they were sprinkling poison.

original: siñcamānā viya ca samalaṃ micchādiṭṭhidhammaṃ desayiṃsu. Te kira buddhakolāhalānussavena
analyzed: siñcamānāḥ viya ca sa malam micchādiṭṭhi dhammam desayiṃsu te kira buddha kolāhala anussavena
translated: They were, it seems, curious to hear the Buddha’s reputation,

original: sañjātakutūhalā lokaṃ vañcetvā kohaññe ṭhatvā sabbaññutaṃ paṭijānantā yaṃ kiñci adhammaṃyeva
analyzed: sañjāta kutūhalāḥ lokam vañcetvā kohaññe ṭhatvā sabbaññu tam paṭijānantāḥ yam kiñci
translated: and so they deceived the world, stood in a place of honour, and claimed to be omniscient. Whatever was an unDhamma

original: dhammoti dīpesuṃ. Apāpuretanti vivara etaṃ. Amatassa dvāranti amatassa nibbānassa
analyzed: dhammoti dīpesum apāpuḥ etanti vivare etam amatassa dvāram ti amatassa nibbānassa
translated: “Dhamma” they expounded. “They opened up” means they revealed it. “The door to the Deathless” means the door to Nibbāna,

original: dvārabhūtaṃ ariyamaggaṃ. Idaṃ vuttaṃ hoti – etaṃ kassapassa bhagavato sāsanantaradhānato
analyzed: dvāra bhūtam ariya maggam idam vuttam hoti etam kassapassa bhagavato sāsana antaradhānato
translated: They showed the Dhamma. They opened it up. The door to the Deathless: the Noble Path, which is the door to the Deathless Nibbāna. This is the meaning. From the time of the disappearance of the Dispensation of the Blessed One Kassapa

original: pabhuti pihitaṃ nibbānanagarassa mahādvāraṃ ariyamaggaṃ saddhammadesanāhatthena apāpura🔽vivara ugghāṭehīti. Suṇantu dhammaṃ vimalenānubuddhanti ime sattā rāgādimalānaṃ abhāvato
analyzed: pabhuti pihitam nibbāna nagarassa mahā dvāram ariya maggam saddhamma desanā hatthena apāpura  vivare ugghāṭehi iti suṇantu dhammam vimalena anubuddhanti ime sattāḥ rāga ādi malānam abhāvataḥ
translated: the great door to the city of Nibbāna, the Noble Path, was closed. With the hand of the teaching of the True Dhamma, open it up,

original: vimalena sammāsambuddhena anubuddhaṃ catusaccadhammaṃ suṇantu tāva bhagavāti yācati.🔽Selapabbato ucco hoti thiro ca, na paṃsupabbato missakapabbato vāti āha “sele yathā🔽pabbatamuddhaniṭṭhito”ti. Tassattho “selamaye ekagghane pabbatamuddhani yathāṭhitova.
analyzed: vimalena sammāsambuddhena anubuddham catu sacca dhammam suṇantu tāva bhagavā ati yācati  sela pabbataḥ uccaḥ hoti thiraḥ ca na paṃsu pabbataḥ missaka pabbataḥ vā ati āha sele yathā  pabbata muddhani ṭṭhitaḥ ti tassa atthaḥ sela maye ekagghane pabbata muddhani yathā ṭhitaḥ uva
translated: uncover it, and reveal it. Let them hear the Dhamma discovered by the stainless one: let these beings first hear the Dhamma of the Four Noble Truths, which was discovered by the Perfectly Enlightened One who is stainless because he is devoid of the stains of lust, etc. Thus he requests the Blessed One.🔽Sela Mountain is high and firm, not a mountain of sand or a mountain of clay. Therefore he said: “As though he stood upon a mountain peak” . The meaning is: “As though he stood on the peak of a mountain of solid rock.”

original: Na hi tattha ṭhitassa dassanatthaṃ gīvukkhipanapasāraṇādikiccaṃ atthī”ti. Tathūpamanti
analyzed: na hi tattha ṭhitassa dassana attham gīvukkhipana pasāraṇa ādi kiccam atthi iti tathūpamanti
translated: For one who stands there has no need to stretch out his neck or to strain his eyes in order to see. “Just so” means:

original: tappaṭibhāgaṃ selapabbatūpamaṃ. Dhammamayaṃ pāsādanti lokuttaradhammamāha. So hi🔽sabbaso pasādāvaho sabbadhamme atikkamma abbhuggataṭṭhena pāsādasadiso ca, paññāpariyāyo
analyzed: tad paṭibhāgam sela pabbata upamam dhamma mayam pāsādam ti lokuttara dhammam āha saḥ hi  sabbasas pasāda āvahaḥ sabba dhamme atikkamma abbhuggata ṭṭhena pāsāda sadiso ca paññā pariyāyo
translated: and the counterpart of that is the simile of the Sela rock. The “palace of Dhamma” is the supramundane Dhamma. For that

original: vā idha dhamma-saddo. Paññā hi abbhuggataṭṭhena pāsādoti abhidhamme niddiṭṭhā. Tathā cāha –
analyzed: vā idha dhamma saddo paññā hi abbhuggata ṭṭhena pāsādaḥ ti abhidhamme niddiṭṭhā tathā ca āha
translated: is like a palace in the sense of being exalted above all the Dhamma of the worlds. Or else the word “Dhamma” here refers to the mode of understanding. For understanding is called a “palace” in the sense of being exalted, as it is said:

original: “Paññāpāsādamāruyha, asoko sokiniṃ pajaṃ;
analyzed: paññāpāsādam āruyha asokaḥ sokinim pajam
translated: “Having mounted the palace of understanding, the sorrowless one,

original: Pabbataṭṭhova bhūmaṭṭhe, dhīro bāle avekkhatī”ti. ;
analyzed: pabbata aṭṭhaḥ uva bhūma aṭṭhe dhīraḥ bāle avekkhati iti
translated: The wise one looks down on the world of sorrow, as from a mountain top.”

original: Ayaṃ panettha saṅkhepattho – yathā selapabbatamuddhani yathāṭhitova cakkhumā puriso🔽samantato janataṃ passeyya, tathā tvampi sumedha sundarapañña sabbaññutaññāṇena samantacakkhu
analyzed: ayam pana ittha saṅkhepa atthaḥ yathā sela pabbata muddhani yathā ṭhitaḥ iva cakkhumā puriso  samantataḥ janatam passeyya tathā tvam pi sumedha sundara pañña sabbaññuta ññāṇena samanta cakkhu
translated: The meaning of this passage in brief is as follows. Just as a man with eyes standing on the top of the Sela rock🔽would see the people all around, so you, O wise one, O you of beautiful understanding, the Blessed One, the Omniscient One, the All-Seeing One,

original: bhagavā dhammamayaṃ paññāmayaṃ pāsādamāruyha sayaṃ apetasoko sokāvatiṇṇaṃ jātijarābhibhūtaṃ
analyzed: bhagavā dhamma mayam paññā mayam pāsādam āruyha sayam apeta sokaḥ soka avatiṇṇam jāti jarā abhibhūtam
translated: having mounted the palace of understanding, the Dhamma, which is made of understanding, looks down on the world of sorrow, which is overcome by birth and aging and is immersed in sorrow.

original: janataṃ avekkhassu upadhāraya upaparikkhāti. Ayaṃ panettha adhippāyo – yathā hi pabbatapāde
analyzed: janatam avekkhassu upadhāraya upaparikkhāti ayam pana ittha adhippāyaḥ yathā hi pabbata pāde
translated: Just as if, on the slopes of a mountain,

original: samantā mahantaṃ khettaṃ katvā tattha kedārapāḷīsu kuṭikāyo katvā rattiṃ aggiṃ jāleyyuṃ,
analyzed: samantā mahantam khettam katvā tattha kedāra pāḷīsu kuṭikāyo katvā rattim aggim jāleyyuṃ
translated: a great field had been cleared all round, and there huts had been built in the boundary fences, and at night fires had been lit,

original: caturaṅgasamannāgatañca andhakāraṃ assa, atha tassa pabbatassa matthake ṭhatvā cakkhumato
analyzed: catur aṅga samannāgatam ca andhakāram assa atha tassa pabbatassa matthake ṭhatvā cakkhumataḥ
translated: and there were darkness with four surfaces,

original: purisassa bhūmiṃ olokayato neva khettaṃ, na kedārapāḷiyo, na kuṭiyo, na tattha sayitamanussā
analyzed: purisassa bhūmim olokayataḥ na iva khettam na kedāra pāḷiyaḥ na kuṭiyaḥ na tattha sayita manussā
translated: then if a man with eyes stood on the top of the mountain and looked at the ground, he would not see the field, nor the boundary fences, nor the huts, nor the people lying there,

original: paññāyeyyuṃ anujjalabhāvato, kuṭikāsu pana aggijālāmattameva paññāyeyya ujjalabhāvato,
analyzed: paññāyeyyum an ujjala bhāvataḥ kuṭikāsu pana aggi jālā mattam eva paññāyeyya ujjala bhāvataḥ
translated: because of the darkness, but he would see only the flames of the fires because of the brightness;

original: evaṃ dhammapāsādaṃ āruyha sattanikāyaṃ olokayato tathāgatassa ye te akatakalyāṇā
analyzed: evam dhamma pāsādam āruyha satta nikāyam olokayataḥ tathāgatassa ye te a kata kalyāṇā
translated: so too, when the Perfect One has ascended the Palace of the Dhamma and looks down on the generation, those beings who have not done what is wholesome

original: sattā, te ekavihāre dakkhiṇajāṇupasse nisinnāpi buddhacakkhussa āpāthaṃ nāgacchanti
analyzed: sattā te eka vihāre dakkhiṇajāṇupasse nisinnā api buddha cakkhussa āpātham na āgacchanti
translated: do not come within the scope of his Buddha-eye, even though they are sitting with their knees knocking against each other in a single monastery,

original: ñāṇagginā anujjalabhāvato anuḷārabhāvato ca, rattiṃ khittā sarā viya honti. Ye pana
analyzed: ñāṇa agginā anujjala bhāvataḥ anuḷāra bhāvataḥ ca rattim khittā sarāḥ viya honti ye pana
translated: because of the darkness of their non-manifestation of what is wholesome and because of their non-manifestation of what is bright; they are like the stars at night. But those who have done what is wholesome

original: katakalyāṇā veneyyapuggalā, te evassa dūrepi ṭhitā āpāthamāgacchanti paripakkañāṇaggitāya
analyzed: kata kalyāṇā veneyya puggalā te eva assa dūre pi ṭhitāḥ āpātham āgacchanti paripakka ñāṇaggi tāya
translated: and the good people to be trained, even though far away, come within his range, because of the heat of his knowledge that is fully developed.

original: samujjalabhāvato uḷārasantānatāya ca, so aggi viya himavantapabbato viya ca. Vuttampi cetaṃ –
analyzed: samujjala bhāvataḥ uḷāra santāna tāya ca so aggi viya himavanta pabbataḥ viya ca vuttam pi ca itam
translated: He is like a fire and like the Himalaya mountain. And this is said:🔽“The good shine forth afar,

original: “Dūre santo pakāsenti, himavantova pabbato;
analyzed: dūre santaḥ pakāsenti himavantaḥ iva pabbato
translated: Like the Himalaya mountain;🔽The bad are not seen here,

original: Asantettha na dissanti, rattiṃ khittā yathā sarā”ti. ;
analyzed: asantā ittha na dissanti rattim khittā yathā sarāti
translated: Like the stars by day.”

original: Uṭṭhehīti bhagavato dhammadesanatthaṃ cārikacaraṇaṃ yācanto bhaṇati. Uṭṭhehīti vā
analyzed: uṭṭhehi iti bhagavataḥ dhamma desana attham cārika caraṇam yācantaḥ bhaṇati uṭṭhehi iti vā
translated: “Rise up” : he says this urging the Blessed One to go on a journey for the purpose of teaching the Dhamma. Or else, “rise up” means:🔽rise up from the state of contraction called non-diligence in teaching the Dhamma, from the state of laziness.

original: dhammadesanāya appossukkatāsaṅkhātasaṅkocāpattito kilāsubhāvato uṭṭhaha. Vīrātiādīsu🔽bhagavā sātisayacatubbidhasammappadhānavīriyavantatāya vīro, devaputtamaccukilesābhisaṅkhārānaṃ
analyzed: dhamma desanāya appossukka tā saṅkhāta saṅkoca āpattitaḥ kilāsu bhāvataḥ uṭṭhaha vīra ati ādīsu  bhagavā sa atisaya catubbidha sammappadhāna vīriyavanta tāya vīraḥ
translated: In the words “heroic, etc.,”🔽the Blessed One is a hero because he possesses the fourfold right effort in an eminent degree. He is a conqueror in battle because he has conquered the defilements, the devaputras, and the formations.

original: vijitattā vijitasaṅgāmo, jātikantārādito veneyyasatthaṃ vāhanasamatthatāya nibbānasaṅkhātaṃ
analyzed: vijita ttā vijita saṅgāmaḥ jāti kantāra āditaḥ veneyya sattham vāhana samattha tāya nibbāna saṅkhātam
translated: He is able to lead the people to be trained to the state called nibbana, which is the end of the desert of births, etc., because he possesses the fourfold right exertion in an eminent degree.

original: khemappadesaṃ sampāpanasamatthatāya satthavāho, kāmacchandaiṇassa abhāvato aṇaṇoti
analyzed: khema ppadesam sampāpana samattha tāya satthavāhaḥ kāmacchanda eṇassa abhāvataḥ
translated: He is a caravan leader because he is able to bring people to a place of safety. He is free from debt because he is free from the debt of sense desires.

original: veditabbo. Yo hi paresaṃ iṇaṃ gahetvā vināseti, so tehi “iṇaṃ dehī”ti tajjamānopi
analyzed: veditabbaḥ yaḥ hi paresam iṇam gahetvā vināseti saḥ tehi iṇam dehi iti tajjamānaḥ api
translated: For when someone has borrowed a debt from others and then goes to ruin, he is pursued by them with the cry, “Pay back the debt!”

original: pharusaṃ vuccamānopi vambhamānopi vadhiyamānopi kiñci paṭippaharituṃ na sakkoti,🔽sabbaṃ titikkhati. Titikkhakāraṇañhissa taṃ iṇaṃ hoti, evameva yo yamhi kāmacchandena🔽rajjati, taṇhāgahaṇena taṃ vatthuṃ gaṇhāti, so tena pharusaṃ vuccamānopi vambhamānopi
analyzed: pharusam vuccamānaḥ api vambhamānaḥ api vadhiyamānaḥ api kiñci paṭippaharitum na sakkoti  sabbam titikkhati titikkha kāraṇam hi ssa tat hoti evam eva yaḥ yamhi kāmacchandena  rajjati taṇhā gahaṇena tam vatthum gaṇhāti saḥ tena pharusam vuccamānaḥ api vambhamānaḥ api
translated: And though he is reviled, abused, and threatened, he is unable to ward them off in any way;

original: vadhiyamānopi kiñci paṭippaharituṃ na sakkoti, sabbaṃ titikkhati. Titikkhakāraṇañhissa
analyzed: vadhiyamānaḥ api kiñci paṭippaharitum na sakkoti sabbam titikkhati titikkha kāraṇam hi ssa
translated: he endures it all. For the reason for his endurance is that debt. So too, when someone is bound by sense desire to a certain object, he has taken it up with the grasping of craving. Then, though he is reviled, abused, and threatened, he is unable to ward it off in any way; he endures it all. For the reason for his endurance is that sense desire.

original: so kāmacchando hoti gharasāmikehi viheṭhiyamānānaṃ itthīnaṃ viya. Kasmā? Iṇasadisattā kāmacchandassa.
analyzed: saḥ kāmacchandaḥ hoti ghara sāmikehi viheṭhiyamānānam itthīnam viya kasmai iṇa sadisa ttā kāmacchandassa
translated: It is like the case of women who are persecuted by their husbands’ families. Why? Because sense desire is like a debt.

original: 9. Ajjhesananti garuṭṭhānīyaṃ payirupāsitvā garutaraṃ payojanaṃ uddissa abhipatthanā
analyzed: ajjhesanam ti garuṭṭhānīyam payis upāsitvā garutaram payojanam uddissa abhipatthanā
translated: “Solicitation” is the seeking of a more and more lofty object after having paid respect to one who is worthy of respect.

original: ajjhesanā, sāpi atthato yācanā eva. Buddhacakkhunāti indriyaparopariyattañāṇena ca🔽āsayānusayañāṇena ca. Imesañhi dvinnaṃ ñāṇānaṃ buddhacakkhūti nāmaṃ, sabbaññutaññāṇassa
analyzed: ajjhesanā sā api atthataḥ yācanā eva buddha cakkhunā ati indriya para upari yatta ñāṇena ca  āsaya anusaya ñāṇena ca imesam hi dvinnam ñāṇānam buddha cakkhu iti nāmam sabbaññuta ññāṇassa
translated: The invitation is a request. The Buddha eye is the knowledge of the difference in the faculties of other beings and the knowledge of the destination of beings after death. These two kinds of knowledge are called the Buddha eye. The knowledge of omniscience is called the wheel of the Dhamma.

original: samantacakkhūti. Heṭṭhimānaṃ tiṇṇaṃ maggañāṇānaṃ dhammacakkhūti. Apparajakkhetiādīsu🔽yesaṃ vuttanayeneva paññācakkhumhi rāgādirajaṃ appaṃ, te apparajakkhā. Yesaṃ taṃ
analyzed: samantacakkhu iti heṭṭhimānam tiṇṇam magga ñāṇānam dhammacakkhu iti apparajakkha iti ādīsu  yesam vutta nayena iva paññā cakkhumhi rāga ādi rajam appam te apparajakkhāḥ yesam tam
translated: The invitation is a request in meaning. The Buddha eye: the knowledge of the penetration of the minds of others and the knowledge of the destruction of the cankers. For these two knowledges are called the Buddha eye, and the knowledge of omniscience is called the all-seeing eye. The three lower kinds of knowledge are called the eye of Dhamma. In the passage beginning “Those whose dust is small” ,

original: mahantaṃ, te mahārajakkhā. Yesaṃ saddhādīni indriyāni tikkhāni, te tikkhindriyā.
analyzed: mahantam te mahārajakkhāḥ yesam saddhā ādīni indriyāni tikkhāni te tikkhindriyāḥ
translated: those whose dust, i.e., passion, etc., is small in the eye of wisdom in the way stated are those “whose dust is small.” Those whose dust is great are those “whose dust is great.” Those whose faculties of faith, etc., are sharp are those “of sharp faculties.”

original: Yesaṃ tāni mudūni, te mudindriyā. Yesaṃ teyeva saddhādayo ākārā sundarā, te svākārā.🔽Ye kathitakāraṇaṃ sallakkhenti, sukhena sakkā honti viññāpetuṃ, te suviññāpayā. Ye
analyzed: tāni mudūni te mud indriyāḥ yesam teyā iva saddha ādayaḥ ākārā sundarā te su ākārā  ye kathita kāraṇam sallakkhenti sukhena sakkāḥ honti viññāpetum te su viññāpayāḥ ye
translated: Those whose faculties are weak are those “of weak faculties.” Those whose modes, i.e., faith, etc., are beautiful are those “of beautiful modes.”

original: paralokañceva vajjañca bhayato passanti, te paralokavajjabhayadassāvino nāma.
analyzed: para lokañca iva vajjañca bhayataḥ passanti te para loka vajja bhaya dassāvinaḥ nāma
translated: Those who reflect on the reason stated are those “who are easy to advise.” Those who see the world beyond and the danger in evil are called “those who see the danger in the world beyond and in evil.”

original: Uppalāni ettha santīti uppalinī, gacchopi jalāsayopi, idha pana jalāsayo adhippeto,
analyzed: uppalāni ettha santi iti uppalinī gacchaḥ api jalāsayaḥ api idha pana jalāsayaḥ adhippeto
translated: “There are lotuses here” is “lotusy” . It is both a river and a pool, but here it is a pool that is intended.

original: tasmā uppaliniyanti uppalavaneti evamattho gahetabbo. Ito paresupi eseva nayo. Antonimuggaposīnīti
analyzed: tasmai uppaliniyanti uppala vane ti evam atthaḥ gahetabbaḥ itas paresu pi esa iva nayaḥ iti
translated: So the meaning here should be taken as “in a lotus grove.” The same method of explanation applies in the rest of the passage. “With their heads and eyes turned inward” :

original: yāni udakassa anto nimuggāneva hutvā pussanti vaḍḍhanti, tāni antonimuggaposīni.🔽Udakaṃ accuggamma tiṭṭhantīti udakaṃ atikkamitvā tiṭṭhanti. Tattha yāni accuggamma🔽ṭhitāni sūriyarasmisamphassaṃ āgamayamānāni, tāni ajja pupphanakāni. Yāni samodakaṃ
analyzed: yāni udakassa antar nimuggāna eva hutvā pussanti vaḍḍhanti tāni antonimuggaposīni  udakam accuggamma tiṭṭhanti iti udakam atikkamitvā tiṭṭhanti tattha yāni accuggamma  ṭhitāni sūriya rasmi samphassam āgamayamānāni tāni ajja pupphanakāni yāni samodakam
translated: those that grow and increase while remaining submerged in the water are “with their heads and eyes turned inward.”🔽“Standing with their heads and eyes turned outward” :🔽they stand after emerging from the water. Among them, those that stand with their heads and eyes turned outward, receiving the rays of the sun, will bloom today. Those that stand in the water

original: ṭhitāni, tāni sve pupphanakāni. Yāni udakā anuggatāni antonimuggaposīni, tāni tatiyadivase
analyzed: ṭhitāni tāni sve pupphanakāni yāni udakā anuggatāni antonimugga posīni tāni tatiya divase
translated: will bloom tomorrow. Those that are submerged in the water, with their heads and eyes turned inward, will bloom on the third day. But there are other lotus flowers, such as the Saroga lotus, that are submerged in the water

original: pupphanakāni. Udakā pana anuggatāni aññānipi sarogauppalādīni nāma atthi, yāni neva🔽pupphissanti macchakacchapabhakkhāneva bhavissanti, tāni pāḷiṃ nāruḷhāni, āharitvā
analyzed: pupphanakāni udakā pana anuggatāni aññāni pi sarogauppala ādīni nāma atthi yāni na iva 🔽pupphissanti maccha kacchapa bhakkhānā iva bhavissanti tāni pāḷim na āruḷhāni āharitvā
translated: and will not bloom at all, but will be eaten by fish and turtles. They are not mentioned in the text.

original: pana dīpetabbānīti aṭṭhakathāyaṃ pakāsitāni. Yatheva hi tāni catubbidhāni pupphāni,
analyzed: pana dīpetabbāni iti aṭṭhakathā ayam pakāsitāni yathā iva hi tāni catubbidhāni pupphāni
translated: But they are to be illustrated, so they are shown in the Commentary.🔽And just as those flowers are of four kinds,

original: evameva ugghaṭitaññū vipañcitaññū neyyo padaparamoti cattāro puggalā.🔽Tattha yassa puggalassa saha udāhaṭavelāya dhammābhisamayo hoti, ayaṃ “cattāro satipaṭṭhānā”tiādinā
analyzed: evam eva ugghaṭita ññū vipañcita ññū neyyaḥ pada paramaḥ ti cattāro puggalā  tattha yassa puggalassa saha udāhaṭa velāya dhamma abhisamayaḥ hoti ayam cattāro sati paṭṭhāna iti ādinā
translated: so too there are four kinds of persons, namely, those who understand from a brief statement, those who understand from an expanded statement, those who are led , and those who are at the peak .🔽Herein, the person in whom there is penetration of the Dhamma when the Thread is stated to him briefly is called one who understands from a brief statement.

original: nayena saṅkhittena mātikāya ṭhapiyamānāya desanānusārena ñāṇaṃ pesetvā arahattaṃ🔽gaṇhituṃ samattho puggalo ugghaṭitaññūti vuccati. Yassa puggalassa saṅkhittena bhāsitassa
analyzed: nayena saṅkhittena mātikāya ṭhapiyamānāya desanā anusārena ñāṇam pesetvā arahattam  gaṇhitum samatthaḥ puggalaḥ ugghaṭita ññū ti vuccati yassa puggalassa saṅkhittena bhāsitassa
translated: He is able to take up the path and reach Arahantship by directing his knowledge in accordance with the teaching when the teaching is set forth in the way beginning, “There are these four foundations of mindfulness” .

original: vitthārena atthe vibhajiyamāne dhammābhisamayo hoti, ayaṃ vuccati puggalo vipañcitaññū.🔽Yassa puggalassa uddesato paripucchato yoniso manasikaroto kalyāṇamitte sevato bhajato
analyzed: vitthārena atthe vibhajiyamāne dhamma abhisamayaḥ hoti ayam vuccati puggalaḥ vipañcitaññū  yassa puggalassa uddesataḥ paripucchataḥ yonisas manasikarotaḥ kalyāṇa mitte sevataḥ bhajato
translated: The person in whom there is penetration of the Dhamma when the meaning is expounded in detail of what was stated briefly is called one who understands from an expanded statement.🔽The person in whom there is penetration of the Dhamma when he is taught the Teaching, questioned about it, and wisely attends to it, and when he frequents, associates with, and venerates good friends is called one who is led.

original: payirupāsato anupubbena dhammābhisamayo hoti, ayaṃ vuccati puggalo neyyo. Yassa puggalassa
analyzed: payirupāsato anupubbena dhamma abhisamayaḥ hoti ayam vuccati puggalo neyyaḥ yassa puggalassa
translated: The person in whom there is penetration of the Dhamma when he is taught the Teaching, questioned about it, and wisely attends to it, and when he frequents, associates with, and venerates good friends is called one who is led.

original: bahumpi suṇato bahumpi bhaṇato bahumpi dhārayato bahumpi vācayato na tāya jātiyā
analyzed: bahumpi suṇataḥ bahumpi bhaṇataḥ bahumpi dhārayataḥ bahumpi vācayataḥ na tāya jātiyā
translated: and though he hears much, speaks much, bears much in mind, and repeats much,

original: dhammābhisamayo hoti, tena attabhāvena maggaṃ vā phalaṃ vā antamaso jhānaṃ vā vipassanaṃ🔽vā nibbattetuṃ na sakkoti, ayaṃ vuccati puggalo padaparamo. Tattha bhagavā uppalavanādisadisaṃ🔽dasasahassilokadhātuṃ olokento ajja pupphanakāni viya ugghaṭitaññū, sve pupphanakāni
analyzed: dhamma abhisamayaḥ hoti tena atta bhāvena maggam vā phalam vā antamasaḥ jhānam vā vipassanam  vā nibbattetum na sakkoti ayam vuccati puggalaḥ pada paramaḥ tattha bhagavā uppala vana ādi sadisam  dasa sahassi lokadhātum olokento ajja pupphanakāni viya ugghaṭita ññū sve pupphanakāni
translated: there is no penetration of the Dhamma in that kind of person. He is incapable of producing the path and fruition, or even jhāna or insight, in that existence.

original: viya vipañcitaññū, tatiyadivase pupphanakāni viya neyye, macchakacchapabhakkhapupphāni🔽viya padaparame ca addasa, passanto ca “ettakā apparajakkhā, ettakā mahārajakkhā,
analyzed: viya tatiya divase pupphanakāni viya neyye maccha kacchapa bhakkha pupphāni  viya pada parame ca addasa passanto ca ettakāḥ apparajakkhāḥ ettakāḥ mahārajakkhāḥ
translated: This kind of person is called “one of the highest type of understanding.” The Blessed One surveyed the ten-thousandfold world element like a mass of flowers in bloom, seeing those of the highest type of understanding like the flowers of the previous day, those of the type ready for further teaching like the flowers of the next day, and those of the type to be developed like the flowers being eaten by the fish and turtles.

original: tatrāpi ettakā ugghaṭitaññū”ti evaṃ sabbākāratova addasa.
analyzed: tatra api ettakā evam sabba ākārataḥ va addasa
translated: And he saw in all aspects how few were the people of the highest type of understanding and how many were the people of the other two types.

original: Tattha tiṇṇaṃ puggalānaṃ imasmiññeva attabhāve bhagavato dhammadesanā atthaṃ sādheti.
analyzed: tattha tiṇṇam puggalānam imasmin ñeva atta bhāve bhagavataḥ dhamma desanā attham sādheti
translated: Herein, the Blessed One’s teaching of the Dhamma succeeds in the case of these three kinds of persons in this very life.

original: Padaparamānaṃ anāgatatthāya vāsanā hoti. Atha bhagavā imesaṃ catunnaṃ puggalānaṃ🔽atthāvahaṃ dhammadesanaṃ viditvā desetukamyataṃ uppādetvā puna sabbepi tīsu bhavesu
analyzed: pada paramānam anāgata tthāya vāsanā hoti atha bhagavā imesam catunnam puggalānam  attha āvaham dhamma desanam viditvā desetu kamyatam uppādetvā puna sabbe api tīsu bhavesu
translated: And the seed of the future fruit is the state of being perfumed.🔽Then, when the Exalted One had seen that the teaching would be fruitful for these four persons, he aroused the desire to teach.

original: satte bhabbābhabbavasena dve koṭṭhāse akāsi. Ye sandhāya vuttaṃ “ye te sattā kammāvaraṇena🔽samannāgatā vipākāvaraṇena samannāgatā kilesāvaraṇena samannāgatā assaddhā acchandikā
analyzed: satte bhabba abhabba vasena dve koṭṭhāse akāsi ye sandhāya vuttam ye te sattā kamma āvaraṇena  samannāgatā vipāka āvaraṇena samannāgatā kilesa āvaraṇena samannāgatā assaddhā acchandikā
translated: Then he divided all beings in the three worlds into two groups according to their ability.

original: duppaññā abhabbā niyāmaṃ okkamituṃ kusalesu dhammesu sammattaṃ, ime te sattā abhabbā.
analyzed: duppaññāḥ abhabbāḥ niyāmam okkamitum kusalesu dhammesu sammattam ime te sattāḥ abhabbā
translated: With reference to them it is said: “Those beings who are hindered by kamma, hindered by the result of kamma, hindered by defilements, who are without faith, without desire, and dull witted, are incapable of entering into the fixed course in skillful dhammas. These beings are incapable.

original: Katame te sattā bhabbā? Ye te sattā na kammāvaraṇena…pe… ime te sattā bhabbā”ti.
analyzed: katame te sattā bhabbā ye te sattā na kamma āvaraṇena pe ime te sattā bhabbā ti
translated: “Which beings are capable? Those beings who are not hindered by kamma … These beings are capable.”

original: Tattha sabbepi abhabbapuggale pahāya bhabbapuggaleyeva ñāṇena pariggahetvā “ettakā
analyzed: tattha sabbe api abhabba puggale pahāya bhabba puggale iva ñāṇena pariggahetvā ettakā
translated: Here the Exalted One, having abandoned all incapable persons, discerned only the capable ones with his knowledge. He then divided them into six groups:

original: rāgacaritā, ettakā dosa, moha, vitakka, saddhā, buddhicaritā”ti cha koṭṭhāse akāsi,
analyzed: rāga caritā ettakā dosa moha vitakka saddhā buddhi caritā ati cha koṭṭhāse akāsi
translated: “So many are of the temperament of lust, so many of the temperament of hatred, of delusion, of thinking, of faith, of wisdom.”

original: evaṃ katvā dhammaṃ desessāmīti cintesi. Ettha ca apparajakkhādibhabbādivasena āvajjentassa
analyzed: evam katvā dhammam desessāmi iti cintesi ettha ca appara jakkha ādi bhabba ādi vasena āvajjentassa
translated: and he thought, “I will teach the Dhamma after doing this.” And here, when he adverts to them by means of the “lesser jhāna” and so on,

original: bhagavato te sattā puñjapuñjāva hutvā upaṭṭhahanti, na ekekāti daṭṭhabbaṃ.🔽Paccabhāsīti patiabhāsi. Apārutāti vivaṭā. Amatassa dvārāti ariyamaggo. So hi amatasaṅkhātassa
analyzed: bhagavataḥ te sattā puñja puñjā ava hutvā upaṭṭhahanti na ekekā iti daṭṭhabbaṃ  paccabhāsi iti apārutā ati vivaṭā amatassa dvārā ati ariya maggo saḥ hi amata saṅkhātassa
translated: those beings appear to him as so many heaps of flesh, and they should be regarded as appearing to him as one.🔽He spoke in reply : he spoke in response. The door to the Deathless : the noble path. For that is the door to the deathless Nibbāna,

original: nibbānassa dvāraṃ, so mayā vivaritvā ṭhapito mahākaruṇūpanissayena sayambhūñāṇena
analyzed: nibbānassa dvāram saḥ mayā vivaritvā ṭhapitaḥ mahā karuṇūpanissayena sayambhū ñāṇena
translated: and he shows that he has opened it and left it open by his own knowledge, which is due to his great compassion.

original: adhigatattāti dasseti. “Apārutaṃ tesaṃ amatassa dvāra”nti keci paṭhanti. Pamuñcantu🔽saddhanti sabbe attano saddhaṃ muñcantu vissajjentu pavedentu, mayā desite dhamme🔽mayi ca attano saddahanākāraṃ uṭṭhāpentūti attho. Pacchimapadadvaye ayamattho – ahañhi
analyzed: adhigata ttā ati dasseti apārutam tesam amatassa dvāran ti keci paṭhanti pamuñcantu  saddhanti sabbe attanaḥ saddham muñcantu vissajjentu pavedentu mayā desite dhamme  mayi ca attano saddahana ākāram uṭṭhāpentu iti pacchima pada dvaye ayam atthaḥ aham hi
translated: Some read “apārutaṃ tesaṃ amatassa dvāraṃ” .

original: attano paguṇaṃ suppavattitampi imaṃ paṇītaṃ uttamaṃ dhammaṃ kāyavācākilamathasaññī
analyzed: attano paguṇam imam paṇītam uttamam dhammam kāya vācā kilamatha saññī
translated: Let them release their faith : let them all release their faith, let them give it scope, let them show it, in the Dhamma taught by me and in me. The meaning is that they should arouse their faith in me. In the last two lines the meaning is this. I have opened the door to the Deathless, which is the noble path, and I have made it well known. But if they do not have faith in me, they will not enter it even though I have opened it and made it well known. So I shall teach the Dhamma in order to arouse faith in them. And I shall teach it in such a way that they will understand it and penetrate it by the attainment of the paths and fruits.

original: hutvā na bhāsiṃ, na bhāsissāmīti cintesiṃ, idāni pana sabbo jano saddhābhājanaṃ upanetu,
analyzed: hutvā na bhāsim na bhāsissāmi iti cintesim idāni pana sabbaḥ janaḥ saddhā bhājanam upanetu
translated: I did not speak, nor did I think, ‘I will not speak.’ But now let all people bring their faith-offering vessels,

original: pūressāmi nesaṃ saṅkappanti. Antaradhāyīti satthāraṃ gandhamālādīhi pūjetvā antarahito,
analyzed: pūressāmi na īsam saṅkappanti antaradhāyi iti satthāram gandha mālā ādīhi pūjetvā antarahitaḥ
translated: and I will fulfill their intention.” “Disappeared”: after worshipping the Teacher with perfumes, garlands, etc., he disappeared,

original: sakaṭṭhānameva gatoti attho. Satthusantikañhi upagatānaṃ devānaṃ brahmānañca tassa
analyzed: saka ṭṭhānam eva gataḥ ti attho satthu santikam hi upagatānam devānam brahmānam ca tassa
translated: and went to his own place, is the meaning. For the gods and Brahmās who approached the Teacher,

original: purato antaradhānaṃ nāma sakaṭṭhānagamanameva.
analyzed: puratas antaradhānam nāma saka ṭṭhāna gamanam eva
translated: to disappear in his presence means only to go to their own places.

original: Brahmayācanakathāvaṇṇanā niṭṭhitā.
analyzed: brahma yācana kathā vaṇṇanā niṭṭhitā
translated: The explanation of the story of the invitation by Brahmā is ended.

original: Pañcavaggiyakathāvaṇṇanā🔽10. Etadahosīti etaṃ ahosi, “kassa nu kho ahaṃ paṭhamaṃ dhammaṃ deseyya”nti ayaṃ🔽dhammadesanāpaṭisaṃyutto vitakko udapādīti attho. Āḷāroti tassa nāmaṃ. Dīghapiṅgalo
analyzed: pañcavaggiya kathā vaṇṇanā  etat ahosi iti etam ahosi kassa nu kho aham paṭhamam dhammam deseyyan ti ayaṃ  dhamma desanā paṭisaṃyuttaḥ vitakkaḥ udapādi iti attho āḷāraḥ ti tassa nāmam dīghapiṅgalo
translated: The explanation of the story of the group-of-five

original: kiresa. So hi tuṅgasarīratāya dīgho, piṅgalacakkhutāya piṅgalo, tenassa “āḷāro”ti
analyzed: kiresa saḥ hi tuṅga sarīra tāya dīghaḥ piṅgala cakkhu tāya piṅgalo tena assa āḷāro ti
translated: “This occurred to him”: this occurred to him: “To whom should I first teach the Dhamma?” This is the meaning. The thought connected with teaching the Dhamma arose in him. Āḷāra means his name. Kālāma means “the dark one.” He was called Āḷāra because he was tall and dark.

original: nāmaṃ ahosi. Kālāmoti gottaṃ. Paṇḍitoti paṇḍiccena samannāgato, samāpattipaṭilābhasaṃsiddhena🔽adhigamabāhusaccasaṅkhātena paṇḍitabhāvena samannāgatoti attho. Byattoti veyyattiyena🔽samannāgato, samāpattipaṭilābhapaccayena pārihārikapaññāsaṅkhātena byattabhāvena
analyzed: nāmam ahosi kālāmo ti gottam paṇḍito ti paṇḍiccena samannāgato samāpatti paṭilābha saṃsiddhena  adhigama bāhusacca saṅkhātena paṇḍita bhāvena samannāgataḥ ti atthaḥ byattaḥ ti veyyattiyena  samannāgataḥ samāpatti paṭilābha paccayena pārihārika paññā saṅkhātena byatta bhāvena
translated: His clan was Kālāma. He was wise: he was endowed with wisdom, with the success of attaining jhāna,🔽with the state of being wise called “great learning.” He was proficient: he was endowed with proficiency, with the proficiency called “insight” that is the result of attaining jhāna,

original: samannāgatoti attho. Medhāvīti ṭhānuppattiyā paññāya samannāgato. Atha vā medhāvīti
analyzed: samannāgataḥ ti atthaḥ medhāvī iti ṭhāna uppattiyā paññāya samannāgataḥ atha vā medhāvī iti
translated: with the state of being proficient. He was intelligent: he was endowed with the wisdom of discerning the right and wrong occasion. Or else he was intelligent

original: tihetukapaṭisandhipaññāsaṅkhātāya taṃtaṃitikattabbatāpaññāsaṅkhātāya ca medhāya samannāgatoti🔽evamettha attho daṭṭhabbo. Apparajakkhajātikoti samāpattiyā vikkhambhitattā nikkilesajātiko
analyzed: ti hetuka paṭisandhi paññā saṅkhātāya taṃ taṃ iti kattabba tā paññā saṅkhātāya ca medhāya samannāgataḥ ti  evam ettha atthaḥ daṭṭhabbo appara jakkha jātiko ti samāpattiyāḥ vikkhambhita ttā nikkilesa jātiko
translated: because he was endowed with the wisdom called “rebirth-linking with three roots” and the wisdom called “the wisdom of knowing what is proper and improper.”

original: visuddhasatto. Ājānissatīti sallakkhessati paṭivijjhissati.🔽Bhagavatopi kho ñāṇaṃ udapādīti bhagavatopi sabbaññutaññāṇaṃ uppajji. Bhagavā kira
analyzed: visuddhasattaḥ ājānissati iti sallakkhessati paṭivijjhissati 🔽bhagavataḥ api kho ñāṇam udapādi iti bhagavataḥ api sabbaññu taññāṇam uppajji bhagavā kira
translated: This is how the meaning should be understood here. He was of good birth: he was of a pure birth, of a birth that was restrained by jhāna. He would understand: he would discern, he would penetrate.

original: devatāya kathiteneva niṭṭhaṃ agantvā sayampi sabbaññutaññāṇena olokento ito sattamadivasamatthake
analyzed: devatāya kathitena iva niṭṭham a gantvā sayam pi sabbaññuta ññāṇena olokento itas sattama divasa matthake
translated: Without being satisfied with the information given by the deity, he himself looked into the matter with his knowledge of omniscience and saw that it would be seven days hence.

original: kālaṃ katvā ākiñcaññāyatane nibbattoti addasa. Taṃ sandhāyāha “bhagavatopi kho ñāṇaṃ🔽udapādī”ti. Mahājāniyoti sattadivasabbhantare pattabbamaggaphalato parihīnattā mahatī🔽jāni parihāni assāti mahājāniyo.
