translated: There they put on their robes, entered the city for alms, and after the meal, when they had finished their business, they rose up into the air again

original: gacchanti. Iti isayo ettha nipatanti uppatanti cāti taṃ ṭhānaṃ “isipatana”nti saṅkhaṃ
analyzed: gacchanti iti isayaḥ ettha nipatanti uppatanti ca ati tam ṭhānam saṅkham
translated: and departed. Thus that place became known as “Isipatana” because the seers alighted there and rose up from there.

original: gataṃ, migānaṃ pana abhayatthāya dinnattā “migadāyo”ti vuccati. Tena vuttaṃ “isipatane
analyzed: gatam migānam pana abhaya tthāya dinna ttā migadāyaḥ ti vuccati tena vuttam isipatane
translated: Therefore it is said, “in the Deer Park at Isipatana.”

original: migadāye”ti. Aññe buddhā paṭhamaṃ dhammadesanatthāya gacchantā ākāsena gantvā tattheva🔽otaranti, amhākaṃ pana bhagavā upakassa ājīvakassa upanissayaṃ disvā “upako imaṃ
analyzed: migadāya iti aññe buddhā paṭhamam dhamma desana tthāya gacchantā ākāsena gantvā tattha eva  otaranti amhākam pana bhagavā upakassa ājīvakassa upanissayam disvā upakaḥ imaṃ
translated: Other Buddhas, when going to teach the Dhamma for the first time, go through the air and alight there.

original: addhānaṃ paṭipanno, so maṃ disvā sallapitvā gamissati, atha puna nibbinno āgamma
analyzed: addhānam paṭipannaḥ saḥ mam disvā sallapitvā gamissati atha puna nibbinnaḥ āgamma
translated: But our Blessed One, seeing that Upaka the Ājīvaka had the necessary latent disposition, thought, “Upaka is traveling this way. He will see me and talk with me. Then he will go away. Later, becoming disenchanted, he will come and

original: arahattaṃ sacchikarissatī”ti ñatvā aṭṭhārasayojanaṃ maggaṃ padasāva agamāsi. Tena
analyzed: arahattam sacchikarissati iti ñatvā aṭṭhārasa yojanam maggam padasāva agamāsi tena
translated: attain arahatship.” Knowing this, he went the eighteen leagues on foot.

original: vuttaṃ “yena bārāṇasī, tena cārikaṃ pakkāmī”ti.🔽11. Antarā ca gayaṃ antarā ca bodhinti gayāya ca bodhissa ca vivare tigāvutantare
analyzed: vuttam yena bārāṇasī tena cārikam pakkāmi iti  antarā ca gayam antarā ca bodhinti gayāya ca bodhiḥ ca vivare
translated: Therefore it is said, “He went on walking tour to Bārāṇasī.”🔽Between Gayā and the Bodhi Tree: in the place between Gayā and the Bodhi Tree, three gavutas distant.

original: ṭhāne. Bodhimaṇḍato hi gayā tīṇi gāvutāni, bārāṇasī aṭṭhārasa yojanāni. Upako bodhimaṇḍassa
analyzed: ṭhāne bodhimaṇḍataḥ hi gayā tīṇi gāvutāni bārāṇasī aṭṭhārasa yojanāni upakaḥ bodhimaṇḍassa
translated: For Gayā is three gavutas from the Bodhi Tree, and Bārāṇasī is eighteen leagues from the Bodhi Tree.

original: ca gayāya ca antare bhagavantaṃ addasa. Antarā-saddena pana yuttattā upayogavacanaṃ🔽kataṃ. Īdisesu ca ṭhānesu akkharacintakā “antarā gāmañca nadiñca yātī”ti evaṃ ekameva
analyzed: ca gayāya ca antare bhagavantam addasa antarāsaddena pana upayoga vacanam  īdisesu ca ṭhānesu akkhara cintakāḥ antarā gāmam ca nadim ca yāti iti evam ekam eva
translated: and between Gayā and Rājagaha. But because of the word ‘between’ the word ‘used’🔽is used. And in such places as this the grammarians use the word ‘between’ once only,

original: antarā-saddaṃ payujjanti, so dutiyapadenapi yojetabbo hoti, ayojiyamāne upayogavacanaṃ
analyzed: antarāsaddam payujjanti saḥ dutiya padena api yojetabbaḥ hoti a yojiyamāne upayoga vacanam
translated: saying ‘between the village and the river he goes’, and it has to be used with the second word as well, and if it is not used in this way the word ‘used’

original: na pāpuṇāti sāmivacanassa pasaṅge antarā-saddayogena upayogavacanassa icchitattā.🔽Idha pana yojetvā eva vutto. Addhānamagganti addhānasaṅkhātaṃ maggaṃ, dīghamagganti
analyzed: na pāpuṇāti sāmi vacanassa pasaṅge antarāsadda yogena upayoga vacanassa icchita ttā  idha pana yojetvā eva vuttaḥ addhāna magganti addhāna saṅkhātam maggam dīgha magganti
translated: is not used. Because of the word ‘between’ being used in the place of the word ‘with’, the word ‘used’ is wanted.

original: attho. Addhānagamanasamayassa vibhaṅge “addhayojanaṃ gacchissāmīti bhuñjitabba”ntiādivacanato🔽addhayojanampi addhānamaggo hoti. Bodhimaṇḍato pana gayā tigāvutaṃ. Vippasannānīti
analyzed: atthaḥ addhāna gamana samayassa vibhaṅge addha yojanam gacchissāmi iti bhuñjitabba nti ādi vacanataḥ  addha yojanam pi addhānamaggaḥ hoti bodhimaṇḍataḥ pana gayā tigāvutam vippasannāni iti
translated: But here it is used after being used with the second word. The ‘road to be gone along’ is the road called ‘to be gone along’, the meaning is ‘long road’. In the analysis of the time of going along the road, because of the words ‘I will go half a league’ and so on,

original: suṭṭhu pasannāni. Indriyānīti manacchaṭṭhāni indriyāni. Parisuddhoti niddoso. Pariyodātoti
analyzed: suṭṭhu pasannāni indriyāni iti manacchaṭṭhāni indriyāni parisuddhaḥ ti niddoso pariyodātā ti
translated: half a league is also a road to be gone along. But from the Bodhi Tree to Gayā it is three gavutas. ‘Clear’ means very clear. ‘Faculties’ means the six faculties with the mind. ‘Pure’ means without defilements. ‘Bright’ means

original: tasseva vevacanaṃ. Nirupakkilesatāyeva hi esa “pariyodāto”ti vutto, na setabhāvena.
analyzed: tassa iva vevacanam nirupakkilesa tāya iva hi esa vuttaḥ na seta bhāvena
translated: and this is a synonym for it. For it is said to be “purified” because it is free from defilement, not because of the whiteness of its colour.

original: Etassa pariyodātataṃ disvāva indriyānaṃ vippasannataṃ aññāsi, nayaggāhīpaññā kiresā tassa ājīvakassa.
analyzed: etassa pariyodāta tam disvāva indriyānam vippasanna tam aññāsi tassa ājīvakassa
translated: Seeing his purifiedness, he knew the clarity of his faculties. This is the kind of understanding that is called “understanding that grasps a guide-line.”

original: Sabbābhibhūti sabbaṃ tebhūmakadhammaṃ abhibhavitvā ṭhito. Sabbavidūti sabbaṃ catubhūmakadhammaṃ
analyzed: sabba abhibhūti sabbam te bhūmaka dhammam abhibhavitvā ṭhitaḥ sabba catu bhūmaka dhammam
translated: “Master of all”: he stands having overcome all states of the three planes. “Omniscient”: he has experienced, known, all states of the four planes.

original: avediṃ aññāsiṃ sabbaso ñeyyāvaraṇassa pahīnattā. Sabbesu dhammesu anūpalittoti sabbesu
analyzed: avedim aññāsim sabbasas ñeyya āvaraṇassa pahīna ttā sabbesu dhammesu an upalitto ti sabbesu
translated: Because the hindrance of the known has been abandoned, he is “all-knowing.” “Unstained by sensual pleasures”:🔽he is not stained by the defilements of lust, hate, delusion, etc.,

original: tebhūmakadhammesu rajjanadussanamuyhanādinā kilesalepena alitto. Sabbañjahoti sabbaṃ🔽tebhūmakadhammaṃ jahitvā ṭhito. Appahātabbampi hi kusalābyākataṃ tappaṭibaddhakilesappahānena
analyzed: tebhūmaka dhammesu rajjana dussana muyhana ādinā kilesa lepena a littaḥ sabbam jahoti sabbam  tebhūmaka dhammam jahitvā ṭhitaḥ a pahātabbam api hi kusala abyākatam tad paṭibaddha kilesa ppahānena
translated: which are the stains of the states of the three planes. “Having renounced all”: he stands having renounced all states of the three planes.🔽For even though the profitable and indeterminate states are not to be abandoned, still they are “renounced” because the defilements bound up with them are abandoned.

original: pahīnattā na hotīti jahitameva hoti. Taṇhakkhaye vimuttoti taṇhakkhaye nibbāne ārammaṇakaraṇavasena
analyzed: pahīna ttā na hoti iti jahitam eva hoti taṇhakkhaye vimutto ti taṇhakkhaye nibbāne ārammaṇa karaṇa vasena
translated: “Liberated through the destruction of craving”: by making craving’s destruction, i.e. Nibbāna, his object,

original: vimutto. Sayaṃ abhiññāyāti sabbaṃ catubhūmakadhammaṃ attanāva jānitvā. Kamuddiseyyanti
analyzed: vimuttaḥ sayam abhiññāya ati sabbam catu bhūmaka dhammam attanā ava jānitvā kam uddiseyyanti
translated: Vimutto: liberated. Sayaṃ abhiññāyāti: having known by himself all the things of the four planes. Kamuddiseyyanti:

original: kaṃ aññaṃ “ayaṃ me ācariyo”ti uddiseyyaṃ.
analyzed: kam aññam ayam me ācariyo ti uddiseyyaṃ
translated: whom else should I point out, saying: “This is my teacher?”

original: Na me ācariyo atthīti lokuttaradhamme mayhaṃ ācariyo nāma natthi. Kiñcāpi hi lokiyadhammānampi
analyzed: na me ācariyaḥ atthi iti lokuttara dhamme mayham ācariyaḥ nāma natthi kiñcā api hi lokiya dhammānam pi
translated: Na me ācariyo atthīti: I have no teacher in the supramundane things. Although in the mundane things,

original: yādiso lokanāthassa adhigamo, na tādiso adhigamo parūpadeso atthi, lokuttaradhamme
analyzed: yādisaḥ lokanāthassa adhigamaḥ na tādisaḥ adhigamaḥ para upadesaḥ atthi lokuttara dhamme
translated: there is no one who has attained like the Lord of the world, there is not even a trace of him in the supramundane things.

original: panassa lesopi natthi. Natthi me paṭipuggaloti mayhaṃ sīlādīhi guṇehi paṭinidhibhūto
analyzed: panassa lesaḥ api natthi natthi me mayham sīla ādīhi guṇehi paṭinidhi bhūtaḥ
translated: Natthi me paṭipuggalo: there is no person who is my equal in virtue and other qualities.

original: puggalo nāma natthi. Sammāsambuddhoti hetunā nayena cattāri saccāni sayaṃ buddho.
analyzed: puggalo nāma na atthi sammāsambuddhaḥ ti hetunā nayena cattāri saccāni sayam buddhaḥ
translated: Sammāsambuddho: having by himself, through the means of the cause, understood the four truths.

original: Sītibhūtoti sabbakilesagginibbāpanena sītibhūto, kilesānaṃ yeva nibbutattā nibbuto.
analyzed: sīti bhūtaḥ ti sabba kilesa aggi nibbāpanena sīti bhūtaḥ kilesānam yā iva nibbuta ttā nibbutaḥ
translated: Sītibhūto: having become cool by extinguishing the fire of all defilements, he is nibbuto, extinguished, because of the extinction of defilements.

original: Kāsinaṃ puranti kāsiraṭṭhe nagaraṃ. Āhañchanti āhanissāmi. Amatadundubhinti veneyyānaṃ
analyzed: kāsinam kāsi raṭṭhe nagaram āhañchanti āhanissāmi amata dundubhinti veneyyānam
translated: Kāsinaṃ puranti: in the city of Kāsī. Āhañcāti: I will go. Amatadundubhinti: the drum of the deathless for the disciples.

original: amatādhigamāya ugghosanādiṃ katvā satthu dhammadesanā “amatadundubhī”ti vuttā, dhammacakkapaṭilābhāya
analyzed: amata adhigamāya ugghosana ādim katvā satthu dhamma desanā amatadundubhī iti vuttā dhammacakka paṭilābhāya
translated: The Exalted One’s discourse on the Dhamma, which he delivered after proclaiming the drumbeat of the Deathless, is called the “drumbeat of the Deathless” .

original: taṃ amatabheriṃ paharissāmīti gacchāmīti vuttaṃ hoti.
analyzed: tam amata bherim paharissāmi iti gacchāmi iti vuttam hoti
translated: I will go to beat the drum of the Deathless, which is the attainment of the Dhamma wheel.

original: Arahasi anantajinoti anantajinopi bhavituṃ yuttoti attho. Anantañāṇo jitakilesoti🔽anantajino. Hupeyyapāvusoti āvuso evampi nāma bhaveyya, evaṃvidhe nāma rūparatane
analyzed: arahasi ananta jino ti ananta jino api bhavitum yutto ti atthaḥ ananta ñāṇaḥ jita kileso ti  ananta jinaḥ āvuso evam pi nāma bhaveyya evaṃvidhe nāma rūpa ratane
translated: You are worthy, O Victorious One beyond compare: the meaning is, you are fit to be victorious beyond compare. He who has infinite knowledge and has conquered the defilements is “victorious beyond compare” .

original: īdisena ñāṇena bhavitabbanti adhippāyo. Ayañhissa pabbajjāya paccayo jāto. Katādhikāro
analyzed: īdisena ñāṇena bhavitabbanti adhippāyaḥ ayam hissa pabbajjāya paccayaḥ jātaḥ kata adhikāraḥ
translated: O Venerable One, you are worthy to be so called: the intention is, “Venerable One, you are worthy to be so called, to be endowed with such a jewel of form and such knowledge.” This was the condition for his going forth.🔽He has done his duty.

original: hesa. Tathā hi bhagavā tena samāgamanatthaṃ padasāva taṃ maggaṃ paṭipajji. Pakkāmīti
analyzed: ha isa tathā hi bhagavā tena samāgamana attham tam maggam paṭipajji pakkāmi iti
translated: For this is why the Exalted One set out on foot along that road in order to meet him. He went forth:

original: vaṅkahārajanapadaṃ nāma agamāsi.🔽Tatthekaṃ migaluddakagāmakaṃ nissāya vāsaṃ kappesi, jeṭṭhakaluddako taṃ upaṭṭhāsi.
analyzed: vaṅkahāra janapadam nāma agamāsi  tattha ekam migaluddaka gāmakam nissāya vāsam kappesi jeṭṭhaka luddakaḥ tam upaṭṭhāsi
translated: he went to a country called Vaṅkaka.🔽There he took up residence near a village of hunters, and the chief hunter attended on him.

original: Tasmiñca janapade caṇḍā makkhikā honti. Atha naṃ ekāya cāṭiyā vasāpesuṃ. Migaluddako
analyzed: tasmin ca janapade caṇḍāḥ makkhikāḥ honti atha nam ekāya cāṭiyā vasāpesum migaluddakaḥ
translated: In that country there were fierce flies. So they had him placed in a basket. The hunter

original: dūraṃ migavaṃ gacchanto “amhākaṃ arahante mā pamajjī”ti cāpaṃ nāma dhītaraṃ āṇāpetvā
analyzed: dūram migavam gacchantaḥ amhākam arahante mā pamajji iti cāpam nāma dhītaram āṇāpetvā
translated: and he sent his daughter Cāpā to him, saying, “Do not be careless of our Arahat.”🔽and went away with his son and his brother. His daughter was beautiful and well-formed.

original: agamāsi saddhiṃ puttabhātukehi. Sā cassa dhītā dassanīyā hoti koṭṭhāsasampannā. Dutiyadivase
analyzed: agamāsi saddhim putta bhātukehi sā ca ssa dhītā dassanīyā hoti koṭṭhāsa sampannā dutiya divase
translated: On the second day

original: upako gharaṃ āgato taṃ dārikaṃ sabbaṃ upacāraṃ katvā parivisituṃ upagataṃ disvā rāgena🔽abhibhūto bhuñjitumpi asakkonto bhājanena bhattaṃ ādāya vasanaṭṭhānaṃ gantvā bhattaṃ
analyzed: upakaḥ gharam āgataḥ tam dārikam sabbam upacāram katvā parivisitum upagatam disvā rāgena  abhibhūtaḥ bhuñjitum pi a sakkontaḥ bhājanena bhattam ādāya vasanaṭṭhānam gantvā bhattam
translated: Upaka came to the house. Seeing the girl serving him with all the attentions, he was overcome with passion.

original: ekamantaṃ nikkhipitvā “sace cāpaṃ labhāmi, jīvāmi. No ce, marāmī”ti nirāhāro sayi.
analyzed: ekamantam nikkhipitvā sace cāpam labhāmi jīvāmi no ce marāmi iti nirāhāraḥ
translated: Unable to eat, he took his food in a vessel, went to his lodging, and put the food aside. “If I can get Cāpā,” he thought, “I shall live. If not, I shall die.” And he lay down without eating.

original: Sattame divase māgaviko āgantvā dhītaraṃ upakassa pavattiṃ pucchi. Sā “ekadivasameva🔽āgantvā puna nāgatapubbo”ti āha.
analyzed: sattame divase māgavikaḥ āgantvā dhītaram upakassa pavattim pucchi sā eka divasam eva  āgantvā puna na āgata pubbā iti āha
translated: On the seventh day the hunter came and asked his daughter about Upaka. She said, “He came one day and has not been here since.”

original: Māgaviko āgataveseneva naṃ upasaṅkamitvā pucchissāmīti taṅkhaṇaṃyeva gantvā “kiṃ,
analyzed: māgavikaḥ āgata vesena iva nam upasaṅkamitvā pucchissāmi iti gantvā kim
translated: The hunter thought, “I will go and ask him as soon as he comes.” So he went at once and asked, “Why do you not come to my house any more?”🔽“I have no desire for your daughter.”

original: bhante, aphāsuka”nti pāde parāmasanto pucchi. Upako nitthunanto parivattatiyeva.🔽So “vada bhante, yaṃ mayā sakkā kātuṃ, sabbaṃ karissāmī”ti āha. Upako “sace cāpaṃ🔽labhāmi, jīvāmi, no ce, mayhameva maraṇaṃ seyyo”ti āha. Jānāsi kira, bhante, kiñci
analyzed: bhante a phāsukanti pāde parāmasantaḥ pucchi upakaḥ nitthunantaḥ  saḥ vada bhante yam mayā sakkā kātum sabbam karissāmi iti āha upakaḥ sace cāpam  labhāmi jīvāmi no ce mayham eva maraṇam āha jānāsi kira bhante kiñci
translated: and he asked him, “Venerable sir, I am not well.” Upaka turned over and over, unable to get up.

original: sippanti? Na jānāmīti. Na, bhante, kiñci sippaṃ ajānantena sakkā gharāvāsaṃ adhiṭṭhātunti.🔽So āha “nāhaṃ kiñci sippaṃ jānāmi, apica tumhākaṃ maṃsahārako bhavissāmi, maṃsañca🔽vikkiṇissāmī”ti. Māgaviko “amhākampi etadeva ruccatī”ti uttarasāṭakaṃ datvā gharaṃ
analyzed: sippanti na jānāmi iti na bhante kiñci sippam a jānantena sakkā ghara āvāsam adhiṭṭhātunti  saḥ āha na aham kiñci sippam jānāmi apica tumhākam maṃsa hārakaḥ bhavissāmi maṃsam ca  vikkiṇissāmi iti māgavikaḥ amhākam pi etat eva ruccati iti uttara sāṭakam da tvā gharam
translated: “Say, venerable sir, what I can do. I will do all.” Upaka said, “If I can get a bow, I shall live; if not, it is better for me to die.” “Do you know, venerable sir, any craft?” “I do not know any.” “Venerable sir, it is not possible to live in a house without knowing any craft.”

original: ānetvā dhītaraṃ adāsi. Tesaṃ saṃvāsamanvāya putto vijāyi, “subhaddo”tissa nāmaṃ akaṃsu.
analyzed: ānetvā dhītaram adāsi tesam saṃvāsam anvāya putto vijāyi subhaddā tissa nāmam akaṃsu
translated: He said, “I do not know any craft. However, I will be a flesh-carrier for you, and I will sell the flesh.” The hunter said, “That is what we want.” He gave him the upper robe, took him home, and gave him his daughter. They lived together, and a son was born to them. They named him Subhadda.

original: Cāpā tassa rodanakāle “maṃsahārakassa putta migaluddakassa putta mā rodi mā rodī”tiādīni
analyzed: cāpā tassa rodana kāle maṃsahārakassa putta migaluddakassa putta mā rodi mā rodi itiādīni
translated: When Cāpā’s son cried, she said, “Son of a flesh-carrier, son of a deer-hunter, do not cry, do not cry.”

original: vadamānā puttatosanagītena upakaṃ uppaṇḍesi. “Bhadde tvaṃ maṃ anāthoti maññasi, atthi
analyzed: vadamānā putta tosana gītena upakam uppaṇḍesi bhadde tvam mama anāthaḥ iti maññasi atthi
translated: and she mocked him with a song about a son. “Dear, you think I’m helpless, but

original: me anantajino nāma sahāyo, tassāhaṃ santikaṃ gamissāmī”ti āha. Cāpā “evamayaṃ aṭṭīyatī”ti
analyzed: me anantajinaḥ nāma sahāyaḥ tassa aham santikam gamissāmi iti āha cāpā evam ayam aṭṭīyati iti
translated: I have a friend called Anantajina. I’ll go to him.” Cāpā thought, “He’s being tormented,”

original: ñatvā punappunaṃ kathesi. So ekadivasaṃ anārocetvāva majjhimadesābhimukho pakkāmi.
analyzed: ñatvā punappunam kathesi saḥ eka divasam an ārocetvā ava majjhima desa abhimukhaḥ pakkāmi
translated: and she spoke to him again and again. One day he left without telling her, heading for the Middle Country.

original: Bhagavā ca tena samayena sāvatthiyaṃ viharati jetavane, atha kho bhagavā paṭikacceva
analyzed: bhagavā ca tena samayena sāvatthiyam viharati jetavane atha kho bhagavā paṭikaccā iva
translated: At that time the Buddha was staying at Sāvatthī in Jeta’s Grove. The Buddha then instructed the monks,

original: bhikkhū āṇāpesi “yo, bhikkhave, anantajinoti pucchamāno āgacchati, tassa maṃ dasseyyāthā”ti.
analyzed: bhikkhū āṇāpesi yaḥ bhikkhave pucchamānaḥ āgacchati tassa mama dasseyyātha ati
translated: saying, “If anyone comes asking for Anantajina, show him to me.”

original: Upakopi kho “kuhiṃ anantajino vasatī”ti pucchanto anupubbena sāvatthiṃ āgantvā vihāramajjhe
analyzed: upakaḥ api kho kuhim ananta jinaḥ vasati iti pucchantaḥ anupubbena sāvatthim āgantvā vihāra majjhe
translated: Upaka went to Sāvatthī, asking, “Where does Anantajina live?” He stood in the middle of the monastery

original: ṭhatvā “kuhiṃ anantajino”ti pucchi. Taṃ bhikkhū bhagavato santikaṃ nayiṃsu. So ca

analyzed: anuyogaḥ kilesa kāma saṃyuttassa sukhassa anugataḥ ti atthaḥ hīnaḥ iti lāmakaḥ gammaḥ ti gāma vāsīnam
translated: “Following” : it is followed by the pleasure associated with defilement. “Low” : inferior. “Vulgar” : common to the villagers.

original: santako tehi sevitabbatāya. Pothujjanikoti puthujjanena andhabālajanena āciṇṇo. Anariyoti
analyzed: santako tehi sevitabba tāya pothujjanikaḥ iti puthujjanena andha bāla janena āciṇṇaḥ anariyaḥ ti
translated: “Common” : common to them, because they frequent it. “Mundane” : frequented by the world, by the blind fools. “Unedifying” :

original: na ariyo na visuddho na uttamo, na vā ariyānaṃ santako. Anatthasaṃhitoti na atthasaṃhito,
analyzed: na ariyaḥ na visuddhaḥ na uttamaḥ na vā ariyānam santakaḥ anattha saṃhitaḥ ti na attha saṃhitaḥ
translated: not edifying, not pure, not noble, not common to the Noble Ones. “Unbeneficial” : not beneficial,

original: hitasukhāvahakāraṇaṃ anissitoti attho. Attakilamathānuyogoti attano kilamathassa
analyzed: hita sukha āvaha kāraṇam anissitaḥ ti atthaḥ atta kilamatha anuyogaḥ ti attanaḥ kilamathassa
translated: not a means of bringing about welfare and pleasure. “Self-tormenting” : tormenting oneself,

original: anuyogo, dukkhakaraṇaṃ dukkhuppādananti attho. Dukkhoti kaṇṭakāpassayaseyyādīhi attabādhanehi🔽dukkhāvaho. Majjhimā paṭipadāti ariyamaggaṃ sandhāya vuttaṃ. Maggo hi kāmasukhallikānuyogo
analyzed: anuyogaḥ dukkha karaṇam dukkha uppādananti atthaḥ dukkhaḥ ti kaṇṭaka apassaya seyya ādīhi atta bādhanehi  dukkha āvahaḥ majjhimā paṭipadā ti ariya maggam sandhāya vuttam maggaḥ hi kāma sukhallikā anuyogaḥ
translated: causing suffering, producing suffering, is the meaning. “Painful” : bringing pain through such self-torment as sleeping on a bed of thorns.🔽“The middle way” is said with reference to the Noble Path. For the path does not approach either of these two extremes, it does not go to either, but

original: eko anto, attakilamathānuyogo eko anto, ete dve ante na upeti na upagacchati, vimutto
analyzed: ekaḥ antaḥ atta kilamatha anuyogaḥ ekaḥ antaḥ ete dve ante na upeti na upagacchati vimuttaḥ
translated: goes beyond both, being free from the extreme of indulgence in sensual pleasure and the extreme of self-torment.

original: etehi antehi, tasmā “majjhimā paṭipadā”ti vuccati. Etesaṃ majjhe bhavattā majjhimā,🔽vaṭṭadukkhanissaraṇatthikehi paṭipajjitabbato ca paṭipadāti, tathā lobho eko anto,
analyzed: etehi antehi tasmā majjhimā paṭipadā ati vuccati etesam majjhe bhavattā majjhimā  vaṭṭa dukkha nissaraṇa atthikehi paṭipajjitabbato ca paṭipadā ati tathā lobho ekaḥ antaḥ
translated: It is called the Middle Way because it is free from these extremes. It is the middle because it occurs in the middle between these two,🔽and it is the way because it is the way to be practised by those who seek deliverance from the suffering of the round.

original: doso eko anto. Sassataṃ ekaṃ antaṃ, ucchedo eko antoti purimanayeneva vitthāretabbaṃ.
analyzed: dosaḥ ekaḥ antaḥ sassatam ekam antam ucchedaḥ ekaḥ antaḥ ti purima nayena iva vitthāretabbam
translated: And greed is one extreme, and hate is one extreme. Eternalism is one extreme, and annihilationism is one extreme. This should be expanded as in the previous case.

original: Cakkhukaraṇītiādīhi tameva paṭipadaṃ thometi. Paññācakkhuṃ karotīti cakkhukaraṇī.
analyzed: cakkhukaraṇī itiādīhi tam eva paṭipadam thometi paññācakkhum karoti iti cakkhukaraṇī
translated: He extols that same way in the next clause, “making for the eye of wisdom.” It makes the eye of wisdom, thus it is making for the eye of wisdom.

original: Sā hi catunnaṃ saccānaṃ dassanāya saṃvattati pariññābhisamayādibhedassa dassanassa🔽pavattanaṭṭhenāti “cakkhukaraṇī”ti vuccati. Tayidaṃ satipi paṭipadāya anaññatte avayavavasena
analyzed: sā hi catunnam saccānam dassanāya saṃvattati pariññā abhisamaya ādi bhedassa dassanassa  pavattana ṭṭhena ati cakkhukaraṇī iti vuccati tayidam sati pi paṭipadāya an aññatte avayava vasena
translated: For it leads to the seeing of the four noble truths, to the seeing consisting in full understanding, penetration, etc.,🔽by acting as the proximate cause for it. That is why it is called “making for the eye of wisdom.” And although the way is not different from itself, still the meaning is established by analysis into its component parts,

original: sijjhamāno attho samudāyena kato nāma hotīti upacāravasena vuttanti daṭṭhabbaṃ. Dutiyapadaṃ
analyzed: sijjhamānaḥ atthaḥ samudāyena kataḥ nāma hoti iti upacāra vasena vuttan ti daṭṭhabbam dutiya padam
translated: and so it is as if the way were made up of the collection of these component parts. So it should be regarded as stated by a figurative use of speech. The second clause

original: tasseva vevacanaṃ. Upasamāyāti kilesupasamatthāya. Abhiññāyāti catunnaṃ saccānaṃ
analyzed: tassa iva vevacanam upasamāyāti kilesa upasamatthāya abhiññāyāti catunnam saccānam
translated: is a synonym for the first. For peace: for the peace of defilements. For direct knowledge: for the direct knowledge of the four noble truths.

original: abhijānanatthāya. Sambodhāyāti tesaṃyeva sambujjhanatthāya. Nibbānāyāti nibbānasacchikiriyāya.
analyzed: abhijānana tthāya sambodhāya ati tesam yeva sambujjhana tthāya nibbānāya ati nibbāna sacchikiriyāya
translated: For the purpose of direct knowledge. For the purpose of full enlightenment: for the purpose of their full enlightenment. For the purpose of Nibbāna: for the realization of Nibbāna.

original: Atha vā nibbānāyāti anupādisesanibbānāya. “Upasamāyā”ti hi iminā saupādisesanibbānaṃ gahitaṃ.
analyzed: atha vā nibbānāya ati anupādisesa nibbānāya upasamāyāti hi iminā sa aupādisesa nibbānam gahitam
translated: Or alternatively, for the purpose of Nibbāna: for Nibbāna without trace left. For ‘for peace’ refers to Nibbāna with trace left.

original: Idāni taṃ majjhimappaṭipadaṃ sarūpato dassetukāmo “katamā ca sā”ti pucchitvā “ayamevā”tiādinā
analyzed: idāni tam majjhima ppaṭipadam sarūpataḥ dassetu kāmo katamā ca sā ati pucchitvā ayam eva ati ādinā
translated: Now, wanting to show the middle way as it is, he asks, ‘And what is that middle way?’ and he answers with ‘This Noble Eightfold Path’ and so on.

original: nayena vissajjesi. Tattha ayamevāti avadhāraṇavacanaṃ aññassa nibbānagāmimaggassa
analyzed: nayena vissajjesi tattha ayam eva ati avadhāraṇa vacanam aññassa nibbāna gāmi maggassa
translated: Herein, this is a delimiting expression. It is intended to deny the existence of any other path leading to Nibbāna.

original: atthibhāvapaṭisedhanatthaṃ. Sattāpaṭikkhepo hi idha paṭisedhanaṃ alabbhamānattā aññassa🔽maggassa. Ariyoti kilesānaṃ ārakattā ariyo niruttinayena. Aripahānāya saṃvattatītipi
analyzed: atthi bhāva paṭisedhana attham sattā a paṭikkhepaḥ hi idha paṭisedhanam a labbhamāna ttā aññassa  maggassa ariyaḥ ti kilesānam ārakattā ariyaḥ nirutti nayena ari pahānāya saṃvattati iti pi
translated: For the denial here is of a being, not of another path, because there is no such other path.🔽Noble: noble because it is far from defilements in the sense of being remote from them. It is also noble because it leads to the abandoning of what is not noble, that is, because evil persons go away from it and leave it.

original: ariyo arayo pāpadhammā yanti apagacchanti etenāti katvā. Ariyena bhagavatā desitattā
analyzed: ariyaḥ arayaḥ pāpa dhammāḥ yanti apagacchanti etena ati katvā ariyena bhagavatā desita ttā
translated: And it is noble because it was taught by the noble Enlightened One.

original: ariyassa ayantipi ariyo, ariyabhāvappaṭilābhāya saṃvattatītipi ariyo. Ettha pana
analyzed: ariyassa ayan tipi ariyaḥ ariya bhāva paṭilābhāya saṃvattati iti ariyaḥ ettha pana
translated: and it is noble because it is the going of the noble ones. It is noble too because it leads to the acquisition of the noble state. Herein,

original: ariyakaro ariyotipi uttarapadalopena ariya-saddasiddhi veditabbā. Aṭṭhahi aṅgehi
analyzed: uttara pada lopena veditabbā aṭṭhahi aṅgehi
translated: however, the derivation of the word ariya should be understood as follows: it is ariya because it makes for ariyaness . It is an eight-factored

original: upetattā aṭṭhaṅgiko. Maggaṅgasamudāye hi maggavohāro, samudāyo ca samudāyīhi samannāgato
analyzed: upeta ttā aṭṭhaṅgikaḥ magga aṅga samudāye hi magga vohāro samudāyo ca samudāyīhi samannāgato
translated: path because it is endowed with eight factors. For the term “path” is a collective term for the factors of the path, and a collection is called the🔽same name as its components. But the word-meaning here is this: it has

original: nāma hoti. Ayaṃ panettha vacanattho – attano avayavabhūtāni aṭṭhaṅgāni etassa santīti🔽aṭṭhaṅgikoti. Paramatthato pana aṅgāniyeva maggo pañcaṅgikatūriyādīni viya, na ca🔽aṅgavinimutto chaḷaṅgo vedo viya. Kilese mārento gacchatīti maggo niruttinayena,🔽nibbānaṃ maggati gavesatīti vā maggo. Ariyamaggo hi nibbānaṃ ārammaṇaṃ karonto gavesanto
analyzed: nāma hoti ayam pana ittha vacana atthaḥ attanaḥ avayava bhūtāni aṭṭhaṅgāni etassa santi iti  aṭṭhaṅgiko ti paramatthato pana maggo pañcaṅgika tūriya ādīni na ca  aṅga vinimutto chaṭṭha aṅgaḥ vedaḥ viya kilese mārentaḥ gacchati iti maggaḥ nirutti nayena  nibbānam maggati gavesati iti vā maggaḥ ariya maggaḥ hi nibbānam ārammaṇam karontaḥ gavesantaḥ
translated: eight factors that are its own components, thus it is an eight-factored

original: viya hoti. Nibbānatthikehi maggīyatīti vā maggo vivaṭṭūpanissayapuññakaraṇato paṭṭhāya
analyzed: viya hoti nibbāna atthikehi maggīyati iti vā maggaḥ vivaṭṭu upanissaya puñña karaṇataḥ paṭṭhāya
translated: path . But in the ultimate sense the path is the factors themselves, as in the case of the five- factored tune, and it is not a six-factored path with the factors added, as in the case of the Vedas. It is a path because it goes by killing defilements, according to the method of verbal root etymologies . Or alternatively, it is a path because it seeks , i.e. seeks out, nibbāna. For the noble path is as if it were seeking nibbāna by making it its object. Or it is a path because it is gone by those who seek nibbāna. Or it is a path because it is gone by those who make merit that is a proximate condition for nibbāna, beginning with the giving of a mere handful of boiled rice.

original: tadatthapaṭipattito. Gammati vā tehi paṭipajjīyatīti maggo. Ettha pana ādiantavipariyāyena🔽saddasiddhi veditabbā.
analyzed: tad attha paṭipattitaḥ gammati vā tehi paṭipajjīyati iti maggaḥ ettha pana ādi anta vipariyāyena  sadda siddhi veditabbā
translated: and by the practice of their meaning. Or alternatively, it is a path because it is gone by means of them. Herein, the derivation of the word should be understood in the opposite sense to that given in the Paṭisambhidā:🔽“The path is so called because it is gone by means of the eight factors, that is, right view, and so on” .

original: Seyyathidanti nipāto, tassa katamo so iti ceti attho, katamāni vā tāni aṭṭhaṅgānīti.
analyzed: nipātaḥ tassa katamaḥ saḥ iti ca iti attho katamāni vā tāni aṭṭhaṅgāni iti
translated: The word “namely” is a demonstrative; its meaning is “which.” The meaning is: which are those eight factors?

original: Sabbaliṅgavibhattivacanasādhāraṇo hi ayaṃ nipāto. Ekamekampi aṅgaṃ maggoyeva. Yathāha
analyzed: sabba liṅga vibhatti vacana sādhāraṇaḥ hi ayam nipātaḥ ekam ekam pi aṅgam yathā āha
translated: For this word is common to all cases, genders, and numbers. And each factor is a path. As it is said:🔽“Right view is a path and a cause” . And the Ancients said:

original: “sammādiṭṭhi maggo ceva hetu cā”ti. Porāṇāpi bhaṇanti “dassanamaggo sammādiṭṭhi,
analyzed: sammādiṭṭhi maggo ca iva hetu ca ati porāṇā api bhaṇanti dassana maggo sammādiṭṭhi
translated: “The path of seeing is right view,

original: abhiniropanamaggo sammāsaṅkappo…pe… avikkhepamaggo sammāsamādhī”ti. Nanu ca aṅgāni
analyzed: abhiniropana maggo sammāsaṅkappa upe avikkhepa maggo sammāsamādhi iti nanu ca aṅgāni
translated: the path of preparation is right thought, … the path of purification is right effort, … the path of relinquishment is right mindfulness, … the path of non-confusion is right concentration” .🔽But are not the factors collectively the path, since there is no noble path consisting of fewer than eight factors?

original: samuditāni maggo antamaso sattaṅgavikalassa ariyamaggassa abhāvatoti? Saccametaṃ🔽saccasampaṭivedhe, maggappaccayatāya pana yathāsakaṃ kiccakaraṇena paccekampi tāni
analyzed: samuditāni maggaḥ antamasaḥ sattaṅga vikalassa ariya maggassa abhāvato ti saccam etam  sacca sampaṭivedhe magga ppaccaya tāya pana yathāsakam kicca karaṇena paccekam pi tāni
translated: That is true,🔽but in the penetration of the four truths each one individually is a path because it performs the function of a path by accomplishing its particular function. Otherwise the function of the path would not be accomplished even by the combined factors.

original: maggoyeva, aññathā samuditānampi tesaṃ maggakiccaṃ na sambhaveyyāti. Sammādiṭṭhiādīsu
analyzed: maggo yā iva aññathā samuditānam pi tesam magga kiccam na sambhaveyya ati sammādiṭṭhi ādīsu
translated: As regards right view, etc.,

original: sammā passatīti sammādiṭṭhi, sammā saṅkappeti sampayuttadhamme nibbānasaṅkhāte ārammaṇe🔽abhiniropetīti sammāsaṅkappo, sammā vadati etāyāti sammāvācā, sammā karoti etenāti🔽sammākammaṃ, tadeva sammākammanto, sammā ājīvati etenāti sammāājīvo, sammā vāyamati
analyzed: sammā passati iti sammā diṭṭhi sammā saṅkappeti sampayutta dhamme nibbāna saṅkhāte ārammaṇe  abhiniropeti iti sammā saṅkappaḥ sammā vadati etāya ati sammā vācā sammā karoti etena ati  sammākammam tat eva sammākammantaḥ sammā ājīvati etena ati sammāājīvaḥ sammā vā āyamati
translated: He sees rightly, thus it is right view. He resolves the states associated with it on to the object called Nibbāna, thus it is right thought. He speaks rightly by means of this, thus it is right speech. He does rightly by means of this, thus it is right action. That itself is right action. He makes a living rightly by means of this, thus it is right livelihood. He strives rightly by means of this, thus it is right effort.

original: ussahatīti sammāvāyāmo, sammā sarati anussaratīti sammāsati, sammā samādhiyati cittaṃ
analyzed: ussahati iti sammā vāyāmaḥ sammā sarati anussarati iti sammā sati sammā samādhiyati cittam
translated: He sees rightly, thus it is right view. He resolves the associated states on to the object called Nibbāna, thus it is right resolve. He speaks rightly by means of this, thus it is right speech. He acts rightly by means of this, thus it is right action. That same right action is right livelihood. He strives rightly, thus it is right effort. He remembers rightly, thus it is right mindfulness. He concentrates rightly by means of this, thus it is right concentration. This is how the derivation should be understood.

original: etenāti sammāsamādhīti evaṃ nibbacanaṃ veditabbaṃ. Idāni ayaṃ kho sā bhikkhaveti🔽tameva paṭipadaṃ nigamento āha. Tassattho – yvāyaṃ cattāropi lokuttaramagge ekato
analyzed: etena ati sammāsamādhi iti evam nibbacanam veditabbam idāni ayam kho sā bhikkhave ti  tam eva paṭipadam nigamentaḥ āha tassa atthaḥ yvā ayam cattāraḥ api lokuttara magge ekatas
translated: Now, as to the words, “This, bhikkhus, is the middle way”:

original: katvā kathito aṭṭhaṅgiko maggo, ayaṃ kho sā bhikkhave…pe… nibbānāya saṃvattatīti.
analyzed: katvā kathitaḥ aṭṭhaṅgikaḥ maggo ayam kho sā bhikkha vepe nibbānāya saṃvattati iti
translated: he said this in order to conclude that same way. Its meaning is this. This Noble Eightfold Path, which is taught by combining the four supramundane paths together, is the middle way, bhikkhus, which … leads to Nibbana.🔽Having thus shown the middle way by its characteristics, he now said,

original: 14. Evaṃ majjhimapaṭipadaṃ sarūpato dassetvā idāni cattāri ariyasaccāni dassetuṃ
analyzed: evam majjhima paṭipadam sarūpataḥ dassetvā idāni cattāri ariya saccāni dassetum
translated: in order to show the four noble truths,

original: “idaṃ kho pana, bhikkhave”tiādimāha. Tattha dukkhanti ettha du-iti ayaṃ saddo kucchite
analyzed: idam kho pana bhikkhave ti ādim āha tattha dukkham ti ettha ayam saddo kucchite
translated: “But this, bhikkhus,” he said. Herein, suffering: here the prefix du- is seen to have the sense of badness.

original: dissati. Kucchitañhi puttaṃ “duputto”ti vadanti, khaṃ-saddo pana tucche. Tucchañhi
analyzed: dissati kucchitam hi puttam du putto ti vadanti khaṃsaddaḥ pana tucche tuccham hi
translated: For they call a bad son “du son” . The prefix kha- has the sense of voidness.🔽For they call void space “kha” .

original: ākāsaṃ “kha”nti vuccati. Idañca paṭhamasaccaṃ kucchitaṃ anekaupaddavādhiṭṭhānato,🔽tucchaṃ bālajanaparikappitadhuvasubhasukhattabhāvavirahitato, tasmā kucchitattā tucchattā
analyzed: ākāsam khanti vuccati idam ca paṭhama saccam kucchitam aneka opaddava adhiṭṭhānato  tuccham tuccha tā
translated: And this first truth is bad because it is the basis for the many calamities beginning with ageing,🔽and it is void because it is devoid of the permanence, beauty, pleasure, and self that fools imagine in it. That is why it is called “suffering” because it is bad and because it is void.

original: ca “dukkha”nti vuccati. Yasmā panetaṃ buddhādayo ariyā paṭivijjhanti, tasmā “ariyasacca”nti
analyzed: ca dukkhanti vuccati yasmai pana etam buddha ādayaḥ ariyā paṭivijjhanti tasmai ariya saccanti
translated: But since it is penetrated by Noble Ones beginning with the Buddhas, it is called “a noble truth.”

original: vuccati. Ariyapaṭivijjhitabbañhi saccaṃ purimapade uttarapadalopena “ariyasacca”nti
analyzed: vuccati ariya paṭivijjhitabbam hi saccam purima pade uttara pada lopena ariya saccanti
translated: For the truth that should be penetrated by Noble Ones is called “a noble truth” by ellipsis of the middle term.

original: vuttaṃ. Ariyassa tathāgatassa saccantipi ariyasaccaṃ. Tathāgatena hi sayaṃ adhigatattā
analyzed: vuttam ariyassa tathāgatassa ariya saccam ti pi ariya saccam tathāgatena hi sayam adhigata ttā
translated: And it is also a noble truth in the sense that it is a truth for the Noble One, the Enlightened One, because it was discovered by the Enlightened One himself.

original: paveditattā tato eva ca aññehi adhigamanīyattā taṃ tassa hotīti. Atha vā etassa abhisambuddhattā🔽ariyabhāvasiddhito ariyasādhakaṃ saccantipi ariyasaccaṃ pubbe viya uttarapadalopena.
analyzed: pavedita ttā tatas eva ca aññehi adhigamanīya ttā tam tassa hoti iti atha vā etassa abhisambuddha ttā  ariya bhāva siddhitaḥ ariya sādhakam ariya saccam pubbe uttara pada lopena
translated: and because it is announced, and because it is to be reached by others after him, it is his.🔽Or alternatively, it is noble because it is accomplished by the noble path, and it is truth because it is not otherwise, and it is noble and truth, thus it is a noble truth, in the way already stated with the omission of the middle term.

original: Avitathabhāvena vā araṇīyattā adhigantabbattā ariyaṃ saccantipi ariyasaccaṃ. Saccatthaṃ
analyzed: avitatha bhāvena vā araṇīya ttā adhigantabba ttā ariyam ariya saccam saccattham
translated: Or alternatively, it is noble because it is to be reached by the noble , and it is truth because it is not otherwise, thus it is a noble truth.

original: pana catunnampi saccānaṃ parato ekajjhaṃ dassayissāma.
analyzed: pana catunnam pi saccānam paratas ekajjham dassayissāma
translated: But the meaning of truth in the case of all four truths will be given later in the section dealing with the four truths as a whole .

original: Idāni taṃ dukkhaṃ ariyasaccaṃ sarūpato dassetuṃ “jātipi dukkhā”tiādimāha. Tatrāyaṃ
analyzed: idāni tam dukkham ariya saccam sarūpataḥ dassetum dukkha ati ādim āha tatra ayam
translated: Now, in order to show the noble truth of suffering in its individual essence, he said “Birth is suffering” . Herein,

original: jāti-saddo anekattho. Tathā hesa “ekampi jātiṃ dvepi jātiyo”ti ettha bhave āgato.
analyzed: jāti saddaḥ aneka atthaḥ tathā ha esa ekam pi jātim dve pi jātiyaḥ iti ettha bhave āgataḥ
translated: the word birth has many meanings. For it is found in the sense of becoming in such passages as “One birth, two births” ,🔽in the sense of a sect in such passages as “There are, Visākhā, certain recluses and brahmans who are of the first birth” ,

original: “Atthi, visākhe, nigaṇṭhā nāma samaṇajātī”ti ettha nikāye. “Jāti dvīhi khandhehi
analyzed: atthi visākhe nigaṇṭhā nāma samaṇa jātī iti ettha nikāye jāti dvīhi khandhehi
translated: in the sense of a characteristic of the formed in such passages as “Birth is included in two aggregates” ,

original: saṅgahitā”ti ettha saṅkhatalakkhaṇe. “Yaṃ mātukucchismiṃ paṭhamaṃ cittaṃ uppannaṃ
analyzed: saṅgahitā ati ettha saṅkhata lakkhaṇe yam mātukucchismim paṭhamam cittam uppannam

analyzed: saṃkhittena pañca upādānakkhandhāḥ dukkhā ti ettha pana yasmai indhanam iva pāvakaḥ lakkham iva  paharaṇāni go rūpam viya ḍaṃsama kasā ādayaḥ khettam iva lāyakāḥ gāmam viya gāma ghātakā  upādāna kkhandha pañcakam eva jāti ādayaḥ nānā pakārehi tiṇa latā ādīni viya bhūmiyam
translated: In brief, the five aggregates as objects of clinging are suffering: here, just as fire burns fuel, just as a saw cuts wood, just as a needle pierces cloth,🔽just as a pestle pounds grain, just as a scythe cuts grass, just as a razor shaves hair, just as a knife cuts meat, just as a hook pulls out a fish, just as a snare catches deer, just as a net catches birds, just as a noose catches cattle, just as a thief breaks into a house, just as a murderer kills a man, just as a fire burns a forest, just as a saw cuts wood, just as a needle pierces cloth,

analyzed: puppha phala pallavāni viya rukkhesu upādānakkhandhesu yeva nibbattanti upādānakkhandhānam ca

original: ādidukkhaṃ jāti, majjhedukkhaṃ jarā, pariyosānadukkhaṃ maraṇaṃ, manorathavighātappattānañca
analyzed: ādi dukkham jāti majjhedukkham jarā pariyosāna dukkham maraṇam manoratha vighāta pattānam ca
translated: just as a pestle pounds grain, just as a scythe cuts grass, just as a razor shaves hair, just as a knife cuts meat, just as a hook pulls out a fish, just as a snare catches deer, just as a net catches birds, just as a noose catches cattle, just as a thief breaks into a house, just as a murderer kills a man, just as a fire burns a forest, just as a saw cuts wood, just as a needle pierces cloth,

original: icchāvighātadukkhaṃ icchitālābhoti evaṃ nānappakārato upaparikkhiyamānā upādānakkhandhāva🔽dukkhāti yadetaṃ ekamekaṃ dassetvā vuccamānaṃ anekehipi kappehi na sakkā anavasesato
analyzed: icchā vighāta dukkham icchitā lābhaḥ ti evam nānā pakārataḥ upaparikkhiyamānāḥ upādāna kkhandhāḥ ava 🔽dukkhā iti yat etam ekam ekam dassetvā vuccamānam anekehi pi kappehi na sakkā anavasesato
translated: just as a pestle pounds grain, just as a scythe cuts grass, just as a razor shaves hair, just as a knife cuts meat, just as a hook pulls out a fish, just as a snare catches deer, just as a net catches birds, just as a noose catches cattle, just as a thief breaks into

original: vattuṃ, tasmā taṃ sabbampi dukkhaṃ ekajalabindumhi sakalasamuddajalarasaṃ viya yesu🔽kesuci pañcupādānakkhandhesu saṅkhipitvā dassetuṃ “saṃkhittena pañcupādānakkhandhā
analyzed: vattum tasmā tam sabbam pi dukkham eka jala bindumhi sakala samudda jala rasam viya yesu  kesuci pañca upādānakkhandhesu saṅkhipitvā dassetum saṃkhittena pañca upādānakkhandhāḥ
translated: Therefore, all that suffering is to be shown in brief, as it were, by including it in some of the five aggregates as objects of clinging, just as the taste of the water of the whole ocean is included in a drop of ocean water.🔽“In brief, the five aggregates as objects of clinging are suffering” .🔽

original: dukkhā”ti bhagavā avoca. Tenāhu porāṇā –
analyzed: bhagavā avoca tena āhu porāṇā
translated: Therefore all that suffering is included in the five aggregates as objects of clinging and can be shown as a whole in the way stated in the way stated in the passage beginning, “Bhikkhus, in brief, the five aggregates as objects of clinging are suffering.” Hence the Ancients said:

original: “Jātippabhutikaṃ dukkhaṃ, yaṃ vuttamidha tādinā;
analyzed: jāti ppabhutikam dukkham yam vuttam idha tādinā
translated: “The suffering beginning with birth, Which the Peerless One has stated,

original: Avuttaṃ yañca taṃ sabbaṃ, vinā ete na vijjati.
analyzed: avuttam yat ca tam sabbam vinā ete na vijjati
translated: And all the suffering not stated, Are not without these aggregates.

original: “Yasmā tasmā upādāna-kkhandhā saṅkhepato ime;
analyzed: yasmai tasmai upādāna khandhā saṅkhepataḥ ime
translated: “Therefore these aggregates as objects of clinging, In brief, are suffering,

original: Dukkhāti vuttā dukkhanta-desakena mahesinā”ti.🔽Evaṃ sarūpato dukkhasaccaṃ dassetvā idāni samudayasaccaṃ dassetuṃ “idaṃ kho pana,🔽bhikkhave, dukkhasamudaya”ntiādimāha. Tattha saṃ-iti ayaṃ saddo “samāgamo sameta”ntiādīsu
analyzed: dukkhā ati vuttā dukkhanta desakena mahesinā  evam sarūpataḥ dukkha saccam dassetvā idāni samudaya saccam dassetuṃ idam kho pana  bhikkhave dukkha samudaya nti ādim āha tattha sam iti ayam saddo samāgamaḥ sameta nti ādīsu
translated: So the Great Seer has stated, Who has shown the end of suffering.”

original: saṃyogaṃ dīpeti, u-iti ayaṃ “uppannaṃ udita”ntiādīsu uppattiṃ. Aya-saddo pana kāraṇaṃ
analyzed: saṃyogam dīpeti u iti ayam uppannam udita nti ādīsu uppattim aya saddaḥ pana kāraṇam
translated: Having thus shown the truth of suffering in its individual aspect, he now said, “Bhikkhus, this is the noble truth of the origin of suffering” in order to show the truth of suffering in its collective aspect. Herein, the prefix sam in samudaya signifies a coming together, as in the words “a coming together, a meeting” . The prefix u signifies arising, as in the words “arisen, appeared” . The root ya signifies a cause, as in the words “the cause, the reason” .

original: dīpeti. Idañcāpi dutiyasaccaṃ avasesapaccayasamāyoge sati dukkhassuppattikāraṇanti
analyzed: dīpeti idam ca api dutiya saccam avasesa paccaya samāyoge sati dukkhassa uppatti kāraṇam ti
translated: and it illuminates. And this second truth is the cause of the arising of suffering when the remaining conditions are present.

original: dukkhassa saṃyoge uppattikāraṇattā “dukkhasamudaya”nti vuccati. Yāyaṃ taṇhāti yā🔽ayaṃ taṇhā. Ponobbhavikāti punabbhavakaraṇaṃ punabbhavo uttarapadalopena, punabbhavo
analyzed: dukkhassa saṃyoge uppatti kāraṇa ttā dukkha samudayanti vuccati yā ayam taṇhā ati yā  ayam taṇhā ponobbhavikā iti punarbhava karaṇam punabbhavaḥ uttara pada lopena punabbhavaḥ
translated: It is called the “origin of suffering” because it is the cause of the arising of suffering when suffering is present.🔽“This craving” is this craving.🔽“Which leads to renewed existence” is renewed existence, which is the making of renewed existence. The latter part of the compound is omitted, as in the expression “a plough-ox” (go).🔽“Which leads to renewed existence” is craving for renewed existence.

original: sīlametissāti ponobbhavikā. Nandīrāgena sahagatāti nandīrāgasahagatā. Idaṃ vuttaṃ
analyzed: sīlam etissā ti ponobbhavikā nandī rāgena sahagatā ati nandī rāga sahagatā idam vuttam
translated: “Accompanied by delight and lust” is accompanied by delight and lust. This is said:

original: hoti “nandanato rajjanato ca nandīrāgabhāvaṃ sabbāsu avatthāsu appaccakkhāya vuttiyā
analyzed: hoti nandanataḥ rajjanataḥ ca nandī rāga bhāvam sabbāsu avatthāsu appaccakkhāya vuttiyā
translated: “Without having fully understood the state of being accompanied by delight and lust through delighting in and lusting after all states in all their aspects,

original: nandīrāgasahagatā”ti. Tatratatrābhinandinīti yatra yatra attabhāvo nibbattati, tatratatrābhinandinī.🔽Seyyathidanti nipāto, tassa sā katamāti ceti ayamattho. Rūpataṇhādibhedena chabbidhāyeva
analyzed: nandī rāga sahagatā ati tatra tatra abhinandinī iti yatra yatra atta bhāvaḥ nibbattati tatra tatra abhinandinī  nipātaḥ tassa sā katamā ati ca iti ayam attho rūpa taṇhā ādi bhedena cha bidhāya iva
translated: one lives with that delight and lust.” “Delighting in this and that” is delighting in this and that state of being.🔽“For example” is a particle. The meaning is: “What is that?”🔽Craving is said to be threefold as craving for sense desires, craving for becoming, and craving for non-becoming, according to the mode of its occurrence, although it is of six kinds as classified according to the objects of the six senses.

original: taṇhā pavattiākārabhedato kāmataṇhādivasena tividhā vuttā. Rūpataṇhāyeva hi yadā
analyzed: taṇhā pavatti ākāra bhedataḥ kāma taṇhā ādi vasena tividhā vuttā rūpa taṇhāya iva hi yadā
translated: For craving for sense desires is simply craving for visible forms, etc.

original: cakkhussa āpāthamāgataṃ rūpārammaṇaṃ kāmassādavasena assādayamānā pavattati, tadā🔽kāmataṇhā nāma hoti. Yadā tadevārammaṇaṃ dhuvaṃ sassatanti pavattāya sassatadiṭṭhiyā
analyzed: cakkhussa āpātham āgatam rūpa ārammaṇam kāma ssāda vasena assādayamānā pavattati tadā  kāma taṇhā nāma hoti yadā tat eva ārammaṇam dhuvam pavattāya sassata diṭṭhiyā
translated: When it occurs enjoying the object of visible form that has come into focus in the eye by means of the enjoyment of sensual desires,🔽then it is called craving for sensual pleasures. When it occurs together with the eternalist view that occurs thus “This visible form is permanent, everlasting”

original: saddhiṃ pavattati, tadā bhavataṇhā nāma hoti. Sassatadiṭṭhisahagato hi rāgo “bhavataṇhā”ti
analyzed: saddhim pavattati tadā bhava taṇhā nāma hoti sassata diṭṭhi sahagataḥ hi rāgaḥ bhava taṇhā ati
translated: then it is called craving for becoming. For lust accompanied by eternalist view is called “craving for becoming.”

original: vuccati. Yadā pana tadevārammaṇaṃ ucchijjati vinassatīti pavattāya ucchedadiṭṭhiyā
analyzed: vuccati yadā pana tat eva ārammaṇam ucchijjati vinassati iti pavattāya uccheda diṭṭhiyā
translated: But when it occurs together with the annihilationist view that occurs thus “This visible form is annihilated, destroyed,”

original: saddhiṃ pavattati, tadā vibhavataṇhā nāma hoti. Ucchedadiṭṭhisahagato hi rāgo “vibhavataṇhā”ti
analyzed: saddhim pavattati tadā vibhava taṇhā nāma hoti uccheda diṭṭhi sahagataḥ hi rāgaḥ vibhava taṇhā ati
translated: then it is called craving for non-becoming. For lust accompanied by annihilationist view is called “craving for non-becoming.”

original: vuccati. Esa nayo saddataṇhādīsupi.🔽Kasmā panettha taṇhāva samudayasaccaṃ vuttāti? Visesahetubhāvato. Avijjā hi bhavesu
analyzed: vuccati esa nayaḥ sadda taṇhā ādīsu pi  kasmā pana ittha samudaya saccam vuttā ati visesa hetu bhāvataḥ avijjā hi bhavesu
translated: So too with the craving for sounds, and so on.

original: ādīnavaṃ paṭicchādentī diṭṭhiādiupādānañca tattha tattha abhinivisamānaṃ taṇhaṃ abhivaḍḍheti,
analyzed: ādīnavam paṭicchādentī diṭṭhi ādi upādānam ca tattha tattha abhinivisamānam taṇham abhivaḍḍheti
translated: But why is craving alone stated here as the truth of the origin? Because it is the cause of distinction. For ignorance, by concealing the danger in becoming, increases craving, which is clinging consisting in views, etc., by taking up each case as it arises.

original: dosādayopi kammassa kāraṇaṃ honti, taṇhā pana taṃtaṃbhavayonigativiññāṇaṭṭhitisattāāvāsasattanikāyakulabhogissariyādivicittataṃ
analyzed: dosa ādayaḥ api kammassa kāraṇam honti taṇhā pana
translated: and hate, etc., are also a reason for kamma, but craving, which is the cause of the various kinds of becoming, generation, destiny, station of consciousness, abode of beings, group of beings, family, wealth, rulership, etc.,

original: abhipatthentī kammavicittatāya upanissayataṃ kammassa ca sahāyabhāvaṃ upagacchantī🔽bhavādivicittataṃ niyameti, tasmā dukkhassa visesahetubhāvato aññesupi avijjāupādānakammādīsu
analyzed: abhipatthentī kamma vicitta tāya upanissaya tam kammassa ca sahāya bhāvam upagacchantī  bhava ādi vicitta tam niyameti tasmā dukkhassa visesa hetu bhāvataḥ aññesu pi avijjā upādāna kamma ādīsu
translated: by being a decisive support for the various kinds of kamma and by being a companion to kamma, determines the various kinds of becoming, etc.,

original: sutte abhidhamme ca avasesakilesākusalamūlādīsu vuttesu dukkhahetūsu vijjamānesu
analyzed: sutte abhidhamme ca avasesa kilesa akusala mūla ādīsu vuttesu dukkha hetūsu vijjamānesu
translated: and so it is the specific cause of suffering. Therefore, although in the suttas and in the Abhidhamma other states such as ignorance, clinging, kamma, etc., are mentioned as causes of suffering,

original: taṇhāva “samudayasacca”nti vuttāti veditabbaṃ.
analyzed: taṇhā va samudaya saccan ti vuttā iti veditabbam
translated: it should be understood that craving alone is called the “truth of the origin” because it is the specific cause of suffering.

original: Idāni dukkhanirodhaṃ ariyasaccaṃ dassetuṃ “idaṃ kho pana, bhikkhave, dukkhanirodha”ntiādimāha.🔽Tattha yasmā ni-saddo abhāvaṃ, rodha-saddo ca cārakaṃ dīpeti, tasmā abhāvo ettha
analyzed: idāni dukkha nirodham ariya saccam dassetuṃ idam kho pana bhikkhave dukkha nirodha nti ādim āha  tattha yasmā nisaddaḥ abhāvam rodha saddaḥ ca cārakam dīpeti tasmā abhāvaḥ ettha
translated: Now, in order to show the noble truth of the cessation of suffering, the Exalted One said, “And this, bhikkhus, is the noble truth of the cessation of suffering” .

original: saṃsāracārakasaṅkhātassa dukkharodhassa sabbagatisuññattā, samadhigate vā tasmiṃ
analyzed: saṃsāra cāraka saṅkhātassa dukkha rodhassa sabba gati suññattā samadhigate vā tasmin
translated: Herein, the prefix ni- indicates non-existence, and the verbal root rodh means “to obstruct.” Thus cessation is the non-existence of the obstruction of suffering, which is called the round of rebirths. It is the complete voidness of all destinies. Or, when it is attained,

original: saṃsāracārakasaṅkhātassa dukkharodhassa abhāvo hoti tappaṭipakkhattātipi “dukkhanirodha”nti
analyzed: saṃsāra cāraka saṅkhātassa dukkha rodhassa abhāvaḥ hoti dukkha nirodhan ti
translated: The absence of the suffering-flood called the round of rebirths is the opposite of that, and so it is called “the cessation of suffering.”

original: vuccati. Dukkhassa vā anuppādanirodhapaccayattā dukkhanirodhaṃ. Dukkhanirodhaṃ dassentena
analyzed: vuccati dukkhassa vā anuppāda nirodha paccaya ttā dukkha nirodham dukkha nirodham dassentena
translated: Or alternatively, it is the cessation of suffering because it is the condition for the non-arising of suffering.🔽Herein, the cessation of the origin is stated by the Blessed One in the way beginning, “With the remainderless fading away and cessation of that same craving” .

original: cettha “yo tassāyeva taṇhāyā”tiādinā nayena samudayanirodho vutto, so kasmā vuttoti
analyzed: ca ittha yo tassāya eva taṇhāya ati ādinā nayena samudaya nirodho vutto so kasmā vutto ti
translated: Why is it stated?🔽Because the cessation of suffering is due to the cessation of the origin.

original: ce? Samudayanirodhena dukkhanirodho. Byādhinimittavūpasamena byādhivūpasamo viya
analyzed: ce samudaya nirodhena dukkha nirodhaḥ byādhi nimitta vūpasamena byādhi vūpasamaḥ viya
translated: For just as the cessation of the disease is due to the cessation of the cause of the disease,

original: hi hetunirodhena phalanirodho, tasmā samudayanirodheneva dukkhaṃ nirujjhati, na aññathā. Tenāha –🔽“Yathāpi mūle anupaddave daḷhe;🔽Chinnopi rukkho punareva rūhati;
analyzed: hi hetu nirodhena phala nirodho tasmā samudaya nirodhena iva dukkham nirujjhati na aññathā tena āha  yathā api mūle anupaddave daḷhe  chinnaḥ api rukkhaḥ punar eva rūhati
translated: so too the cessation of the fruit is due to the cessation of the cause. Therefore suffering ceases only through the cessation of the origin, not otherwise. That is why the Blessed One said:

original: Evampi taṇhānusaye anūhate;
analyzed: evam pi taṇhā anusaye
translated: “Just as though a man needing heartwood, seeking heartwood, wandering in search of heartwood, should pass over the root and trunk as well, and cutting off the smaller branches and twigs, go off carrying them, thinking: ‘This is the heartwood’;

original: Nibbattatī dukkhamidaṃ punappuna”nti. ;
analyzed: nibbattatī dukkham idam punappunanti
translated: so too, bhikkhus, do you … go off carrying them, thinking: ‘This is the heartwood.’ But, bhikkhus, the heartwood of the holy life is this: the four foundations of mindfulness” .

original: Iti yasmā samudayanirodheneva dukkhaṃ nirujjhati, tasmā bhagavā dukkhanirodhaṃ dassento
analyzed: iti yasmai samudaya nirodhena iva dukkham nirujjhati tasmai bhagavā dukkha nirodham dassento
translated: So since suffering ceases only through the cessation of the origin, the Blessed One,

original: samudayanirodhena desesi. Sīhasamānavuttino hi tathāgatā. Te dukkhaṃ nirodhentā dukkhanirodhañca🔽desentā hetumhi paṭipajjanti, na phale. Yathā hi sīho yenattani saro khitto, tattheva🔽attano balaṃ dasseti, na sare, tathā buddhānaṃ kāraṇe paṭipatti, na phale. Titthiyā
analyzed: samudaya nirodhena desesi sīha samāna vuttinaḥ hi tathāgatā te dukkham nirodhentā dukkha nirodham ca  desentā hetumhi paṭipajjanti na phale yathā hi sīhaḥ saraḥ khitto tattha iva  attanaḥ balam dasseti na sare tathā buddhānam kāraṇe paṭipatti na phale titthiyā
translated: and he taught the cessation of suffering by the cessation of its origin. For Buddhas are like lions in their behavior. When they put a stop to suffering and teach the cessation of suffering, they do so by way of the cause, not by way of the effect. For just as a lion shows its power by going straight to the place where the arrow was shot, not to the arrow itself, so the Buddhas’ practice is by way of the cause, not by way of the effect.

original: pana suvānavuttino. Te dukkhaṃ nirodhentā dukkhanirodhañca desentā attakilamathānuyogadesanādīhi🔽phale paṭipajjanti, na hetumhi. Yathā hi sunakhā kenaci leḍḍuppahāre dinne bhussantā🔽leḍḍuṃ khādanti, na pahāradāyake uṭṭhahanti, evaṃ aññatitthiyā dukkhaṃ nirodhetukāmā🔽kāyakhedamanuyujjanti, na kilesanirodhanaṃ, evaṃ tāva dukkhanirodhassa samudayanirodhavasena
analyzed: pana suvāna vuttino te dukkham nirodhentā dukkha nirodham ca desentā atta kilamatha anuyoga desanā ādīhi  phale paṭipajjanti na hetumhi yathā hi su nakhā kenacid leḍḍu pahāre dinne bhussantā  leḍḍum khādanti na pahāra dāyake uṭṭhahanti evam añña titthiyāḥ dukkham nirodhetu kāmā  kāya khedam anuyujjanti na kilesa nirodhanam evam tāva dukkha nirodhassa samudaya nirodha vasena
translated: But the sectarians are like dogs in their behavior. When they put a stop to suffering and teach the cessation of suffering, they do so by way of the effect, not by way of the cause, by teaching the practice of self-mortification, etc.

original: desanāya payojanaṃ veditabbaṃ.
analyzed: desanāya payojanam veditabbam
translated: For just as dogs, when struck with a clod, eat the clod, not the one who threw it, so too the sectarians, when they want to stop suffering, practice self-mortification, not the cessation of defilements. This, firstly, is how the purpose of teaching the cessation of suffering by the cessation of its origin should be understood.

original: Ayaṃ panettha attho. Tassāyeva taṇhāyāti tassā “ponobbhavikā”ti vatvā kāmataṇhādivasena🔽vibhattataṇhāya. Virāgo vuccati maggo. “Virāgā vimuccatī”ti hi vuttaṃ. Virāgena nirodho
analyzed: ayam pana ittha attho tassāya eva taṇhāya ati tassā ponobbhavikā iti vatvā kāma taṇhā ādi vasena  vibhatta taṇhāya virāgaḥ vuccati maggaḥ virāgā vimuccati iti hi vuttam virāgena nirodhaḥ
translated: The meaning here is this. Of that craving: of that craving already analysed as sense-desire craving, etc.,

original: virāganirodho, anusayasamugghātato aseso virāganirodho asesavirāganirodho. Atha vā🔽virāgoti pahānaṃ vuccati, tasmā anusayasamugghātato aseso virāgo aseso nirodhoti
analyzed: virāga nirodhaḥ anusaya samugghātataḥ asesaḥ virāga nirodhaḥ asesa virāga nirodhaḥ atha vā  virāgaḥ ti pahānam vuccati tasmai anusaya samugghātataḥ asesaḥ virāgaḥ asesaḥ nirodho ti

original: evampettha yojanā daṭṭhabbā, atthato pana sabbāneva etāni nibbānassa vevacanāni.
analyzed: evam pi ittha yojanā daṭṭhabbā atthataḥ pana etāni nibbānassa vevacanāni

So the construction here should be seen in this way. But in meaning all these are synonyms for Nibbāna.

original: Paramatthato hi dukkhanirodho ariyasaccanti nibbānaṃ vuccati. Yasmā pana taṃ āgamma
analyzed: paramatthataḥ hi dukkha nirodhaḥ ariya saccanti nibbānam vuccati yasmai pana tam āgamma

analyzed: taṇhā virajjati ca iva nirujjhati ca tasmai virāgo ti ca nirodho ti ca vuccati yasmai
translated: it is called “fading away” and “cessation.” And because the relinquishing, etc., of craving come about on arrival at Nibbāna,

analyzed: ca tat eva āgamma tassā cāga ādayaḥ honti kāma guṇa ālaya ādīsu ca ittha ekaḥ api ālayaḥ natthi
translated: there is no reliance on any of the bases for the obsessions, such as the strands of sensual desire, etc.,

original: tasmā cāgo paṭinissaggo mutti anālayoti vuccati.🔽Idāni dukkhanirodhagāminipaṭipadāariyasaccaṃ dassetuṃ “idaṃ kho pana, bhikkhave,
analyzed: tasmā cāgaḥ paṭinissaggo mutti anālayo ti vuccati  idāni dukkha nirodha gāmini paṭipadā ariya saccam dassetuṃ idam kho pana bhikkhave
translated: So it is said that “giving up, relinquishing, is freedom, which is the same as non-clinging” .🔽Now, in order to show the noble truth of the way leading to the cessation of suffering, he said: “And this, bhikkhus, is the noble truth of the way leading to the cessation of suffering” .

analyzed: ārammaṇa vasaena tad abhimukha bhūta ttā paṭipadā ca hoti dukkha nirodha ppattiyā tasmā  dukkha nirodha gāminī paṭipadā ti vuccati sesam ettha vutta nayam eva kaḥ pana nesam

original: dukkhādīnaṃ saccaṭṭhoti? Yo paññācakkhunā upaparikkhiyamānānaṃ māyāva viparīto, marīciva🔽visaṃvādako, titthiyānaṃ attā viya anupalabbhasabhāvo ca na hoti, atha kho bādhanappabhavasantiniyyānappakārena
analyzed: dukkha ādīnam saccaṭṭhaḥ ti yaḥ paññā cakkhunā upaparikkhiyamānānam māyā va viparītaḥ marīci va  visaṃvādako titthiyānam attā viya anupalabbha sabhāvaḥ ca na hoti atha kho bādhana pabhava santi niyyāna ppakārena
translated: It is this. When they are investigated with the eye of understanding, they are not like a magical creation, nor like a mirage,🔽nor like the self of the sectarians, which has no real individual essence.🔽But rather, they are the province of noble knowledge in the mode of being that is real, not unreal, since they are the mode of being that is the source of suffering, etc., and the mode of being that is the cessation of that, and the mode of being that is the way going to the cessation of that.

original: tacchāviparītabhūtabhāvena ariyañāṇassa gocaro hotiyeva, esa aggilakkhaṇaṃ viya lokapakati
analyzed: tacchā viparīta bhūta bhāvena ariya ñāṇassa gocaraḥ esa aggi lakkhaṇam viya loka pakati

analyzed: viya ca tad chā viparīta bhūta bhāvo saccaṭṭhaḥ ti veditabbo ettha ca aggi lakkhaṇam nāma  tat hi katthaci kaṭṭha ādi upādāna bhede visaṃvādakam viparītam abhūtam vā kadāci pi  na hoti jāti dhammā jarā dhammā atho maraṇa dhammino ti evam vutta jāti ādikā loka pakatī iti  veditabbā ekaccānam tiracchānānam tiriyam dīgha tā manussa ādīnam uddham dīgha tā  vuddhi niṭṭha ppattānam puna evamādikā ca lokapakatī iti vadanti  api ca  na ābādhakam yatas dukkham dukkhāḥ aññam na bādhakam  bādhaka tta niyāmena tatas saccam idam matam

original: Taṃ vinā nāññato dukkhaṃ, na hoti na ca taṃ tato;
analyzed: tam vinā na aññatas dukkham na hoti na ca tam tatas
translated: For that is never misleading, nor is it the opposite of that, nor is it unreal, in the various instances of its occurrence as fuel, etc.

analyzed: pubbe an anussutesu iti itas pubbe idam dukkham ti ādinā na anussutesu a suta pubbesu  catu sacca dhammesu cakkhu nti ādīni ñāṇa vevacanāni iva ñāṇam eva ha ittha paccakkhataḥ dassana ṭṭhena
translated: Never before heard: not heard before as “This is suffering,” etc.,🔽in the four truths that have never been heard before.🔽Eye, etc., are merely synonyms for knowledge. For knowledge is the eye here in the sense of seeing by direct experience;

original: cakkhu viyāti cakkhu, ñāṇaṭṭhena ñāṇaṃ, pakārato jānanaṭṭhena paññā, paṭivijjhanaṭṭhena
analyzed: cakkhu viyā ti cakkhu ñāṇa ṭṭhena ñāṇam pakārataḥ jānana ṭṭhena paññā paṭivijjhana ṭṭhena

original: tiṇṇaṃ parivaṭṭānaṃ vasena tiparivaṭṭaṃ. Saccañāṇādivasena hi tayo parivaṭṭā etassāti🔽tiparivaṭṭanti vuccati ñāṇadassanaṃ. Ettha ca “idaṃ dukkhaṃ ariyasaccaṃ, idaṃ dukkhasamudaya”nti🔽evaṃ catūsu saccesu yathābhūtañāṇaṃ saccañāṇaṃ nāma. Tesuyeva “pariññeyyaṃ pahātabbaṃ
analyzed: tiṇṇam parivaṭṭānam vasena ti parivaṭṭam sacca ñāṇa ādi vasena hi tayo parivaṭṭāḥ etassa ati  ti parivaṭṭanti vuccati ñāṇa dassanaṃ ettha ca idam dukkham ariya saccaṃ idam dukkha samudaya nti  evam catūsu saccesu yathā bhūta ñāṇam saccañāṇam nāma tesu yeva pariññeyyam pahātabbam
translated: ‘For as long as’ means for as long a time as. ‘Three times round’ means three times round by way of the three revolutions,🔽which are called the revolution of knowledge of the Truths, the revolution of knowledge of the task, and the revolution of knowledge of what is to be done.🔽For this is called ‘three times round’ because it has three revolutions by way of knowledge of the Truths, etc. And here the knowledge of the four Truths as they are, thus: ‘This is the noble truth of suffering, this is the noble truth of the origin of suffering’ is called ‘knowledge of the Truths.’

original: sacchikātabbaṃ bhāvetabba”nti evaṃ kattabbakiccajānanañāṇaṃ kiccañāṇaṃ nāma. “Pariññātaṃ
