analyzed: pahīnam sacchikatam bhāvitam ti evam tassa kata bhāva jānana ñāṇam kata ñāṇam nāma dvādasa ākāranti 🔽tesam yeva ekekasmin sacce tiṇṇam tiṇṇam ākārānam vasena dvādasa ākāram ñāṇa dassananti
translated: the truth of cessation of suffering has been realized by me, the truth of the way leading to cessation of suffering has been developed by me’ is called ‘knowledge of what is to be done.’ ‘Twelve aspects’ means twelve aspects by way of the three aspects of each of the four Truths. ‘Knowledge and vision’

original: etesaṃ tiparivaṭṭānaṃ dvādasannaṃ ākārānaṃ vasena uppannañāṇasaṅkhātaṃ dassanaṃ.🔽Anuttaraṃ sammāsambodhinti uttaravirahitaṃ sabbaseṭṭhaṃ sammā sāmañca bodhiṃ. Atha
analyzed: etesam ti parivaṭṭānam dvādasannam ākārānam vasena uppanna ñāṇa saṅkhātam dassanam  anuttaram sammāsambodhim ti uttara virahitam sabba seṭṭham sammā sāmañca bodhim atha
translated: The knowledge that arises by means of these twelve aspects in the three turns is called “seeing.”

original: vā pasatthaṃ sundarañca bodhiṃ. Bodhīti ca bhagavato arahattamaggo idhādhippeto.
analyzed: vā pasattham sundaram ca bodhim bodhi iti ca bhagavataḥ arahatta maggaḥ idha adhippetaḥ
translated: “The supreme perfect enlightenment”: enlightenment that is without anything higher, the best of all, and rightly and truly penetrated. Or alternatively, enlightenment that is praised and beautiful. And here the Blessed One’s path of arahatship is intended by “enlightenment.”

original: Sāvakānaṃ arahattamaggo anuttarā bodhi hoti, na hotīti? Na hoti. Kasmā? Asabbaguṇadāyakattā.
analyzed: sāvakānam arahatta maggaḥ anuttarā bodhi hoti na hoti iti na hoti kasmai a sabba guṇa dāyaka ttā
translated: Is the path of arahatship of the disciples the supreme enlightenment or not? It is not. Why? Because it does not give all the special qualities.

original: Tesañhi kassaci arahattamaggo arahattaphalameva deti, kassaci tisso vijjā, kassaci
analyzed: tesam hi kassaci arahatta maggaḥ arahatta phalam eva deti kassaci tissaḥ vijjā kassaci
translated: For some it gives only the fruit of arahatship, for some the three knowledges, for some

original: cha abhiññā, kassaci catasso paṭisambhidā, kassaci sāvakapāramīñāṇaṃ. Paccekabuddhānampi🔽paccekabodhiñāṇameva deti, buddhānaṃ pana sabbaguṇasampattiṃ deti abhiseko viya rañño
analyzed: cha abhiññā kassaci catasso paṭisambhidā kassaci sāvaka pāramī ñāṇam paccekabuddhānam pi  pacceka bodhi ñāṇam eva deti buddhānam pana sabba guṇa sampattim deti abhisekaḥ viya rañño
translated: the six kinds of direct knowledge, for some the four discriminations, for some the knowledge of the perfections of a disciple. For the paccekabuddhas it gives

original: sabbalokissariyabhāvaṃ. Tasmā aññassa kassacipi anuttarā bodhi na hotīti. Abhisambuddhoti
analyzed: sabba lokissariya bhāvam tasmai aññassa kassaci pi anuttarā bodhi na hoti iti abhisambuddhā iti
translated: only the knowledge of a paccekabuddha, but for the Buddhas it gives the complete perfection of all special qualities, like a royal anointing gives a king the status of universal ruler over the whole world. Therefore it is not the supreme enlightenment for anyone else. “Enlightened”

original: paccaññāsinti abhisambuddho ahaṃ patto paṭivijjhitvā ṭhitoti evaṃ paṭijāniṃ. Ñāṇañca🔽pana me dassanaṃ udapādīti adhigataguṇānaṃ yāthāvato dassanasamatthaṃ paccavekkhaṇañāṇañca
analyzed: paccaññāsinti abhisambuddhaḥ aham pattaḥ paṭivijjhitvā ṭhitaḥ ti evam paṭijānim ñāṇam ca  pana me dassanam udapādi iti adhigata guṇānam yāthāvataḥ dassana samattham paccavekkhaṇa ñāṇam ca
translated: ‘I have understood’: I have acknowledged that I am fully enlightened, having attained and realized it myself. ‘And knowledge and insight arose in me’: knowledge of reviewing arose in me, capable of seeing the qualities I had attained.

original: pana me udapādi. Akuppā me vimuttīti ayaṃ mayhaṃ arahattaphalavimutti akuppā paṭipakkhehi
analyzed: pana me udapādi akuppā me vimutti iti ayam mayham arahatta phala vimutti akuppā paṭipakkhehi
translated: ‘My mind is freed from the taints’: the knowledge arose in me that this my liberation of mind is unshakable, since it cannot be disturbed by any opposing states.

original: na kopetabbāti evaṃ ñāṇaṃ udapādi. Tattha dvīhākārehi akuppatā veditabbā maggasaṅkhātakāraṇato
analyzed: na kopetabbā ati evam ñāṇam udapādi tattha dvīhā ākārehi akuppa tā veditabbā magga saṅkhāta kāraṇato
translated: Herein, the unshakable state should be understood in two ways:🔽as to cause and as to object.

original: ca ārammaṇato ca. Sā hi catūhi maggehi samucchinnakilesānaṃ puna anivattanatāya kāraṇatopi🔽akuppā, akuppadhammaṃ nibbānaṃ ārammaṇaṃ katvā pavattatāya ārammaṇatopi akuppā anākuppārammaṇānaṃ
analyzed: ca ārammaṇato ca sā hi catūhi maggehi samucchinna kilesānam puna anivattanatāya kāraṇataḥ pi  akuppā akuppa dhammam nibbānam ārammaṇam katvā pavatta tāya ārammaṇataḥ pi akuppā an ākuppa ārammaṇānam
translated: For it is unshakable as to cause because the defilements that have been severed by the four paths do not occur again;🔽and it is unshakable as to object because it occurs with Nibbāna, which is unshakable, as object, since mundane attainments, which are subject to shaking, do not have that as their object.

original: lokiyasamāpattīnaṃ tadabhāvato. Antimāti pacchimā. Natthi dāni punabbhavoti idāni
analyzed: lokiya samāpattīnam tad abhāvataḥ antimā ati pacchimā na atthi dāni punabbhavo ti idāni
translated: ‘The last’: the last, that is, the last of the four paths.

original: puna añño bhavo nāma natthīti.
analyzed: puna aññaḥ bhavaḥ nāma natthi iti
translated: ‘There is no more of this hereafter’: there is no more of this kind of existence hereafter.

original: Imasmiñca pana veyyākaraṇasminti imasmiṃ niggāthake sutte. Niggāthakañhi suttaṃ pucchāvissajjanasahitaṃ
analyzed: imasmin ca pana veyyākaraṇasmin ti imasmim niggāthake sutte niggāthakam hi suttam pucchā vissajjana sahitam
translated: And in this Thread: in this stanza-verse Thread. For a Thread consisting of a question and an answer is called “a Thread of exposition” .

original: “veyyākaraṇa”nti vuccati. Bhaññamāneti bhaṇiyamāne, desiyamāneti attho. Virajanti🔽apāyagamanīyarāgarajādīnaṃ vigamena virajaṃ. Vītamalanti anavasesadiṭṭhivicikicchāmalāpagamena
analyzed: veyyākaraṇam ti vuccati bhaññamāne iti bhaṇiyamāne desiyamāne iti atthaḥ virajanti  apāya gamanīya rāga raja ādīnam vigamena virajam vīta malanti anavasesa diṭṭhi vicikicchā mala apagamena
translated: Is being expounded: is being spoken, is being taught, is the meaning. Dust-free: dust-free through the absence of the dust of lust, etc., that lead to the bad destinations.🔽Stainless: stainless through the absence of the stains of view and doubt without remainder.

original: vītamalaṃ. Paṭhamamaggavajjhakilesarajābhāvena vā virajaṃ, pañcavidhadussīlyamalāpagamena
analyzed: vīta malam paṭhama magga vajjha kilesa raja abhāvena vā virajam pañcavidha dussīlya mala apagamena
translated: Or alternatively, it is dust-free through the absence of the dust of defilements abandoned by the first path, and it is stainless through the absence of the stain of the five kinds of debased morality.

original: vītamalaṃ. Dhammacakkhunti brahmāyusutte heṭṭhimā tayo maggā vuttā, cūḷarāhulovāde
analyzed: vīta malam dhamma cakkhunti brahmāyusutte heṭṭhimā tayaḥ maggā vuttā cūḷarāhulovāde
translated: The eye of Dhamma: in the Brahmayu-sutta the first three paths are called the eye of Dhamma, and in the Cula-Rahulovada-sutta the ending of the taints is so called. But here the path of stream-entry is intended.

original: āsavakkhayo, idha pana sotāpattimaggo adhippeto. Catusaccasaṅkhātesu dhammesu tesaṃ
analyzed: āsava kkhayo idha pana sotāpatti maggo adhippeto catu sacca saṅkhātesu dhammesu tesam
translated: In the case of the four truths, which are called “Dhamma,” it is the eye in the sense of seeing them.

original: dassanaṭṭhena cakkhūti dhammacakkhu, heṭṭhimesu vā tīsu maggadhammesu ekaṃ sotāpattimaggasaṅkhātaṃ
analyzed: dassana ṭṭhena cakkhu āti dhammacakkhu heṭṭhimesu vā tīsu magga dhammesu ekam sotāpatti magga saṅkhātam
translated: Or alternatively, it is the eye in the sense of seeing one of the three kinds of Dhamma that are called the path of stream-entry.

original: cakkhūti dhammacakkhu, samathavipassanādhammanibbattatāya sīlāditividhadhammakkhandhabhūtatāya🔽vā dhammamayaṃ cakkhūtipi dhammacakkhu, tassa uppattiākāradassanatthaṃ “yaṃ kiñci
analyzed: cakkhu uti dhamma cakkhu samatha vipassanā dhamma nibbatta tāya sīla āditividha dhammakkhandha bhūta tāya  vā dhamma mayam cakkhu iti pi dhammacakkhu tassa uppatti ākāra dassana ttham yam kiñci
translated: “Eye” is the eye of Dhamma, which is so called because it is produced by the Dhamma of serenity and insight, or because it is the Dhamma consisting of the three kinds of virtue.🔽Or else, the eye of Dhamma is the eye that is made of Dhamma. The phrase “whatever is subject to arising is subject to cessation” is stated to show the mode of appearance of that eye.

original: samudayadhammaṃ, sabbaṃ taṃ nirodhadhamma”nti āha. Nanu ca maggañāṇaṃ asaṅkhatadhammārammaṇaṃ,🔽na saṅkhatadhammārammaṇanti? Saccametaṃ, yasmā taṃ nirodhaṃ ārammaṇaṃ katvā kiccavasena
analyzed: samudaya dhammam sabbam tat nirodha dhamman ti āha nanu ca magga ñāṇam asaṅkhata dhamma ārammaṇam  na saṅkhata dhamma ārammaṇanti saccam etam yasmā tam nirodham ārammaṇam katvā kicca vasena
translated: But does not the knowledge of the path have as its object the unformed element, not the formed element?🔽This is true, but it arises in such a way that, having made cessation its object, it penetrates all the formed elements by way of its function, and it penetrates them by way of the penetration of non-delusion.

original: sabbasaṅkhataṃ asammohappaṭivedhavasena paṭivijjhantaṃ uppajjati, tasmā tathā vuttaṃ.
analyzed: sabba saṅkhatam asammoha paṭivedha vasena paṭivijjhantam uppajjati tasmā tathā vuttam
translated: Therefore it is said in this way.

original: 17. Dhammacakketi paṭivedhañāṇañceva desanāñāṇañca pavattanaṭṭhena cakkanti dhammacakkaṃ.
analyzed: dhamma cakka iti paṭivedha ñāṇañca iva desanā ñāṇañca pavattana ṭṭhena cakkanti dhamma cakkam
translated: The wheel of Dhamma is the knowledge of penetration and the knowledge of teaching, which are called “wheels” because they roll on.

original: Bodhipallaṅke nisinnassa hi catūsu saccesu uppannaṃ dvādasākāraṃ paṭivedhañāṇampi,
analyzed: bodhi pallaṅke nisinnassa hi catūsu saccesu uppannam dvādasa ākāram paṭivedha ñāṇam pi
translated: For the knowledge of penetration, which consists of the twelve aspects of the four truths, arises in one who is seated on the terrace of enlightenment.

original: isipatane nisinnassa dvādasākārāya saccadesanāya pavattakaṃ desanāñāṇampi dhammacakkaṃ
analyzed: isipatane nisinnassa dvādasa ākārāya sacca desanāya pavattakam desanā ñāṇam pi dhammacakkam
translated: The knowledge of teaching, which occurred in the Blessed One as he sat at the root of the Bodhi Tree, in the form of the twelve aspects of the Four Noble Truths, is also called the Wheel of the Dhamma.

original: nāma. Ubhayampi hetaṃ dasabalassa ure pavattañāṇameva. Tadubhayaṃ imāya desanāya
analyzed: nāma ubhayam pi ha itam dasabalassa ure pavatta ñāṇam eva tat ubhayam imāya desanāya
translated: Both of these are the knowledge that occurred in the heart of the One of Ten Powers. The Blessed One, who was revealing both of these by this teaching,

original: pakāsentena bhagavatā dhammacakkaṃ pavattitaṃ nāma. Taṃ panetaṃ dhammacakkaṃ yāva
analyzed: pakāsentena bhagavatā dhammacakkam pavattitam nāma tam pana itam dhammacakkam yāva
translated: is said to have set the Wheel of the Dhamma rolling. But this Wheel of the Dhamma is said to be set rolling by the Blessed One

original: aññāsikoṇḍaññatthero aṭṭhārasahi brahmakoṭīhi saddhiṃ sotāpattiphale patiṭṭhāti,
analyzed: aññāsikoṇḍañña ttheraḥ aṭṭhārasahi brahmakoṭīhi saddhim sotāpatti phale patiṭṭhāti
translated: as long as the Elder Aññāsikoṇḍañña is not established in the fruit of stream-entry together with eighteen koṭis of Brahmās,

original: tāva bhagavā pavatteti nāma pavattanakiccassa aniṭṭhitattā. Patiṭṭhite pavattitaṃ
analyzed: tāva bhagavā pavattā iti nāma pavattana kiccassa a niṭṭhita ttā patiṭṭhite pavattitam
translated: because the act of setting in motion has not been completed. When he is established, the Wheel of the Dhamma is said to have been set rolling

original: nāma kassapasammāsambuddhassa sāsanantaradhānato paṭṭhāya yāva buddhuppādo, ettakaṃ🔽kālaṃ appavattapubbassa pavattitattā. Taṃ sandhāya “pavattite ca pana bhagavatā dhammacakke
analyzed: nāma kassapa sammāsambuddhassa sāsana antaradhānataḥ paṭṭhāya yāva buddhuppādo ettakam  kālam appavatta pubbassa pavattita ttā tam sandhāya pavattite ca pana bhagavatā dhammacakke
translated: because it has been set rolling for the first time in so long a period, from the time of the disappearance of the Dispensation of the Perfectly Enlightened One Kassapa until the arising of the Buddha.

original: bhummā devā saddamanussāvesu”ntiādi vuttaṃ. Tattha bhummāti bhūmaṭṭhakadevatā. Saddamanussāvesunti
analyzed: bhummā devā saddam anussāvesun tiādi vuttam tattha bhummā ati bhūmaṭṭhaka devatā saddam anussāvesun ti
translated: With reference to this, it is said: “And when the Wheel of the Dhamma had been set rolling by the Blessed One, the gods of the earth cried out: ‘This is the Dhamma-wheel, which cannot be rolled back by any ascetic or brahmin or god or Māra or Brahmā in the world.’ And so it was that the cry of the gods of the earth was echoed by the gods of the Four Great Kings, the gods of the Thirty-three, the Yāma gods, the gods of the Tusita heaven, the gods who delight in creating, the gods who wield power over others’ creations, the gods of Brahmā’s retinue, the gods of Brahmā’s ministers, the gods of great Brahmā, the gods of limited radiance, the gods of unlimited radiance, the gods of streaming radiance, the gods of limited glory, the gods of unlimited glory, the gods of refulgent glory, the gods of the cloudless world, the gods of the Avīci hell, the gods of the exalted gods, the world-sphere gods, and finally the gods of the highest world-sphere. And so there went up to the world-sphere of the highest gods a cry: ‘The Dhamma-wheel has been set rolling by the Blessed One, who has attained supreme enlightenment, at Isipatana near Bārāṇasī, and it cannot

original: ekappahāreneva sādhukāraṃ datvā “etaṃ bhagavatā”tiādīni vadantā anussāvayiṃsu. Obhāsoti
analyzed: eka pahārena iva sādhukāram da tvā etam bhagavatā atiādīni vadantāḥ anussāvayiṃsu
translated: and they all gave their approval with a single shout, saying: “This has been spoken by the Blessed One.”

original: sabbaññutaññāṇānubhāvena pavatto cittapaccayautusamuṭṭhāno obhāso. So hi tadā devānaṃ🔽devānubhāvaṃ atikkamitvā virocittha. Aññāsi vata bho koṇḍaññoti imassapi udānassa
analyzed: sabbaññu taññāṇa anubhāvena pavatto citta paccaya otu samuṭṭhāno obhāsaḥ saḥ hi tadā devānam  deva anubhāvam atikkamitvā virocittha aññāsi vata bho koṇḍañño ti imassa api udānassa
translated: Light: a light arisen by the power of consciousness and temperature, which is a manifestation of the Blessed One’s knowledge of omniscience. For it surpassed the splendour of the devas’ own radiance.

original: udāharaṇaghoso dasasahassilokadhātuṃ pharitvā aṭṭhāsi. Bhagavato hi dhammacakkappavattanassa🔽ārambhe viya parisamāpanepi ativiya uḷāratamaṃ pītisomanassaṃ udapādi.
analyzed: udāharaṇa ghosaḥ dasa sahassi lokadhātum pharitvā aṭṭhāsi bhagavataḥ hi dhamma cakka ppavattanassa  ārambhe parisamāpane pi uḷāratamam pīti somanassam udapādi
translated: The sound of the exclamation: the sound of the exclamation “Koṇḍañña has understood!” spread through the ten-thousandfold world element and remained. For the Blessed One experienced an extreme happiness and gladness on the completion of the setting in motion of the Wheel of the Dhamma as on its commencement.

original: 18. Diṭṭho ariyasaccadhammo etenāti diṭṭhadhammo. Esa nayo sesapadesupi. Ettha ca🔽dassanaṃ nāma ñāṇadassanato aññampi atthīti taṃnivattanatthaṃ “pattadhammo”ti vuttaṃ.
analyzed: diṭṭhaḥ ariya sacca dhammaḥ etena ati diṭṭhadhammaḥ esa nayaḥ sesa padesu pi ettha ca  dassanam nāma ñāṇa dassanataḥ aññam pi atthi iti tad nivattana attham patta dhammaḥ ti vuttam
translated: He has seen the Dhamma, that is, the four noble truths, with the seeing consisting in direct-knowledge. The same method of explanation applies in the other three cases.🔽And here, since there is also seeing other than seeing consisting in direct-knowledge, the word “known” is used in order to exclude that.

original: Patti ca ñāṇasampattito aññāpi vijjatīti tato visesanatthaṃ “viditadhammo”ti vuttaṃ.
analyzed: ca ñāṇa sampattitaḥ aññā api vijjati iti tatas visesana attham vidita dhammo ti vuttam
translated: And since there is also knowing other than the knowing consisting in the attainment of direct-knowledge, the word “penetrated” is used in order to exclude that.

original: Sā panesā viditadhammatā ekadesatopi hotīti nippadesato viditabhāvaṃ dassetuṃ “pariyogāḷhadhammo”ti
analyzed: sā pana esā vidita dhamma tā eka desataḥ pi hoti iti nippadesataḥ vidita bhāvam dassetum pariyogāḷha dhammā ti
translated: But this is a fact known to him in part only; to show that he knows it in its entirety he says “the Dhamma with its fruits in all its aspects” .

original: vuttaṃ. Tenassa saccābhisambodhiṃyeva dīpeti. Maggañāṇañhi ekābhisamayavasena pariññādikiccaṃ
analyzed: vuttam tena assa sacca abhisambodhiṃ yeva dīpeti magga ñāṇam hi eka abhisamaya vasena pariññā ādi kiccam
translated: Thus he shows that he has realized the Four Noble Truths. For the path knowledge, accomplishing the functions of full understanding, etc.,

original: sādhentaṃ nippadesena catusaccadhammaṃ samantato ogāḷhaṃ nāma hoti. Sappaṭibhayakantārasadisā
analyzed: sādhentam nippadesena catu sacca dhammam samantataḥ ogāḷham nāma hoti sa paṭibhaya kantāra sadisā
translated: in one act of direct-knowledge, is called “the Dhamma with its fruits in all its aspects” because it has completely penetrated the Four Noble Truths in their entirety.

original: soḷasavatthukā aṭṭhavatthukā ca tiṇṇā vicikicchā anenāti tiṇṇavicikiccho. Pavattiādīsu
analyzed: soḷasa vatthukā aṭṭha vatthukā ca tiṇṇā vicikicchā anena ati tiṇṇavicikiccho pavatti ādīsu
translated: He has crossed over doubt about the sixteen and eight bases, thus he is one “who has crossed over doubt” .

original: “evaṃ nukho na nukho”ti evaṃ pavattikā vigatā samucchinnā kathaṃkathā assāti vigatakathaṃkatho.🔽Vesārajjappattoti sārajjakarānaṃ pāpadhammānaṃ pahīnattā tappaṭipakkhesu ca sīlādīsu
analyzed: evam nukho na nukhoti evam pavattikā vigatā samucchinnā kathaṃkathā assa ati vigata kathaṃkathaḥ  vesārajja ppatto ti sārajja karānam pāpa dhammānam pahīna ttā tad paṭipakkhesu ca sīla ādīsu
translated: He has no perplexity about the way things happen, etc., thus he is one “who has no perplexity” .🔽He has attained the state of fearlessness, thus he is one “who has attained fearlessness” . He has abandoned the states of non-Dhamma that cause fear, and he has well established himself in the states of Dhamma that are their opposites, virtue, etc.,

original: guṇesu suppatiṭṭhitattā visāradabhāvaṃ veyyattiyaṃ patto adhigato. Svāyaṃ vesārajjappattisuppatiṭṭhitabhāvo
analyzed: guṇesu suppatiṭṭhita ttā visārada bhāvam veyyattiyam pattaḥ adhigataḥ svāyam vesārajja ppatti suppatiṭṭhita bhāvo
translated: and so he has attained the state of fearlessness, the state of confidence.

original: katthāti āha “satthusāsane”ti. Attanā paccakkhato adhigatattā na paraṃ pacceti, parassa
analyzed: kattha iti āha satthu sāsane iti attanā paccakkhataḥ adhigata ttā na param pacceti parassa
translated: As to where? He said: “in the Teacher’s Dispensation.” Because he has himself realized it, he does not rely on another, he does not proceed by faith in another,

original: saddhāya ettha nappavattati, na tassa paro paccetabbo atthīti aparappaccayo.
analyzed: saddhāya ettha na pavattati na tassa paraḥ paccetabbaḥ atthi iti aparappaccayo
translated: he has no need to rely on another.

original: Labheyyāhanti labheyyaṃ ahaṃ, āyācanavacanametaṃ. Ehīti āyācitānaṃ pabbajjūpasampadānaṃ
analyzed: labheyya aham iti labheyyam aham āyācana vacanam etam ehi iti āyācitānam pabbajju upasampadānam
translated: Labheyyāhaṃ: I might obtain. This is a word of request. Ehīti: this is a word of permission to those who have requested the going forth and the higher ordination.

original: anumatabhāvappakāsanavacanaṃ, tasmā ehi sampaṭicchāhi yathāyācitaṃ pabbajjūpasampadavisesanti
analyzed: anumata bhāva ppakāsana vacanam tasmai ehi sampaṭicchāhi yathā yācitam
translated: Therefore the meaning is: Come, accept the going forth and the higher ordination as requested.🔽The word iti is to show the end of the words that are the cause for his obtaining the going forth and the higher ordination by the Come, bhikkhu!

original: attho. Iti-saddo tassa ehibhikkhūpasampadāpaṭilābhanimittavacanapariyosānadassano.🔽Tadavasāno hi tassa bhikkhubhāvo. Tenevāha “ehi bhikkhūti bhagavato vacanena abhinipphannā
analyzed: atthaḥ iti saddaḥ tassa ehi bhikkhu upasampadā paṭilābha nimitta vacana pariyosāna dassanaḥ  tad avasānaḥ hi tassa bhikkhu bhāvaḥ tena iva āha ehi bhikkhu iti bhagavataḥ vacanena abhinipphannā
translated: method.🔽For his bhikkhu status ends with that. That is why it is said: “The venerable one’s going forth and higher ordination by the Come, bhikkhu!

original: sāva tassa āyasmato ehibhikkhūpasampadā ahosī”ti. Cara brahmacariyanti uparimaggattayasaṅkhātaṃ
analyzed: sā ava tassa āyasmataḥ ehi bhikkhu upasampadā ahosi iti cara brahmacariyan ti upari magga ttaya saṅkhātam
translated: method took place with the Blessed One’s utterance of the words Come, bhikkhu” . Cara brahmacariyan ti: lead the holy life.

original: brahmacariyaṃ samadhigaccha. Kimatthaṃ? Sammā dukkhassa antakiriyāya. Idhāpi “avocā”ti
analyzed: brahmacariyam samadhigaccha kimattham sammā dukkhassa anta kiriyāya idha api avoca ati
translated: and to attain the life of purity. For what purpose? For the complete destruction of suffering. Here too, “he said” should be supplied.

original: sambandhitabbaṃ. “Nava koṭisahassānī”tiādinā vuttappabhedānaṃ anekasahassānaṃ saṃvaravinayānaṃ
analyzed: sambandhitabbam nava koṭi sahassāni iti ādinā vutta ppabhedānam aneka sahassānam saṃvara vinayānam
translated: Having undertaken the various thousands of rules of restraint and training,

original: samādiyitvā vattanena uparibhūtā aggabhūtā sampadāti upasampadā.🔽19. Nīhārabhattoti nīhaṭabhatto, gāmato bhikkhaṃ nīharitvā bhikkhūhi dinnabhattoti
analyzed: samādiyitvā vattanena upari bhūtā agga bhūtā sampadā ati upasampadā  nīhāra bhatto ti nīhaṭa bhattaḥ gāmataḥ bhikkham nīharitvā bhikkhūhi dinna bhatto ti
translated: the highest and best perfection is reached by conduct.

original: attho. Bhagavā hi daharakumārake viya te bhikkhū pariharanto pāṭipadadivasato paṭṭhāya
analyzed: atthaḥ bhagavā hi dahara kumārake viya te bhikkhū pariharantaḥ pāṭipada divasato paṭṭhāya
translated: The meal brought in: the meal brought in is the meaning. The Blessed One, looking after the bhikkhus as if they were young children,

original: piṇḍapātatthāyapi gāmaṃ apavisitvā antovihāreyeva vasi.
analyzed: gāmam apavisitvā antovihāreya iva vasi
translated: did not go to the village for alms even on the following day, but stayed in the monastery itself.

original: Dhammacakkappavattanasuttavaṇṇanā niṭṭhitā.
analyzed: dhammacakkappavattana sutta vaṇṇanā niṭṭhitā
translated: The Commentary on the Discourse on the Setting in Motion of the Wheel of the Dhamma is finished.

original: Anattalakkhaṇasuttavaṇṇanā
analyzed: anattalakkhaṇa sutta vaṇṇanā
translated: The Analysis of the Characteristic of Not Being a Self

original: 20. Āmantesīti āsāḷhīpuṇṇamadivase dhammacakkappavattanato paṭṭhāya anukkamena sotāpattiphale
analyzed: āmantesi iti āsāḷhīpuṇṇama divase dhammacakka ppavattanataḥ paṭṭhāya anukkamena sotāpatti phale
translated: He addressed: after the setting in motion of the wheel of the Dhamma on the full-moon day of Āsāḷhi, gradually, in the fruit of stream-entry,

Anattāti avasavattanaṭṭhena asāmikaṭṭhena🔽suññataṭṭhena attapaṭikkhepaṭṭhenāti evaṃ catūhi kāraṇehi anattā. translated: When the five bhikkhus with Aññā-Koṇḍañña as chief had been established, he knew that now he would teach them the Dhamma for the destruction of cankers.

analyzed: evaṃbhūtaḥ attā abhavissāti adhippāyaḥ evam hi sati rūpassa ābādhāya saṃvattanam ayujjamānakam
translated: The intention is that the self would be of such a kind. For if it were so, it would be impossible for it to be the cause of affliction of material form.

original: siyā. Kāmañcettha “yasmā ca kho, bhikkhave, rūpaṃ anattā, tasmā rūpaṃ ābādhāya saṃvattatī”ti🔽rūpassa anattatāya dukkhatā vibhāvitā viya dissati, tathāpi “yasmā rūpaṃ ābādhāya
analyzed: siyā kāmañca ittha yasmai ca kho bhikkhave rūpam anattā tasmai rūpam ābādhāya saṃvattati iti  rūpassa anatta tāya dukkha tā vibhāvitā viya dissati tathā api yasmai rūpam ābādhāya
translated: “Bhikkhus, because material form is not self, therefore material form is the cause of affliction” .

original: saṃvattati, tasmā anattā”ti pākaṭāya sābādhatāya rūpassa attasārābhāvo vibhāvito,🔽tato eva ca “na ca labbhati rūpe ‘evaṃ me rūpaṃ hotu, evaṃ me rūpaṃ mā ahosī’ti”
analyzed: saṃvattati tasmai anattā ati pākaṭāya sa ābādha tāya rūpassa atta sāra abhāvaḥ vibhāvitaḥ  tatas eva ca na ca labbhati rūpe evam me rūpam hotu evam me rūpam mā ahosi iti
translated: Herein, although the fact that material form is suffering is as if demonstrated by the fact that material form is not self, nevertheless the absence of any core of self in material form is demonstrated by the fact that it is the cause of affliction, which is evident,🔽and also the fact that no one has any power over it, and the fact that it is not subject to being made otherwise than it is made, are demonstrated by the fact that it is the cause of affliction.

original: rūpe kassaci anissaratā tassa ca avasavattanākāro dassito. Vedanādīsupi eseva nayo.
analyzed: rūpe kassaci a nissara tā tassa ca avasavattana ākāraḥ dassitaḥ vedanā ādīsu pi esā iva nayo
translated: And the same method of explanation applies in the case of feeling, and so on.

original: 21. Taṃ kiṃmaññatha bhikkhaveti idaṃ kasmā āraddhaṃ? Ettakena ṭhānena anattalakkhaṇameva
analyzed: tam kiṃmaññatha bhikkhave iti idam kasmai āraddham ettakena ṭhānena anatta lakkhaṇam eva
translated: Why is it asked, “What do you think, bhikkhus?”? Because up to this point only the characteristic of not-self has been stated,

original: kathitaṃ, na aniccadukkhalakkhaṇāni, idāni tāni dassetvā samodhānetvā tīṇipi lakkhaṇāni
analyzed: kathitam na anicca dukkha lakkhaṇāni idāni tāni dassetvā samodhānetvā tīṇi pi lakkhaṇāni
translated: not the characteristics of impermanence and pain. Now, after pointing out those two, he will conclude with the three characteristics.

original: dassetuṃ idamāraddhanti veditabbaṃ. Aniccaṃ bhanteti bhante yasmā hutvā na hoti,🔽tasmā aniccaṃ. Yasmā pubbe asantaṃ paccayasamavāyena hutvā uppajjitvā puna bhaṅgupagamanena
analyzed: dassetum idam āraddha nti veditabbam aniccam bhante iti bhante yasmai hutvā na hoti  tasmai aniccam yasmai pubbe asantam paccaya samavāyena hutvā uppajjitvā puna bhaṅga upagamanena
translated: As to the meaning of the words: “Impermanent, venerable sir,” is said because it is not after having been.🔽Because it is not after having been, after having arisen through the concurrence of conditions, through the occurrence of dissolution,

original: na hoti, tasmā na niccanti aniccaṃ, addhuvanti adhippāyo. Atha vā uppādavayavantatāya
analyzed: na hoti tasmai na aniccam addhuvanti adhippāyaḥ atha vā uppāda vayavantatāya
translated: therefore it is impermanent. The intention is: not lasting. Or alternatively, it is impermanent because of the presence of arising and presence of dissolution,

original: tāvakālikatāya vipariṇāmakoṭiyā niccappaṭikkhepatoti imehipi kāraṇehi aniccaṃ. Ettha
analyzed: tāvakālikatāya vipariṇāma koṭiyā nicca ppaṭikkhepato ti imehi pi kāraṇehi aniccam ettha
translated: because of the presence of the momentary, because of the presence of the ultimate dissolution, because of the denial of permanence. Herein,

original: khaṇe khaṇe uppajjanavasena nirujjhanavasena ca pavattanato uppādavayavantatā. Taṅkhaṇikatāya🔽tāvakālikatā. Vipariṇāmavantatāya vipariṇāmakoṭi. Rūpañhi uppādādivikārāpajjanena
analyzed: khaṇe khaṇe uppajjana vasena nirujjhana vasena ca pavattanataḥ uppāda vayavanta tā taṅkhaṇikatāya  tāvakālika tā vipariṇāmavant tāya vipariṇāma koṭi uppāda ādi vikāra āpajjanena
translated: the presence of arising and presence of dissolution is its occurrence by arising in each moment and by ceasing in each moment.🔽The presence of the momentary is its momentaryness.🔽The presence of the ultimate dissolution is its liability to ultimate dissolution. For materiality reaches dissolution, which is called “ultimate dissolution,”

original: vipariṇāmantaṃ vināsaṃ pāpuṇāti. Niccasabhāvābhāvo eva niccapaṭikkhepo. Aniccā hi
analyzed: vipariṇāmantam vināsam pāpuṇāti nicca sabhāva abhāvaḥ eva nicca paṭikkhepaḥ aniccā hi
translated: through the occurrence of change by the appearance of alteration in arising, etc. The denial of permanence is the mere absence of a permanent individual essence.🔽For impermanent states,

original: dhammā, teneva attano aniccabhāvena atthato niccataṃ paṭikkhipanti nāma.
analyzed: dhammā tena iva attanaḥ anicca bhāvena atthataḥ nicca tam paṭikkhipanti nāma
translated: by their very impermanence, are in fact a denial of permanence.

original: Dukkhaṃ bhanteti bhante paṭipīḷanākārena dukkhaṃ. Uppādajarābhaṅgavasena hi rūpassa🔽nirantaraṃ bādhati, paṭipīḷanākārenassa dukkhatā. Atha vā santāpaṭṭhena dukkhamaṭṭhena
analyzed: dukkham bhante ti bhante paṭipīḷana ākārena dukkham uppāda jarā bhaṅga vasena hi rūpassa  nirantaram bādhati paṭipīḷana ākārena assa dukkha tā atha vā santāpa ṭṭhena dukkhamaṭṭhena
translated: “Painful, venerable sir,” means painful by way of oppression. For material form oppresses without interval by way of arising, aging, and dissolution. Its characteristic of painfulness is by way of oppression. Or else, by way of the characteristic of burning, by way of the characteristic of painfulness,

original: dukkhavatthukaṭṭhena sukhapaṭikkhepaṭṭhena cāti catūhi kāraṇehi dukkhaṃ. Ettha ca🔽santāpo nāma dukkhadukkhatādivasena santāpanaṃ paridahanaṃ. Tato evassa dussahatāya
analyzed: dukkha vatthuka ṭṭhena sukha paṭikkhepa ṭṭhena ca ati catūhi kāraṇehi dukkham ettha ca  santāpaḥ nāma dukkha dukkha tā ādi vasena santāpanam paridahanam tatas evassa dussaha tāya
translated: “Painful, venerable sir” : painful in the mode of oppression. For material form oppresses without interval by means of arising, ageing, and dissolution. Its painfulness is in the mode of oppression. Or alternatively, it is painful in four ways: as pain, as the root of pain, as the foundation of pain, and as the opposite of pleasure. Herein,

original: dukkhamatā. Tissannaṃ dukkhatānaṃ saṃsāradukkhassa ca adhiṭṭhānatāya dukkhavatthukatā.
analyzed: dukkhama tā tissannam dukkha tānam saṃsāra dukkhassa ca adhiṭṭhāna tāya dukkha vatthuka tā
translated: pain is the painfulness as pain, etc., which oppresses and burns by means of the painfulness of pain, and so on. Because of that it is painful as the root of pain, since it is hard to endure. It is painful as the foundation of pain because it is the basis for the three kinds of pain and for the pain of the round of rebirths.

original: Sukhasabhāvābhāvo eva sukhapaṭikkhepo. Vipariṇāmadhammanti jarāya maraṇena ca vipariṇāmasabhāvaṃ.🔽Kallaṃ nūti yuttaṃ nu. Tanti evaṃ aniccaṃ dukkhaṃ vipariṇāmadhammaṃ rūpaṃ. Etaṃ mamāti
analyzed: sukha sabhāva abhāvaḥ eva sukha paṭikkhepaḥ vipariṇāma dhammanti jarāya maraṇena ca vipariṇāma sabhāvam  kallam nu uti yuttam nu tanti evam aniccam dukkham vipariṇāma dhammam rūpam etam mama ati
translated: The opposite of pleasure is the mere absence of pleasure. “Subject to change”: having the nature of change by ageing and by death.

original: taṇhāgāho mamaṅkārabhāvato. Esohamasmīti mānagāho ahaṅkārabhāvato. Eso me attāti
analyzed: taṇhā gāhaḥ mamaṅkāra bhāvataḥ eṣa uham asmi iti māna gāhaḥ ahaṅkāra bhāvataḥ eṣaḥ me attā ati
translated: “Is it proper?” : is it suitable? “This” : this material form that is impermanent, painful, and subject to change. “This is mine” : as an object of the conceit “I am.” “This I am” : as an object of the conceit “I am.” “This is my self” : as an object of the false view of self.

original: diṭṭhigāho attabhāvavipallāsaggāhato. Taṇhāgāho cettha aṭṭhasatataṇhāvicaritavasena,
analyzed: diṭṭhi gāhaḥ atta bhāva vipallāsa ggāhato taṇhā gāho ca ittha aṭṭha sata taṇhā vicarita vasena
translated: The ‘grasping of views’ is the perversion of the self-view. The ‘grasping of craving’ is the eighty-eight kinds of craving.

original: mānagāho navavidhamānavasena, diṭṭhigāho dvāsaṭṭhidiṭṭhivasena veditabbo. Imesaṃ
analyzed: māna gāhaḥ navavidha māna vasena diṭṭhi gāhaḥ dvāsaṭṭhi diṭṭhi vasena veditabbo imesam
translated: The ‘grasping of conceit’ is the nine kinds of conceit. The ‘grasping of views’ is the sixty-two views.

original: tiṇṇaṃ taṇhāmānadiṭṭhigāhānaṃ vasena yuttaṃ nu taṃ samanupassitunti vuttaṃ hoti.
analyzed: tiṇṇam taṇhā māna diṭṭhi gāhānam vasena yuttam nu tam samanupassitunti vuttam hoti
translated: It is said: “Is it proper to regard anything as self in terms of these three: craving, conceit, and views?”

original: Iti bhagavā aniccadukkhavasena anattalakkhaṇaṃyeva dassesi. Bhagavā hi katthaci aniccavasena🔽anattataṃ dasseti, katthaci dukkhavasena, katthaci ubhayavasena. Tathā hi “cakkhu
analyzed: iti bhagavā anicca dukkha vasena anatta lakkhaṇam yeva dassesi bhagavā hi katthaci anicca vasena  anatta tam dasseti katthaci dukkha vasena katthaci ubhaya vasena tathā hi cakkhu
translated: Thus the Blessed One taught the characteristic of non-self by way of impermanence and suffering. For the Blessed One sometimes teaches non-self by way of impermanence,

original: attāti yo vadeyya, taṃ na upapajjati, cakkhussa uppādopi vayopi paññāyati. Yassa
analyzed: attā iti yaḥ vadeyya tam na upapajjati cakkhussa uppādaḥ api vayaḥ api paññāyati yassa
translated: sometimes by way of suffering, and sometimes by way of both. Thus, “If anyone were to say, ‘The eye is the self,’ that would not be tenable. The arising and falling away of the eye are discerned.

original: kho pana uppādopi vayopi paññāyati, ‘attā me uppajjati ceva veti cā’ti iccassa evamāgataṃ
analyzed: kho pana uppādaḥ api vayaḥ api paññāyati attā me uppajjati ca iva veti ca ati iccassa evamāgatam
translated: For one for whom the arising and falling away are discerned, it would follow: ‘My self arises and falls away.’

original: hoti, tasmā taṃ na upapajjati. ‘Cakkhu attā’ti yo vadeyya, iti cakkhu anattā”ti imasmiñca
analyzed: hoti tasmā tam na upapajjati cakkhu attā ati yaḥ vadeyya iti cakkhu anattā ati imasmin ca
translated: Therefore that is not tenable. If anyone were to say, ‘The eye is the self,’ thus the eye is not the self.”

original: chachakkasutte aniccavasena anattataṃ dassesi. “Rūpañca hidaṃ, bhikkhave, attā abhavissa…pe…🔽evaṃ me rūpaṃ mā ahosī”ti imasmiṃyeva anattalakkhaṇasutte dukkhavasena anattataṃ🔽dassesi. “Rūpaṃ, bhikkhave, aniccaṃ, yadaniccaṃ taṃ dukkhaṃ, yaṃ dukkhaṃ tadanattā,
analyzed: chachakka sutte anicca vasena anatta tam dassesi rūpam ca hi dam bhikkhave attā  evam me rūpam mā ahosi iti imasmin yeva anatta lakkhaṇa sutte dukkha vasena anatta taṃ  dassesi rūpam bhikkhave aniccam yat aniccam tat dukkham yat dukkham tat anattā
translated: In the Chachakka Sutta he taught non-self by way of impermanence. In the Anattalakkhana Sutta he taught non-self by way of suffering in the passage beginning: “If now, bhikkhus, this material form were the self, this material form would not lead to affliction, and it should obtain in regard to this material form: ‘Let my material form be thus, let my material form be not thus’ …🔽🔽In the Anattalakkhana Sutta he taught non-self by way of suffering in the passage beginning: “Material form, bhikkhus, is impermanent, what is impermanent is suffering, what is suffering is non-self,🔽🔽

original: yadanattā, taṃ ‘netaṃ mama, nesohamasmi, na me so attā’ti evametaṃ yathābhūtaṃ sammappaññāya🔽daṭṭhabba”nti imasmiṃ arahantasutte ubhayavasena anattataṃ dassesi. Kasmā? Aniccaṃ
analyzed: yat anattā tam na itam mama na isaḥ ham asmi na me saḥ attā ati evam etam yathābhūtam sammappaññāya  daṭṭhabbanti imasmim arahanta sutte ubhaya vasena anatta tam dassesi kasmai aniccam
translated: In the Chachakka Sutta he taught non-self by way of impermanence. In the Anattalakkhaṇa Sutta he taught non-self by way of suffering in the passage beginning: “If, bhikkhus, material form were self, this material form would not lead to affliction, and it should obtain in regard to material form: ‘Let my material form be thus, let my material form be not thus’ …

original: dukkhañca pākaṭaṃ, anattā apākaṭaṃ. Paribhogabhājanādīsu hi bhinnesu “aho anicca”nti🔽vadanti, “aho anattā”ti pana vattā nāma natthi. Sarīre gaṇḍapiḷakāsu vā uṭṭhitāsu
analyzed: dukkham ca pākaṭam anattā apākaṭam paribhoga bhājana ādīsu hi bhinnesu aho aniccanti  vadanti aho anattā ati pana vattā nāma natthi sarīre gaṇḍa piḷakāsu vā uṭṭhitāsu
translated: In the Arahant Sutta he taught non-self by way of both impermanence and suffering. Why? Because impermanence and suffering are obvious, but non-self is not. For when a vessel used for eating, etc., is broken, people say: “Oh, how impermanent it is!”🔽But there is no one who says: “Oh, how non-self it is!” When boils or pimples appear on the body, or when one is pricked by a thorn, people cry out: “Oh, how painful it is!”

original: kaṇṭakena vā viddhā “aho dukkha”nti vadanti, “aho anattā”ti pana vattā nāma natthi.
analyzed: kaṇṭakena vā viddhā aho dukkhanti vadanti aho anattā ati pana vattā nāma natthi
translated: But there is no one who cries out: “Oh, how non-self it is!”

original: Kasmā? Idañhi anattalakkhaṇaṃ nāma avibhūtaṃ duddasaṃ duppaññāpanaṃ. Tathā hi sarabhaṅgādayopi🔽satthāro nāddasaṃsu, kuto paññāpanā, tena naṃ bhagavā aniccavasena vā dukkhavasena
analyzed: kasmai idam hi anatta lakkhaṇam nāma avibhūtam duddasam duppaññāpanam tathā hi sarabhaṅga ādayaḥ api  satthāraḥ na addasaṃsu kutas paññāpanā tena nam bhagavā anicca vasena vā dukkha vasena
translated: Why? Because this characteristic of not-self is subtle, hard to see, hard to comprehend, hard to penetrate. For even such teachers as Sarabhangas

original: vā ubhayavasena vā dassesi. Tayidaṃ imasmimpi teparivaṭṭe aniccadukkhavaseneva dassitaṃ.
analyzed: vā ubhaya vasena vā dassesi tayidam imasmim pi anicca dukkha vasena iva dassitam
translated: did not see it, so how could they teach it? Therefore the Blessed One showed it by way of the impermanent and painful or by way of both. And here in this Thread it is shown by way of the impermanent and painful.

original: Vedanādīsupi eseva nayo.🔽22. Tasmātihāti tasmā icceva vuttaṃ. Ti-kāra ha-kārā nipātā, yasmā ime pañcakkhandhā🔽aniccā dukkhā anattā, tasmāti attho. Yaṃ kiñcīti anavasesapariyādānametaṃ. Yanti
analyzed: vedanā ādī supi esā iva nayoḥ  tasmā atihāti tasmai icca iva vuttam tikāra hakārāḥ nipātāḥ yasmai ime pañca khandhā  aniccā dukkhā anattā tasmā ati atthaḥ yam kiñci iti anavasesa pariyādānam etam yanti
translated: The same method applies to feeling, and so on.

original: hi sāmaññena aniyamadassanaṃ, kiñcīti pakārato bhedaṃ āmasitvā aniyamadassanaṃ. Ubhayenapi
analyzed: hi sāmaññena aniyama dassanam kiñci iti pakārataḥ bhedam āmasitvā aniyama dassanam ubhayena api
translated: So: “Therefore” is what is said. The words “ti” and “ha” are particles. The meaning is: because these five categories are impermanent and painful and not-self. “ Whatever” is an expression for the complete inclusion of what is meant. “ What” is a non-specific way of seeing, while “ whatever” is a non-specific way of seeing after the specific difference has been touched upon.🔽By both together is meant what is not fit to be demonstrated as a neuter.

original: atītaṃ vā…pe… santike vā appaṃ vā bahuṃ vā yādisaṃ vā tādisaṃ vā napuṃsakaniddesārahaṃ
analyzed: atītam vāpe santike vā appam vā bahum vā yādisam vā tādisam vā napuṃsaka niddesa araham
translated: Whether past, future, or present, near or far, little or much, whatever kind it is, that kind.

original: sabbaṃ byāpetvā saṅgaṇhāti, tasmā anavasesapariyādānametaṃ “yaṃ kiñcī”ti. Evañca🔽sati aññesupi napuṃsakaniddesārahesu pasaṅgaṃ disvā tattha adhippetatthaṃ adhicca🔽pavattanato atippasaṅgassa niyamanatthaṃ “rūpa”nti vuttaṃ. Evaṃ padadvayenapi rūpassa
analyzed: sabbam byāpetvā saṅgaṇhāti tasmai anavasesa pariyādānam etam yam kiñci iti evam ca  sati aññesu pi napuṃsaka niddesa arahesu pasaṅgam disvā tattha adhippetattham adhicca  pavattanataḥ atippasaṅgassa niyamana attham rūpan ti vuttam evam pada dvayena api rūpassa
translated: and it includes all, therefore it is a complete pervasion.🔽And when that is so, then, seeing that the expression “anything” is applicable in other instances as well, it is stated as “materiality” in order to restrict the meaning intended here by preventing the occurrence of the expression “anything” in those other instances.

original: asesapariggaho kato hoti. Athassa atītādivibhāgaṃ ārabhati “atītānāgatapaccuppanna”ntiādinā.
analyzed: asesa pariggahaḥ kataḥ hoti athassa atīta ādi vibhāgam ārabhati atīta anāgata paccuppanna nti ādinā
translated: So by the two words “anything” and “materiality” the complete pervasion of materiality is made. Then he begins the analysis of it as past, etc., with the words “Past, future, and present” .🔽For some of it is past, some future, and some present.

original: Tañhi kiñci atītaṃ kiñci anāgatādibhedanti. Esa nayo vedanādīsupi.
analyzed: tat hi atītam anāgata ādi bhedanti esa nayaḥ
translated: The same method applies in the case of feeling, and so on.

original: Tattha rūpaṃ tāva addhāsantatisamayakhaṇavasena catudhā atītaṃ nāma hoti, tathā anāgatapaccuppannaṃ.🔽Tattha addhāvasena tāva ekassa ekasmiṃ bhave paṭisandhito pubbe atītaṃ, cutito uddhamanāgataṃ,
analyzed: tattha rūpam tāva addhā santati samaya khaṇa vasena catudhā atītam nāma hoti tathā anāgata paccuppannam  tattha addhā vasena tāva ekassa ekasmin bhave paṭisandhitaḥ pubbe atītam cutitaḥ uddham anāgatam
translated: Herein, materiality is called past, future, and present according to whether it is in the past, future, or present time period, according to its continuity, according to its occasion, and according to its moment.🔽Herein, according to time period is how it is in the first place. For that of one who is in a single becoming is past before the rebirth-linking and after the death,

original: ubhinnamantare paccuppannaṃ. Santativasena sabhāgekautusamuṭṭhānaekāhārasamauṭṭhānañca
analyzed: ubhinnam antare paccuppannam santati vasena
translated: and it is future in between. According to continuity is how it is in a single continuity. For that of one who is of mixed sex is past in one who has become a male or a female,🔽and it is future in one who is still sexless.

original: pubbāpariyavasena vattamānampi paccuppannaṃ, tato pubbe visabhāgautuāhārasamuṭṭhānaṃ🔽atītaṃ, pacchā anāgataṃ. Cittajaṃ ekavīthiekajavanaekasamāpattisamuṭṭhānaṃ paccuppannaṃ,
analyzed: pubba apariya vasena vattamānam pi paccuppannam tatas pubbe visabhāga otu āhāra samuṭṭhānam  atītam pacchā anāgatam citta jam eka vīthi eka javana eka samāpatti samuṭṭhānam paccuppannam
translated: What is occurring in the past and future by way of succession is still present. What is originated by temperature and nutriment prior to that is past. What is originated by temperature and nutriment subsequent to that is future. What is originated by consciousness is present if it is originated by a single consciousness, a single impulsion, a single jhāna.

original: tato pubbe atītaṃ, pacchā anāgataṃ. Kammasamuṭṭhānassa pāṭiyekkaṃ santativasena atītādibhedo🔽natthi. Tesaṃyeva pana utuāhāracittasamuṭṭhānānaṃ upatthambhakavasena tassa atītādibhāvo
analyzed: tatas pubbe atītam pacchā anāgatam kamma samuṭṭhānassa pāṭiyekkam santati vasena atīta ādi bhedaḥ  natthi tesam yeva pana utu āhāra citta samuṭṭhānānam upatthambhaka vasena tassa atīta ādi bhāvo
translated: What is originated by consciousness prior to that is past. What is originated by consciousness subsequent to that is future. As to what is originated by kamma, there is no division into past, etc., by way of its own continuity.

original: veditabbo. Samayavasena ekamuhuttapubbaṇhasāyanharattidivādīsu samayesu santānavasena🔽pavattamānaṃ taṃtaṃsamayavantaṃ rūpaṃ paccuppannaṃ nāma, tato pubbe atītaṃ, pacchā🔽anāgataṃ. Khaṇavasena uppādādikkhaṇattayapariyāpannaṃ paccuppannaṃ, tato pubbe atītaṃ,
analyzed: veditabbaḥ samaya vasena eka muhutta pubbaṇha sāyanharatti divā ādīsu samayesu santāna vasena  pavattamānam taṃ taṃ samayavantam rūpam paccuppannam nāma tatas pubbe atītam pacchā  anāgatam khaṇa vasena uppāda ādi khaṇa ttaya pariyāpannam paccuppannam tatas pubbe atītam
translated: But its pastness, etc., should be understood according to the pastness, etc., of the temperature and nutriment and consciousness that maintain it.🔽As to occasion: what occurs in a continuity in the various occasions such as a single moment, a morning, an evening, a night and day, etc., is called present. What occurred in a similar occasion in the past is past. What will occur in a similar occasion in the future is future.

original: pacchā anāgataṃ, idamevettha nippariyāyaṃ, sesā pariyāyakathā.
analyzed: pacchā anāgatam idam eva itthā nippariyāyam sesā pariyāya kathā
translated: As to instant: what is included in the three instants beginning with arising is present. What was included in these instants in the past is past. What will be included in them in the future is future. This is the literal meaning here. The rest is a commentary on the categories.

original: Ajjhattaṃ vā bahiddhā vāti cakkhādipañcavidhaṃ rūpaṃ attabhāvaṃ adhikicca pavattattā
analyzed: ajjhattam vā bahiddhā vāti cakkhu ādi pañcavidham rūpam atta bhāvam adhikicca pavatta ttā
translated: Either internally or externally: the five kinds of materiality beginning with the eye is “internally” because it occurs in dependence on what is one’s own self;

original: ajjhattaṃ, sesaṃ tato bāhirattā bahiddhā. Apica niyakajjhattampi idha ajjhattaṃ,🔽parapuggalikampi ca bahiddhāti veditabbaṃ. Oḷārikaṃ vā sukhumaṃ vāti cakkhādīni nava,
analyzed: ajjhattam sesam tatas bahiddhā apica niyaka jjhattam pi idha ajjhattam  parapuggalikam pi ca bahiddhā ti veditabbam oḷārikam vā sukhumam vā ati cakkha ādīni nava
translated: the rest is “externally” because it is outside that. Furthermore, what is one’s own is “internally” here;🔽and what belongs to another person is “externally.”

original: āpodhātuvajjā tisso dhātuyo cāti dvādasavidhaṃ rūpaṃ ghaṭṭanavasena gahetabbato oḷārikaṃ,
analyzed: āpaḥ dhātu vajjāḥ tissaḥ dhātuyaḥ ca ati dvādasavidham rūpam ghaṭṭana vasena gahetabbataḥ oḷārikam
translated: Gross or subtle: the nine beginning with the eye, and the three elements excluding the water element, that is to say, twelve kinds of materiality, are “gross” because they are apprehensible by impinging;

original: sesaṃ tato viparītattā sukhumaṃ. Hīnaṃ vā paṇītaṃ vāti ettha hīnapaṇītabhāvo pariyāyato🔽nippariyāyato ca. Tattha akaniṭṭhānaṃ rūpato sudassīnaṃ rūpaṃ hīnaṃ, tadeva sudassānaṃ
analyzed: sesam tatas viparīta ttā sukhumam hīnam vā paṇītam vā ati ettha hīna paṇīta bhāvaḥ pariyāyato  nippariyāyato ca tattha akaniṭṭhānam rūpataḥ sudassīnam rūpam hīnam tat eva sudassānam
translated: the rest is “subtle” because it is the opposite of that. Inferior or superior: here the state of being inferior or superior is in terms of a roundabout way🔽and in terms of a direct way. Herein, the materiality of the Sudassī Brahmās is inferior in kind to that of the Akaniṭṭha Brahmās;🔽that same materiality of the Sudassī Brahmās is superior in kind to that of the Vehapphala Brahmās. So too in the case of the Aviha Brahmās, and so on, down among human beings.

original: rūpato paṇītaṃ. Evaṃ yāva narakasattānaṃ rūpaṃ, tāva pariyāyato hīnapaṇītatā veditabbā.
analyzed: rūpataḥ paṇītam evam yāva naraka sattānam rūpam tāva pariyāyataḥ hīna paṇīta tā veditabbā
translated: This is how the state of being inferior and superior should be understood in a roundabout way.

original: Nippariyāyato pana yaṃ ārammaṇaṃ katvā akusalavipākaviññāṇaṃ uppajjati, taṃ hīnaṃ
analyzed: nippariyāyataḥ pana yam ārammaṇam katvā akusala vipāka viññāṇam uppajjati tam hīnam
translated: But in the direct way, that object is inferior in kind in regard to which unprofitable resultant consciousness arises,

original: aniṭṭhabhāvato. Yaṃ pana ārammaṇaṃ katvā kusalavipākaviññāṇaṃ uppajjati, taṃ paṇītaṃ
analyzed: aniṭṭha bhāvataḥ yam pana ārammaṇam katvā kusala vipāka viññāṇam uppajjati tam paṇītam
translated: As to unattractiveness. But that object in dependence on which profitable resultant consciousness arises is superior,

original: iṭṭhabhāvato. Yathā hi akusalavipāko sayaṃ aniṭṭho aniṭṭhe eva uppajjati, na iṭṭhe,
analyzed: iṭṭha bhāvataḥ yathā hi akusala vipākaḥ sayam aniṭṭhaḥ aniṭṭhe eva uppajjati na iṭṭhe
translated: as to attractiveness. For just as unprofitable resultant consciousness, being itself unpleasing, arises only in relation to what is unpleasing, not in relation to what is pleasing,

original: evaṃ kusalavipākopi sayaṃ iṭṭho iṭṭheyeva uppajjati, na aniṭṭhe. Yaṃ dūre santike
analyzed: evam kusala vipākaḥ api sayam iṭṭhaḥ iṭṭhe iva uppajjati na aniṭṭhe yam dūre santike
translated: so profitable resultant consciousness, being itself pleasing, arises only in relation to what is pleasing, not in relation to what is unpleasing. What is subtle is far,

original: vāti yaṃ sukhumaṃ, tadeva duppaṭivijjhasabhāvattā dūre, itaraṃ suppaṭivijjhasabhāvattā🔽santike. Apicettha okāsatopi upādāyupādāya dūrasantikatā veditabbā. Taṃ sabbanti🔽taṃ atītādīhi padehi visuṃ niddiṭṭhaṃ sabbaṃ rūpaṃ. Sammappaññāya daṭṭhabbanti sahavipassanāya
analyzed: vāti yam su khumam tat eva duppaṭivijjha sabhāva ttā dūre itaram  santike api ca ittha okāsataḥ pi upādāya upādāya dūra santika tā veditabbā tam sabbam ti  tam atīta ādīhi padehi visum niddiṭṭham sabbam rūpam sammappaññāya daṭṭhabbanti saha vipassanāya
translated: because of the difficulty of discerning it, and what is gross is near, because of the ease of discerning it.🔽And here the farness and nearness should be understood according to the position of the object in space and according to the kind of object.

original: maggapaññāya daṭṭhabbaṃ.
analyzed: magga paññāya daṭṭhabbam
translated: All that is … to be seen … with right understanding: all that materiality, which is stated in the various ways by means of the terms “past,” etc., is to be seen with understanding accompanied by the path.

original: Yā kāci vedanātiādīsu pana santativasena ca khaṇavasena ca vedanāya atītānāgatapaccuppannabhāvo
analyzed: yā kāci vedanā ati ādīsu pana santati vasena ca khaṇa vasena ca vedanāya atīta anāgata paccuppanna bhāvaḥ
translated: As to feeling, etc., the past, future and present state should be understood according to continuity and according to moment.

original: veditabbo. Tattha santativasena ekavīthiekajavanaekasamāpattipariyāpannā ekavidhavisayasamāyogappavattā
analyzed: veditabbaḥ tattha santati vasena eka vīthi eka javana eka samāpatti pariyāpannā ekavidha visaya samāyoga ppavattā
translated: and should be known. Herein, as to continuity, they are included in a single life, a single impulsion, a single attainment, and they occur in association with a single object.

original: ca divasampi buddharūpaṃ passantassa dhammaṃ suṇantassa pavattasaddhādisahitavedanā
analyzed: ca divasam pi buddha rūpam passantassa dhammam suṇantassa pavatta saddhā ādi sahita vedanā
translated: And when a man is looking at the Enlightened One’s bodily form or listening to the Dhamma, the feeling that occurs together with the faith, etc., is present.🔽That is present. Before that it was past. After that it will be future.

original: paccuppannā, tato pubbe atītā, pacchā anāgatā. Khaṇavasena khaṇattayapariyāpannā
analyzed: paccuppannā tatas pubbe atītā pacchā anāgatā khaṇa vasena khaṇa ttaya pariyāpannā
translated: As to instant: that included in the three instants is present.🔽Before that it was future; after that it will be past.

original: paccuppannā, tato pubbe atītā, pacchā anāgatā. Ajjhattabahiddhābhedo niyakajjhattavasena🔽veditabbo. Oḷārikasukhumabhedo “akusalā vedanā oḷārikā, kusalābyākatā vedanā sukhumā”tiādinā🔽nayena vibhaṅge vuttena jātisabhāvapuggalalokiyalokuttaravasena veditabbo. Jātivasena
analyzed: paccuppannā tatas pubbe atītā pacchā anāgatā ajjhatta bahiddhā bhedaḥ niyaka jjhatta vasena  veditabbaḥ oḷārika sukhuma bhedaḥ akusalā vedanā oḷārikā kusalā abyākatā vedanā sukhumā ati ādinā  nayena vibhaṅge vuttena jāti sabhāva puggala lokiya lokuttara vasena veditabbaḥ jāti vasena
translated: As to internal and external: it should be understood as one’s own by internal, and as another’s by external.🔽As to gross and subtle: unwholesome feeling is gross, and wholesome and indeterminate feeling is subtle. This is how it should be understood according to the method stated in the Vibhaṅga .🔽As to kind: unwholesome feeling is called “blameworthy” because it is a cause for reproachable kamma, and because it is of a nature to torment with defilements.

original: tāva akusalavedanā sāvajjakiriyahetuto kilesasantāpasabhāvato ca avūpasantavuttīti
analyzed: tāva akusala vedanā sāvajja kiriya hetutaḥ kilesa santāpa sabhāvataḥ ca a vūpasanta vutti iti
translated: It is called “unprofitable” because it is a cause for unprofitable result, and because it is a cause for the occurrence of unprofitable things.

original: kusalavedanāya oḷārikā, sabyāpārato saussāhato savipākato kilesasantāpasabhāvato
analyzed: kusala vedanāya oḷārikā sa byāpārato sa aussāhato sa vipākato kilesa santāpa sabhāvato
translated: It is gross compared with profitable feeling, because of its grossness, its being with prompting, its being with strain, its having a sequel, and its being of the nature associated with the defilements’ heat.

original: sāvajjato ca vipākābyākatāya oḷārikā, savipākato kilesasantāpasabhāvato sabyāpajjato🔽sāvajjato ca kiriyābyākatāya oḷārikā, kusalābyākatā pana vuttavipariyāyato akusalāya🔽sukhumā. Dvepi kusalākusalavedanā sabyāpārato saussāhato savipākato ca yathāyogaṃ
analyzed: sāvajjataḥ ca vipāka abyākatāya oḷārikā sa vipākataḥ kilesa santāpa sabhāvataḥ sa byāpajjataḥ  sā avajjataḥ ca kiriyā abyākatāya oḷārikā kusala abyākatā pana vutta vipariyāyataḥ akusalāya  sukhumā dve api kusala akusala vedanā sa byāpārataḥ sa aussāhataḥ sa vipākataḥ ca yathāyogam
translated: It is gross compared with the resultant-neutral feeling, because of its having a sequel and its being of the nature associated with the defilements’ heat, and because of its blameableness.🔽It is gross compared with the functional-neutral feeling, because of its having a sequel. But the profitable-neutral feeling is subtle compared with the unprofitable, and vice versa, in the opposite way.🔽And the two kinds of feeling, profitable and unprofitable, are gross compared with the two kinds of neutral feeling, according as is appropriate, because of their being with prompting, their being with strain, and their having a sequel.

original: duvidhāyapi abyākatāya oḷārikā, vuttavipariyāyena duvidhāpi abyākatā tāhi sukhumā.
analyzed: oḷārikā vutta vipariyāyena duvidhā api abyākatā sukhumā
translated: But the two kinds of neutral feeling are subtle compared with those two, in the opposite way.

original: Evaṃ tāva jātivasena oḷārikasukhumatā veditabbā.🔽Sabhāvavasena pana dukkhavedanā nirassādato savipphārato ubbejanīyato abhibhavanato
analyzed: evam tāva jāti vasena oḷārika sukhuma tā veditabbā  sabhāva vasena pana dukkha vedanā nirassādato sa vipphārataḥ ubbejanīyataḥ abhibhavanato
translated: This, in the first place, is how grossness and subtlety should be understood according to kind.🔽But as to individual essence, painful feeling is gross compared with the other two because of its unsatisfactoriness, its being with prompting, its being agitating, and its being over-ridden.

original: ca itarāhi dvīhi oḷārikā, itarā pana dve sātato santato paṇītato manāpato majjhattato
analyzed: ca itarāhi dvīhi oḷārikā itarā pana dve sātataḥ santataḥ paṇītataḥ manāpataḥ majjhattataḥ
translated: But the other two are subtle compared with the painful, because of their satisfaction, their peace, their excellence, their agreeableness, and their neutrality.

original: ca yathāyogaṃ dukkhāya sukhumā. Ubho pana sukhadukkhā savipphārato khobhakaraṇato🔽pākaṭato ca adukkhamasukhāya oḷārikā, sā vuttavipariyāyena tadubhayato sukhumā. Evaṃ
analyzed: ca yathāyogam dukkhāya sukhumā ubho pana sukha dukkhā sa vipphārato khobha karaṇato  pākaṭato ca adukkhamasukhāya oḷārikā sā vutta vipariyāyena tad ubhayataḥ sukhumā evam
translated: and the pleasant is subtle in the opposite way. But both the painful and the pleasant are gross in one who is agitated, in one who is not concentrated, in one who is undeveloped, and subtle in one who is not agitated, in one who is concentrated, in one who is developed.🔽And both the painful and the pleasant are gross in one who is ordinary, and subtle in one who is a noble disciple.

original: sabhāvavasena oḷārikasukhumatā veditabbā. Puggalavasena pana asamāpannassa vedanā
analyzed: sabhāva vasena oḷārika sukhuma tā veditabbā puggala vasena pana asamāpannassa vedanā
translated: This is how they should be understood as gross and subtle according to individual essence.

original: nānārammaṇavikkhittabhāvato samāpannassa vedanāya oḷārikā, vipariyāyena itarā sukhumā.
analyzed: nānā ārammaṇa vikkhitta bhāvataḥ samāpannassa vedanāya oḷārikā vipariyāyena itarā sukhumā
translated: But in the case of the feeling of one who is not concentrated, the object is diversified and scattered, and so it is gross compared with the feeling of one who is concentrated. The opposite is subtle.

original: Evaṃ puggalavasena oḷārikasukhumatā veditabbā. Lokiyalokuttaravasena pana sāsavā🔽vedanā lokiyā. Sā āsavuppattihetuto oghaniyato yoganiyato ganthaniyato nīvaraṇiyato
analyzed: evam puggala vasena oḷārika sukhuma tā veditabbā lokiya lokuttara vasena pana sa āsavā  vedanā lokiyā sā āsava uppatti hetutaḥ ogha niyataḥ yoga niyataḥ gantha niyataḥ nīvara niyataḥ
translated: This is how they should be understood as gross and subtle according to the individual.

original: upādāniyato saṃkilesikato puthujjanasādhāraṇato ca anāsavāya oḷārikā, sā vipariyāyena
analyzed: upādāniyato saṃkilesikato puthujjana sādhāraṇato ca anāsavāya oḷārikā sā vipariyāyena
translated: But in the case of the feeling of one who is in the mundane, it is gross compared with the supramundane, because it is the cause for the occurrence of the taints, because it is subject to the floods,13 because it is subject to the bonds, because it is subject to the ties, because it is subject to the hindrances, because it is subject to defilement, and because it is shared by ordinary people. The opposite is subtle.

original: sāsavāya sukhumā. Evaṃ lokiyalokuttaravasena oḷārikasukhumatā veditabbā.
analyzed: sa āsavāya sukhumā evam lokiya lokuttara vasena oḷārika sukhuma tā veditabbā
translated: This is how they should be understood as gross and subtle according to the mundane and supramundane.

original: Tattha jātiādivasena sambhedo pariharitabbo. Akusalavipākakāyaviññāṇasampayuttā hi🔽vedanā jātivasena abyākatattā sukhumāpi samānā sabhāvādivasena oḷārikā hoti. Vuttañhetaṃ🔽“abyākatā vedanā sukhumā, dukkhā vedanā oḷārikā. Asamāpannassa vedanā oḷārikā, sāsavā
analyzed: tattha jāti ādi vasena sambhedaḥ pariharitabbaḥ akusala vipāka kāya viññāṇa sampayuttāḥ hi  vedanā jāti vasena sukhumā api samānā sabhāva ādi vasena oḷārikā hoti vuttam ha etam  abyākatā vedanā sukhumā dukkhā vedanā oḷārikā asamāpannassa vedanā oḷārikā sa āsavā
translated: Here the confusion due to birth, etc., should be avoided. For the feeling associated with the resultant body-consciousness is indeterminate.🔽Although subtle by birth, it is gross by individual essence, etc. For this is said:🔽“Indeterminate feeling is subtle; painful feeling is gross. The feeling of one who is not fully absorbed is gross; the feeling of one who is fully absorbed is subtle. The feeling of one who is not free from lust is gross; the feeling of one who is free from lust is subtle” .

original: vedanā oḷārikā”ti. Yathā ca dukkhavedanā, evaṃ sukhādayopi jātivasena oḷārikā, sabhāvādivasena🔽sukhumā honti. Tasmā yathā jātiādivasena sambhedo na hoti, tathā vedanānaṃ oḷārikasukhumatā🔽veditabbā. Seyyathidaṃ – abyākatā jātivasena kusalākusalāhi sukhumā. Na tattha “katamā
analyzed: vedanā oḷārikā ti yathā ca dukkha vedanā evam sukha ādayaḥ api jāti vasena oḷārikā sabhāva ādi vasena  sukhumāḥ honti tasmai yathā jāti ādi vasena sambhedaḥ na tathā oḷārika sukhuma tā  veditabbā sā iyyathidam abyākatā jāti vasena kusala akusalāhi sukhumā na tattha katamā
translated: And just as painful feeling is gross by birth, so too are pleasant, etc., feelings gross by birth, but subtle by individual essence, etc.🔽Therefore the grossness and subtlety of feelings should be understood in such a way that there is no confusion due to birth, etc.

original: abyākatā, kiṃ dukkhā, kiṃ sukhā, kiṃ samāpannassa, kiṃ asamāpannassa, kiṃ sāsavā,
analyzed: abyākatā kim dukkhā kim sukhā kim samāpannassa kim asamāpannassa kim sa āsavā
translated: For example, the indeterminate is subtle by birth compared with the profitable and unprofitable. And there is no need to specify its individual essence, etc., as follows: “What is indeterminate? Is it painful, or pleasant, or neither-painful-nor-pleasant? Is it the feeling of one who is not fully absorbed, or of one who is fully absorbed? Is it the feeling of one who is not free from lust, or of one who is free from lust?

original: kiṃ anāsavā”ti evaṃ sabhāvādibhedo parāmasitabbo. Esa nayo sabbattha.
analyzed: kim anāsavā ti evam sabhāva ādi bhedaḥ parāmasitabbaḥ esa nayaḥ sabbattha
translated: Is it the feeling of one who is not free from ignorance, or of one who is free from ignorance?” The same method applies in all cases.

original: Apica “taṃ taṃ vā pana vedanaṃ upādāyupādāya vedanā oḷārikā sukhumā daṭṭhabbā”ti
analyzed: apica tam tam vā pana vedanam upādāya upādāya vedanā oḷārikā sukhumā daṭṭhabbā ati
translated: Furthermore, “Any feeling whatsoever that is clung to is to be seen as gross and subtle” .

original: vacanato akusalādīsupi lobhasahagatāya dosasahagatavedanā aggi viya attano nissayadahanato
analyzed: vacanataḥ akusala ādīsu pi lobha sahagatāya dosa sahagata vedanā aggi viya attanaḥ nissaya dahanato
translated: So too, in the case of unprofitable and so on: the feeling associated with greed is gross compared with that associated with hate, because the former’s nutriment is what is devoured by the latter.

original: oḷārikā, lobhasahagatā sukhumā. Dosasahagatāpi niyatā oḷārikā, aniyatā sukhumā. Niyatāpi
analyzed: oḷārikā lobha sahagatā sukhumā dosa sahagatā api niyatā oḷārikā aniyatā sukhumā niyatā api
translated: That associated with greed is subtle compared with that associated with hate. That associated with hate is gross if it is fixed , and subtle if it is unfixed.

original: kappaṭṭhitikā oḷārikā, itarā sukhumā. Kappaṭṭhitikāsupi asaṅkhārikā oḷārikā, itarā🔽sukhumā. Lobhasahagatā pana diṭṭhisampayuttā oḷārikā, itarā sukhumā. Sāpi niyatā
analyzed: kappaṭṭhitikā oḷārikā itarā sukhumā kappaṭṭhitikāsu pi asaṅkhārikā oḷārikā itarā  sukhumā lobha sahagatā pana diṭṭhi sampayuttā oḷārikā itarā sukhumā sā api niyatā
translated: That which is fixed is gross if it lasts for an aeon, and subtle if it does not. That which lasts for an aeon is gross if it is unprompted, and subtle if it is prompted.

original: kappaṭṭhitikā asaṅkhārikā oḷārikā, itarā sukhumā, avisesena akusalā bahuvipākā oḷārikā,🔽appavipākā sukhumā. Kusalā pana appavipākā oḷārikā, bahuvipākā sukhumā.
analyzed: kappa ṭṭhitikā asaṅkhārikā oḷārikā itarā sukhumā avisesena akusalā bahu vipākā oḷārikā  appa vipākā sukhumā kusalā pana appa vipākā oḷārikā bahu vipākā sukhumā
translated: That associated with greed is gross if associated with false view, and subtle if not so associated. That too is gross if fixed, lasting for an aeon, and unprompted, and subtle if not so. Unprofitable feeling is gross if it has much kamma-result, and subtle if it has little.🔽But profitable feeling is gross if it has little kamma-result, and subtle if it has much.

original: Apica kāmāvacarakusalā oḷārikā, rūpāvacarā sukhumā, tato arūpāvacarā, tato lokuttarā.
analyzed: apica kāmāvacara kusalā oḷārikā rūpāvacarā sukhumā tatas arūpāvacarā tatas lokuttarā
translated: Furthermore, profitable feeling in the sense sphere is gross, that in the fine-material sphere is subtle; that in the fine-material sphere is gross, that in the immaterial sphere is subtle; that in the immaterial sphere is gross, the supramundane is subtle.

original: Kāmāvacarā ca dānamayā oḷārikā, sīlamayā sukhumā, tato bhāvanāmayā. Bhāvanāmayāpi
analyzed: kāmāvacarā ca dāna mayā oḷārikā sīla mayā sukhumā tatas bhāvanā mayā bhāvanā mayā api
translated: And the sense-sphere profitable is gross compared with the sense-sphere unprofitable, and the sense-sphere profitable is gross compared with the fine-material profitable, and the sense-sphere profitable is gross compared with the immaterial profitable.🔽The sense-sphere profitable is gross compared with the sense-sphere unprofitable, and the sense-sphere profitable is gross compared with the fine-material profitable, and the sense-sphere profitable is gross compared with the immaterial profitable.

original: duhetukā oḷārikā, tihetukā sukhumā. Tihetukāpi sasaṅkhārikā oḷārikā, asaṅkhārikā🔽sukhumā. Rūpāvacarā paṭhamajjhānikā oḷārikā…pe… pañcamajjhānikā sukhumāva. Arūpāvacarā🔽ākāsānañcāyatanasampayuttā oḷārikā…pe… nevasaññānāsaññāyatanasampayuttā sukhumāva.
analyzed: du hetukā oḷārikā ti hetukā sukhumā ti hetukā api sa saṅkhārikā oḷārikā asaṅkhārikā  sukhumā rūpāvacarā paṭhama jhānikā pañcama jhānikā sukhumā ava arūpāvacarā  ākāsa anañcāyatana sampayuttā nevasaññānāsaññāyatana sampayuttā
translated: The fine-material profitable is gross compared with the immaterial profitable.

original: Lokuttarā ca sotāpattimaggasampayuttā oḷārikā…pe… arahattamaggasampayuttā sukhumāva.
analyzed: lokuttarā ca sotāpatti magga sampayuttā arahatta magga sampayuttā
translated: The immaterial profitable is gross compared with the supramundane profitable.🔽So too with the resultant and functional kinds of feeling.

original: Esa nayo taṃtaṃbhūmivipākakiriyavedanāsu dukkhādiasamāpannādisāsavādivasena vuttavedanāsu ca.
analyzed: esa nayo taṃ taṃ bhūmi vipāka kiriya vedanāsu dukkha ādi asamāpanna ādi sāsava ādi vasena vutta vedanāsu ca
translated: And as regards the kinds of feeling classed according to the plane, the kinds of feeling classed according to the fruition attainment, and the kinds of feeling classed as subject to cankers, etc., the gross kind should be understood in each case as that which is respectively associated with the first jhāna, etc., and the subtle kind as that which is respectively associated with the second jhāna, etc.

original: Okāsavasena cāpi niraye dukkhā oḷārikā, tiracchānayoniyaṃ sukhumā…pe… paranimmitavasavattī
analyzed: okāsa vasena ca api niraye dukkhā oḷārikā tiracchānayoniyam sukhumāpe
translated: And as regards the kinds of feeling classed according to the place of rebirth, the feeling in hell is gross, that in the animal womb is subtle; that in the realm of ghosts is gross, that in the animal womb is subtle; that in the animal womb is gross, that in the realm of ghosts is subtle; that in the realm of ghosts is gross, that in the Asura realm is subtle; that in the Asura realm is gross, that in the human world is subtle; that in the human world is gross, that in the deva world is subtle; that in the deva world is gross, that in the Brahmā-world is subtle.

original: sukhumāva. Yathā ca dukkhā, evaṃ sukhāpi sabbattha yathānurūpaṃ yojetabbā. Vatthuvasena
analyzed: yathā ca dukkhā evam sukhā api sabbattha yathānurūpam yojetabbā vatthu vasena
translated: And as with the gross and subtle in the kinds of feeling classed according to the place of rebirth, so also with the gross and subtle in the kinds of feeling classed according to the kind of action, the kinds of feeling classed according to the kind of destiny, the kinds of feeling classed according to the kind of kamma, the kinds of feeling classed according to the kind of kamma-result, the kinds of feeling classed according to the kind of kamma-resultant, the kinds of feeling classed according to the kind of kamma-born, the kinds of feeling classed according to the kind of kamma-born-resultant, the kinds of feeling classed according to the kind of kamma-born-born, the kinds of feeling classed according to the kind of kamma-born-

original: cāpi hīnavatthukā yā kāci vedanā oḷārikā, paṇītavatthukā sukhumā. Hīnappaṇītabhede
analyzed: ca api hīna vatthukā yā kāci vedanā oḷārikā paṇīta vatthukā sukhumā hīna ppaṇīta bhede
translated: and the gross feeling is the gross-based one, the subtle one is the subtle-based one.

original: yā oḷārikā, sā hīnā. Yā ca sukhumā, sā paṇītāti veditabbā. Dūrapadaṃ pana akusalā
analyzed: yā oḷārikā sā hīnā yā ca sukhumā sā paṇītā ati veditabbā dūra padam pana akusalā
translated: The gross should be understood as the gross-based one, and the subtle as the subtle-based one.

original: vedanā kusalābyākatāhi vedanāhi dūre, santikapadaṃ akusalā vedanā akusalāya vedanāya🔽santiketiādinā nayena vibhattaṃ. Tasmā akusalā vedanā visabhāgato asaṃsaṭṭhato asarikkhato
analyzed: vedanā kusalā abyākatā hi vedanāhi dūre santika padam akusalā vedanā akusalāya vedanāya  santika iti ādinā nayena vibhattam tasmai akusalā vedanā visabhāgataḥ a saṃsaṭṭhataḥ a sarikkhataḥ
translated: The word “far” is used of the unprofitable feeling in the sense of its being far from the profitable and indeterminate feelings.🔽The word “near” is used of the unprofitable feeling in the sense of its being near to the unprofitable feeling.🔽So too with the profitable and indeterminate feelings. Thus the unprofitable feeling is far from the profitable and indeterminate feelings because it is unlike them, is not mixed with them, and is not similar to them.

original: ca kusalābyākatāhi dūre, tathā kusalābyākatā akusalāya. Esa nayo sabbavāresu. Akusalā
analyzed: ca kusala abyākatāhi dūre tathā kusala abyākatā akusalāya esa nayo sabba vāresu akusalā
translated: And so too with the profitable and indeterminate feelings.🔽But the unprofitable feeling is near to the unprofitable feeling because it is like it, is mixed with it, and is similar to it.

original: pana vedanā sabhāgato ca saṃsaṭṭhato ca sarikkhato ca akusalāya santiketi. Taṃtaṃvedanāsampayuttānaṃ
analyzed: pana vedanā sabhāgato ca saṃsaṭṭhato ca sarikkhato ca akusalāya santike iti taṃ taṃ vedanā sampayuttānam
translated: And so too with the profitable and indeterminate feelings.🔽And the same method applies to the other triads.

original: pana saññādīnampi evameva veditabbaṃ.
analyzed: pana saññā ādīnam pi evam eva veditabbam
translated: The same method applies to the other dyads too.🔽The learned are so called because they possess much learning consisting of the scriptures and the realization .

original: 23. Sutavāti āgamādhigamasaṅkhātena bāhusaccena samannāgatattā sutavā. Nibbindatīti
analyzed: sutavā iti āgama adhigama saṅkhātena bāhusaccena samannāgata ttā sutavā nibbindati iti
translated: He becomes dispassionate.

analyzed: ukkaṇṭhati ettha ca nibbidā ti vuṭṭhāna gāminī vipassanā adhippetā nibbindam virajjati iti  ettha virāga vasena cattāraḥ maggā kathitāḥ virāgā vimuccati iti virāgena maggena iva hetu bhūtena

original: vimuttamiti ñāṇaṃ hotīti iminā pana paccavekkhaṇañāṇaṃ kathitaṃ. Khīṇā jātītiādīhi

analyzed: tassa bhūmi tena hi ñāṇena ariya sāvako paccavekkhantaḥ khīṇā jātī iti ādīni pajānāti  katamā pana assa jāti khīṇā katham ca nam pajānāti iti na tāva assa atītā jāti khīṇā pubbā eva
