analyzed: na ādesanā anusāsanī pāṭihāriyanti tividham hi pāṭihāriyam iddhi pāṭihāriyam ādesanā pāṭihāriyam  anusāsanī pāṭihāriyanti tattha idha bhikkhu ekaḥ api hutvā bahudhā hoti bahudhā api
translated: The meaning is that it is not the miracle of reading the minds of others and of instruction. For the miracle is threefold as the miracle of psychic potency, the miracle of reading the minds of others,

original: hutvā eko hoti āvibhāvaṃ tirobhāva”ntiādinayappavattaṃ iddhividhameva iddhipāṭihāriyaṃ.
analyzed: hutvā ekaḥ hoti āvi bhāvam tirobhāva nti ādi naya ppavattam iddhi vidham eva iddhi pāṭihāriyam
translated: and the miracle of instruction. Herein, the miracle of psychic potency is the psychic potency that occurs in the way beginning “Here a bhikkhu, becoming one, becomes many” , “He makes one, becomes many” , “He makes himself visible to one, invisible to another” , and so on.

original: “Idha bhikkhu parasattānaṃ parapuggalānaṃ cittampi ādisati, cetasikampi ādisati,
analyzed: idha bhikkhu para sattānam para puggalānam cittam api ādisati cetasikam api ādisati
translated: “Here a bhikkhu reveals the minds of other beings, of other persons, having encompassed them with his own mind. He knows the minds with lust as with lust, and the mind without lust as without lust;

original: vitakkitampi ādisati, vicāritampi ādisati ‘evampi te mano, itthampi te mano”’tiādinayappavattaṃ🔽parassa cittaṃ ñatvā kathanaṃ ādesanāpāṭihāriyaṃ. “Idha bhikkhu evamanusāsati ‘evaṃ🔽vitakketha, mā evaṃ vitakkayittha, evaṃ manasi karotha, mā evaṃ mānasā karittha,
analyzed: vitakkitam pi ādisati vicāritam pi ādisati evam pi te mano ittham pi te mano ti ādi naya ppavattam  parassa cittam ñatvā kathanaṃ ādesanā pāṭihāriyam idha bhikkhu evam anusāsati evam  vitakketha mā evam vitakkayittha evam manasi karotha mā evam mānasā karittha
translated: the mind with hate as with hate, and the mind without hate as without hate; the mind with delusion as with delusion, and the mind without delusion as without delusion;🔽the contracted mind as contracted, and the distracted mind as distracted; the exalted mind as exalted, and the unexalted mind as unexalted; the surpassable mind as surpassable, and the unsurpassable mind as unsurpassable;🔽the concentrated mind as concentrated, and the unconcentrated mind as unconcentrated; the liberated mind as liberated, and the unliberated mind as unliberated.

original: idaṃ pajahatha, idaṃ upasampajja viharathā”’ti evamādinayappavattā sāvakānaṃ buddhānañca🔽sabbakālaṃ desetabbadhammadesanā anusāsanīpāṭihāriyaṃ.🔽Tattha pāṭihāriyapadassa vacanatthaṃ paṭipakkhaharaṇato rāgādikilesāpanayanato pāṭihāriyanti
analyzed: idam pajahatha idam upasampajja viharatha ati evamādi naya ppavattā sāvakānam buddhānam ca  sabbakālam desetabba dhamma desanā anusāsanī pāṭihāriyam  tattha pāṭihāriya padassa vacana attham paṭipakkha haraṇataḥ rāga ādi kilesa apanayanataḥ pāṭihāriyanti
translated: “Here a bhikkhu instructs, urges, rouses, and encourages disciples with talk on the training rules, talk on concentration, and talk on wisdom.🔽This is called the miracle of instruction.

original: vadanti. Bhagavato pana paṭipakkhā rāgādayo na santi ye haritabbā, puthujjanānampi
analyzed: vadanti bhagavataḥ pana paṭipakkhāḥ rāga ādayaḥ na santi ye haritabbā puthujjanānam pi
translated: Herein, the word ‘miracle’ is said to be because of the removal of the opposite, because of the removal of defilements such as lust. But the Blessed One has no opposite, which would have to be removed, and so have ordinary people,

original: vigatūpakkilese aṭṭhaguṇasamannāgate citte hatapaṭipakkhe iddhividhaṃ vattati, tasmā🔽tattha pavattavohārena ca na sakkā idha pāṭihāriyanti vattuṃ. Sace pana mahākāruṇikassa
analyzed: vigata upakkilese aṭṭha guṇa samannāgate citte hata paṭipakkhe iddhi vidham vattati tasmā  tattha pavatta vohārena ca na sakkā idha vattum sace pana mahā kāruṇikassa
translated: and when the mind has eight factors, being free from defilements and having destroyed its opposing factors, then the various kinds of supernormal power occur.

original: bhagavato veneyyagatā ca kilesā paṭipakkhā, tesaṃ haraṇato pāṭihāriyanti vuttaṃ,🔽evaṃ sati yuttametaṃ. Atha vā bhagavato ca sāsanassa ca paṭipakkhā titthiyā, tesaṃ🔽haraṇato pāṭihāriyaṃ. Te hi diṭṭhiharaṇavasena diṭṭhippakāsane asamatthabhāvena ca
analyzed: bhagavataḥ veneyya gatā ca kilesā paṭipakkhā tesam haraṇataḥ pāṭihāriyan ti vuttam  evam sati yuttam etam atha vā bhagavataḥ ca sāsanassa ca paṭipakkhāḥ titthiyāḥ tesam  haraṇataḥ pāṭihāriyam te hi diṭṭhi haraṇa vasena diṭṭhi ppakāsane asamattha bhāvena ca
translated: Therefore it is not proper to call it a miracle in the sense of a wonder, according to the explanation given here. But if the defilements in the disciples of the Blessed One, the Greatly Compassionate One, are the opposing factors, and the miracle is called such because of the removal of those,🔽then it is proper to call it a miracle in that sense. Or else the opposing factors are the sectarians, the opponents of the Blessed One and his Dispensation,

original: iddhiādesanānusāsanīhi haritā apanītā hontīti. Paṭīti vā ayaṃ saddo pacchāti etassa
analyzed: iddhi ādesana anusāsanīhi haritāḥ apanītāḥ honti iti vā ayam saddo etassa
translated: and the miracle is called such because of the removal of them. For they are removed, they are put away, by the supernormal power of the Buddha, by the teaching of the Dhamma, and by the giving of advice, because they are incapable of teaching the Dhamma and revealing their own views.

original: atthaṃ bodheti “tasmiṃ paṭipaviṭṭhamhi, añño āgañchi brāhmaṇo”tiādīsu viya, tasmā
analyzed: attham bodha iti tasmin paṭipaviṭṭhamhi aññaḥ āgañchi brāhmaṇa uti ādīsu viya tasmā
translated: Or else the word “miracle” is a derivation and it signifies that which is to be removed later , like the word “remnant” , in the passage: “When he had entered there, another brahmin came” .

original: samāhite citte vigatūpakkilesena katakiccena pacchā haritabbaṃ pavattetabbanti paṭihāriyaṃ,
analyzed: samāhite citte vigata upakkilesena kata kiccena pacchā haritabbam pavattetabbam ti paṭihāriyam
translated: Therefore it is a miracle in the sense that it is to be removed later , in the sense that it is to be made to occur later , when the mind has been concentrated and is free from defilements and has done its task.

original: attano vā upakkilesesu catutthajjhānamaggehi haritesu pacchā haraṇaṃ paṭihāriyaṃ,
analyzed: attanaḥ vā upakkilesesu catuttha jhāna maggehi haritesu pacchā haraṇam paṭihāriyam
translated: And when his own defilements have been removed by the paths of the fourth jhāna, the subsequent removal of others’ defilements is a miracle.

original: iddhiādesanānusāsaniyo ca vigatūpakkilesena katakiccena sattahitatthaṃ puna pavattetabbā,
analyzed: iddhi ādesanā anusāsaniyaḥ ca vigata upakkilesena kata kiccena satta hita attham puna pavattetabbā
translated: And the supernormal power, the reading of the mind, and the instruction are to be repeated for the benefit of others’ welfare when the defilements have been removed and the task done.

original: haritesu ca attano upakkilesesu parasattānaṃ upakkilesaharaṇāni hontīti paṭihāriyāni🔽bhavanti, paṭihāriyameva pāṭihāriyaṃ. Paṭihāriye vā iddhiādesanānusāsanīsamudāye🔽bhavaṃ ekekaṃ pāṭihāriyanti vuccati. Paṭihāriyaṃ vā catutthajjhānaṃ maggo ca paṭipakkhaharaṇato,🔽tattha jātaṃ nimittabhūte, tato vā āgatanti pāṭihāriyaṃ. Svātanāyāti sve dātabbassa atthāya.
analyzed: haritesu ca attanaḥ upakkilesesu para sattānam upakkilesa haraṇāni honti iti paṭihāriyāni  bhavanti paṭihāriyam eva pāṭihāriyam paṭihāriye vā iddhi ādesanā anusāsanī samudāye  bhavam ekekam pāṭihāriyanti vuccati paṭihāriyam vā catuttha jhānam maggo ca paṭipakkha haraṇato  tattha jātam nimitta bhūte tatas vā āgatanti pāṭihāriyam svātanāya ati sve dātabbassa atthāya
translated: And when his own defilements have been removed, the removal of others’ defilements is a miracle.

original: 46-49. Jaṭilāti tāpasā. Te hi jaṭādhāritāya idha “jaṭilā”ti vuttā. Antaraṭṭhakāsu
analyzed: jaṭilā ati tāpasā te hi jaṭā dhāritāya idha jaṭilā ati vuttā antaraṭṭhakāsu
translated: Ascetics: ascetics. They are called “ascetics” here because they wear matted hair. In the countries in between

original: himapātasamayeti hemantassa utuno abbhantarabhūte māghamāsassa avasāne catasso, phagguṇamāsassa🔽ādimhi catassoti evaṃ ubhinnamantare aṭṭharattīsu himapatanakāle. Nerañjarāya ummujjantīti
analyzed: hima pāta samaya iti hemantassa utuno abbhantara bhūte māgha māsassa avasāne catasso phagguṇa māsassa  ādimhi catasso ti evam ubhinnam antare aṭṭha rattīsu hima patana kāle nerañjarāya ummujjanti iti
translated: the snowfall is like this: in the last four nights of the month of Māgha, which is in the middle of the winter season, and in the first four nights of the month of Phagguna,

original: keci tasmiṃ titthasammate udake paṭhamaṃ nimuggasakalasarīrā tato ummujjantā vuṭṭhahanti🔽uppilavanti. Nimujjantīti sasīsaṃ udake osīdanti. Ummujjananimujjanampi karontīti
analyzed: keci tasmim tittha sammate udake paṭhamam nimugga sakala sarīrā tatas ummujjantā vuṭṭhahanti  uppilavanti nimujjanti iti sa sīsam udake osīdanti ummujjana nimujjanam pi karonti iti
translated: thus in the eight nights in between the two, at the time of the snowfall. Emerging from the Nerañjara: some say that in that water considered a bathing place, first the whole body is submerged, then emerging from it, they come out

original: punappunaṃ ummujjananimujjanānipi karonti. Tattha hi keci “ekummujjaneneva pāpasuddhi
analyzed: punappunam ummujjana nimujjanāni api karonti tattha hi keci eka ummujjanena iva
translated: floating. Submerged: with the head they sink into the water. Emerging and submerged: they do the act of emerging and submerging again and again. There, some say: “By one emergence, the purification of evil🔽is accomplished.”

original: hotī”ti evaṃdiṭṭhikā, te ummujjanameva katvā gacchanti. Ummujjanaṃ pana nimujjanamantarena🔽natthīti avinābhāvato nimujjanampi te karontiyeva. Yepi “ekanimujjaneneva pāpasuddhi🔽hotī”ti evaṃdiṭṭhikā, tepi ekavārameva nimujjitvā vuttanayeneva avinābhāvato ummujjanampi
analyzed: hoti iti evaṃdiṭṭhikā te ummujjanam eva katvā gacchanti ummujjanam pana nimujjanam antarena  natthi iti avinābhāvataḥ nimujjanam pi te ye pi eka nimujjanena iva  hoti iti evaṃdiṭṭhikā te api eka vāram eva nimujjitvā vutta nayena iva avinābhāvataḥ ummujjanam pi
translated: They go on doing this until they die. But since it is impossible to emerge without first sinking, they do so.🔽Those who hold the view that “Purification is effected by one sinking” do so after emerging once. But since it is impossible to emerge without first sinking, they do so.

original: katvā pakkamanti. Apare “punappunaṃ ummujjananimujjanāni katvā nahāte pāpasuddhi🔽hotī”ti evaṃdiṭṭhikā, te kālena kālaṃ ummujjananimujjanāni karonti. Te sabbepi sandhāya
analyzed: katvā pakkamanti apare punappunam ummujjana nimujjanāni katvā nahāte pāpa suddhi  hoti iti evaṃdiṭṭhikā te kālena kālam ummujjana nimujjanāni karonti te sabbe api sandhāya
translated: Those who hold the view that “Purification is effected by one sinking once” do so after emerging once. But since it is impossible to emerge without first sinking, they do so.🔽Those who hold the view that “Purification is effected by bathing after repeatedly emerging and sinking” do so.

original: vuttaṃ “ummujjantipi nimujjantipi ummujjananimujjanampi karontī”ti. Ettha ca kiñcāpi🔽nimujjanapubbakaṃ ummujjanaṃ, nimujjanameva pana karontā katipayā, ummujjanaṃ tadubhayañca
analyzed: vuttam ummujjanti api nimujjanti api ummujjana nimujjanam karonti iti ettha ca kiñcā api  nimujjana pubbakam ummujjanam nimujjanam eva pana karontā katipayāḥ ummujjanam tat ubhayañca
translated: All these are referred to by the words “They emerge and sink and perform the act of emerging and sinking.”

original: karontā bahūti tesaṃ yebhuyyabhāvadassanatthaṃ ummujjanaṃ paṭhamaṃ vuttaṃ.
analyzed: karontā bahū ti tesam yebhuyya bhāva dassana attham ummujjanam paṭhamam vuttam
translated: And here, although the act of emerging is preceded by the act of sinking, the former is mentioned first in order to show that there are fewer who perform the act of sinking alone and more who perform the act of emerging and the other two acts.

original: 50-51. Udakavāhakoti udakogho. Reṇuhatāyāti rajogatāya, rajokiṇṇāyāti vuttaṃ hoti.
analyzed: udaka vāhakaḥ iti udaka oghaḥ reṇu hatāya ati rajaḥ gatāya rajaḥ kiṇṇāya ati vuttam hoti
translated: The “water-bearing cloud” is a mass of water. “Blown by the wind” means “blown by the wind of dust,” i.e., “covered with dust.”

original: Neva ca kho tvaṃ kassapa arahāti etena tadā kassapassa asekkhabhāvaṃ paṭikkhipati,🔽nāpi arahattamaggasamāpannoti etena sekkhabhāvaṃ. Ubhayenapissa anariyabhāvameva
analyzed: na iva ca kho tvam kassapa etena tadā kassapassa asekkha bhāvam paṭikkhipati  na api arahatta magga samāpannaḥ ti etena sekkha bhāvam ubhayena api ssa anariya bhāvam eva
translated: “You are not even a stream-enterer, Kassapa” — by this he denies Kassapa’s state of being a non-trainee.🔽“Nor are you one who has entered the path to the fruit of stream-entry” — by this he denies his state of being a trainee. By both he shows his unworthiness.

original: dīpeti. Sāpi te paṭipadā natthi, yāya tvaṃ arahā vā assasi arahattamaggaṃ vā samāpannoti
analyzed: dīpeti sā api te paṭipadā natthi yāya tvam arahā vā assasi arahatta maggam vā samāpanno ti
translated: “You have no path by which you could be a stream-enterer or one who has entered the path to the fruit of stream-entry” —

original: iminā panassa kalyāṇaputhujjanabhāvampi paṭikkhipati. Tattha paṭipadāti sīlavisuddhiādayo🔽cha visuddhiyo. Paṭipajjati etāya ariyamaggoti paṭipadā. Assasīti bhaveyyāsi. Cirapaṭikāti🔽cirakālato paṭṭhāya, nāgadamanato paṭṭhāyāti attho. Khārikājamissanti ettha khārīti
analyzed: iminā pana assa kalyāṇa puthujjana bhāvam pi paṭikkhipati tattha paṭipadā ti sīla visuddhi ādayaḥ  cha visuddhiyaḥ paṭipajjati etāya ariya maggo ti paṭipadā assasi iti bhaveyyāsi cira paṭikā ati  cira kālataḥ paṭṭhāya nāgadamanataḥ paṭṭhāya ati attho khārikājamissanti ettha khārī iti
translated: by this he denies his state of being a good worldling. Herein, “path” is the six purifications beginning with purification of virtue.🔽“One practices by means of this, it is a path” . “You could be” means you could become. “For a long time” means “from a long time ago,” i.e., “from the time of taming the nāgas.”

original: araṇīkamaṇḍalusūciādayo tāpasaparikkhārā, taṃ haraṇakājaṃ khārikājaṃ. Aggihutamissanti
analyzed: araṇī kamaṇḍalu sūci ādayo tāpasa parikkhārā tam haraṇaka ajam khārikā jam aggi hutam issanti
translated: “Mixed with the refuse of the fire-sticks” — here “refuse” is the requisites of the ascetic such as the fire-stick, the fire-drilling stick, the awl, etc. The refuse of these is the refuse of the fire-sticks. “Mixed with the refuse of the fire-sticks” means mixed with the refuse of the fire-sticks. “Mixed with the refuse of the fire-sticks” means mixed with the refuse of the fire-sticks. “Mixed with the refuse of the fire-sticks” means mixed with the refuse of the fire-sticks.

original: dabbiādiaggipūjopakaraṇaṃ.
analyzed: dabbi ādi aggi pūjā upakaraṇam
translated: and the requisites for worship such as the fan, the water-sistrum, and the incense-holder.

original: 52-53. Upasaggoti upaddavo. Idāni aḍḍhuḍḍhāni pāṭihāriyasahassāni ekato gaṇetvā dassetuṃ🔽“bhagavato adhiṭṭhānena pañca kaṭṭhasatāni na phāliyiṃsū”tiādi āraddhaṃ. Nāgadamanādīni
analyzed: upasaggo ti upaddavaḥ idāni aḍḍhuḍḍhāni pāṭihāriya sahassāni ekatas gaṇetvā dassetuṃ  bhagavataḥ adhiṭṭhānena pañca kaṭṭha satāni na āraddham nāgadamana ādīni
translated: The word “calamity” means “disaster.” Now, in order to show that all the more than one thousand two hundred and fifty miracles are included in the five miracles,

original: pana soḷasa pāṭihāriyāni idha na gaṇitāni, tehi saddhiṃ soḷasātirekaaḍḍhuḍḍhapāṭihāriyasahassānīti veditabbaṃ.
analyzed: pana soḷasa pāṭihāriyāni idha na gaṇitāni tehi saddhim soḷasa atireka aḍḍhuḍḍha pāṭihāriya sahassāni iti veditabbam
translated: “by the Blessed One’s resolve five hundred logs did not split” is mentioned. But the sixteen miracles beginning with the taming of the elephant Dhanapālaka are not included in the five miracles. It should be understood that they are included in the more than one thousand two hundred and fifty miracles.

original: Ādittapariyāyasuttavaṇṇanā
analyzed: āditta pariyāya sutta vaṇṇanā
translated: The explanation of the Discourse on the Simile of the Burning House is finished.

original: 54. Idāni tassa bhikkhusahassassa ādittapariyāyadesanāya arahattappattiṃ dassetuṃ🔽“atha kho bhagavā”tiādi āraddhaṃ. Tattha gayāyaṃ viharati gayāsīseti gayānāmikāya
analyzed: idāni tassa bhikkhu sahassassa āditta pariyāya desanāya arahatta ppattim dassetuṃ  atha kho bhagavā atiādi āraddham viharati gayā sīsa iti gayā nāmikāya
translated: Now, in order to show that the thousand bhikkhus attained arahatship through the Blessed One’s teaching of the Discourse on the Simile of the Burning House,

original: nadiyā avidūre bhavattā gāmo gayā nāma, tassaṃ gayāyaṃ viharati. Samīpatthe cetaṃ
analyzed: nadiyāḥ avidūre bhavattā gāmaḥ gayā nāma tassam gayāyam viharati samīpa atthe
translated: “Then the Blessed One” is mentioned. Therein, he dwells at Gayā, on Gayā Head: the village is called Gayā because it is not far from the river called Gayā. He dwells at Gayā. This is a locative of place.

original: bhummavacanaṃ. Gayāgāmassa hi avidūre gayāti ekā pokkharaṇīpi atthi nadīpi gayāsīsanāmako
analyzed: bhumma vacanam gayā gāmassa hi avidūre gayā ti ekā atthi nadī api gayāsīsa nāmako
translated: For not far from the village of Gayā there is a lotus-pond called Gayā and a river called Gayā Head.

original: hatthikumbhasadiso piṭṭhipāsāṇopi. Yattha bhikkhusahassassa okāso pahoti, bhagavā
analyzed: hatthi kumbha sadisaḥ piṭṭhi pāsāṇaḥ api yattha bhikkhu sahassassa okāsaḥ pahoti bhagavā
translated: and the rock-slab called Gayasisa, which is like the forehead of an elephant, and which is large enough for a thousand bhikkhus to sit down upon.

original: tattha viharati. Tena vuttaṃ “gayāsīse”ti, gayāgāmassa āsanne gayāsīsanāmake piṭṭhipāsāṇe
analyzed: tattha viharati tena vuttam gayāsīse iti gayā gāmassa āsanne gayāsīsa nāmake piṭṭhi pāsāṇe
translated: The Blessed One was living there. Therefore it was said: “at Gayasisa.” Near the town of Gaya, on the rock-slab called Gayasisa,

original: viharatīti vuttaṃ hoti. Bhikkhū āmantesīti tesaṃ sappāyadhammadesanaṃ vicinitvā taṃ
analyzed: viharati iti vuttam hoti bhikkhū āmantesi iti tesam sappāya dhamma desanam vicinitvā tam
translated: “was living” means was staying. He addressed the bhikkhus: having examined what kind of Dhamma talk would be suitable for them,

original: desessāmīti āmantesi. Bhagavā hi taṃ iddhimayapattacīvaradharaṃ samaṇasahassaṃ ādāya
analyzed: desessāmi iti āmantesi bhagavā hi tam iddhi maya patta cīvara dharam samaṇa sahassam ādāya
translated: he addressed them, thinking: “I will teach them that.” For the Blessed One, taking with him a thousand ascetics who were possessed of the supernormal powers and wearing robes and carrying bowls that were created supernaturally,

original: gayāsīsaṃ gantvā tena parivārito nisīditvā “katarā nu kho etesaṃ dhammakathā sappāyā”ti🔽cintento “ime sāyaṃ pātaṃ aggiṃ paricaranti, imesaṃ dvādasāyatanāni ādittāni sampajjalitāni
analyzed: gayāsīsam gantvā tena parivāritaḥ nisīditvā katarā nu kho etesam dhamma kathā sappāyāti  cintentaḥ ime sāyam pātam aggim paricaranti dvādaśa āyatanāni ādittāni sampajjalitāni
translated: went to Gayasisa, sat surrounded by them, and thought: “What kind of Dhamma talk would be suitable for them?”

original: viya katvā dassessāmi, evaṃ ime arahattaṃ pāpuṇituṃ sakkhissantī”ti sanniṭṭhānamakāsi.
analyzed: viya katvā dassessāmi evam ime arahattam pāpuṇitum sakkhissanti iti sanniṭṭhānam akāsi
translated: He thought: “These people attend to the sacred fire in the morning and in the evening. I will teach them the twelve bases as if they were burning with fire and blazing. In this way they will be able to attain arahatship.”

original: Atha nesaṃ tathā desetuṃ “sabbaṃ, bhikkhave, āditta”ntiādinā imaṃ ādittapariyāyaṃ abhāsi.
analyzed: atha nesam tathā desetum sabbam bhikkhave ādittam ti ādinā imam āditta pariyāyam abhāsi
translated: Then in order to teach them in this way, he spoke this discourse on burning, beginning: “Bhikkhus, all is burning” .

original: Tattha sabbaṃ nāma catubbidhaṃ sabbasabbaṃ āyatanasabbaṃ sakkāyasabbaṃ padesasabbanti. Tattha –
analyzed: tattha sabbam nāma catubbidham sabba sabbam āyatana sabbam sakkāya sabbam padesa sabbanti tattha
translated: Herein, all is of four kinds as all-encompassing all, all as the categories, all as the bases, and all as a part:

original: “Na tassa addiṭṭhamidhatthi kiñci;
analyzed: na tassa addiṭṭham idhatthi kiñci
translated: There is nothing not seen by him,

original: Atho aviññātamajānitabbaṃ;
analyzed: atho a viññātam a jānitabbam
translated: Nor anything not known or understood;

original: Sabbaṃ abhiññāsi yadatthi neyyaṃ;
analyzed: sabbam abhiññāsi yat atthi na iyyam
translated: He knows all that can be known,

original: Tathāgato tena samantacakkhū”ti –🔽Idaṃ sabbasabbaṃ nāma. “Sabbaṃ vo, bhikkhave, desessāmi, taṃ suṇāthā”ti idaṃ āyatanasabbaṃ
analyzed: tathāgato tena  idam sabbasabbam nāma sabbam vaḥ bhikkhave desessāmi tam suṇātha ati idam āyatana sabbam
translated: So he is the Enlightened One, the All-Seeing One.

original: nāma. “Sabbadhammamūlapariyāyaṃ vo, bhikkhave, desessāmī”ti idaṃ sakkāyasabbaṃ nāma.
analyzed: nāma sabba dhamma mūla pariyāyam vaḥ bhikkhave desessāmi iti idam sakkāyasabbam nāma
translated: This is called all-encompassing all. “Bhikkhus, I shall teach you all, so listen” . This is called all as the categories. “Bhikkhus, I shall teach you the section on the root of all things” . This is called all as the bases.

original: “Sabbadhammesu vā paṭhamasamannāhāro uppajjati cittaṃ mano mānasaṃ tajjā manoviññāṇadhātū”ti
analyzed: sabba dhammesu vā paṭhama samannāhāraḥ uppajjati cittam manaḥ mānasam tad jāḥ manaḥ viññāṇa dhātū ti
translated: “Bhikkhus, the first consciousness arises in dependence upon a pair” .

original: idaṃ padesasabbaṃ nāma. Iti pañcārammaṇamattaṃ padesasabbaṃ, tebhūmakā dhammā sakkāyasabbaṃ,
analyzed: idam padesa sabbam nāma iti pañca ārammaṇa mattam padesa sabbam tebhūmakāḥ dhammāḥ sa kāya sabbam
translated: This is called all as a part. So all as a part is the mere five categories of object; all as the categories is states belonging to the three planes;

original: catubhūmakā dhammā āyatanasabbaṃ, yaṃ kiñci neyyaṃ sabbasabbaṃ. Padesasabbaṃ sakkāyasabbaṃ
analyzed: catu bhūmakāḥ dhammāḥ āyatana sabbam yat kiñci neyyam sabba sabbam padesa sabbam sakkāya sabbam
translated: all as the bases is states belonging to the four planes; all-encompassing all is anything that can be known. All as a part and all as the categories

original: na pāpuṇāti tassa tebhūmakadhammesupi ekadesassa asaṅgaṇhanato. Sakkāyasabbaṃ āyatanasabbaṃ
analyzed: na pāpuṇāti tassa tebhūmaka dhammesu pi eka desassa a saṅgaṇhanataḥ sakkāya sabbam āyatana sabbam
translated: because it does not include a part of the states of the three planes. The all of the khandhas and the all of the sense bases

original: na pāpuṇāti lokuttaradhammānaṃ asaṅgaṇhanato. Āyatanasabbaṃ sabbasabbaṃ na pāpuṇāti.
analyzed: na pāpuṇāti lokuttara dhammānam a saṅgaṇhanataḥ āyatana sabbam sabba sabbam na pāpuṇāti
translated: do not include the supramundane states. The all of the sense bases and the all of the all do not include the characteristics and the terms.

original: Kasmā? Yasmā āyatanasabbena catubhūmakadhammāva pariggahitā, na lakkhaṇapaññattiyoti.
analyzed: kasmai yasmai āyatana sabbena pariggahitāḥ na lakkhaṇa paññattiyaḥ ti
translated: Why? Because the all of the sense bases includes only the states of the four planes, not the characteristics and the terms.

original: Imasmiṃ pana sutte āyatanasabbaṃ adhippetaṃ, tatthāpi idha vipassanupagadhammāva gahetabbā.
analyzed: imasmim pana sutte āyatana sabbam adhippetam tattha api idha vipassana upaga dhammā ava gahetabbā
translated: But in this sutta the all of the sense bases is intended, and there too only those states that are suitable for insight should be taken.

original: Cakkhūti dve cakkhūni ñāṇacakkhu ceva maṃsacakkhu ca. Tattha ñāṇacakkhu pañcavidhaṃ
analyzed: cakkhu iti dve cakkhūni ñāṇa cakkhu ca iva maṃsa cakkhu ca tattha ñāṇa cakkhu pañcavidham
translated: Eye: there are two eyes, the eye of knowledge and the fleshly eye. Herein, the eye of knowledge is fivefold:

original: buddhacakkhu dhammacakkhu samantacakkhu dibbacakkhu paññācakkhūti. Tesu buddhacakkhu
analyzed: buddha cakkhu dhammacakkhu samantacakkhu dibbacakkhu paññācakkhu iti tesu buddha cakkhu
translated: the Buddha eye, the Dhamma eye, the eye of wisdom, the divine eye, and the fleshly eye. Herein, the Buddha eye is

original: nāma āsayānusayañāṇañceva indriyaparopariyattañāṇañca, yaṃ “buddhacakkhunā lokaṃ
analyzed: nāma āsaya anusaya ñāṇañca iva indriya paropari yatta ñāṇañca yam buddha cakkhunā lokaṃ
translated: the knowledge of the disposition and latent tendency of beings and the knowledge of the superiority and inferiority of their faculties, which is called “seeing the world with the Buddha eye” . The Dhamma eye is

original: volokento”ti āgataṃ. Dhammacakkhu nāma heṭṭhimā tayo maggā tīṇi ca phalāni, yaṃ “virajaṃ
analyzed: volokento ti āgatam dhammacakkhu nāma heṭṭhimā tayaḥ maggā tīṇi ca phalāni yam virajam
translated: the three lower paths and the three fruits, which is called “the Dhamma eye that arises in him” . The eye of wisdom is

original: vītamalaṃ dhammacakkhuṃ udapādī”ti āgataṃ. Samantacakkhu nāma sabbaññutaññāṇaṃ, yaṃ🔽“pāsādamāruyha samantacakkhū”ti āgataṃ. Dibbacakkhu nāma ālokavaḍḍhanena uppannañāṇaṃ,
analyzed: vīta malam dhammacakkhum udapādi iti āgatam samantacakkhu nāma sabbaññuta ññāṇam yaṃ  pāsādam āruyha samantacakkhu iti āgatam dibbacakkhu nāma āloka vaḍḍhanena uppanna ñāṇam
translated: which is mentioned in the passage: “Having ascended the Palace of the Dhamma, the All-Seeing One.”🔽“The Divine Eye” is the knowledge arisen through the development of the light of the physical eye,🔽which is mentioned in the passage: “With the divine eye, which is purified and surpasses the human.”

original: yaṃ “dibbena cakkhunā visuddhenā”ti āgataṃ. Paññācakkhu nāma catusaccaparicchedakañāṇaṃ,
analyzed: yam dibbena cakkhunā visuddhena ati āgatam paññācakkhu nāma catu sacca paricchedaka ñāṇam
translated: “The Wisdom Eye” is the knowledge that discerns the Four Noble Truths,🔽which is mentioned in the passage: “The eye arose, knowledge arose, wisdom arose, and light arose.”

original: yaṃ “cakkhuṃ udapādī”ti āgataṃ. Maṃsacakkhupi duvidhaṃ sasambhāracakkhu pasādacakkhūti.
analyzed: yam cakkhum udapādi iti āgatam maṃsa cakkhu pi duvidham sa sambhāra cakkhu pasāda cakkhu iti
translated: The flesh eye is also twofold: the eye with its accessories and the eye as a mere faculty.

original: Tesu yvāyaṃ akkhikūpake akkhipaṭalehi parivārito maṃsapiṇḍo, yattha catasso dhātuyo🔽vaṇṇagandharasojā sambhavo jīvitaṃ bhāvo cakkhuppasādo kāyappasādoti saṅkhepato terasa🔽sambhārā honti, vitthārato pana catasso dhātuyo vaṇṇagandharasojā sambhavoti ime
analyzed: tesu yvā ayam akkhikūpake akkhi paṭalehi parivāritaḥ maṃsa piṇḍaḥ yattha catasso dhātuyaḥ  vaṇṇa gandha rasojāḥ sambhavaḥ jīvitam bhāvaḥ cakkhu ppasādo kāya ppasādo ti saṅkhepato terasa  sambhārāḥ honti vitthārato pana catasso dhātuyaḥ vaṇṇa gandha rasojā sambhavo ti ime
translated: Of these, the flesh eye with its accessories is the lump of flesh in the eye socket surrounded by the eyelids, in which there are four elements,

original: nava catusamuṭṭhānavasena chattiṃsa, jīvitaṃ bhāvo cakkhuppasādo kāyappasādoti ime
analyzed: nava catu samuṭṭhāna vasena chattiṃsa jīvitam bhāvo cakkhu ppasādo kāya ppasādo ti ime
translated: four great entities, four derived elements, and four derived entities. In brief, there are thirteen factors: color, odor, flavor, nutritive essence, origination, continuance, decay, impermanence, eye sensitivity, life faculty, bodily intimation, vocal intimation, and the eye faculty. In detail, there are thirty-six factors: the four elements, color, odor, flavor, nutritive essence, origination, continuance, decay, impermanence, life faculty, bodily intimation, vocal intimation, eye sensitivity, and the eye faculty. These are the thirteen factors. The four elements are each threefold, making twelve. The eye sensitivity is threefold, making fifteen. The life faculty is threefold, making eighteen. Bodily intimation is threefold, making twenty-one. Vocal intimation is threefold, making twenty-four. The eye faculty is threefold, making twenty-seven. The four derived entities are each threefold, making thirty-six.

original: kammasamuṭṭhānā tāva cattāroti cattālīsa sambhārā honti, idaṃ sasambhāracakkhu nāma.
analyzed: kamma samuṭṭhānā tāva cattāro ti cattālīsa sambhārāḥ honti idam sa sambhāracakkhu nāma
translated: The forty are the forty constituents of the eye as a product. This is what is called the eye with its constituents.

original: Yaṃ panettha setamaṇḍalaparicchinnena kaṇhamaṇḍalena parivārite diṭṭhimaṇḍale sanniviṭṭhaṃ🔽rūpadassanasamatthaṃ pasādamattaṃ, idaṃ pasādacakkhu nāma. Tassa tato paresañca sotādīnaṃ
analyzed: yam pana itthā seta maṇḍala paricchinnena kaṇha maṇḍalena parivārite diṭṭhi maṇḍale sanniviṭṭham  rūpa dassana samattham pasāda mattam idam pasādacakkhu nāma tassa tatas paresam ca sota ādīnam
translated: But the mere confidence in the eye that is capable of seeing visible forms and is situated in the eye’s location, enclosed by the black circle of the iris and the white of the eye,

original: vitthārakathā visuddhimagge vuttāva.
analyzed: vitthāra kathā visuddhi magge vuttā ava
translated: is called the confidence-eye. The detailed explanation of this and of the other faculties beginning with the ear is given in the Path of Purity .🔽Herein, the Blessed One, taking the confidence-eye, said, “The eye is afire,”

original: Tattha yadidaṃ pasādacakkhu, tañca gahetvā bhagavā “cakkhu āditta”ntiādimāha. Tattha🔽ādittanti padittaṃ, sampajjalitaṃ ekādasahi aggīhi ekajālībhūtanti attho. Cakkhusannissitaṃ🔽viññāṇaṃ cakkhuviññāṇaṃ, cakkhussa vā kāraṇabhūtassa viññāṇaṃ cakkhuviññāṇaṃ. Kāmaṃ
analyzed: tattha yat idam pasāda cakkhu tat ca gahetvā bhagavā cakkhu tattha  ādittam ti padittam sampajjalitam ekādasahi aggīhi ekajālībhūtam ti attho cakkhu sannissitam  viññāṇam cakkhu viññāṇam cakkhussa vā kāraṇa bhūtassa viññāṇam cakkhu viññāṇam kāmam
translated: and so on. Herein,🔽afire : burning, blazing, with the eleven fires become one conflagration. The consciousness that is dependent on the eye is eye-consciousness. Or the consciousness that is the eye’s function is eye-consciousness.

original: rūpālokamanasikārādayopi tassa viññāṇassa kāraṇaṃ, te pana sādhāraṇakāraṇaṃ, cakkhu
analyzed: rūpa āloka manasikāra ādayaḥ api tassa viññāṇassa kāraṇam te pana sādhāraṇa kāraṇam cakkhu
translated: Certainly the directing of attention to visible forms, light, etc., is a condition for that consciousness, but that is a common condition. The eye is a condition for that consciousness in a specific way.

original: asādhāraṇanti asādhāraṇakāraṇenāyaṃ niddeso yathā “yavaṅkuro”ti. Sotaviññāṇādīsupi
analyzed: asādhāraṇanti asādhāraṇa kāraṇena ayam niddesaḥ yathā sota viññāṇa ādīsu pi
translated: “Uncommon” is a description by way of uncommon cause, like “the sprout of barley.”🔽The same method applies in the case of ear-consciousness, etc.

original: eseva nayo. Cakkhusannissito phasso cakkhusamphasso, cakkhuviññāṇasampayuttaphassassetaṃ
analyzed: esa iva nayaḥ cakkhu sannissito phassaḥ cakkhu samphasso cakkhu viññāṇa sampayutta phassassa etam
translated: Contact dependent on the eye is eye-contact; this is a term for the contact associated with eye-consciousness.🔽The same method applies in the case of ear-contact, etc.

original: adhivacanaṃ. Sotasamphassādīsupi eseva nayo. Cakkhusamphassapaccayā uppajjati vedayitanti🔽cakkhusamphassaṃ mūlapaccayaṃ katvā uppannā sampaṭicchanasantīraṇavoṭṭhabbanajavanavedanā.🔽Cakkhuviññāṇasampayuttāya pana vedanāya cakkhusamphassassa paccayabhāve vattabbameva
analyzed: adhivacanam sota samphassa ādīsu pi esa iva nayaḥ cakkhu samphassa paccayā uppajjati vedayitan ti  cakkhu samphassam mūla paccayam katvā uppannā sampaṭicchana santīraṇa voṭṭhabbana javana vedanā  cakkhu viññāṇa sampayuttāya pana vedanāya cakkhu samphassassa paccaya bhāve vattabbam eva
translated: “With the contact at the eye as condition there arises in the eye what is felt that is pleasant or painful or neither-painful-nor-pleasant” .🔽The pleasant and painful and neither-painful-nor-pleasant feeling that arises with the contact at the eye as its root-condition is the feeling of acquaintance, the feeling of choice, the feeling of adverting, and the feeling of impulsion.🔽But there is nothing to be said about the contact at the eye being a condition for the feeling associated with eye-consciousness.

original: natthi. Cakkhusamphasso hi sahajātāya vedanāya sahajātādivasena, asahajātāya upanissayādivasena
analyzed: natthi cakkhu samphassaḥ hi sahajātāya vedanāya sahajāta ādi vasena asahajātāya upanissaya ādi vasena
translated: For the contact at the eye is a condition for the feeling that is conascent with it as conascence, etc., and for the feeling that is not conascent with it as decisive-support, etc.

original: paccayo hoti. Teneva “cakkhusamphassapaccayā uppajjati vedayitaṃ sukhaṃ vā dukkhaṃ
analyzed: paccayaḥ hoti tena iva cakkhu samphassa paccayā uppajjati vedayitam sukham vā dukkham
translated: That is why it is said: “With the contact at the eye as condition there arises in the eye what is felt that is pleasant or painful or neither-painful-nor-pleasant” .

original: vā adukkhamasukhaṃ vā”ti vuttaṃ. Sotadvāravedanādīsupi eseva nayo. Ettha pana manoti🔽bhavaṅgacittaṃ manodvārassa adhippetattā. Dhammāti dhammārammaṇaṃ. Manoviññāṇanti
analyzed: vā adukkham asukham vā ti vuttam sota dvāra vedanā ādīsu pi esa iva nayaḥ ettha pana mano ti  bhavaṅga cittam manaḥ dvārassa adhippeta ttā dhammā ati dhamma ārammaṇam manaḥ viññāṇam ti
translated: and neither-painful-nor-pleasant feeling. The same method applies to the feeling that arises with the ear door, and so on. Herein, mind is🔽the life-continuum consciousness, since that is what is intended as the mind door. Idea is the object of the life-continuum consciousness. Mind-consciousness element is

original: sahāvajjanakaṃ javanaṃ. Manosamphassoti bhavaṅgasahajāto phasso. Vedayitanti āvajjanavedanāya
analyzed: saha āvajjanakam javanam manaḥ samphassaḥ iti bhavaṅga sahajātaḥ phassaḥ āvajjana vedanāya
translated: the impulsion consciousness that impels with the life-continuum consciousness. Mind-contact is the contact associated with the life-continuum. Feeling is the feeling that arises with the impulsion,

original: saddhiṃ javanavedanā. Bhavaṅgasampayuttāya pana vedanāya gahaṇe vattabbameva natthi.
analyzed: saddhim javana vedanā bhavaṅga sampayuttāya pana vedanāya gahaṇe vattabbam eva natthi
translated: together with the feeling that arises with the adverting. But there is no need to mention the feeling associated with the life-continuum.

original: Āvajjanaṃ vā bhavaṅgato amocetvā manoti sāvajjanaṃ bhavaṅgaṃ daṭṭhabbaṃ. Dhammāti🔽dhammārammaṇameva. Manoviññāṇanti javanaviññāṇaṃ. Manosamphassoti bhavaṅgāvajjanasahajāto
analyzed: āvajjanam vā bhavaṅgataḥ a mocetvā sa āvajjanam bhavaṅgam daṭṭhabbam dhamma ati  dhamma ārammaṇam eva manaḥ viññāṇanti javana viññāṇam manaḥ samphasso ti bhavaṅgāvajjana sahajātaḥ
translated: Or alternatively, mind should be regarded as the life-continuum together with the adverting, since the adverting does not emerge from the life-continuum. Idea is🔽only the object of the life-continuum. Mind-consciousness element is the impulsion consciousness. Mind-contact is the contact associated with the life-continuum and the adverting. Feeling is the feeling that arises with the impulsion,

original: phasso. Vedayitanti javanasahajātā vedanā, bhavaṅgāvajjanasahajātāpi vaṭṭatiyeva.
analyzed: phassaḥ javana sahajātā vedanā bhavaṅgā vajjana sahajātā api vaṭṭatiyā iva
translated: but the feeling that arises with the life-continuum and the adverting is also included.

original: Rāgagginātiādīsu rāgova anudahanaṭṭhena aggīti rāgaggi. Rāgo hi tikhiṇaṃ hutvā uppajjamāno
analyzed: rāga gginā ati ādīsu rāgaḥ uva anudahana ṭṭhena aggī iti rāga ggi rāgaḥ hi tikhiṇam hutvā uppajjamānaḥ
translated: As regards the passage beginning “The fire of passion, etc.,” passion itself is a fire in the sense of burning. For passion arises as if it were sharp,

original: satte anudahati jhāpeti, tasmā “aggī”ti vuccati. Itaresupi dvīsu eseva nayo. Tatrimāni
analyzed: satte anudahati jhāpeti tasmai aggi iti vuccati itaresu pi dvīsu esa iva nayaḥ
translated: It burns and consumes beings, and that is why it is called fire. The same method applies in the other two cases. Here are the stories.

original: vatthūni – ekā daharabhikkhunī cittalapabbatavihāre uposathāgāraṃ gantvā dvārapālarūpaṃ
analyzed: vatthūni ekā dahara bhikkhunī cittalapabbata vihāre uposatha āgāram gantvā dvārapāla rūpam
translated: A young bhikkhunī went to the Uposatha house on the Cittalapabbata. Standing there looking at the figure of the door-keeper,

original: olokayamānā ṭhitā. Athassā anto rāgo tikhiṇataro hutvā uppanno, tasmā taṃsamuṭṭhānā
analyzed: olokayamānā ṭhitā athassāḥ antaḥ rāgaḥ tikhiṇataraḥ hutvā uppanno tasmā tad samuṭṭhānā
translated: the lust in her mind became keener and keener. So the fire-element that arose with it as its support,

original: tejodhātu ativiya tikhiṇabhāvena saddhiṃ attanā sahajātadhammehi hadayapadesaṃ jhāpesi🔽yathā taṃ bāhirā tejodhātu sannissayaṃ, tena sā bhikkhunī jhāyitvā kālamakāsi. Bhikkhuniyo
analyzed: tejodhātu tikhiṇa bhāvena saddhim attanā sahajāta dhammehi hadaya padesam jhāpesi  yathā tam bāhirā tejodhātu sannissayam tena sā bhikkhunī jhāyitvā kālam akāsi bhikkhuniyo
translated: burning the heart-basis with its extreme heat, as if with an external fire-element,

original: gacchamānā “ayaṃ daharā ṭhitā, pakkosatha na”nti āhaṃsu. Ekā gantvā “kasmā ṭhitāsī”ti

analyzed: dosassa pana anudahana tāya manopadosikāḥ devāḥ daṭṭhabbā tesu kira ekaḥ deva putto nakkhattam  kīḷissāmi iti sa parivāraḥ rathena vīthim paṭipajjati athaññaḥ nikkhamantaḥ tam puratas  gacchantam disvā bho ayam kapaṇaḥ a diṭṭha pubbam viya etam disvā pītiyā uddhu māto  viya bhijjamānaḥ viya ca gacchati iti kujjhati puratas gacchantaḥ api nivattitvā tam kuddham
translated: The gods who are angry in mind should be understood as being due to the lack of moderation in anger. translated: The gods who are offenders against the mind should be understood as the gods of the Thirty-three, since they are not restrained in body and speech. It seems that a certain god of the Thirty-three sets out in a chariot with his retinue to play in the Nandana Grove. Another god comes out to meet him and sees him going in front. He becomes angry, thinking, “Look at this wretch! He is so excited by his sight of this that he goes along as though he were inflated with pride and bursting.” The god in front turns round and sees him angry. He thinks, “Those who are angry are easy to know,” and he understands that he is angry. So he becomes angry in return, thinking, “What can you do to me when you are angry? This glory of mine has been obtained by me through generosity, virtue, etc., not through you.”

original: anupādāno ekavārameva uppattiyā anāsevano cāvetuṃ na sakkoti, udakaṃ patvā aggi viya

translated: What is the strength of ten chaddantas is the strength of one Tathagata’s bodily strength. original: “Puna caparaṃ, sāriputta, tathāgato anekavihitaṃ pubbenivāsaṃ anussarati. Seyyathidaṃ?
analyzed: puna ca param sāriputta tathāgataḥ aneka vihitam pubbenivāsam anussarati sā iyyathidam
translated: “Again, Sariputta, the Tathagata recollects his manifold past lives, that is, one birth, two births, three births, four births, five births, ten births, twenty births, thirty births, forty births, fifty births, a hundred births, a thousand births, a hundred thousand births, many eons of world-dissolution, many eons of world-evolution, many eons of world-dissolution and world-evolution: ‘There I was so named, of such a race, with such an appearance, such was my food, such my experience of pleasure and pain, such the end of my life. Passing away from that state, I re-arose there; there too I was so named, of such a race, with such an appearance, such was my food, such my experience of pleasure and pain, such the end of my life. Passing away from that state, I re-arose here.’ Thus he recollects his manifold past lives in their modes and details.

original: Ekampi jātiṃ dvepi jātiyo…pe… iti sākāraṃ sauddesaṃ anekavihitaṃ pubbenivāsaṃ anussarati…pe…. (8)🔽“Puna caparaṃ, sāriputta, tathāgato dibbena cakkhunā visuddhena atikkantamānusakena🔽satte passati cavamāne upapajjamāne hīne paṇīte suvaṇṇe dubbaṇṇe sugate duggate,🔽yathākammūpage satte pajānāti…pe…. (9)🔽“Puna caparaṃ, sāriputta, tathāgato āsavānaṃ khayā anāsavaṃ cetovimuttiṃ paññāvimuttiṃ
analyzed: ekam pi jātim dve pi jāti yope iti sa ākāram sa uddesam aneka vihitam pubbenivāsam anussarati pe  puna ca param sāriputta tathāgataḥ dibbena cakkhunā visuddhena atikkanta mānusakena  satte passati cavamāne upapajjamāne hīne paṇīte suvaṇṇe dubbaṇṇe sugate duggate  yathā kammūpage satte  puna ca param sāriputta tathāgataḥ āsavānam khayā anāsavam cetaḥ vimuttim paññā vimuttim
translated: He recollects his manifold past lives, that is, one birth, two five, ten fifty, a hundred, a thousand, a hundred thousand, many eons of cosmic contraction, many eons of cosmic expansion, many eons of cosmic contraction & expansion: ‘There I had such a name, belonged to such a clan, had such an appearance. Such was my food, such my sensitivity, such my experience of pleasure & pain, such the end of my life. Passing away from that state, I re-arose there. There too I had such a name, belonged to such a clan, had such an appearance. Such was my food, such my sensitivity, such my experience of pleasure & pain, such the end of my life. Passing away from that state, I re-arose here.’ Thus he recollects his manifold past lives in their modes & details.

original: diṭṭheva dhamme sayaṃ abhiññā sacchikatvā upasampajja viharati…pe… idampi, sāriputta,🔽tathāgatassa tathāgatabalaṃ hoti, yaṃ balaṃ āgamma tathāgato āsabhaṃ ṭhānaṃ paṭijānāti,
analyzed: diṭṭhe iva dhamme sayam abhiññā sacchikatvā upasampajja viharati pe idam pi sāriputta  tathāgatassa tathāgata balam hoti yam balam āgamma tathāgataḥ āsabham ṭhānam paṭijānāti
translated: “And further, with his mind thus concentrated, purified, and bright, unblemished, free from defects, pliant, malleable, steady, and attained to imperturbability, the monk directs and inclines it to the knowledge of the passing away and reappearance of beings. He sees — by means of the divine eye, purified and surpassing the human — beings passing away and reappearing, and he discerns how they are inferior and superior, beautiful and ugly, fortunate and unfortunate in accordance with their kamma: ‘These beings — who were endowed with bad conduct of body, speech, and mind, who reviled the noble ones, held wrong views and undertook actions under the influence of wrong views — with the break-up of the body, after death, have re-appeared in the plane of deprivation, the bad destination, the lower realms, in hell. But these beings — who were endowed with good conduct of body, speech, and mind, who did not revile the noble ones, who held right views and undertook actions under the influence of right views — with the break-up of the body, after death, have re-appeared in the good destinations, in the heavenly world.’ Thus — by means of the divine eye, purified and surpassing the human — he sees beings passing away and re-appearing, and he discerns how they are inferior and superior, beautiful and ugly, fortunate and unfortunate in accordance with their kamma.

original: parisāsu sīhanādaṃ nadati, brahmacakkaṃ pavatteti. Imāni kho, sāriputta, dasa tathāgatassa🔽tathāgatabalānī”ti. (10)
analyzed: parisāsu sīha nādam nadati brahmacakkam pavatteti imāni kho sāriputta dasa tathāgatassa 🔽tathāgata balāni iti
translated: “And further, with his mind thus concentrated, purified, and bright, unblemished, free from defects, pliant, malleable, steady, and attained to impert

original: Tattha ṭhānañca ṭhānatoti kāraṇañca kāraṇato. “Ye ye dhammā yesaṃ yesaṃ dhammānaṃ🔽hetū paccayā uppādāya, taṃ taṃ ṭhānaṃ. Ye ye dhammā yesaṃ yesaṃ dhammānaṃ na hetū🔽na paccayā uppādāya, taṃ taṃ aṭṭhāna”nti pajānanto ṭhānañca ṭhānato aṭṭhānañca aṭṭhānato
analyzed: tattha ṭhānam ca ṭhānato ti kāraṇam ca kāraṇataḥ ye ye dhammāḥ yesam yesam dhammānam  hetū paccayā uppādāya tam tam ṭhānam ye ye dhammā yesam yesam dhammānam na hetū  na paccayāḥ uppādāya tam tam aṭṭhānanti pajānanto ṭhānam ca ṭhānataḥ aṭṭhānam ca aṭṭhānataḥ
translated: Herein, the possible is the possible, and the impossible is the impossible. “When certain ideas are causes and conditions for the arising of certain ideas, that is possible. When certain ideas are not causes and conditions for the arising of certain ideas, that is impossible” . Understanding thus “The possible is the possible, the impossible is the impossible” is knowledge of the possible and the impossible.

original: yathābhūtaṃ pajānāti. Yampīti yena ñāṇena.
analyzed: yathābhūtam pajānāti yam pi iti yena ñāṇena
translated: Herein, the possible is the possible, and the impossible is the impossible. He understands “The states that are causes and conditions for these states, that is the possible; the states that are not causes and conditions for these states, that is the impossible” . He understands the possible as possible and the impossible as impossible. “By what knowledge?” By the knowledge of the way things are.

original: Kammasamādānānanti samādiyitvā katānaṃ kusalākusalakammānaṃ, kammameva vā kammasamādānaṃ.🔽Ṭhānaso hetusoti paccayato ceva hetuto ca. Tattha gatiupadhikālapayogā vipākassa
analyzed: kamma samādānānam ti samādiyitvā katānam kusala akusala kammānam kammam eva vā kamma samādānam  ṭhānaso hetuso ti paccayato ca iva hetuto ca tattha gati upadhi kāla payogāḥ vipākassa
translated: “By the undertaking of what is profitable”: by the profitable and unprofitable actions that are undertaken, or the undertaking of profitable action itself.

original: ṭhānaṃ, kammaṃ hetu.
analyzed: ṭhānam kammam hetu
translated: “By the source”: by the cause. Herein, the source of the result is the destiny, the station, the abode, the foundation, the door, the origin, the birth, the arising, the production, the manifestation of the result. Action is the cause.

original: Sabbatthagāmininti sabbagatigāminiñca agatigāminiñca. Paṭipadanti maggaṃ. Yathābhūtaṃ
analyzed: sabbattha gāminin ti sabba gati gāminin ca agati gāminin ca paṭipadanti maggam yathābhūtam
translated: “By the way leading everywhere”: by the way leading to all destinations and by the way not leading to all destinations. “Way” is path.

original: pajānātīti bahūsupi manussesu ekameva pāṇaṃ ghātentesu kāmaṃ sabbesampi cetanā tassevekassa
analyzed: pajānāti iti bahūsu pi manussesu ekam eva pāṇam ghātentesu kāmam sabbesam pi cetanā tassa iva ekassa
translated: He understands as it actually is: although many people kill a living being, the volition of only one of them is that of a murderer, not the volition of the others.

original: jīvitindriyārammaṇā, taṃ pana kammaṃ tesaṃ nānākāraṃ. Tesu hi eko ādarena chandajāto
analyzed: jīvita indriya ārammaṇā tam pana kammam tesam nānākāram tesu hi ekaḥ ādarena chanda jātaḥ
translated: and the life faculty is the object of that kamma. But that kamma is of different kinds in them. For one of them does it out of respect and with a willing mind;

original: karoti, eko “ehi tvampi karohī”ti parehi nippīḷito karoti, eko samānacchando viya
analyzed: karoti ekaḥ ehi tvam pi karohi iti parehi nippīḍitaḥ karoti ekaḥ
translated: one does it being pressed by others, “Come, do this too!”; one wanders about as if he had the same wish

original: hutvā appaṭibāhiyamāno vicarati, tasmā tesu eko teneva kammena niraye nibbattati,
analyzed: hutvā a paṭibāhiyamānaḥ vicarati tasmā tesu ekaḥ tena iva kammena niraye nibbattati
translated: and does not resist. Therefore one of them is reborn in hell by that kamma,

original: eko tiracchānayoniyaṃ, eko pettivisaye. Taṃ tathāgato āyūhanakkhaṇeyeva “iminā nīhārena
analyzed: tam tathāgataḥ iminā nīhārena
translated: one in the animal kingdom, and one in the realm of ghosts. The Tathāgata knows this even at the time of the accumulation of the kamma thus:

analyzed: āyūhita ttā esa niraye nibbattissati esa tiracchānayoniyam esa petti visaya iti jānāti
translated: “By this kamma this being will be reborn in hell, by this one in the animal kingdom, by this one in the ghost realm.”

original: Niraye nibbattamānampi “esa mahāniraye nibbattissati, esa ussadaniraye”ti jānāti.
analyzed: niraye nibbattamānam api esa mahāniraye nibbattissati esa ussada niraya iti jānāti
translated: And when he is being reborn in hell he knows “He will be reborn in the great hells,” or “He will be reborn in the adjacent hells.”

original: Tiracchānayoniyaṃ nibbattamānampi “esa apādako bhavissati, esa dvipādako, esa catuppādo,
analyzed: tiracchānayoniyam nibbattamānam pi esa a pādakaḥ bhavissati esa dvi pādakaḥ esa catuppādaḥ

analyzed: esa bahu pādaḥ ti jānāti petti visaye nibbattamānam pi esa nijjhāma taṇhikaḥ bhavissati

original: esa khuppipāsiko, esa paradattūpajīvī”ti jānāti. Tesu ca kammesu “idaṃ kammaṃ paṭisandhiṃ
analyzed: esa khuppipāsikaḥ esa para dattu upajīvī iti jānāti tesu ca kammesu idam kammam paṭisandhim
translated: he knows, “This one is hungry, this one is not hungry; this one is poor, this one is not poor; this one is miserable, this one is not miserable; this one is a beggar, this one is not a beggar.”

analyzed: ākaḍḍhissati etam aññena dinnāya paṭisandhiyā upadhi vepakkam bhavissati iti jānāti
translated: And he knows, “This action will lead to rebirth-linking; this will ripen in suffering in the next existence after being given rebirth-linking by another action.”

analyzed: tam pana kammam tesam nānā ākāram tesu hi ekaḥ ādarena karoti iti sabbam purima sadisam  tasmā tesu ca keci deva loke nibbattanti keci manussa loke tam tathāgataḥ āyūhanakkhaṇeya iva

analyzed: jānāti iminā nīhārena āyūhita ttā esa manussa loke nibbattissati esa deva loke tattha api

analyzed: esa tusitesu esa yāmesu esa tāvatiṃsesu esa cātumahārājikesu  bhumma devesu iti ādinā tattha tattha hīna paṇīta suvaṇṇa dubbaṇṇa appa parivāra mahā parivāra tā ādi bhedam

analyzed: jānāti kasiṇa parikammam karontesu pi imassa parikamma mattam eva bhavissati nimittam

original: pana dvedhā vuttaṃ. Indriyaparopariyattanti saddhādīnaṃ indriyānaṃ parabhāvañca aparabhāvañca,

analyzed: vuddhiñca hāniñca ati attho
translated: The world: the world of the aggregates, bases, and elements.🔽He understands how it is in conformity with reality: he penetrates the individual essences of those elements without reversal.🔽With its diversity

analyzed: vuttam bhavaṅgena sabba jhānehi vuṭṭhānam hoti phala samāpattiyā nirodha samāpattito
