analyzed: aham āvuso itthannāmāya āpattiyā vematikaḥ yadā nibbematikaḥ bhavissāmi tadā tam

analyzed: aṭṭhakathā ayam atthi desite pana doso na atthi itas vuṭṭhahitvā paṭikarissāmi iti ettha api  esa iva nayaḥ ti gaṇṭhi padesu vuttam yathā sabbaḥ saṅghaḥ sabhāga āpattim āpajjitvā suṇātu

translated: The measure is whether one is within arm’s reach: the intention is that whether the nuns, etc., are standing or sitting,

analyzed: bhikkhu gatiko ti bhikkhu nissitako so pana yasmai bhikkhūhi saddhim vasati tasmai
translated: ‘A monk’s attendant’: one who is dependent on a monk. But since he lives with monks,

original: vuttaṃ “bhikkhūhi saddhiṃ vasanakapuriso”ti. Sattāhakaraṇīyena gantvā bahiddhā aruṇuṭṭhāpanaṃ
analyzed: vuttam bhikkhūhi saddhim vasanaka puriso ti satta aha karaṇīyena gantvā bahiddhā aruṇuṭṭhāpanam
translated: it is said, ‘a man who lives with monks.’ ‘The dawn breaks outside’: after going on seven-day business,

original: ratticchedo. Animantitena gantuṃ na vaṭṭatīti ettha animantitattā sattāhakiccaṃ adhiṭṭhahitvā
analyzed: ratti chedaḥ a nimantitena gantum na vaṭṭati iti ettha a nimantita ttā satta aha kiccam adhiṭṭhahitvā
translated: the dawn breaks outside the monastery zone. ‘He should not go without being invited’: here, since he is not invited,

original: gacchantassapi vassacchedo ceva dukkaṭañca hotīti veditabbaṃ. Yathāvuttañhi ratticchedakāraṇaṃ
analyzed: gacchantassa api vassa chedo ca iva dukkaṭam ca hoti iti veditabbam yathāvuttam hi ratti cheda kāraṇam
translated: it should be understood that if he goes after determining the seven-day business, there is a breach of the rains residence and an offense of wrong conduct. For they say that🔽there is a breach of the rains residence even for one who goes thinking, “I will stay outside the monastery zone and then return,”

original: vinā tirovihāre vasitvā āgacchissāmīti gacchatopi vassacchedaṃ vadanti. Gantuṃ vaṭṭatīti
analyzed: vinā tirovihāre vasitvā āgacchissāmi iti gacchataḥ api vassa chedam vadanti gantum vaṭṭati iti
translated: without the reason for breaking the rains residence as stated. ‘He may go’:

original: sattāhakaraṇīyena gantuṃ vaṭṭati. Evaṃ gacchantena ca antoupacārasīmāyaṃ ṭhiteneva
analyzed: satta aha karaṇīyena gantum vaṭṭati evam gacchantena ca ṭhitena iva
translated: he may go on seven-day business. And when he goes in this way, he should stand

original: “antosattāhe āgacchissāmī”ti ābhogaṃ katvā gantabbaṃ. Sace ābhogaṃ akatvā upacārasīmaṃ🔽atikkamati, chinnavassova hotīti vadanti. Bhaṇḍakanti cīvaraṃ sandhāya vuttaṃ. Pahiṇantīti🔽cīvaradhovanādikammena pahiṇanti. Sampāpuṇituṃ na sakkoti, vaṭṭatīti ettha “ajjeva🔽āgamissāmī”ti sāmantavihāraṃ gantvā puna āgacchantassa antarāmagge sace aruṇuggamanaṃ🔽hoti, vassacchedopi na hoti, ratticchedadukkaṭañca natthīti vadanti. “Ācariyaṃ passissāmī”ti🔽pana gantuṃ labhatīti “agilānampi ācariyaṃ upajjhāyaṃ vā passissāmī”ti sattāhakaraṇīyena
analyzed: antosattāhe āgacchissāmi iti ābhogam katvā gantabbam sace ābhogam a katvā upacāra sīmam  atikkamati chinna vassā uva hoti iti vadanti bhaṇḍakam ti cīvaram sandhāya vuttam pahiṇanti iti  cīvara dhovana ādi kammena pahiṇanti sampāpuṇitum na sakkoti vaṭṭati iti ettha ajja eva  āgamissāmi iti sāmantavihāram gantvā punar āgacchantassa antara āmagge sace aruṇuggamanam  hoti vassa chedaḥ api na hoti ratti cheda dukkaṭam ca natthi iti vadanti ācariyam passissāmi iti  pana gantum labhati iti a gilānam pi ācariyam upajjhāyam vā passissāmi iti satta aha karaṇīyena
translated: “I shall come back within seven days” and then he may go. If he goes beyond the boundary of the access-meditation without making such a resolve, they say that his rains is broken. “Luggage” is said with reference to robes. “Send” means🔽they send him off with the work of washing robes, etc. “If he cannot manage to return” means that if he goes to a neighbouring monastery thinking “I shall return today” and the dawn breaks while he is on the way back,🔽they say that his rains is not broken, and there is no offense entailing confession for the night-time. But he is allowed to go “to see the teacher”🔽“I shall see my teacher or preceptor” and then he may go on seven-day business.

original: gantuṃ labhati. Sace pana naṃ ācariyo “ajja mā gacchā”ti vadati, vaṭṭatīti evaṃ sattāhakaraṇīyena
analyzed: gantum labhati sace pana naṃ ācariyaḥ ajja mā gacchāti vadati vaṭṭati iti evam satta aha karaṇīyena
translated: “I shall come within seven days” and then go. If he goes beyond the access-resolution without making such an aspiration, they say that his rains should be counted as broken. “A bundle” : this is said with reference to a robe. “Send it”: they send it with the work of washing the robe, etc., as a pretext. “If he cannot manage to reach it, it is allowable”: here they say that if he goes to a neighbouring monastery thinking, “I shall come back today,” and the dawn breaks while he is on the way back, his rains are not broken, nor is there an offense entailing confession for the night of the break in the rains. “If he thinks, ‘I shall see the teacher,’ ” he is allowed to go. “If he thinks, ‘I shall see the preceptor,’ he is allowed to go on seven-day business. But if the teacher says, ‘Don’t come today,’ it is allowable” .

original: gataṃ antosattāheyeva puna āgacchantaṃ sace ācariyo upajjhāyo vā “ajja mā gacchā”ti
analyzed: gatam punar āgacchantam sace ācariyaḥ upajjhāyaḥ vai ajja mā gacchāti
translated: If the teacher or preceptor says, “Don’t go today,”🔽

original: vadati, vaṭṭati, sattāhātikkamepi anāpattīti adhippāyo, vassacchedo pana hotiyevāti
analyzed: vadati vaṭṭati satta aha atikkame pi anāpatti iti adhippāyaḥ vassa chedaḥ pana hotiyā iva āti
translated: If the teacher or preceptor says, “Don’t go today,” it is allowable. The intention is that there is no offense even if the seven days are exceeded, but the rains should be regarded as being interrupted,

original: daṭṭhabbaṃ sattāhassa bahiddhā vītināmitattā.
analyzed: daṭṭhabbam sattāhassa bahiddhā vītināmita ttā
translated: because the seven days have been spent outside.

original: Antarāye anāpattivassacchedakathāvaṇṇanā
analyzed: antarāye anāpatti vassa cheda kathā vaṇṇanā
translated: The explanation of the non-offense when there is a hindrance

original: 201. Sace dūraṃ gato hoti, sattāhavārena aruṇo uṭṭhāpetabboti iminā vassacchedakāraṇe sati sattāhakaraṇīyena gantuṃ vaṭṭatīti dīpeti.
analyzed: sace dūram gataḥ hoti satta aha vārena aruṇo uṭṭhāpetabbo ti iminā vassa cheda kāraṇe sati satta aha karaṇīyena gantum vaṭṭati iti dīpeti
translated: If he has gone a long distance, the dawn must be reached by counting seven days. This shows that if there is a reason for interrupting the rains, it is allowable to go on seven-day business.

original: Vajādīsu vassūpagamanakathāvaṇṇanā🔽203. “Idha vassaṃ upemī”ti tikkhattuṃ vattabbanti satthassāvihārattā “imasmiṃ vihāre”ti🔽avatvā “idha vassaṃ upemī”ti ettakameva vattabbaṃ. Satthe pana vassaṃ upagantuṃ na
analyzed: vaja ādīsu vassu upagamana kathā vaṇṇanā  idha vassam upemi iti tikkhattum vattabbanti satthassa a vihāra ttā imasmin vihāre iti  a vatvā idha vassam upemi iti ettakam eva vattabbam satthe pana vassam upagantum na
translated: The explanation of the entering of the rains in a chariot, etc.🔽“I will enter the rains here” should be said three times. Without saying “in this dwelling,”🔽because the dwelling belongs to the chariot, it is only necessary to say “I will enter the rains here.” But it is not allowable to enter the rains in a chariot.

original: vaṭṭatīti kuṭikādīnaṃ abhāve “idha vassaṃ upemī”ti vacībhedaṃ katvā upagantuṃ na
analyzed: vaṭṭati iti kuṭikā ādīnam abhāve idha vassam upemi iti vacībhedam katvā upagantum na
translated: If there is no hut, etc., it is not allowable to enter the rains by saying “I will enter the rains here” and then changing the words.

original: vaṭṭati, ālayakaraṇamatteneva vaṭṭatīti adhippāyo. Vippakiratīti visuṃ visuṃ gacchati.
analyzed: vaṭṭati ālaya karaṇa mattena iva vaṭṭati iti adhippāyaḥ vippakirati iti visum visum gacchati
translated: The meaning is that it is allowable only as a shelter from the elements. It disperses: it goes in different directions.

original: Tīsu ṭhānesu natthi vassacchede āpattīti tehi saddhiṃ gacchantasseva natthi āpatti,
analyzed: tīsu ṭhānesu natthi vassa chede āpatti iti tehi saddhim gacchantassa iva natthi āpatti
translated: There is no offence for one who goes with them in these three cases if there is no break in the rains.

original: tehi viyujjitvā gamane pana āpattiyeva, pavāretuñca na labhati.
analyzed: tehi viyujjitvā gamane pana āpattiyā iva pavāretum ca na labhati
translated: But if he goes after separating from them, there is an offence, and he is not allowed to invite.

original: Vassaṃ anupagantabbaṭṭhānakathāvaṇṇanā
analyzed: vassam an upagantabba ṭṭhāna kathā vaṇṇanā
translated: The explanation of the section in the Discussion of the Observance for Going into Retreat

original: 204. Seyyathāpi pisācillikāti ettha pisācā eva pisācillikā, pisācadārakātipi vadanti.🔽Pavisanadvāraṃ yojetvāti sakavāṭabaddhameva yojetvā. Pañcannaṃ chadanānanti tiṇapaṇṇaiṭṭhakasilāsudhāsaṅkhātānaṃ
analyzed: sā iyyathā api pisācillikā ati ettha pisācāḥ eva pisācillikā vadanti  pavisana dvāram yojetvā ati sa kavāṭa baddham eva yojetvā pañcannam chadanānanti tiṇa paṇṇa eṭṭhaka silā sudhā saṅkhātānam
translated: In the case of a demoness: here “demoness” is a female demon, they also say “demon child.”🔽Having fastened the door for entering: having fastened it with a bolt. Of the five kinds of roofs: of the five kinds of roofs consisting of grass, leaves, split cane, clay, and wood.

original: pañcannaṃ chadanānaṃ. Idañca yebhuyyena vuttanti veditabbaṃ rukkhādīsu padaracchadanāyapi
analyzed: pañcannam chadanānam idam ca yebhuyyena vutta nti veditabbam rukkha ādīsu
translated: And this should be understood as said generally. For it is said that one may go into retreat in a hut roofed with tree branches, etc.,

original: kuṭikāya vassūpagamanassa vuttattā. Na, bhikkhave, asenāsanikena vassaṃ upagantabbanti
analyzed: kuṭikāya vassūpagamanassa vuttattā na bhikkhave asenāsanikena vassam upagantabbanti
translated: “Monks, you should not go into retreat without a dwelling.”

original: vacībhedaṃ katvā vassūpagamanaṃ sandhāyeva paṭikkhepo, na ālayakaraṇavasena upagamanaṃ
analyzed: vacībhedam katvā vassu upagamanam sandhāya iva paṭikkhepaḥ na ālaya karaṇa vasena upagamanam
translated: The prohibition is in regard to the undertaking of the rains by means of a verbal act, not in regard to the undertaking of the rains by means of the act of making a dwelling.

original: sandhāyāti vadanti. Pāḷiyaṃ pana avisesena vuttattā aṭṭhakathāyañca dutiyapārājikasaṃvaṇṇanāyaṃ
analyzed: sandhāya iti vadanti pāḷiyam pana avisesena vutta ttā aṭṭhakathāyam ca dutiya pārājika saṃvaṇṇanāyam
translated: So they say. But because of the words of the text, which are without distinction, and because of the commentary on the second offence entailing expulsion in the Khandhaka,

original: “vassaṃ upagacchantena hi nālakapaṭipadaṃ paṭipannenapi pañcannaṃ chadanānaṃ aññatarena🔽channeyeva sadvārabandhe senāsane upagantabbaṃ. Tasmā vassakāle sace senāsanaṃ labhati,
analyzed: vassam upagacchantena hi nālaka paṭipadam paṭipannena api pañcannam chadanānam aññatarena  sa dvāra bandhe senāsane upagantabbam tasmā vassa kāle sace senāsanam labhati
translated: where it is said: “One who undertakes the rains should undertake it in a dwelling with a closed door and with one of the five kinds of roofing.🔽Therefore, if one gets a dwelling in the rains, that is good. If not, he should have one built by paid labour.

original: iccetaṃ kusalaṃ. No ce labhati, hatthakammaṃ pariyesitvāpi kātabbaṃ. Hatthakammaṃ
analyzed: iccā itam kusalam no ce labhati hatthakammam pariyesitvā api kātabbam hatthakammam
translated: If he cannot get paid labour, he should even do the work himself.

original: alabhantena sāmampi kātabbaṃ, na tveva asenāsanikena vassaṃ upagantabba”nti daḷhaṃ
analyzed: a labhantena sāmam pi kātabbam na tu eva a senāsanikena vassam upagantabbanti daḷham
translated: But he should not undertake the rains without a dwelling.”

original: katvā vuttattā asenāsanikassa nāvādiṃ vinā aññattha ālayo na vaṭṭatīti amhākaṃ khanti.
analyzed: katvā vutta ttā asenāsanikassa nāvā ādim vinā aññattha ālayaḥ na vaṭṭati iti amhākam khanti
translated: and because it is said so strongly, we think that it is not allowable for one without a dwelling to make a home anywhere except in a boat, etc.

original: Nāvāsatthavajesuyeva hi “anujānāmi, bhikkhave, nāvāya vassaṃ upagantu”ntiādinā sati
analyzed: hi anujānāmi bhikkhave nāvāya vassam upagantuṃ ti ādinā sati
translated: For in the passage: “Monks, I allow you to undertake the rains in a boat” , etc.,

original: asati vā senāsane vassūpagamanassa visuṃ anuññātattā “na, bhikkhave, asenāsanikena
analyzed: asati vā senāsane vassūpagamanassa visum anuññāta ttā na bhikkhave a senāsanikena
translated: But if there is no dwelling, because going into the Rains Retreat has been allowed separately, “Monks, one who is not staying in a dwelling should not go into the Rains Retreat.

original: vassaṃ upagantabba”nti ayaṃ paṭikkhepo tattha na labbhatīti asati senāsane ālayavasenapi
analyzed: vassam upagantabbanti ayam paṭikkhepaḥ tattha na labbhati iti asati senāsane ālaya vasena api
translated: Or, since the undertaking of the rains residence is allowed separately even if there is no dwelling, this prohibition, “Monks, you should not undertake the rains residence without a dwelling,” is not applicable there. So it is said that one may undertake it there without a dwelling, even if one is not free from desire for it.

original: nāvādīsu upagamanaṃ vuttaṃ. Ṭaṅkitamañco nāma dīghe mañcapāde majjhe vijjhitvā aṭaniyo🔽pavesetvā kato mañco. Tassa idaṃ upari idaṃ heṭṭhāti natthi, parivattetvā atthatopi🔽tādisova hoti, taṃ susāne devaṭṭhāne ca ṭhapenti, catunnaṃ pāsāṇānaṃ upari pāsāṇaṃ
analyzed: nāvā ādīsu upagamanam vuttam ṭaṅkitamañcaḥ nāma dīghe mañca pāde majjhe vijjhitvā aṭaniyaḥ  pavesetvā kataḥ mañcaḥ tassa idam upari idam heṭṭhā ti natthi parivattetvā atthataḥ pi  tādisaḥ uva hoti tam susāne devaṭṭhāne ca ṭhapenti catunnam pāsāṇānam upari pāsāṇam
translated: A “fixed bed” is a bed made by fixing the legs in the middle with pegs driven into holes in the legs.

original: attharitvā kataṃ gehampi “ṭaṅkitamañco”ti vuccati.
analyzed: attharitvā katam geham pi ṭaṅkita mañco ti vuccati
translated: There is no difference between the one above and the one below. It is the same whether it is set up or turned over. They put it in a charnel ground or in a temple. A building made by putting a stone on top of four stones is also called a “fixed bed.”

original: Vassaṃ anupagantabbaṭṭhānakathāvaṇṇanā niṭṭhitā.
analyzed: vassam an upagantabba ṭṭhāna kathā vaṇṇanā niṭṭhitā
translated: The explanation of the places where one should not undertake the rains is finished.

original: Adhammikakatikakathāvaṇṇanā
analyzed: adhammika katika kathā vaṇṇanā
translated: The explanation of the section on illegitimate schism in the Monastic Code

original: 205. Tassā lakkhaṇaṃ mahāvibhaṅge vuttanti catutthapārājikasaṃvaṇṇanāyaṃ “yo imamhā
analyzed: tassāḥ lakkhaṇam mahāvibhaṅge vuttanti catuttha pārājika saṃvaṇṇanāyam yaḥ imamhā
translated: The characteristic of this is given in the analysis of the fourth offense entailing expulsion: “If a monk should wish: ‘Let me, with the dissolution of the body, after death, be reborn among the gods of the class of the Four Great Kings’ …🔽… among the gods of the Thirty-three …🔽… among the Yama gods …🔽… among the gods of the Tusita heaven …🔽… among the gods who delight in creating …🔽… among the gods who wield power over others’ creations …🔽… among the Brahmā gods …🔽… among the gods of streaming radiance …🔽… among the gods of refulgent glory …🔽… among the gods of great fruit …🔽… among the Aviha gods …🔽… among the Atappa gods …🔽… among the Sudassa gods …🔽… among the Sudassī gods …🔽… among the Akaniṭṭha gods’ …

original: āvāsā paṭhamaṃ pakkamissati, taṃ mayaṃ arahāti jānissāmā”ti ettha dassitaṃ adhammikakatikavattalakkhaṇaṃ
analyzed: āvāsā paṭhamam pakkamissati tam mayam arahā ati jānissāma ati ettha dassitam adhammika katika vatta lakkhaṇam
translated: He is speaking with reference to the characteristic of an illegitimate agreement as shown in the passage: “If the resident bhikkhu goes away first, we shall know that he has given up his claim to the dwelling.”

original: sandhāya vadati, paratopi senāsanakkhandhakavaṇṇanāyaṃ adhammikaṃ katikavattaṃ āvi bhavissatiyeva.
analyzed: sandhāya vadati paratas pi senāsana khandhaka vaṇṇanāyam adhammikam katika vattam āvi bhavissatiyā eva
translated: And it will be shown as illegitimate in the commentary on the “Rules for the Rains” chapter.

original: Paṭissavadukkaṭāpattikathāvaṇṇanā
analyzed: paṭissava dukkaṭa āpatti kathā vaṇṇanā
translated: The explanation of the offence of wrong-doing in the case of a promise to share

original: 207. Yasmā nānāsīmāyaṃ dvīsu āvāsesu vassaṃ vasantassa dutiye “vasāmī”ti citte uppanne
analyzed: yasmā dvīsu āvāsesu vassam vasantassa dutiye vasāmi iti citte uppanne
translated: Since, when one who has entered upon the rains in two different residences in different territories thinks, “I shall live in the second,”

original: paṭhamasenāsanaggāho paṭippassambhati, puna paṭhameyeva “vasāmī”ti citte uppanne
analyzed: paṭhama senāsana ggāho paṭippassambhati puna paṭhameya iva vasāmi iti citte uppanne
translated: the first appropriation of a dwelling is abandoned, and when he thinks, “I shall live in the first,”

original: dutiyo paṭippassambhati, tasmā “tassa, bhikkhave, bhikkhuno purimikā ca na paññāyatī”ti🔽vuttaṃ. Paṭissavassa visaṃvādanapaccayā hontampi dukkaṭaṃ satiyeva paṭissave hotīti
analyzed: dutiyo tasmā tassa bhikkhave bhikkhuno purimikā ca na paññāyati iti  vuttam paṭissavassa visaṃvādana paccayā hontam pi dukkaṭam satiyā iva paṭissave hoti iti
translated: the second is abandoned, it is said: “The first of that bhikkhu is not valid.”🔽But the offence of wrong-doing that arises through deceiving a promise to share is only in the case of a promise to share.

original: āha “tassa tassa paṭissave dukkaṭa”nti. Tenevāha “tañca kho…pe… pacchā visaṃvādanapaccayā”ti.
analyzed: āha tassa tassa paṭissave dukkaṭan ti tena eva āha tat ca khope pacchā visaṃvādana paccayā ti
translated: That is why it is said: “The offence of wrong-doing is in the case of each promise to share.” That is why it is said: “But it is only when he deceives after the rains that he becomes one who has deceived a promise to share.”

original: Akaraṇīyoti sattāhakaraṇīyena akaraṇīyo. Sakaraṇīyoti sattāhakaraṇīyeneva sakaraṇīyo.
analyzed: a karaṇīyaḥ uti sattāha karaṇīyena a karaṇīyaḥ sa karaṇīyaḥ iti sattāha karaṇīyena iva sa karaṇīyaḥ
translated: “Not to be done” means not to be done in seven days. “To be done” means to be done in seven days.

original: Yadi evaṃ “sattāhakaraṇīyena akaraṇīyo sakaraṇīyo”ti ca kasmā na vuttanti? “Akaraṇīyo”ti
analyzed: yadi evam satta aha karaṇīyena akaraṇīyaḥ sa karaṇīyaḥ iti ca kasmā na vuttanti akaraṇīyaḥ iti
translated: If that is so, why is it not said, “Not to be done in seven days, to be done in seven days”?

original: vuttepi sattāhakaraṇīyena sakaraṇīyākaraṇīyatā viññāyatīti katvā na vuttaṃ. Yadi🔽evaṃ parato “sattāhakaraṇīyena pakkamatī”ti vāradvayepi “sakaraṇīyo pakkamatī”ti🔽ettakameva kasmā na vuttanti? Vuccate – tattha “sattāhakaraṇīyenā”ti avatvā “sakaraṇīyo
analyzed: vutte api satta aha karaṇīyena sa karaṇīya akaraṇīya tā viññāyati iti katvā na vuttam yadi  evam paratas satta aha karaṇīyena pakkamati iti vāra dvaye pi sa karaṇīyaḥ pakkamati iti  ettakam eva kasmā na vuttanti vuccate tattha satta aha karaṇīyena ati avatvā sa karaṇīyaḥ
translated: Because it is understood that “not to be done” means not to be done in seven days.🔽If that is so, why is it not said in the two answers, “He goes away to do it in seven days,” “He goes away to do it,”🔽only? It is said: because it cannot be said that he spends that seven days outside, if it is said, “He goes away to do it,”

original: pakkamatī”ti vutte so taṃ sattāhaṃ bahiddhā vītināmetīti na sakkā vattunti “sattāhakaraṇīyena
analyzed: pakkamati iti vutte saḥ tam satta aham bahiddhā vītināmeti iti na sakkā vattum ti satta aha karaṇīyena
translated: without saying, “In seven days.”

original: pakkamatī”ti vuttaṃ. Evañhi vutte sattāhassa adhikatattā so taṃ sattāhaṃ bahi vītināmetīti sakkā vattuṃ.
analyzed: pakkamati iti vuttam evam hi vutte satta ahassa adhikata ttā so tam satta aham bahi vītināmeti iti sakkā vattum
translated: If it is said thus, it can be said that he spends that seven days outside, because it is more than seven days.

original: Ettha ca ādimhi cattāro vārā nirapekkhagamanaṃ sandhāya vuttā, tatthāpi purimā dve🔽vārā vassaṃ anupagatassa vasena vuttā, pacchimā pana dve vārā vassaṃ upagatassa vasena,
analyzed: ettha ca ādimhi cattāraḥ vārāḥ nirapekkha gamanam sandhāya vuttā tattha api purimā dve  vārā vassam an upagatassa vasena vuttā pacchimā pana dve vārā vassam upagatassa vasena
translated: And here the first four sections are spoken in order to show going without concern. And here too the first two🔽sections are spoken in order to show one who has not entered for the Rains. But the last two sections are spoken in order to show one who has entered for the Rains.

original: tato paraṃ dve vārā sāpekkhagamanaṃ sandhāya vuttā, tatthāpi paṭhamavāro sāpekkhassapi
analyzed: tato param dve vārā sāpekkha gamanam sandhāya vuttā tattha api paṭhama vāraḥ sāpekkhassa api
translated: Then the next two sections are spoken in order to show going with concern. And here too the first section is spoken

original: sattāhakaraṇīyena gantvā taṃ sattāhaṃ bahiddhā vītināmentassa vassacchedadassanatthaṃ🔽vutto, itaro vuttanayeneva gantvā antosattāhe nivattantassa vassacchedābhāvadassanatthaṃ.🔽“So sattāhaṃ anāgatāya pavāraṇāya sakaraṇīyo pakkamatī”ti ayaṃ pana vāro navamito
analyzed: sattāha karaṇīyena gantvā tam sattāham bahiddhā vassa cheda dassana attham  vuttaḥ itaraḥ vutta nayena iva gantvā antosattāhe nivattantassa vassa cheda abhāva dassana attham  so satta aham anāgatāya pavāraṇāya sa karaṇīyaḥ pakkamati iti ayam pana vāraḥ
translated: in order to show the interruption of the Rains residence for one who goes with concern and who, having gone, spends that seven days outside.🔽The other is spoken in order to show the non-interruption of the Rains residence for one who goes in the way stated and who returns within the seven days.

original: paṭṭhāya gantvā sattāhaṃ bahiddhā vītināmentassapi vassacchedābhāvadassanatthaṃ vutto.
analyzed: paṭṭhāya gantvā satta aham bahiddhā vassa cheda abhāva dassana ttham vuttaḥ
translated: “If he has business and he goes away before the Invitation ceremony, having seven days left to do” — this section is spoken in order to show the non-interruption of the Rains residence for one who goes from the ninth day onwards and who spends the seven days outside.

original: Ettha ca “akaraṇīyo pakkamatī”ti dutiyavārassa anāgatattā navamito paṭṭhāya gacchantenapi
analyzed: ettha ca a karaṇīyaḥ pakkamati iti dutiya vārassa anāgata ttā paṭṭhāya gacchantena api
translated: And here, because of the non-arrival of the second section “if he has no business and he goes away” from the ninth day onwards,🔽going,

original: satiyeva karaṇīye gantabbaṃ, nāsatīti daṭṭhabbaṃ. Ime ca satta vārā bahiddhā katauposathikassa🔽vasena āgatā, apare satta antovihāraṃ gantvā katauposathassa vasenāti evaṃ purimikāya
analyzed: satiyā iva karaṇīye gantabbam na asati iti daṭṭhabbam ime ca satta vārāḥ bahiddhā kata auposathikassa  vasena āgatāḥ apare satta antovihāram gantvā kata uposathassa vasena ati evam purimikāya
translated: The meaning is that it should be seen that it is only when there is business that one may go, not when there is none. And these seven sections have come up in the case of one who has done the observance-day ceremony outside.🔽The other seven are in the case of one who has done the observance-day ceremony inside the monastery zone. So they are stated in fourteen sections in the case of the former,

original: vasena cuddasa vārā vuttā, tato paraṃ pacchimikāya vasena teyeva cuddasa vārā vuttāti
analyzed: vasena cuddasa vārā vuttā tato param pacchimikāya vasena teyeva cuddasa vārā vuttā ati
translated: and the same fourteen are stated in the case of the latter.

original: evametesaṃ nānākaraṇaṃ veditabbaṃ.
analyzed: evam etesam nānākaraṇam veditabbam
translated: This is how the difference between them should be understood.🔽But in order to show the meaning of all these sections in brief, the following is stated:

original: Imehi pana sabbavārehi vuttamatthaṃ sampiṇḍetvā dassetuṃ “so tadaheva akaraṇīyotiādīsū”tiādi🔽āraddhaṃ. Ko pana vādo dvīhatīhaṃ vasitvā antosattāhe nivattantassāti vassaṃ upagantvā
analyzed: imehi pana sabba vārehi vuttam attham sampiṇḍetvā dassetum saḥ tad ahā iva a karaṇīyaḥ iti ādīsu utiādi  āraddham kaḥ pana vādaḥ dvīhatīham vasitvā antosattāhe nivattantassa ati vassam upagantvā
translated: “If he has business that very day” , and so on.

original: dvīhatīhaṃ vasitvā sattāhakaraṇīyena gantvā antosattāhe nivattantassa ko pana vādo,🔽kathā eva natthīti adhippāyo. Asatiyā pana vassaṃ na upetīti “imasmiṃ vihāre imaṃ
analyzed: dvīhatīham vasitvā sattāha karaṇīyena gantvā antosattāhe nivattantassa kaḥ pana vādaḥ  kathā eva natthi iti adhippāyaḥ asatiyā pana vassam na upeti iti imasmin vihāre imam
translated: But what of one who stays two or three days and returns within seven days?🔽The intention is that there is no question of his not entering the rains.

original: temāsaṃ vassaṃ upemī”ti vacībhedaṃ katvā na upeti.
analyzed: te māsam vassam upemi iti vacī bhedam katvā naḥ upeti
translated: But if he does not enter the rains, saying, “I am entering the rains in this monastery for these three months,”

original: Komudiyā cātumāsiniyāti pacchimakattikapuṇṇamāyaṃ. Sā hi kumudānaṃ atthitāya komudī,
analyzed: komudiyā cātumāsiniyā ati pacchima kattika puṇṇamāyam sā hi kumudānam atthitāya komudī
translated: “At the Komudī full moon of the fourth month”: at the last full moon of the rainy season. For that full moon is called “Komudī” because of the presence of the white water lily,

original: catunnaṃ vassikānaṃ māsānaṃ pariyosānattā “cātumāsinī”ti vuccati. Tadā hi kumudāni🔽supupphitāni honti, tasmā kumudānaṃ samūho, kumudāni eva vā komudā, te ettha atthīti
analyzed: catunnam vassikānam māsānam pariyosāna ttā cātumāsinī iti vuccati tadā hi kumudāni  su pupphitāni honti tasmā kumudānam samūhaḥ kumudāni eva vā komudā te ettha atthi iti
translated: and it is called “of the fourth month” because it is at the end of the four months of the rainy season. For then the white water lilies are in full bloom.🔽Therefore the collection of white water lilies is called “Komudī,” or the white water lilies themselves are called “Komudī,” and that is present here,

original: “komudī”ti vuccati, kumudavatīti vuttaṃ hoti. Sesamettha uttānameva.
analyzed: komudī iti vuccati kumudavatī iti vuttam hoti sesam ettha uttānam eva
translated: so it is called “Komudī.” What is meant is: “endowed with white water lilies.” The rest is clear.

original: Paṭissavadukkaṭāpattikathāvaṇṇanā niṭṭhitā.
analyzed: paṭissava dukkaṭa āpatti kathā vaṇṇanā niṭṭhitā
translated: The explanation of the discussion of the offense of wrong conduct in the case of a reply is finished.

original: Vassūpanāyikakkhandhakavaṇṇanā niṭṭhitā.
analyzed: vassūpanāyika khandhaka vaṇṇanā niṭṭhitā
translated: The section for recitation on entering for the Rains is finished.

original: 4. Pavāraṇakkhandhakaṃ
analyzed: pavāraṇa khandhakam
translated: The chapter on the invitation ceremony

original: Aphāsukavihārakathāvaṇṇanā
analyzed: a phāsuka vihāra kathā vaṇṇanā
translated: The explanation of the discussion of the discomfort of the dwelling

original: 209. Pavāraṇakkhandhake ādito lāpo ālāpo, vacanapaṭivacanavasena samaṃ lāpo sallāpo.
analyzed: pavāraṇa kkhandhake āditas lāpaḥ ālāpaḥ vacana paṭivacana vasena samam lāpaḥ sallāpaḥ
translated: In the chapter on the invitation ceremony, “a quarrel” is a dispute. “A dispute” is a mutual quarrel.

original: Piṇḍāya paṭikkameyyāti gāme piṇḍāya caritvā paccāgaccheyya. Avakkārapātiṃ dhovitvā
analyzed: piṇḍāya paṭikkameyya ati gāme piṇḍāya caritvā paccāgaccheyya avakkāra pātim dhovitvā
translated: “He should go out for alms” means that he should return to the village after walking for alms. After washing the bowl and the bowl-washing water,

original: upaṭṭhāpeyyāti atirekapiṇḍapātaṃ apanetvā ṭhapanatthāya ekaṃ samuggapātiṃ dhovitvā🔽ṭhapeyya. Samuggapāti nāma samuggapuṭasadisā pāti. Appahariteti aparūḷhaharite, yasmiṃ🔽ṭhāne piṇḍapātajjhottharaṇena vinassanadhammāni tiṇāni natthi, tasminti attho. Tena
analyzed: upaṭṭhāpeyya ati atireka piṇḍapātam apanetvā ṭhapana thāya ekam samugga pātim dhovitvā  ṭhapeyya samuggapāti nāma samugga puṭa sadisā pāti appaharitā iti aparūḍha harite yasmin  ṭhāne piṇḍapāta ajjhottharaṇena vinassana dhammāni tiṇāni na atthi tasmin ti atthaḥ tena
translated: He should set out: having taken away the extra almsfood, he should wash a bowl and set it out for the purpose of storing it.🔽A bowl: a bowl like a bowl.🔽In a place where there is no green grass: in a place where the grass is not growing, where the grass will not be destroyed by the stirring up of the almsfood.

original: nittiṇañca mahātiṇagahanañca yattha sakaṭenapi chaḍḍite piṇḍapāte tiṇāni na vinassanti,
analyzed: nittiṇam ca mahā tiṇa gahanam ca sakaṭena api chaḍḍite piṇḍapāte tiṇāni na vinassanti
translated: In other words, it refers to a place that is free of grass and also free of thickets, where the grass will not be destroyed even if the almsfood is thrown out with a cart.

original: tañca ṭhānaṃ pariggahitaṃ hoti. Bhūtagāmasikkhāpadassa hi avikopanatthametaṃ vuttaṃ.
analyzed: tat ca ṭhānam pariggahitam hoti bhūtagāma sikkhāpadassa hi a vikopana attham etam vuttam
translated: And that place is reserved. For this is said for the purpose of not disturbing the training rule on plants.

original: Appāṇaketi nippāṇake, piṇḍapātajjhottharaṇena maritabbapāṇakarahite vā mahāudakakkhandhe.
analyzed: appāṇaka iti nippāṇake piṇḍapāta ajjhottharaṇena maritabba pāṇaka rahite vā mahā udakakkhandhe
translated: In water that is not living: in water that is free of living beings, or in a large mass of water that is free of living beings that might be destroyed by the stirring up of the almsfood.

original: Parittodake eva hi bhattapakkhepena āluḷite sukhumapāṇakā maranti, na mahātaḷākādīsūti.
analyzed: paritta udake eva hi bhatta pakkhepena āluḷite sukhuma pāṇakāḥ maranti na mahā taḷāka ādīsu iti
translated: For when the water is stirred up by the cooking of the almsfood, the small living beings die. But not in a large lake, and so on.🔽For this is said for the purpose of protecting living beings.

original: Pāṇakānurakkhaṇatthañhi etaṃ vuttaṃ. Opilāpeyyāti nimujjāpeyya.
analyzed: pāṇaka anurakkhaṇa attham hi etam vuttam opilāpeyya ati nimujjāpeyya
translated: He should immerse: he should submerge.

original: Vaccaghaṭanti ācamanakumbhī. Rittanti rittakaṃ. Tucchanti tasseva vevacanaṃ. Avisayhanti
analyzed: ācamana kumbhī rittanti rittakam tucchanti tassa iva vevacanam
translated: “Water-pot” is a water-jar. “Empty” means empty. “Bowl” is a synonym for it. “Not having used” means not having used it.

original: ukkhipituṃ asakkuṇeyyaṃ atibhārikaṃ. Hatthavikārenāti hatthasaññāya. Hatthehi ukkhipanaṃ
analyzed: ukkhipitum a sakkuṇeyyam ati bhārikam hattha vikārena ati hattha saññāya hatthehi ukkhipanaṃ
translated: “A water-pot” is a pot for rinsing the mouth. “Empty” means empty. “A bowl” is a synonym for it. “Too heavy to lift” means too heavy to lift. “By a gesture of the hand” means by the sign of the hand. “Lifting with the hands”

original: hatthavilaṅghanaṃ. Tenāha “hatthukkhepakenā”ti. Atha vā vilaṅgheti desantaraṃ pāpeti
analyzed: hattha vilaṅghanam tena āha hatthu khepakena ati atha vā vilaṅgha iti desa antaram pāpa iti
translated: means lifting with the hands. Therefore it is said: “by a gesture of the hand.” Or else, he moves it, he causes it to go to another place,

original: etenāti vilaṅghako, hattho eva vilaṅghako hatthavilaṅghako, tena hatthavilaṅghakena,
analyzed: etena ati vilaṅghakaḥ hatthaḥ eva vilaṅghakaḥ hattha vilaṅghako tena hattha vilaṅghakena
translated: by this, therefore he is a mover. The hand itself is a mover, a hand-mover. By that hand-mover,

original: aññamaññaṃ saṃsibbitahatthenāti vuttaṃ hoti. Dve hi janā hatthena hatthaṃ saṃsibbetvā
analyzed: aññam aññam saṃsibbita hatthena iti vuttam hoti dve hi janā hatthena hattham saṃsibbetvā
translated: the hands are intertwined with each other. This is what is meant. Two people, having intertwined their hands,

original: dvīsu hatthesu ṭhapetvā uṭṭhapentā hatthavilaṅghakena uṭṭhapenti nāma. Titthiyasamādānanti
analyzed: dvīsu hatthesu ṭhapetvā uṭṭhapentā hattha vilaṅghakena uṭṭhapenti nāma titthiya samādānam ti
translated: having placed the hands on the two shoulders, are said to lift by a gesture of the hand. “The undertaking of the sectarians”

original: titthiyehi samādātabbaṃ.🔽Aphāsukavihārakathāvaṇṇanā niṭṭhitā.
analyzed: titthiyehi samādātabbam  aphāsuka vihāra kathā vaṇṇanā niṭṭhitā
translated: means that which should be undertaken by the sectarians.🔽The explanation of the discussion on the dwelling place that is not convenient is finished.

original: Pavāraṇābhedakathāvaṇṇanā
analyzed: pavāraṇā bheda kathā vaṇṇanā
translated: The explanation of the discussion on the schism in the invitation ceremony

original: 212. Dvemā, bhikkhave, pavāraṇā cātuddasikā ca pannarasikā cāti ettha purimavassaṃvutthānaṃ
analyzed: dve imā bhikkhave pavāraṇā cātuddasikā ca pannarasikā ca ati ettha purima vassaṃvutthānam
translated: “Bhikkhus, there are these two Invitation days: the fourteenth and the fifteenth.” Herein, the fourteenth of the waning moon is the Invitation day for those who have kept the rains during the first period.

original: pubbakattikapuṇṇamā, tesaṃyeva sace bhaṇḍanakārakehi upaddutā pavāraṇaṃ paccukkaḍḍhanti,
analyzed: pubba kattika puṇṇamā tesam yeva sace bhaṇḍana kārakehi upaddutā pavāraṇam paccukkaḍḍhanti
translated: If they are disturbed by makers of schisms, they may postpone the Invitation.

original: atha kattikamāsassa kāḷapakkhacātuddaso vā pacchimakattikapuṇṇamā vā, pacchimavassaṃvutthānañca
analyzed: atha kattika māsassa kāḷapakkha cātuddasaḥ vā pacchima kattika puṇṇamā vā pacchima vassaṃvutthānañca
translated: Then the fourteenth of the dark of the month Kattika or the full moon of Kattika is the Invitation day for those who have kept the rains during the second period.

original: pacchimakattikapuṇṇamā eva vāti ime tayo pavāraṇadivasāti veditabbā. Idañca pakaticārittavasena
analyzed: pacchima kattika puṇṇamā eva vāti ime tayo pavāraṇa divasā ti veditabbā idam ca pakati cāritta vasena
translated: And the full moon of Kattika is the Invitation day for those who have kept the rains during the third period. So these are the three Invitation days. This is said with reference to normal practice.

original: vuttaṃ, tathārūpapaccaye pana sati dvinnaṃ kattikapuṇṇamānaṃ purimesu cātuddasesupi🔽pavāraṇaṃ kātuṃ vaṭṭati, teneva mahāvihāre bhikkhū cātuddasiyā pavāretvā pannarasiyā
analyzed: vuttam tathārūpa paccaye pana sati dvinnam kattika puṇṇamānam purimesu cātuddasesu pi  pavāraṇam kātum vaṭṭati tena iva mahāvihāre bhikkhū cātuddasiyā pavāretvā pannarasiyā
translated: But if there are such reasons as these, it is allowable to do the Invitation on the two full-moon days of Kattika or on the two fourteens.🔽That is why the bhikkhus at the Great Monastery do the Invitation on the fourteenth and give the “body-virtue” on the fifteenth.

original: kāyasāmaggiṃ denti, cetiyagirimahadassanatthampi aṭṭhamiyā gacchanti, tampi cātuddasiyaṃ🔽pavāretukāmānaññeva hoti.🔽Pavāraṇādānānujānanakathāvaṇṇanā
analyzed: kāya sāmaggim denti cetiya giri maha dassana attham pi aṭṭhamiyāḥ gacchanti tam pi cātuddasiyam 🔽pavāretu kāmā anaññā iva hoti 🔽pavāraṇa ādāna anujānana kathā vaṇṇanā
translated: And they go on the eighth for the Great Observance of the Cetiya Mountain. That is also for those who want to do the Invitation on the fourteenth.

original: 213. Sace pana vuḍḍhataro hotīti sace pavāraṇadāyako bhikkhu vuḍḍhataro hoti. Tena ca bhikkhunāti pavāraṇadāyakena bhikkhunā.
analyzed: sace pana vuḍḍhataraḥ hoti iti sace pavāraṇa dāyakaḥ bhikkhu vuḍḍhataraḥ hoti tena ca bhikkhunā ati pavāraṇa dāyakena bhikkhunā
translated: By that monk: by the monk who gives the invitation.

original: Anāpattipannarasakakathāvaṇṇanā
analyzed: anāpatti pannarasaka kathā vaṇṇanā
translated: The explanation of the section on “fifteen”.🔽In the fifteen cases: when the invitation has just been given.

original: 222. Pannarasakesu pavāritamatteti pavāritasamanantaraṃ. Avuṭṭhitāya parisāyāti pavāretvā
analyzed: pannarasakesu pavārita matta iti pavārita samanantaram a vuṭṭhitāya parisāya ati pavāretvā
translated: The gathering has not yet risen: after the invitation has been given,

original: pacchā aññamaññaṃ kathentiyā. Ekaccāya vuṭṭhitāyāti ekaccesu yathānisinnesu ekaccesu
analyzed: pacchā aññamaññam kathentiyā ekaccāya vuṭṭhitāya ati ekaccesu yathā nisinnesu ekaccesu
translated: they talk to one another. Some have risen: some of those who were seated

original: sakasakaṭṭhānaṃ gatesu. Puna pavāritabbanti punapi sabbehi samāgantvā pavāretabbaṃ.
analyzed: saka saka ṭṭhānam gatesu puna pavāritabbanti puna api sabbehi samāgantvā pavāretabbam
translated: have gone to their own dwellings. The invitation should be given again: all should come together and give the invitation again.

original: Āgacchanti samasamā, tesaṃ santike pavāretabbanti gate anānetvā nisinnānaññeva santike🔽pavāretabbaṃ. Sabbāya vuṭṭhitāya parisāya āgacchanti samasamā, tesaṃ santike pavāretabbanti
analyzed: āgacchanti samasamā tesam santike pavāretabbanti gate an ānetvā santike  pavāretabbam sabbāya vuṭṭhitāya parisāya āgacchanti samasamā tesam santike pavāretabbanti
translated: If they come together, the invitation should be given in their presence: if they come, they should give the invitation right there, without sitting down.🔽If the whole gathering has risen and they come together, the invitation should be given in their presence:

original: yadi sabbe vuṭṭhahitvā gatā sannipātetuñca na sakkā, ekacce sannipātetvā pavāretuṃ
analyzed: yadi sabbe vuṭṭhahitvā gatā sannipātetun ca na sakkā ekacce sannipātetvā pavāretum
translated: if all have risen and gone, and it is not possible to assemble them, then they should give the invitation after assembling some.

original: vaṭṭati, ñattiṃ ṭhapetvā kattabbasaṅghakammābhāvā vaggaṃ na hoti. Uposathepi eseva nayo.
analyzed: vaṭṭati ñattim ṭhapetvā kattabba saṅgha kamma abhāvā vaggam na hoti uposathe pi esa iva nayo
translated: It is allowable. And because there is no transaction of the Community to be done except the proclamation of the motion, there is no breach of communion. The same method applies in the case of the Uposatha.

original: Pavāraṇāṭhapanakathāvaṇṇanā🔽237. “Natthi dinna”ntiādinayappavattā dasavatthukā micchādiṭṭhi. “Hoti tathāgato
analyzed: pavāraṇā ṭhapana kathā vaṇṇanā  natthi dinna nti ādi naya ppavattā dasa vatthukā micchādiṭṭhi hoti tathāgato
translated: The explanation of the discussion of the proclamation of the Invitation

original: paraṃ maraṇā, na hoti tathāgato paraṃ maraṇā”tiādinā sassatucchedasaṅkhātaṃ antaṃ🔽gaṇhātīti antaggāhikā.
analyzed: param maraṇā na hoti tathāgato param maraṇa ati ādinā sassatu cheda saṅkhātam antam  gaṇhāti iti antaggāhikā
translated: The ten instances of wrong view that occur with the words “There is no giving” and so on. The view that “The Tathagata exists after death” and the view that “The Tathagata does not exist after death” and so on are called the “extreme” because they grasp an “end” .

original: Bhaṇḍanakārakavatthukathāvaṇṇanā
analyzed: bhaṇḍana kāraka vatthu kathā vaṇṇanā
translated: The explanation of the discussion of the grounds for the accusation of causing schism

original: 240. Catutthe kate suṇantīti catutthe pannarasikuposathe kate amhākaṃ pavāraṇaṃ ṭhapessantīti suṇanti. Evampi dve cātuddasikā hontīti tatiyena saddhiṃ dve cātuddasikā honti.
analyzed: catutthe kate suṇanti iti catutthe pannarasika uposathe kate amhākam pavāraṇam ṭhapessanti iti suṇanti evam pi dve cātuddasikāḥ honti iti tatiyena saddhim dve cātuddasikāḥ honti

translated: Over-exerted: too tense. Leads to agitation: leads to a state of agitation. Over- slack:

analyzed: yojanā vidhānam visuddhi magge āgata nayena veditabbam tattha ca nimittam gaṇhāhi iti

Leads to idleness: leads to a state of idleness. “Resolve upon serenity with energy”: resolve upon serenity associated with energy; the meaning is: yoke energy to serenity. “Resolve upon evenness of the faculties”: resolve upon the evenness, the balance, of the faculties of faith, etc. Herein, when one who has faith yokes faith to understanding and understanding to faith, and yokes energy to serenity and serenity to energy, then the evenness of the faculties is resolved upon. translated: And here the words “he took up the sign” mean that he took up the sign of serenity and the sign of insight. Alone:🔽without a companion. Ardent: ardent is zeal, which is bodily and mental travail.

translated: He was ardent in the sense of being heated by the fever of the defilements. He was diligent in the sense of being devoted to the work of burning up the defilements.🔽He was intent on the state of being flung off, in that he was intent on Nibbāna, not caring for body or life.

original: vissaṭṭhaattabhāvo, nibbāne vā pesitacitto. Na cirassevāti kammaṭṭhānārambhato na

analyzed: nekkhamma adhimuttaḥ tiādi sabbam arahatta vasena vuttam arahattam hi sabba kilesehi nikkhanta ttā  nekkhammam tehi iva pavivitta ttā pavivekaḥ byāpajja abhāvataḥ a byāpajjam upādānassa
translated: “He is resolved upon seclusion,” etc., is all said with reference to arahatship. For arahatship is renunciation because it has gone out from all defilements,🔽seclusion because it is secluded from them, non-affliction because it is free from affliction, the destruction of craving because it has arisen with the destruction of craving, the destruction of clinging because it has arisen with the destruction of clinging,

original: khayante uppannattā upādānakkhayo, taṇhāya khayante uppannattā taṇhakkhayo, sammohābhāvato

translated: and it is called non-delusion.

original: Kevalaṃ saddhāmattakanti paṭivedharahitaṃ kevalaṃ paṭivedhapaññāya asammissaṃ saddhāmattakaṃ.🔽Paṭicayanti punappunaṃ karaṇena vaḍḍhiṃ. Vītarāgattāti maggapaṭivedhena rāgassa vihatattāyeva
analyzed: kevalam saddhāmattakanti paṭivedha rahitam kevalam paṭivedha paññāya asammissam saddhāmattakam  paṭicayanti punappunam karaṇena vaḍḍhim vīta rāga ttā ati magga paṭivedhena rāgassa vihata ttāya iva
translated: Faith-only: devoid of penetration, faith-only unmixed with the penetration-understanding.🔽Accumulation: increase by repeated practice.🔽Delighting in renunciation: he has penetrated, has realized, renunciation, which is called Arahantship, by penetrating the path.

original: nekkhammasaṅkhātaṃ arahattaṃ paṭivijjhitvā sacchikatvā ṭhito hoti, phalasamāpattivihārena
analyzed: nekkhamma saṅkhātam arahattam paṭivijjhitvā sacchikatvā ṭhitaḥ hoti phala samāpatti vihārena
translated: He abides in the fruition attainment,

original: viharati, tanninnamānasoyeva hotīti attho. Sesapadesupi eseva nayo.🔽Lābhasakkārasilokanti catupaccayalābhañca tesaṃyeva sukatabhāvañca vaṇṇabhaṇanañca.
analyzed: viharati hoti iti attho sesa padesu pi esa iva nayo  catu paccaya lābhañca tesaṃ yeva su kata bhāvañca vaṇṇa bhaṇanañca
translated: his mind is bent on that, is the meaning. The same method of explanation applies in the other cases.🔽Gain, honor, and fame: gain consisting of the four requisites, and the fact that they are well provided, and the fact that he is spoken of in praise.

original: Nikāmayamānoti icchamāno patthayamāno. Pavivekādhimuttoti “paviveke adhimutto aha”nti
analyzed: nikāmayamāno ti icchamāno patthayamāno paviveka adhimutto ti paviveke adhimuttaḥ ahanti
translated: Longing for: wishing, hoping.

original: evaṃ arahattaṃ byākarotīti attho.
analyzed: evam arahattam byākaroti iti attho
translated: Bent on seclusion: he declares Arahantship thus: “I am bent on seclusion.”

original: Sīlabbataparāmāsanti sīlañca vatañca parāmasitvā gahitaggahaṇamattaṃ. Sārato paccāgacchantoti
analyzed: sīla bbata parāmāsanti sīlam ca vatam ca parāmasitvā gahita ggahaṇa mattam sārataḥ paccāgacchanto ti
translated: Clinging to rules and vows: mere grasping at rules and vows.

original: sārabhāvena jānanto. Abyāpajjādhimuttoti abyāpajjaṃ arahattaṃ byākaroti. Imināva
analyzed: sāra bhāvena jānantaḥ a byāpajja adhimuttaḥ ti a byāpajjam arahattam byākaroti
translated: He declares the Arahantship of non-affliction.🔽The meaning should be regarded in this way in all the instances.

original: nayena sabbavāresu attho daṭṭhabbo. Apicettha “nekkhammādhimuttoti imasmiṃyeva arahattaṃ🔽kathitaṃ, sesesu pañcasu nibbāna”nti eke vadanti. Apare “asammohādhimuttoti ettheva
analyzed: nayena sabba vāresu attho daṭṭhabbo api ca ittha nekkhamma adhimuttaḥ ti imasmin yeva arahattam  kathitam sesesu pañcasu nibbānanti eke vadanti apare asammoha adhimutto ti ettha eva
translated: Besides, here some say that in the case of the “resolve upon renunciation” the Arahantship is stated,🔽and in the case of the other five the extinction of the cankers is stated.🔽Others say that in the case of the “resolve upon non-delusion” the extinction of the cankers is stated,

original: nibbānaṃ kathitaṃ, sesesu arahatta”nti vadanti. Ayaṃ panettha sāro – “sabbesvevetesu
analyzed: nibbānam kathitam sesesu arahatta nti vadanti ayam pana ittha sāraḥ sabbesu eva etesu
translated: and in the case of the other five the Arahantship is stated.🔽But the essence of this matter is this:

original: arahattampi nibbānampi kathitamevāti.
analyzed: arahattam pi nibbānam pi kathitam eva ati
translated: in all these instances the Arahantship and the extinction of the cankers are stated.

original: Bhusāti balavanto dibbarūpasadisā. Nevassa cittaṃ pariyādiyantīti etassa khīṇāsavassa🔽cittaṃ gahetvā ṭhātuṃ na sakkonti. Kilesā hi uppajjamānā cittaṃ gaṇhanti nāma. Amissīkatanti
analyzed: bhusāti balavantaḥ dibba rūpa sadisāḥ na iva assa cittam pariyādiyanti iti etassa khīṇāsavassa  cittam gahetvā ṭhātum na sakkonti kilesāḥ hi uppajjamānāḥ cittam gaṇhanti nāma amissīkatanti
translated: “Powerful” : strong, like a divine form.🔽“Do not overpower his cognizance” : they cannot seize and hold his cognizance, for defilements are called “seizers of cognizance” when they arise.🔽“Unmixed” : unmixed.

original: amissakataṃ. Kilesā hi ārammaṇena saddhiṃ cittaṃ missaṃ karonti, tesaṃ abhāvā amissīkataṃ.
analyzed: amissakatam kilesāḥ hi ārammaṇena saddhim cittam missam karonti tesam abhāvā amissīkatam
translated: For defilements mix cognizance with its object, but because they are absent it is unmixed.

original: Ṭhitanti patiṭṭhitaṃ. Āneñjappattanti acalanappattaṃ. Vayañcassānupassatīti tassa
analyzed: ṭhitam nti patiṭṭhitam āneñja ppattam ati acalana ppattam vayam ca assa anupassati iti tassa
translated: “Is standing” means is established. “Has reached imperturbability” means has reached unshakability. “He contemplates its fall”:

original: cesa cittassa uppādampi vayampi passati. Bhusā vātavuṭṭhīti balavā vātakkhandho.🔽Neva naṃ saṅkampeyyāti ekabhāgena cāletuṃ na sakkuṇeyya. Na sampakampeyyāti thūṇaṃ
analyzed: cesa cittassa uppādam pi vayam pi passati bhusā vāta vuṭṭhī ti balavā vātakkhandho  na iva nam saṅkampeyya ati eka bhāgena cāletum na sakkuṇeyya na sampakampeyya ati thūṇam
translated: he sees the arising and falling of that consciousness. “A violent storm”: a strong mass of wind.🔽“Would not make it shake”: he would not be able to move it even a little. “Would not make it tremble”: he would not be able to make it tremble in every part,

original: viya sabbabhāgato kampetuṃ na sakkuṇeyya. Na sampavedheyyāti vedhetvā pavedhetvā
analyzed: viya sabba bhāgataḥ kampetum na sakkuṇeyya na sampavedheyya ati vedhetvā pavedhetvā
translated: as if it were a pillar. “Would not make it quake”: he would not be able to make it quake and quake again

original: pātetuṃ na sakkuṇeyya.🔽Nekkhammaṃ adhimuttassāti arahattaṃ paṭivijjhitvā ṭhitassa. Sesapadesupi arahattameva🔽kathitaṃ. Upādānakkhayassa cāti upayogatthe sāmivacanaṃ. Asammohañca cetasoti cittassa
analyzed: pātetum na sakkuṇeyya  nekkhammam adhimuttassa ati arahattam paṭivijjhitvā ṭhitassa sesa padesu pi arahattam eva  kathitam upādāna kkhayassa ca ati upayoga atthe sāmi vacanam asammoham ca cetasā ti cittassa
translated: and knock it down.🔽“Who is intent on renunciation”: who, having penetrated to arahatship, is established in it. In the other phrases too arahatship is referred to.

original: ca asammohaṃ adhimuttassa. Disvā āyatanuppādanti āyatanānaṃ uppādañca vayañca disvā.
analyzed: ca asammoham adhimuttassa disvā āyatana uppādanti āyatanānam uppādam ca vayam ca disvā
translated: “And the destruction of clinging”: the genitive has the sense of the instrumental. “And non-delusion in the mind”: he is intent on non-delusion in the mind. “Having seen the arising of the sense bases”: having seen the arising and falling of the sense bases.

original: Sammā cittaṃ vimuccatīti sammā hetunā nayena imāya vipassanāya paṭipattiyā phalasamāpattivasena🔽cittaṃ vimuccati, nibbānārammaṇe adhimuccati. Atha vā iminā khīṇāsavassa pubbabhāgapaṭipadā
analyzed: sammā cittam vimuccati iti sammā hetunā nayena imāya vipassanāya paṭipattiyā phala samāpatti vasena  cittam vimuccati nibbāna ārammaṇe adhimuccati atha vā iminā khīṇāsavassa pubba bhāga paṭipadā
translated: “The mind is rightly liberated”: by the right cause, by the right method, by the right practice, the mind is liberated by way of the attainment of fruition,🔽it is resolved upon Nibbāna as object. Or else, by this practice in the earlier stage of the one who is without cankers,🔽🔽

original: kathitā. Tassa hi āyatanuppādaṃ disvā imāya vipassanāya adhigatassa ariyamaggassa
analyzed: kathitā tassa hi āyatana uppādam disvā imāya vipassanāya adhigatassa ariya maggassa
translated: “The mind is rightly liberated”: by the right means, by the right method, by the practice of this insight, the mind is liberated, is resolved upon Nibbana, as the attainment of fruition. Or else, this passage refers to the preliminary practice of one who is to become an Arahant. For when he has seen the arising of the sense-spheres and has attained the Noble Path by means of this insight,

original: ānubhāvena sabbakilesehi sammā cittaṃ vimuccati. Evaṃ tassa sammā vimuttassa…pe…🔽na vijjati. Tattha santacittassāti nibbutacittassa. Sesamettha uttānatthameva.
analyzed: ānubhāvena sabba kilesehi sammā cittam vimuccati evam tassa sammā vimuttassa pe  na vijjati tattha santa cittassa ati nibbuta cittassa sesam ettha uttānattham eva
translated: his mind is rightly liberated from all defilements by the power of the Noble Path. Thus, of him who is rightly liberated …

original: Soṇassa pabbajjākathāvaṇṇanā niṭṭhitā.🔽Sabbanīlikādipaṭikkhepakathāvaṇṇanā🔽246. Addāriṭṭhakavaṇṇāti abhinavāriṭṭhaphalavaṇṇā. Udakena tintakākapattavaṇṇātipi vadanti.🔽Ajjhārāme upāhanapaṭikkhepakathāvaṇṇanā
analyzed: soṇassa pabbajjā kathā vaṇṇanā niṭṭhitā 🔽sabba nīlikā ādi paṭikkhepa kathā vaṇṇanā 🔽addā ariṭṭhaka vaṇṇā ati abhinava ariṭṭha phala vaṇṇā udakena tinta kāka patta vaṇṇā ati pi vadanti 🔽ajjhārāme upāhana paṭikkhepa kathā vaṇṇanā
translated: is not found. Here, “one whose mind is peaceful” means one whose mind is extinguished. The rest is clear.

original: 248. Abhijīvanti etenāti abhijīvanikaṃ. Kintaṃ? Sippaṃ. Tenāha “yena sippenā”tiādi.
analyzed: abhijīvanti etena ati abhijīvanikam sippam tena āha yena sippena atiādi
translated: Abhijīvanika means that by which one lives. What is that? A craft. Hence he said “by means of a craft” and so on.

original: Kaṭṭhapādukādipaṭikkhepakathāvaṇṇanā
analyzed: kaṭṭha pādukā ādi paṭikkhepa kathā vaṇṇanā
translated: The commentary on the section on the prohibition against sandals of rolls of leather and so on.

original: 251. Uṇṇāhi katapādukāti uṇṇālomamayakambalehi, uṇṇālomehi eva vā katapādukā. Na,🔽bhikkhave, gāvīnaṃ visāṇesu gahetabbantiādīsu “mokkhādhippāyena visāṇādīsu gahetuṃ
analyzed: kata pādukā ati uṇṇā loma maya kambalehi uṇṇā lomehi eva vā kata pādukā na  bhikkhave gāvīnam visāṇesu gahetabbanti ādīsu mokkha adhippāyena visāṇa ādīsu gahetum
translated: Sandals made of rolls of wool means sandals made of rolls of wool-tufts or of wool-tufts alone.

original: vaṭṭatī”ti gaṇṭhipadesu vuttaṃ.
analyzed: vaṭṭati iti gaṇṭhi padesu vuttam
translated: In the case of the words “You should not seize cows by the horns” and so on, it is said in the summary verses that “it is allowable to seize the horns and so on with the intention of saving.”

original: Yānādipaṭikkhepakathāvaṇṇanā🔽253. Anujānāmi, bhikkhave, purisayuttaṃ hatthavaṭṭakanti ettha “anujānāmi, bhikkhave,🔽purisayuttaṃ, anujānāmi, bhikkhave, hatthavaṭṭaka”nti evaṃ paccekavākyaparisamāpanaṃ🔽adhippetanti āha “purisayuttaṃ itthisārathi vā…pe… purisā vā, vaṭṭatiyevā”ti. Pīṭhakasivikanti
analyzed: yāna ādi paṭikkhepa kathā vaṇṇanā  anujānāmi bhikkhave purisa yuttam hattha vaṭṭakanti ettha anujānāmi bhikkhave  purisa yuttam anujānāmi bhikkhave hattha vaṭṭakam ti evam pacceka vākya parisamāpanam  adhippetanti āha purisa yuttam itthi sārathi vāpe purisāḥ vā pīṭhaka sivikam ti
translated: The commentary on the section on the prohibition against vehicles and so on.🔽Here, the words “I allow a vehicle drawn by men, I allow a palanquin” are to be completed by the words “I allow a vehicle drawn by men, I allow a palanquin” respectively.

original: pīṭhakayānaṃ. Pāṭaṅkinti andolikāyetaṃ adhivacanaṃ.
analyzed: pīṭhaka yānam adhivacanam
translated: Hence it is said, “A vehicle drawn by men, with a male driver, with men, is allowable. … with women, with boys, with girls, is allowable.” A palanquin means a palanquin vehicle. A swing means a swing-couch.

original: Uccāsayanamahāsayanapaṭikkhepakathāvaṇṇanā🔽254. Vāḷarūpānīti āharimāni vāḷarūpāni. “Akappiyarūpākulo akappiyamañco pallaṅko”ti
analyzed: uccāsayana mahāsayana paṭikkhepa kathā vaṇṇanā  vāḷarūpāni iti āha rimāni vāḷarūpāni akappiya rūpa ākulaḥ akappiya mañco
translated: The commentary on the section on the prohibition of high and luxurious couches.🔽“With long hair” means with long hair that is not cut. “With a bed and a couch that are not allowable” means

original: sārasamāse vuttaṃ. “Dīghalomako mahākojavoti caturaṅgulādhikalomo kāḷakojavo. “Caturaṅgulādhikāni🔽kira tassa lomānī”ti vacanato caturaṅgulato heṭṭhā vaṭṭatīti vadanti. Vānacitro uṇṇāmayattharaṇoti
analyzed: sāra samāse vuttam dīgha lomakaḥ mahā kojavaḥ ti catur aṅgula adhika lomaḥ kāḷa kojavaḥ catur aṅgula adhikāni  kira tassa lomāni iti vacanataḥ catur aṅgulataḥ heṭṭhā vaṭṭati iti vadanti vānacitraḥ uṇṇāmayattharaṇaḥ ti
translated: with a bed and a couch that are not allowable. “With a long-haired black antelope skin” means with a black antelope skin that has hair more than four fingers long. “It is said that its hairs are more than four fingers long”

original: bhitticchedādivasena vicitro uṇṇāmayattharaṇo. Ghanapupphako uṇṇāmayattharaṇoti uṇṇāmayalohitattharaṇo.
analyzed: bhitti cheda ādi vasena vicitraḥ uṇṇāmaya ttharaṇaḥ ghanapupphakaḥ uṇṇāmaya ttharaṇaḥ ti uṇṇāmaya lohita ttharaṇaḥ
translated: because of this statement, they say that it is allowable if it is less than four fingers. “With a variegated animal skin” means with an animal skin that is variegated with lines on the wall, etc. “With a thick-flowered animal skin” means with an animal skin that is thick with flowers.

original: Pakatitūlikāti rukkhatūlalatātūlapoṭakītūlasaṅkhātānaṃ tiṇṇaṃ tūlānaṃ aññatarapuṇṇā
analyzed: pakatitūlikā ati rukkha tūla latā tūla poṭakī tūla saṅkhātānam tiṇṇam tūlānam aññatara puṇṇā
translated: “With cotton down” means with cotton down that is filled with one of the three kinds of cotton, namely tree cotton, latticed cotton, or pota cotton.

original: tūlikā. “Uddalomīti ubhatodasaṃ uṇṇāmayattharaṇaṃ. Ekantalomīti ekatodasaṃ uṇṇāmayattharaṇa”nti
analyzed: tūlikā uddalomī iti ubhatodasam uṇṇāmayattharaṇam ekantalomī iti ekatodasam uṇṇāmayattharaṇanti
translated: “With long hair on one side” means with an animal skin that has long hair on one side. “With long hair on both sides” means with an animal skin that has long hair on both sides.

original: dīghanikāyaṭṭhakathāyaṃ vuttaṃ, sārasamāse pana “uddalomīti ekato uggatapupphaṃ.
analyzed: dīgha nikāya ṭṭhakathāyam vuttam sāra samāse pana uddalomi iti ekatas uggata puppham
translated: This is said in the commentary to the Dīgha Nikāya. But in the Sārasangaha it is said: “With long hair on one side” means with hair that grows up on one side.

original: Ekantalomīti ubhato uggatapuppha”nti vuttaṃ. “Koseyyakaṭṭissamayanti koseyyakasaṭamaya”nti
analyzed: ekantalomī iti ubhatas uggata pupphanti vuttam koseyyakaṭṭissamayanti koseyyaka saṭamayanti
translated: “‘Made of silk and linen’ means made of silk and linen mixed,” says the teacher Dhammapāla.🔽‘Pure silk’ means without a jewel sewn into it.

original: ācariyadhammapālattherena vuttaṃ. Suddhakoseyyanti ratanaparisibbanarahitaṃ. Dīghanikāyaṭṭhakathāyaṃ
analyzed: ācariya dhammapāla therena vuttam suddha koseyyam ti ratana parisibbana rahitam dīgha nikāya ṭṭhakathāyam
translated: But in the Commentary on the Dīgha Nikāya it is said:

original: panettha “ṭhapetvā tūlikaṃ sabbāneva gonakādīni ratanaparisibbitāni vaṭṭantī”ti vuttaṃ.
analyzed: pana ittha ṭhapetvā tūlikam sabbān eva gonaka ādīni ratana parisibbitāni vaṭṭanti iti vuttam
translated: “Except for cotton, all the rest, such as wool, etc., are allowable if they have a jewel sewn into them.”

original: Tattha “ṭhapetvā tūlika”nti etena ratanaparisibbanarahitāpi tūlikā na vaṭṭatīti dīpeti.
analyzed: tattha ṭhapetvā tūlikanti etena ratana parisibbana rahitā api tūlikā na vaṭṭati iti dīpeti
translated: Herein, by the words “except for cotton” it is shown that cotton, even if it has no jewel sewn into it, is not allowable.

original: “Ratanaparisibbitāni vaṭṭantī”ti iminā pana yāni ratanaparisibbitāni, tāni bhūmattharaṇavasena🔽yathānurūpaṃ mañcādīsu ca upanetuṃ vaṭṭatīti dīpitanti veditabbaṃ. Ettha ca vinayapariyāyaṃ
analyzed: ratana parisibbitāni vaṭṭanti iti iminā pana yāni ratana parisibbitāni tāni bhūmattharaṇa vasena  yathānurūpam mañca ādīsu ca upanetum vaṭṭati iti dīpitam ti veditabbam ettha ca vinaya pariyāyam
translated: But by the words “they have a jewel sewn into them” it is shown that those that have a jewel sewn into them are allowable as a ground-covering and🔽also as a bed, etc., according to the appropriate size. And here the decision should be understood in the way stated here, because in the Vinaya it is laid down as a heavy offence.

original: patvā garuke ṭhātabbattā idha vuttanayenevettha vinicchayo veditabbo. Suttantikadesanāyaṃ
analyzed: patvā garuke ṭhātabba ttā idha vutta nayena iva ittha vinicchayaḥ veditabbo suttantika desanā ayam
translated: But in the Suttantika method of teaching

original: pana gahaṭṭhānampi vasena vuttattā tesaṃ saṅgaṇhanatthaṃ “ṭhapetvā tūlikaṃ…pe… vaṭṭantī”ti vuttanti apare.
analyzed: pana gaha ṭṭhānam pi vasena vutta ttā tesam saṅgaṇhana attham ṭhapetvā tūli kaṃpe vaṭṭanti iti vuttam ti apare
translated: But others say that the words “except hemp, etc., are allowable” are said in order to include householders’ requisites too, since the robe is mentioned in the plural.

original: Ajinacammehīti ajinamigacammehi. Tāni kira cammāni sukhumatarāni, tasmā dupaṭṭatipaṭṭāni
analyzed: ajina cammehi iti ajina miga cammehi tāni kira cammāni sukhumatarāni tasmā du paṭṭati paṭṭāni
translated: With deer-skins: with the skins of spotted deer. It seems that those skins are finer, so they are sewn together to make a double or treble thickness.

original: katvā sibbanti. Tena vuttaṃ “ajinapaveṇī”ti. Uttaraṃ uparibhāgaṃ chādetīti uttaracchado,
analyzed: katvā sibbanti tena vuttam ajina paveṇī iti uttaram upari bhāgam chādeti iti uttaracchadaḥ
translated: That is why it is said “with a spotted deer’s hide” . A canopy is a covering for the upper part , thus it is an upper covering .

original: vitānaṃ, tañca lohitavitānaṃ idhādhippetanti āha “uparibaddhena rattavitānenā”ti.
analyzed: vitānam tat ca lohita vitānam idha adhippetanti āha upari baddhena ratta vitānena ati
translated: And it is a red canopy that is intended here, so it is said “with a red canopy overhead” .

original: “Rattavitānesu ca kāsāvaṃ vaṭṭati, kusumbhādirattameva na vaṭṭatī”ti gaṇṭhipadesu
analyzed: ratta vitānesu ca kāsāvam vaṭṭati kusumbha ādi rattam eva na vaṭṭati iti gaṇṭhi padesu
translated: And in the passages in the Commentaries it is said that “a dyed robe is allowable for a red canopy, but a robe dyed with madder, etc., is not allowable” .

original: vuttaṃ. Mahāupadhānanti pamāṇātikkantaṃ upadhānaṃ. Ettha ca kiñcāpi dīghanikāyaṭṭhakathāyaṃ
analyzed: vuttam mahā upadhānam ti pamāṇa atikkantam upadhānam ettha ca kiñcā api dīgha nikāya ṭṭhakathā ayam
translated: A large sheet is a sheet exceeding the right size. And here, although in the Commentary to the Digha Nikāya it is said:

original: “alohitakāni dvepi vaṭṭantiyeva, tato uttari labhitvā aññesaṃ dātabbāni, dātuṃ asakkonto
analyzed: a lohitakāni dve pi vaṭṭantiyā iva tatas uttari labhitvā aññesam dātabbāni dātum a sakkontaḥ
translated: “Both kinds dyed with turmeric are allowable, but if one gets more than that, it should be given to others. If he is unable to give it to others,

original: mañce tiriyaṃ attharitvā upari paccattharaṇaṃ datvā nipajjitumpi labhatī”ti avisesena🔽vuttaṃ, senāsanakkhandhakavaṇṇanāyaṃ pana “agilānassa sīsupadhānañca pādupadhānañcāti

translated: or it is suitable for you to be devoted to the time mentioned above, it is fitting, proper, and possible for you, not for all time,🔽the meaning is. analyzed: eka vihārī ahosi tena vuttam tiṇṇam vassānam pe sannipātāpetvā ati  vassaṃvutthassa ati vassam upagantvā vusitavataḥ ediso ca ediso ca ati evarūpo ca evarūpo  ca evarūpāya nāma rūpa kāya sampattiyā samannāgataḥ evarūpāya dhammakāya sampattiyā  samannāgatā iti sutoyā iva me so bhagavā na ca mayā sammukhā diṭṭhā ti ettha pana puthujjana saddhāya  eva āyasmā soṇaḥ bhagavantam daṭṭhu kāmo ahosi apara bhāge pana satthārā saddhim eka gandhakuṭiyam

translated: To the people who are intent on seeing the Blessed One’s material body by means of the excellence of his physical beauty, which is pleasing in all aspects,
